Title: Budget took care of Delhi's traders: PM Modi
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

NEW DELHI: In a bid to woo the traders and middle-class voters, Prime Minister Narendra Modi dedicated a major part of his speech to the tax reforms undertaken by his government in the Union Budget .

The Budget will help the youth of the country, women, traders, middle and lower-middle class people and the poor. It will open new avenues of development and employment in the capital, the PM claimed. “Earlier, businesses with a turnover of Rs 1 crore had to be audited, but now no audit is required for all businesses with a turnover up to Rs 5 crore,” Modi said, adding that it was an example of the government’s trust in traders and entrepreneurs of the country, including those in Delhi.

The trading community in the capital, traditionally BJP supporters, holds immense sway and is an influential voting bloc. They are believed to be unhappy with the government post demonetisation and the hasty implementation of the GST has left many traders high and dry. The PM, in his rally , appeared to be healing the old wounds of the traders.

For the first time, the PM said, the IBC legislation has been passed to give entrepreneurs a dignified exit from businesses. “It has been BJP’s efforts to reduce problems of traders and enable them to carry out their work freely,” he said.

The Prime Minister assured the people that multiple provisions have been made in the Budget for tax holidays for startups and that middle-class taxpayers save money. He stated that the central government has also addressed previous complaints from the traders about tax authorities giving them a harrowing time. “Our government has started indirect tax settlement scheme, which has saved countless traders from legal cases,” Modi added.

Title: Patna Municipal Corporation strike: Roads strewn with garbage
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Heaps of garbage were seen on the roads as the daily wage sanitation workers of PMC went on strike on Monday

PATNA: Heaps of garbage were seen on the roads as the daily wage sanitation workers of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) went on strike on Monday.

The workers who even staged dharna at Maurya Lok Complex, neither went for door-to-door garbage collection nor did they sweep the roads on Monday. Hence, around 700 tonnes of the garbage produced daily in the state capital remained in the city roads and lanes. The garbage collected from the city households and shops is dumped at Ramchak Bairiya.

“I was waiting for the vehicle to come for garbage collection, but no one came in my locality today,” said Prabhakar Kumar of Sheikhpura. Same was the problem shared by Mehndi Nagar resident Tarannum Imam. “Every morning, a vehicle comes in my locality for collecting garbage from households. In fact, I am used to waking up to its music. But today neither the garbage was collected, nor our locality was swept,” she said.

Apart from household garbage, trash remained on the roads. Some of the demonstrators even threw garbage on the roads and made the situation even more pathetic. One of the passersby, Santosh Gupta, near Dak Bungalow crossing said, “After a long time, I am seeing such a pathetic situation in the state capital.”

Around 4,500 daily wage workers went on the strike against a letter issued by Urban Development and Housing Department to all the urban local bodies to stop availing their services from February 1 and, instead, rope in outsource agency. However, UDHD issued a fresh letter on Monday in which it extended the deadline for availing the service of daily wage workers till March 31. However, workers were in no mood to call off the strike even after the extension of the deadline.

Patna Nagar Nigam Staff Union president Chandra Prakash said the government was trying to make them fool by just extending the deadline of their service. He said, “PMC board had taken a decision to regularize those workers who have been working for over 10 years. In fact 112 of them have been regularized and 400 are in the process. Now, all of a sudden, they are saying to rope in private agency instead of taking the service of the daily wage workers. This decision will badly hit people belonging to Dalit and other extremely backward community.”

Another worker, Mani Paswan, said, “I have been working for PMC since 2007 and now all of a sudden the decision has been taken not to take our services. What will I do?”

UDHD, in the letter issued on January 28, stated that the Lokayukta, in the inquiry conducted in Darbhanga Municipal Corporation , found group D employees on daily wages as a perennial source of corruption. The municipal bodies not complying with its order were even asked to submit an explanation to the Lokayukta.

However, Patna mayor Sita Sahu expressed displeasure over the letter issued by UDHD. “I fully respect the decision taken by the Lokayukta, but I feel they were not given proper information. We will take up our side now,” said Sahu.

Title: 3 impersonators caught on Day 1 of Inter exams
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PATNA: Altogether three impersonators, including one in Patna, were caught during frisking on Day 1 of the Intermediate examinations on Monday. As many as 91 students were also expelled in 22 districts for using unfair means during the exams, which are conducted by the Bihar School Examination Board (BSEB).

According to a statement issued by the BSEB, the maximum number of examinees (13) were expelled in Nalanda, followed by 12 in Arwal and nine in Gaya.

“Exams in both the sittings were conducted in a fair way amid tight security. Altogether 5,03,934 students of the science stream wrote the physics paper in the first sitting and 5,01,607 took the history exam in the second sitting. Besides, 569 students appeared for the BR Hindi examination on Monday,” the BSEB stated.

This is for the first time that the BSEB has increased the number of objective questions. In the 100 marks’ exam, 60 objective questions were asked, of which examinees had to solve any 50. Similarly, the 70 marks’ paper contained 42 objective questions and the students had to solve 35 of them. The BSEB had also prepared 10 different sets of questions to avoid unfair practices.

BSEB chairman Anand Kishor visited some examination centres on Day 1 to inspect the ongoing process. He instructed the magistrates and invigilators on duty to ensure fair exams at all the centres. He also told them to punish those who are found using unfair means.

The state examination board will conduct the chemistry exam in the first sitting and political science exam in the second on Tuesday. Students of vocational courses will write the English exam in the second sitting.

The Inter exams will conclude on February 13.

Title: More cops, CCTVs to protect protest sites
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kolkata: Police on Monday decided to step up security in the anti-CAA protest zones, including Park Circus. An ACP-ranked officer, along with 40 cops in mufti during the day and 15 during the night, will be present at the sites with local cops. This will be in addition to CCTV surveillance and field intelligence inputs from the various venues.

A senior officer said, “We had been keeping watch on the situation. However, the back-to-back incidents in New Delhi have given us a reason to augment security further. The local police stations are constantly coordinating with the organizers. In addition to this, we will be increasing manpower and surveillance — both physical and technological.”

Those protesting the new citizenship law in Kolkata felt the best way to respond to the hate campaign against them was to reciprocate through love and sympathy. “If they fire bullets, we will retaliate with flowers,” said an organiser at one of the sit-ins a day after another attack at Jamia Millia in the Capital. On Sunday night, a youth on a two-wheeler allegedly fired bullets at students of Jamia Millia. A minister and several BJP functionaries in the Capital have been heard raising slogans which “instigate” people to “shoot the traitors”. Since January 29, there have been three attacks at Jamia Millia and Shaheen Bagh.

Organizers of the protests in Kolkata have appealed to those opposing the CAA and the National Register for Citizens (NRC) to not react to provocation, which may be a ploy to malign the movement, declare it as a violent one and give it a religious colour.

Asmat Jamil from the Park Circus Maidan said she was aware of the oppositions those protesting against CAA and NRC have to face. “I always knew it would not be easy. They will try to scare us in every possible way, but we will not get scared. Whatever is happening in Delhi is unacceptable — bullets are being fired at unarmed people and the administration is just a mute spectator,” said Jamil.

Arshad Parvez Khan, one of the organizers at the sit-in at Nawab Ali Park in Ekbalpore, said the best way to respond to hatred is with love. “These people who are going around firing at protesters in Delhi have been brainwashed and radicalized against one section of the society. They need to be dealt with love and sympathy,” Khan said.

The organizers are also taking adequate security measures to prevent any untoward incident at the demonstration venues. “We are keeping tabs on people who are coming in big groups from other areas to join the protests. We have also requested the police to enhance security around the venue. Our volunteers, too, are very active,” said Jamil.

On Zakaria Street, volunteers have been taking videos of the area earmarked for “floating” protesters. “A portion of the place is cordoned off for the women. In other pockets, our volunteers are making videos at regular intervals to identify anybody engaged in any suspicious activity,” said an organizer.

Title: An academic’s menu on the Union Budget
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: Government of India’s own estimate of its income and expenditure called the Union Budget determines the future of many institutions and individuals. The annual budget’s number crunching exercise has many times seen quotes of Thiruvalluvar and this time Avvaiyar, Kalidasa and Dinanath Kaul.

The mix of numbers, themes, poetic verses and occasional humour make the budget a good economic recipe. The 2020 Budget has all the ingredients of a tasty recipe, now the ministries and institutions have to cook it the best way. A hot-and-sour appetizer, which intentionally comes after the main course, is the issue of exemptions.

Many analysts see the education plate as having only rice and dal (school and higher education), not realising that there is much more that makes it a gastronomic delight. Among the other servings are allocations to department of science and technology, department of biotechnology, department of scientific and industrial research, besides funds for skill development and entrepreneurship. These departments form the backbone for higher education research and the combined allocation to higher education with these departments take the total Budget allocation to `56,950 crore from the 2019’s revised estimate of `53,593 crores, an increase of 6.3% and not 4% as quoted by many.

New items on the menu include a special and much needed scholarship scheme for Jammu and Kashmir with an allocation of `225 crore. Some have been made sweeter or spicier — as the case may be — doubling allocation for Startup India initiatives in higher education institutions, internationalisation and study in India schemes. Other items on the menu are the regular ones with increases and decreases based on the appetites of the stakeholders involved.

Overall, the spread is full and filling. The budget’s trinocular themes are an ‘à la carte’ of sorts — an aspirational India, economic development and a caring society — throwing open a world of opportunities for educational institutions to choose from, based on their capacity and capability. They can work on a spectrum of schemes in collaboration with various agencies to achieve these objectives. With this rich spread, it is the institutions’ choice to starve or have a feast. The menu cannot be blamed at all. Besides these on the main course, exotic items for dessert — extended commercial borrowings and FDI shall be served only when ready and served to all. Till then, no comments. Buffet or à la carte, the recipe is fine.

Now to the hot-and-sour appetizer. Trusts, Societies or Section 8 companies running educational institutions carry exemptions under Sections 10(23C), 12AA and 80(G) and such exemptions are the appetizers for educational institutions without which none can survive. This is not only an appetizer for the educational menu but for all charitable activities irrespective of the cuisine. Budget 2020 amendments to Sections 12AB, 10(23C) and 80G enforcing renewal once in five years and terminating the mutual co-existence of 12AA & 10(23C) recognition are the dual concerns seeking remedial rethink.

The Supreme Court and many judicial authorities have rightly upheld the harmonious co-existence of registrations u/s 10(23C) and 12AA. The present amendment in the Finance Bill fails to understand the basic conception that an "institution" under Section 10(23C) can be part of a Trust/Society under Section 12AA and both can co-exist. The budget amendment denies exemption granted to an institution registered under Section 10(23C) since the larger Trust enjoys exemption u/s 12AA and the proposed insertions are against the basic tenets governing exemptions leading to avoidable chaos.

Second, it was only after careful consideration and through budget amendments between 2006 and 2009, 12AA registration was made permanent with a power to cancel if found violative. To go back to the historic ages of renewal once in five years will create unease as against the promise ease. At best, to eliminate dormant trusts, a unique registration number may be assigned online to existing and active Trusts and Societies on a self-submission or approval basis. When powers to cancel registration are abundantly manifest with income tax authorities, applying for renewal once in five years will lead to avoidable disarray. The exemptions under Sections 10(23C) and 12AA are germane to the philanthropic and charitable capital of India and provides the appetizing starter for the menu of public work that non-governmental organisations undertake.

The finance minister has been very considerate on the basis of trust to provide path-breaking reforms in company law. Trusts are also trustworthy and the same consideration is solicited to make the budget menu delicious from start to end.

(The writer is vice-chancellor of SASTRA Deemed University)

Title: Infant dies after falling into water bucket
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Surat: An 18-month-old girl died of drowning after falling into a water bucket kept outside her house in Pandesara area of the city on Sunday evening.

Saumya Mishra was playing when she lost balance and fell into the bucket full of water kept nearby. She gulped down lots of water and died of drowning. Saumya’s father is driver in a travel firm and is a native from Sultanpur in Uttar Pradesh. The girl was rushed to a private hospital and from there to New Civil Hospital where she died during treatment. Postmortem on her body confirmed her death due to drowning, police said.

Police have registered a case of accidental death and begun investigation.

Title: Over 100 textile shops sealed in Moti Begumwadi over poor fire measures
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Surat: Fire and emergency services department of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) sealed over 100 shops in textile markets at Moti Begumwadi here on Monday. Ten shops are located in Riddhi Siddhi Market, 83 in Arihant Market and 10 in Manish Market at Moti Begumwadi in central zone of the city. These markets were surveyed for fire safety measures and notices issued to their owners. The shops won't be allowed to open unless their owners promise to adhere to fire safety norms, sources said.

The shopkeepers had been given a week’s time earlier to install proper fire safety systems under Gujarat Fire Prevention and Life Safety Measures Act.

Chief fire officer Basant Parikh said, “All these markets have shops in basement and a single staircase with no emergency exit. They don’t have any fire emergency plan either. The owners have made assurances again, but we have asked them to come up with proper planning by architects before they could be allowed to reopen their shops. There are many such markets and each one of them would be made accountable.”

Civic officials said there are at least 50 textile markets in this area and all have been issued notices for poor fire safety measures.

Title: PE/VC deals see a 13% y-o-y dip in Jan
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: PE & VC investors invested $1.97 billion across companies in January, down 13%, owing to VC funds exercising caution in early-stage deals and PE investors taking a break from infra deals, which dominated the scene in 2019. In January 2019, the investments were at $2.24 billion.

“Considering venture funds, there is a clear sign of cautiousness, while later stage deals — series C and higher — witness brisk activity. Indian investors are mirroring the cautious behaviour of their global counterparts, who started tightening purse strings once Softbank’s investee companies’ performance dipped. Only well-established models are attracting interest,” said Arun Natarajan, MD, Venture Intelligence.

He added that PE deals are seeing a dip because the fund houses who had pumped in record funds in 2019 on the infrastructure sector have given a brief pause. Notably, infra deals were absent from the list of top 5 investments.

Exits, on the other hand saw a rise in value, although down by number. During January 10 exits worth $821million were recorded, while last year saw 16 exits at $301 million. Top exits include some investments in Byjus at $200 million and Narayana Health at $39 million. The standout deals in the PE and VC space include Varde Partners and Goldmann Sachs putting in $567 million in RattanIndia Power, edtech platform Byjus raking in $200 million from Tiger Global and Zomato seeing $150 million from Alibaba. Among VC deals, InterviewBit and Mamaearth saw the highest at $20 million and $18 million respectively

Title: Four booked for firing in Kutch
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Rajkot: Four persons were booked for allegedly firing in the air near Khedoi village of Anjar taluka in Kutch district on Sunday night.

Police said the accused, identified as Shaktisinh Sarvaiya, Kuldeepsinh Sarvaiya, Kuldeepsinh Jadeja and Jaipalsinh Jadeja, had opened fire at Gopal Chawda.

According to the police, the victim and the accused were going in their cars on Gandhidham-Mundra Highway. When the accused tried to overtake the car being driven by Chawda, Chawda did not give them side. This angered the accused who overtook Chawda’s car and stopped it by bringing their car in front of Chawda’s vehicle.

“When Chawda alighted from his car, the accused allegedly beat him up with fists and kicks and also lashed him with a belt. One of the accused took out a firearm and opened fire in the air to scare Chawda,” said M B Zala, inspector with Anjar police station.

Title: BJP leader killed in accident
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Rajkot: A BJP leader was killed when the motorcycle he was driving was hit by an unidentified vehicle on Babra-Amreli Highway in Amreli district on Sunday night.

The deceased was identified as Kuldeepsinh Solanki, former president of BJP’s youth wing in Babra. He was also an ex-member of Babra municipality.

“Solanki was returning home after attending a marriage function in Ingorala village of Babra taluka when he met with the accident. We are checking the footages of the CCTVs installed at various places along the highway to ascertain the identity of the vehicle that had caused the accident,” said an official from Babra police station.

Title: Engineering student ends life in Samras Hostel
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Caption

Surat: A 20-year-old engineering student ended life by hanging himself in his hostel room on Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) campus on Udhna Magdalla Road here on Monday. The student in his suicide note said he was fed up of life. Dipak Boricha was a third year engineering student at Bhagvan Mahavir College. He had been securing first class in engineering studies and the exact reason why he committed suicide is still not known, police said.

He was not answering phone calls of a friend after which the latter went to check on him in his hostel room at Samras Hostel because midterm examinations are on in the university. Boricha’s friend informed hostel officials when he did not open the door. The hostel officials broke open the door at around 10.30am and found him hanging from the ceiling fan with a bed sheet. He had written 7.40am atop his suicide note. Police suspect that he may have committed suicide after that.

Boricha’s brother Yogesh, a bachelor’s of commerce student, lives in the same hostel. He told police that he was not aware why his brother was upset. “They had dinner together in the hostel last night after which they went to their respective rooms. Dipak expressed his love for family and friends in the suicide note, but didn’t mention the reason why he was ending his life,” said a police officer at Umra police station.

“The hostel staff was informed by a friend of Dipak that he was not opening the door. Our staff broke open the door of his room and found him hanging,” said an officer of hostel administration.

Dipak was a native of Bhavnagar. His family members are expected to reach the city by late night. “We have not found any reason behind his suicide. There was no pressure on him because he was good in studies. He neither had an affair and nor was facing any financial crisis,” police said.

Title: Three arrested with 26kg ganja worth Rs 1.6L
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Guni Odeja and Sarabjit Singh (seated) were held with 22kg ganja near Surendranagar

Rajkot: Three persons were arrested with 26 kg ganja (marijuana) worth Rs 1.55 lakh in two different raids reported from Rajkot-Ahmedabad Highway near Pansina village in Surendranagar district and Rajkot city in the past 24 hours.

In Pansina village, Guni Odeja (37) and Sarabjitsingh Sikh (31) were arrested with 21.9 kg ganja worth Rs 1.31 lakh that they had stored in their truck on Monday morning.

“During their interrogation, Odeja and Sikh said that they had smuggled the contraband from Andhra Pradesh and were taking it to Lalpur of Jamnagar district. The ganja was hidden beneath iron plates of the truck. The ganja was meant to be supplied to Bhura Nautihar and Imran Khalifa, following which we booked both of them,” said D M Dhol, inspector with Surendranagar local crime branch.

In Rajkot, Mustaq Junach (26) was arrested with 4.43 kg ganja worth Rs 24,258 from Kanta Stree Vikas Gruh. “We arrested Junach on the basis of a tip-off that he was carrying the contraband in his two-wheeler,” said H M Rana, sub-inspector with Rajkot special operation group.

During his interrogation, Junach said he had ordered the contraband to be supplied to him from Surat. A drug dealer had come from Surat and handed him over the contraband at Rajkot bus stand. Junach was taking the drug in the boot of his two-wheeler before he was intercepted by cops and arrested.

Title: RMC launches drive to seal properties
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Rajkot: Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) on Tuesday started a drive to seal properties of to property tax defaulters. In the first phase, the civic body will identify the properties whose outstanding tax amount is above Rs one lakh. RMC has also identified 24 properties which will be auctioned next week after sealing.

According to RMC sources, there are 4,000 property owners, whose outstanding amount is more than Rs one lakh and have defaulted on a total Rs 90 crore. The defaulters with outstanding amount above Rs 5 lakh are 200 and the dues are Rs 110 crore. These properties have already been attached. The majority defaulters in the category of Rs 1 lakh and Rs 5 lakh are commercial and industrial property owners.

Municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal said, “We will seal the attached properties and collect the outstanding tax through auction. We have published the list of defaulters on our website and soon their names will be displayed on the big LED screens across the city to publicly shame them.”

The civic body collects the property tax from 4.84 commercial and industrial establishments. Last year’s collection was Rs 248 crore while in current financial year Rs 158 crore collected against the target of Rs 257 crore. The RMC adopted new formula last year to calculate the tax based on carpet area.

Special teams consisting of 300 RMC staffers have been formed in all the 18 wards for the drive which will continue till the end of the financial year. The civic body will also approach the small residential defaulters and disconnect the water and drainage connection for non-payment.

Title: Shaktikanta Das named APAC ‘central banker of the year’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

RBI governor Shaktikanta Das (Photo:: Reuters)

MUMBAI: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das ’s moves to regulate non-banking finance companies (NBFCs) without hand-outs has won him the title of Asia-Pacific’s central banker of the year .

The award has been instituted by a publication — The Banker — to celebrate the officials that have best managed to stimulate growth and stabilise their economy. In a note, The Banker said the RBI has faced a series of challenges, from non-performing loans to issues around fraud.

“Faced with these challenges, Shaktikanta Das, governor of RBI, has taken steps to bring banking in India up to standard via a restrained approach to governance,” the statement said. It also acknowledged Das’s measures to tighten the rules around shadow banking, and bring lenders outside banking under greater scrutiny.

“Das has been outspoken on the lack of governance in banking, calling for tighter rules for the state-owned banks, which comprise 60% of India’s banking sector. To make the banking system more robust, the central bank is to set up a college for supervisors with the aim of improving supervisory skills,” the note said.

In the past, former governor Raghuram Rajan was felicitated as central banker of the year (global and Asia-Pacific) in 2016 for his role in weathering the risks arising out of US tightening in 2015.

Title: Retaining walls along banks of Krishna soon
Content:
YSRC workers on Monday held a rally in Krishna Lanka here celebrating chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy’s de... Read More

VIJAYAWADA: YSRC workers on Monday held a rally in Krishna Lanka here celebrating chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy’s decision to sanction Rs 125 crore to build retaining walls along the banks of the Krishna.Parts of Krishna Lanka, Balaji Nagar and Ranigari Thota were inundated due to heavy rains in the monsoon. The construction of levees during the TDP’s regime was incomplete and as a result, failed to control flood waters from inundating the areas.The government sanctioned funds to complete the works after requests from the Irrigation department and Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC). YSRC Vijayawada east incharge Devineni Avinash, who oversaw the rally, said Jagan was keen on developing Vijayawada. Ministers Peddireddy Ramachandra Reddy and Botsa Satyanarayana attended the rally.“The TDP government ignored the welfare of Krishna Lanka. Floods in the monsoon season highlighted the need for retaining walls. Jagan listened to the problems of the locals and sanctioned a huge amount for their welfare,” Avinash said.Meanwhile, Telugu Desam slammed YSRC leaders and asked them to stop making false claims. Vijayawada East legislator Gadde Rama Mohana Rao said the project was given top priority during the TDP regime and a major portion of the works was completed. “YSRC leaders deceived the public by hiding facts. The project proposed during YS Rajasekhar Reddy ’s regime was ignored by the Congress-led state government. It is Chandrababu Naidu who prepared the revised estimates for the project and sanctioned Rs 135 crore under the first phase,” Gadde said. The state government has not released enough funds for the second phase of works, but it is not sufficient to take up the works. I demand the government release around Rs 160 crore to complete the second phase, he demanded.

Title: Customer service point incharge shot, Rs 19 lakh looted in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Bike-borne criminals shot dead the incharge of a customer service point (CSP) of SBI and looted Rs5.42 lakh from him near Bedwalia on Raipura-Marhaura road under Bheldi police station in Saran district on Monday. In another incident, Rs13.38 lakh was looted from the managing director of an LPG agency at Makhdumpur in Jehanabad district earlier in the day.

CSP incharge Krishna Rai was returning to his office at Bansdih village after withdrawing money from Garkha branch of the SBI on his motorbike. Saran SP Har Kishore Rai said Krsihna was a resident of Jahri Pakri under Amnaur police station in Saran district.

In Jehanabad, the incident took place around 10am when Gagan Bhushan Prasad, the managing director of Prasad Inden Gas Agency, was about to alight from his car on the Bank of India gate at Makhdumpur to deposit the cash. Four criminals on two motorbikes accosted Prasad and looted the bag containing cash at gunpoint. “They threatened me to shoot. I had no option but to hand over the bag,” Prasad, who is also associated with JD(U), told the senior police officers who reached the spot to inquire into the daylight robbery.

Prasad revealed that the cash was stocked in the office as the bank remained closed for three days due to the strike. The robbers also opened fire in the air to terrorize the local residents and shopkeepers when he raised an alarm after the incident, Prasad said, adding that the criminals escaped towards Tehta on the Gaya-Patna road.

SP Maneesh said a dedicated team of police officers has been formed to nab the criminals. He said there was no CCTV camera at the bank gate. Even the security guard of the bank didn’t intervene when the robbers opened fire, he added.

This is the third cash loot case under Makhdumpur police station area in the last one month. Earlier, a Bandhan Bank employee was robbed of Rs36,000 after being shot at near Paltu Bigha on Sagarpur-Makhdumpur road, followed by a loot of Rs65,000 from incharge of a customer service point (CSP) of a nationalized bank near Nandpura Bypass in January.

Title: Bihar: NABARD unveils Rs 1.36 lakh crore credit plan
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) on Monday unveiled the state’s annual credit plan (ACP) for 2020-21 financial year, pegging it at an ambitious Rs1.36 lakh crores for loan lending purposes in the eight priority sectors.

NABARD chief general manager (CGM) Amitabh Raj said the ACP for 2020-21 has been increased by over Rs7,000 crore, as it was Rs1.29 lakh crore in 2019-20. “It is hoped that the increase would help in doubling the farmers’ income by 2022 and also increase the state’s credit-deposit ratio from the existing 44% compared to the national average of 77%,” Raj said.

Of the eight priority sectors, Rs52,243.53 crore of loan is to be given in the areas of crop production, maintenance and marketing, while Rs17,851.66 crore has been fixed for term loan for agriculture and allied activities. Further, Rs5,587.27 crore would be given against agriculture infrastructure and Rs6,262.08 crore for ancillary activities.

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi released the 2020-21 ACP for the state at a seminar at Gyan Bhavan. Finance department principal secretary S Sidharth, rural development department principal secretary Arvind Chaudhary, RBI regional director Dewesh Lal and SBI CGM Mahesh Goyal also spoke on the occasion.

Modi said the number of Kisan Credit Card (KCC) holders had been falling. Besides, the crop loan disbursed in 2015-16 was to the tune of Rs24,500 crore, when the number of KCC holders was 26.15 lakh. Loan disbursement has also come down to Rs19,445 crore.Lal also asked the bankers to sustain the SHGs, because they had emerged as major driver of local economic activities at the micro level.

Title: Double murder over drinks in Margao, 1 held
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: Fatorda police on Monday arrested Arjun Maruti Kajidoni, 30, a native of Karnataka, on charges of murdering two persons near the SGPDA market in Margao during the intervening night of Sunday and Monday.

The deceased have been identified as Ravi, 20, a casual labourer, and Bhim, 30, a ragpicker, police said. Kajidoni worked as a driver and stayed at Madel in Fatorda.

Briefing reporters about the double murder , South Goa SP Arvind Gawas said that the two died following a scuffle with the accused over sharing of drinks.

“Bhim, Ravi and Sunil Sawant were drinking outside a bar near the SGPDA market late Sunday night. Well past midnight, Arjun came to the bar and on finding the shop closed, asked Bhim to share his drinks with him. When Bhim refused to do so, a scuffle ensued between the four,” Gawas said.

While Arjun hit Bhim’s head with a laterite stone, which apparently led to his instantaneous death, he hit Ravi and Sawant with empty liquor bottles. Ravi also died instantly, but Sawant was grievously injured.

Sawant lay there bleeding till Fatorda police reached the spot around 9 am on Monday after being informed by locals and shifted him to Hospicio in Margao. Sawant is out of danger, police said.

Gawas said that the needle of suspicion pointed to Kajidoni as he was minutely observing police movement at the crime scene from a distance. Constable Avinash Naik attached to the Curchorem police station picked him up for interrogation. Upon sustained questioning, he admitted to having killed the duo.

With the case cracked within 12 hours, IGP Jaspal Singh has announced a reward of Rs 25,000 to the investigating team led by DySP Serafino Dias, Gawas told reporters.

Title: Two mega rallies planned for Biju’s 104th birth anniversary
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The ruling BJD has planned a mega show on the 104th birth anniversary of former chief minister Biju Patnaik that will be celebrated on March 5.

The day also marks completion of 20 years of Naveen Patnaik as chief minister of Odisha.

Though details of the programme are yet to be finalised, the regional party has decided to organize two mega rallies in the state.

While one rally will be held in Cuttack, where the ancestral house (Anand Bhawan) of the legendary leader is located, another rally is likely to be organised in the western Odisha (mostly likely in Bargarh), said official sources. Naveen would attend both rallies.

“The birth anniversary of Biju Patnaik will be celebrated across the state. Several important programmes are being planned and it would soon be finalised. Apart from March 5, there will be week-long programme to mark the occasion,” said BJD general secretary (headquarters) Sanjay Das Burma.

In power for the past 20 years, Naveen had assumed charge as chief minister of Odisha on March 5, 2000, three years after formation of BJD following the death of Biju Patnaik. With a robust organisational base, pro-people schemes and Naveen’s clean image, the party stormed to power for the fifth consecutive time in May last year.

Senior leaders of the party from various districts met here at the party headquarters to discuss plans to celebrate the day. As March 5 is also celebrated as Panchayati Raj day by the state government, several programmes are being planned. Das Burma said the women’s wing, youth and students wings of the regional party will be involved during the week-long celebration in all 33 organizational districts.

Workshops on the success and achievements of BJD government in the past two decades, particularly in poverty alleviation, infrastructure development, sports promotion and disaster preparedness would be organised.

Youth and student conclaves and meetings on various pro-people policies of the government would be organised during the week-long celebration, said BJD insiders.

BJD insiders said the seven-day programme would be a people-connect exercise to further consolidate the party’s base in the state.

Title: VMC declares 7k ineligible for pension
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation’s (VMC) list declaring 7,000 people ineligible to receive pension is making the former beneficiaries run from pillar to post seeking answers.

At the special grievances redressal session conducted by civic authorities here, a number of people were seen waiting at ward secretariats to know the reason they were put on the list.

The state government introduced ward and village secretariat systems to take up door-to-door survey under Nava Sakam. Ward volunteers knocked on every door for data to prepare a preliminary list of beneficiaries of pensions, rice cards and other government schemes.

Around 7,000 pensioners in the city were declared ineligible and were asked to show documents to prove their eligibility to seek pension. Opposition parties in the city strongly condemned the move of the state government.

“The state government is deceiving the poor in the name of Nava Sakam survey. The government which introduced ward volunteers system to ease administration is now making senior citizens wait outside ward secretariats. Around 2,500 senior citizens and widows have been declared ineligible citing silly reasons,” said Gadde Ramamohana Rao, Vijayawada east TDP legislator.

A few pensioners were taken off the beneficiary list for using more than 200 units of power per month and some pensioners were removed for residing in ancestral property of more than 900 square feet, he said.

CPI city assistant secretary G Koteswara Rao demanded the the state government give one month’s time for the beneficiaries to respond to the objections raised by the government.

Krishna district in-charge minister Peddireddy Rama Chandra Reddy condemned the allegations made by the opposition. He said the TDP was trying to create unrest by spreading false news on pensioners.

However, authorities of Vijayawada Municipal Corporation said that they had raised objections on around 7000 pension beneficiaries in the city and issued around 8,000 new pensions in the city.

Title: Kochi educational institutions go solar
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Solar panel on the rooftop of Maharaja’s College boys’ hostel

KOCHI: Educational institutions in the city are taking the green path with many colleges and schools, both government/aided and unaided, now working on rooftop solar projects to decrease the dependence on conventional sources of energy and reduce carbon footprint. Also, several institutions are planning to increase the capacity of their existing solar projects and aim to become fully solar-powered.

Among the latest developments, around 11 government educational institutions, including Maharaja’s College, will soon launch rooftop solar projects within two months as part of the solar project worth 1MW capacity in governmental buildings envisaged by Cochin Smart Mission Ltd (CSML) under the SmartCity project. Besides CSML’s project, rooftop solar panels are under construction at St Albert’s College and Rajagiri Public School. Sacred Heart College, Thevara, is also mooting plans and expects to be fully solar-powered by next academic year.

Under the CSML’s project, Maharaja’s College will have a 70kW solar project, of which solar panels with capacities 50kW and 20kW are installed on the rooftop of boys’ hostel and Britto building on the campus. Works are in final stage and the project is awaiting inspection by electrical inspectorate followed by commissioning.

“Maharaja’s College is the only college under the CSML project, which is expected to cut the electricity consumption of the college to nearly half of the current consumption. This will help the college save around Rs 65,000 monthly. Though the capacity could have been increased much higher than 70kW to fulfil the whole requirement of the college, lack of enough strong roofs in the old building and the green cover inside the campus was a challenge. But with two new buildings coming up, expansion of the capacity is possible in future,” said a college official.

The other educational institutions where installation works are proceeding under the project are GGHSS Panampilly Nagar (25kW), GGHSS Chittoor Road (30kW), GHSS Edakochi (25kW) and GHS Edakochi (20kW), Vennala GHS (40kW), Punnakkal GHS (40kW), Kunnumpuram GHS (20kW) and GHSS (20kW), Edappally GHSS (35kW). The works are in different stages and are expected to be commissioned within three months.

The existing solar project at Sacred Heart College fulfils nearly 20% of the college’s power requirements. “We were the first college in Ernakulam to initiate rooftop solar project in 2011. The present system has 33kW capacity and we are planning to be fully solar-powered in the next academic year. It will help us save around Rs 1.75 lakh per month. Many companies have conducted studies, and negotiations of final terms are on,” said college principal Fr Prashant Palakkappillil.

Rajagiri Public School principal Fr Varghese Kachappilly said that the installation works of solar panels in the school have been completed and are yet to be connected to KSEB’s power grid. “The project will cover 60% of the school’s power needs. It will be ready during the summer vacation,” he said.

While Sacred Heart CMI Public School, Thevara, and Rajagiri College of Social Sciences, Kalamassery, already have existing solar rooftop projects, of which they are planning to increase the capacity in the coming years, Bharata Mata College, Thrikkakara, and ToC-H Public School, Vyttila, are fully solar-powered.

Title: Civic body gets state-of-the-art tech to repair damaged city roads
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vijayawada: Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) is all set to repair the busy Nehru road stretch in One Town area using ‘Z patcher’ technology.

A major portion of the city’s roads got damaged in the monsoon. Potholes , some of which are a foot deep, are causing severe inconvenience to denizens. TOI had its columns highlighted problems faced by motorists due to bad roads.

In response, VMC has finally started road restoration works using advanced technology. VMC commissioner Prasanna Venkatesh inspected ongoing works at Nehru Road and enquired about the advanced technology.

“We are focused on restoring roads in the city. Advanced Z patcher technology helps repair potholes in the shortest possible time. The surface is cleaned using a heavy blower attached to the machine and is filled with emulsion and fine gravel. This technology is long-lasting,” Venkatesh said.

He inspected road expansion works on Nehru Road and asked the city planning wing to take up necessary measures to extend the road.

Officials explained that 90 percent of expansion works on Nehru Road had been completed and the bottleneck near a masjid and church has to be corrected. The Commissioner asked the planning wing to take up consultations with locals and complete expansion works.

Title: Jail inmate turns to art, adds colours to walls
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ramesh Patwa (35) busy completing a painting in Siddharthnagar district jail

Gorakhpur: A jail inmate serving life imprisonment for killing his wife for dowry has added beautiful colours to the walls of Siddharthnagar district jail with his paintings.

Ramesh Patwa (35), a resident of Shohratgarh area in Sidsharth Nagar district killed his wife for dowry in 2011 and is serving life sentence in Siddharthnagar jail since 2013.

Jail superintendent Rakesh Singh said that Ramesh has changed a lot after he started painting. He also helps doctors in the jail as before coming to jail he was assistant to a private doctor and also did a course in pharmacy.

“We always encourage jail inmates to get involved in positive activities and there is no doubt that art has the power to change a person. After he started painting we noticed a huge change in Ramesh. He has become kind and compassionate and always helps doctors and patients. Subjects of his paintings vary from deities to nature and even portraits. Jail provides him colours and brush,” said Singh.

For Ramesh painting is his atonement of sins. He said that he learned painting from a jail inmate Feroz, a native of Basti district. In the jail Ramesh met Feroz who was given the responsibility of colouring walls of the jail. From Feroz, Ramesh learnt to hold brush and paint.

Title: Tourism dept to rejuvenate Akkulam lake at Rs 64 crore
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A decade after a project worth Rs 17 crore to dredge Akkulam lake became a non-starter, even inviting a vigilance probe, the tourism department is set to launch a comprehensive rejuvenation plan for the lake. Kerala infrastructure investment fund board (KIIFB) has given approval for the project worth Rs 64.13 crore.

The project report was completed with technical assistance from Barton Hill Engineering College. The project aims at the revival of Akkulam lake and channels from Kannamoola.

The rejuvenation plan will be executed using eco-friendly technology and detailed project report was prepared by the Transitional Research and Professional Leadership Centre, Bartonhill Engineering College. The plan is to remove the trash and algae accumulated in the water body. The elevated areas near Akkulam lake will be converted into green islands and natural water cleansing mechanism will be implemented in such places.

The first phase aims at removal of unwanted aquatic plants, waste and removal of bund under Akkulam bridge. The works on deepening the boating channel will also be done as part of the first phase.

While new plans are being drawn for Akkulam lake, no questions had been asked regarding crores of rupees wasted on dredging till date. The earlier project, which was conceived in 2009 and launched in 2010, aimed at attaining a depth of 2.2m in Akkulam lake, below mean sea level. The quantity of earth to be dredged to attain this depth was fixed at 7.4 lakh cu.m. The project took off in 2010 and was set a deadline in 2011.

The quick verification report of vigilance and anti-corruption bureau (VACB) and project documents had proved that the state government embarked on the Rs 17 crore worth project to dredge nearly 7 lakh cu.m silt from Akkulam lake without having any idea where and how to dispose the huge volume of matter being dredged. The quick verification report of VACB revealed that even the items in schedule of works pertaining to disposal of silt had been revised. Initially there was a plan to construct a bund using dredged material and form an island in Akkulam lake. However, this was changed to provision for having dumping yards. Six dump yards were determined only after framing the agreement.

Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran said that revival of Ulloor canal, Pattom canal and Medical College canal for a limited distance will also be implemented. The rest of the canal will be cleaned and revived under Smart City project. The minister said that boating will be resumed and adventure sports items will be introduced with a view to attracting visitors to Akkulam. Central government PSU Wapcos has been chosen as the special purpose vehicle for implementing the project.

Title: Dy commissioner, tout caught red-handed accepting Rs1.5L bribe
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Yavatmal: Anti-Corruption Bureau sleuths of Yavatmal and Amravati have in a joint operation on Monday caught deputy commissioner of social welfare department Jaya Vinod Raut (42), senior clerk in her office Nitin Kade, and their tout Savan Prakash Chaudhary (38) red-handed while accepting a bribe of Rs1.5 lakh from a complainant. The ACB sleuths arrested Jaya Raut and Savan Choudhary and seized the bribe amount.

Nitin Kade managed to escape.

The complainant is a teacher and needs caste verification certificate from the District Caste Verification Committee headed by Jaya Vinod Raut, who is a class I officer. The teacher, a resident of Brahmapuri tehsil of Chandrapur, had approached the Yavatmal office and submitted the application. The accused duo demanded bribe of Rs2 lakh for issuing the caste verification certificate.

They named tout Savan Chaudhary as the person to whom the teacher should give the bribe amount. The complainant then lodged a complaint with ACB Amravati regarding the deal.

A trap was laid in the Yavatmal office of Jaya Raut, and the complainant sent with bribe of Rs1.5 lakh as advance.

ACB sleuths had put original currency notes of Rs15,000 and Rs1.35 lakh duplicate notes from a children’s board game, and the bundles were handed over to the tout Savan in the office of Jaya Raut on Monday.

The waiting ACB sleuths then sprang into action and seized the original and duplicate notes worth Rs1.5 lakh from Savan and arrested him. Savan confessed to having received the amount on behalf of Jaya Raut and Nitin Kade.

The ACB sleuths then arrested Jaya Raut from her office. However, her senior clerk Nitin escaped.

Further investigations are being carried out by police inspector Ravindra Jedhe.

Title: Nitish Kumar: AAP focusing on false publicity
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar campaigns in Delhi’s Wazirpur

NEW DELHI: Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar on Monday attacked the Aam Aadmi Party dispensation in Delhi for concentrating on “false publicity and distributing freebies” to be in the limelight rather than then doing “real development”.

Blaming chief minister Arvind Kejriwal for “non-performance” on the development front in the past five years, Nitish asked the voters to give a chance to the BJP-led NDA to form a government in Delhi for overall development like Bihar.

“Making civic amenities free (electricity and water) will never lead to the development of the city. Real development comes with real improvement in infrastructure facilities. Looking at the condition of the city, it is hard to believe that this is the national capital,” Nitish said, while highlighting various projects taken up in Bihar since 2005. He added, “We were never worried about publicity of the projects because their success spoke for them.”

Addressing an election rally in Wazirpur for BJP candidate Mahendra Nagpal, Nitish compared the development works of his government with Delhi. Hundreds of people, mostly Poorvanchalis, had turned up in large numbers to attend the rally.

“AAP claimed that it worked a lot in the education sector by constructing a few hundreds schools. In comparison, we constructed 22,000 primary and 19,000 middle schools in Bihar, but never looked for publicity. After Class V, poverty-ridden people were not sending girls to school, so we introduced the poshak yojana. We wanted girls to study till Class IX, so we introduced cycle yojana,” said Nitish.

The Bihar CM said while Delhi government was only concentrating on electricity supply, Bihar had set a target for replacing all dangling and damaged wires in all cities and villages. “Delhi government is busy offering free electricity. These dangling old wires led to fires in factories and workers, who were natives of Bihar, lost their lives,” he added.

Nitish attacked Kejriwal for his controversial statement in which he had said that people came from Bihar with a railway ticket of Rs 500 and got free treatment in hospitals up to Rs 5 lakh. Agreeing with MoS (home affairs) Nityanand Rai, Nitish blamed Kejriwal for not providing permits to Bihar State Road Transport Corporation for plying buses up to Delhi.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Minor alleges rape, police book youth for harassment
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

Title: Coronavirus scare hits chilli exports from Andhra Pradesh, Telangana to China
Content:
Representative image

GUNTUR: Prices of the famed Guntur and Teja varieties of chilli has dropped by nearly 50% at the Guntur market yard, the biggest chilli marketplace in the country. The sharp fall has largely been triggered by the coronavirus outbreak in China, one of the largest importers of Indian chilli. The neighbouring country has suspended imports since the virus outbreak, leaving chilli farmers in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh worried.The prices have dipped to between Rs 5,000 and Rs 7,000 per quintal in recent days. The chillis, known for their high heat quotient, were commanding a price of between Rs 9,000 and Rs 12,000 till a fortnight ago.In fact, prices of the Teja variety touched between Rs 16,000 and Rs 20,000 per quintal in December, thanks to demand from China and Bangladesh. Bangladesh exports this chilli to China after purchasing the stock from India.The fall of Teja price has affected prices of other low-quality varieties as well. While Rs 8,000 per quintal is considered remunerative for growers, it was hovering between Rs 4,000 and Rs 6,000 per quintal for ordinary varieties.The Teja variety is considered the highest quality stock and commands high price chiefly in China. Interestingly, Teja stock which comes with very high pungency, is not a favourite stock for many other importers as they prefer varieties that sting the palate a little less.“We are closely monitoring the situation. It looks like a temporary halt. We will take appropriate measures to bail out the farmers if prices go down further,” agriculture market committee chairman C Yesuranthnam told TOI.“China uses the Teja variety to make many products which are then exported,” chilli exporter P Suresh Reddy told TOI. He added that traders involved in international businesses have urged merchants in Guntur agriculture yard to go slow on purchase following restriction on exports. Sources said that many Indian companies handle exports to China via Bangladesh due to ease of doing business and low taxation.

Title: Evicted Nilgiris farmers want to put up shops again in R S Puram market
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: As many as 23 farmers from the Nilgiris district who were evicted from R S Puram Uzhavar Sandhai on Monday came to the district collectorate and urged collector K Rajamani to allow them to put up their shops in the market again. While the collector asked the deputy director in charge of agricultural marketing to investigate into the matter, he also directed the officer to ensure that Coimbatore farmers be given priority over farmers from other districts.

The farmers, who displayed identity cards stating that they are members of the RS Puram Uzhavar Sandhai, said they had been setting up shop in the market between nine years and 20 years.

“Some farmers have started selling in the market when it was started 20 years ago. We mostly sell vegetables produced from our family farms. Once we run out of stock, we buy vegetables from neighbouring farmers and sell them,” Sivanandham Bhojan, one of the farmers, said. “As per the rules, we only sell a maximum of three vegetables each. For example, I sell only carrot and beans,” he added.

On Monday, the farmers brought fresh vegetables and began setting up shops when they were suddenly evicted by agriculture officers and police, they said.

Another complaintant said earlier, shop allotments were done by a lot system. Slowly agriculture officers began allotting ‘permanent shop’ to six or seven id card holders and allowed them to sell any number of vegetables.

“When we questioned about this, the authorities evicted us,” Bhojan said, adding, “We now want to be reinstated in the market or to get back our vegetables that we left in the market.”

While the farmers were upset that the collector questioned what Nilgiris farmers were doing the market, Rajamani, however, said priority should be given to local farmers. “I don’t deny that Nilgiris farmers were brought and placed in the Uzhavar Sandhai 20 years ago, when the concept was still new, to ensure adequate supply to the local people.

However, they are forming a lobby in uzhavar sandhais in the district now and are not allowing local farmers to set up shops,” he said.

Besides, none of the complainants are pure farmers as they sometimes act as traders when they buy produce from other farmers. “I am clear that only farmers should be given priority. Traders should either not be allowed or only considered as the last preference,” he said.

However, I have asked the agriculture marketing officer to investigate into all the issues and give me a report within a fortnight, he added.

Title: Work gathers pace, traffic curbs in place for 6 months
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The construction work of Kazhakkoottam flyover has gathered momentum following the traffic diversion in the Kazhakkoottam Junction–CSI Mission Hospital stretch from February 1. Though the traffic curbs affected free movement of vehicles in the initial days, motorists said that the situation has improved now.

Though National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) has made significant progress in works along the Kazhakkoottam-Technopark stretch of the flyover, it had to wait till traffic diversion came into effect to start piling works in the Kazhakkoottam-CSI Mission Hospital stretch. Still, unexpected hurdles have cropped up.

Sources in NHAI said that the presence of a temple on the road side is affecting the work. “The authorities of the nearby Shasta temple have approached high court and secured an interim stay against land acquisition in the area. As per our understanding, the temple is located on government land and thus they are not eligible for compensation. However, we have informed that court that compensation could be given if they could prove ownership,” said NHAI sources.

Meanwhile, traffic diversion is expected to be in place for six months.

Kazhakkoottam assistant commissioner Anil Kumar said that there are no major traffic issues due to the diversion. Vehicles, which arrive in three lanes, have to proceed in one lane from the area where traffic is diverted. That is causing some delay during rush hours,” he said.

Rajeev Krishnan, executive member of Pratidhwani, a socio-cultural organization of employees of companies based in Technopark, said that traffic diversion was an issue only on January 31, when trial run was conducted. “The motorists were caught in the traffic for two-three hours on the day of the trial run. After that, the situation has improved. There is no major traffic issue in the area now,” he said.

Anil Kumar said that the situation will further improve once the work of the service road in the area is completed. However, sources in NHAI said that construction of service road would take some time as they are yet to shift the utilities. “Utilities such as water pipelines, KSEB posts and telecom cables have to be shifted before construction of service road in the area,” said sources.

Title: State police HQ to get crèche soon
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Back to office after six months of maternity leave, T S Rout, who works at the state police headquarters in Cuttack, is heartbroken every time she has to leave her 10-month-old baby girl with a relative.

She is not alone. A number of other working mothers in the police headquarters also have to make arrangements for their children before coming to work. Their worries, however, will end soon as the police headquarters have decided to launch a crèche.

Once launched, the crèche would be the first of its kind in any government establishment in the state. “At least 70 women work in the state police headquarters in different sections. We plan to start the crèche for their benefit soon,” DGP Abhay said.

IGP (modernization and provisioning) Rekha Lohani said the crèche would start functioning in the next few weeks. “Work on it is under way. We will engage one or two women home guards to take care of the children who will be placed in the crèche by their mothers. The crèche will have all facilities for children,” Lohani said.

Employees welcomed the announcement and said it would take a load off their mind. “We (working mothers with small children) are often stressed as we always think of how our children are faring. A crèche at the workplace will help us balance our work and childcare,” an employee said.

At present, some police stations and district police offices, including in Gajapati and Keonjhar, have child-friendly rooms for women employees and visitors.

“Our district police office and two police stations — Paralakhemundi and Garabandh — have facilities for children,” Gajapati SP Sarah Sharma said.

In October last year, the state human rights commission had expressed displeasure at the state government for not providing crèche facilities in its offices in Bhubaneswar and the districts. According to the the national minimum guidelines of the ministry of women and child development, every establishment with 50 or more women employees should have crèche under the Maternity Benefit Amendment Act, 2017.

The state women and child development and Mission Shakti department said efforts were on to provide crèche facilities in the secretariat and big government establishments in Bhubaneswar and across the districts.

“We have written to all government offices to start crèche services at the earliest,” department secretary Anu Garg said.

Title: Maintainence command chief visits Sainik School
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Air Marshal Shashiker Choudhary, the Air Officer Commanding-in-Chief (AOC-in-C) of the Indian Air Force’s (IAF) maintenance command, visited Sainik School Chandrapur recently. Accompanied by his wife Anita Choudhary, he was received by Squadron Leader Naresh Kumar, the school’s principal. The officer also paid tributes at the war memorial there, said a press release issued by the defence PRO’s office.

Choudhary reviewed the functioning of the school and held discussions with the principal and staff members of the school. He expressed satisfaction and appreciated the team effort. The officer toured the school campus also. During his interaction with cadets, he emphasized the importance of upholding military ethos and discipline, said the press release.

Title: Water quality better in Kerala after floods: Study
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

KOZHIKODE: Kerala’s water bodies which have been heavily contaminated due to dumping of various kinds of waste were cleansed during the flooding events which hit the state in 2018. It had a positive effect on the surface water quality in the water bodies, says a study conducted by the researchers of Kochi-headquartered Central marine fisheries research institute ( CMFRI ).

The devastating floods led to increased freshwater flow into the estuaries. The surface waters were sampled from ecosystems, viz. lower end of estuaries, intertidal waters of beaches, mudbank region and inshore waters, from some districts in the state.

“We conducted the water quality assessment during August-September 2018 in a few selected coastal marine ecosystems viz. lower end of estuaries, intertidal waters of beaches, mudbank region and inshore waters from Malappuram, Thrissur, Ernakulam, Alappuzha and Kollam,” said D Prema, principal scientist, fishery environment management division (FEMD), CMFRI.

The surface waters were sampled to analyze selected water quality indicators using standard protocols and analytical methods.

The results revealed that, in comparison to the pre-flood period, there was increased content of nutrients, especially the dissolved inorganic nitrogen (DIN) in the Vembanad and Ashtamudi lakes. The major share of DIN was from the content of total ammoniacal nitrogen. Total suspended solids (TSS) was higher in Ashtamudi but not so in Vembanad lake. In both the lakes, the chlorophyll content was higher compared to the pre-flood period.

Similar trends were seen for nutrients and chlorophyll in the samples collected from the intertidal waters. The mudbank region showed increased nutrients, chlorophyll and TSS. The nearshore regions off Kochi and off Neendakara also showed increased nutrients, chlorophyll and TSS.

Prema said that the study clearly indicated that the ecology of the estuary and coastal waters is impacted by floods which can affect the fishery resources and community strictures of these habitats. The researchers compared the findings with the existing data on water quality.

“This should indicate that there would have been changes in the biodiversity of the systems. Such increase in nutrients could have helped the phytoplanktons which are food for the organic life in the water bodies, including fishes,” Prema added.

Title: After Ram temple, VHP to focus on uniting all Hindus
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

VHP president Vishnu Sadashiv Kokje talks to mediapersons on Magh Mela ground on Monday

Allahabad: Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) president Vishnu Sadashiv Kokje said on Monday that since the organisation’s top agenda of constructing Ram temple in Ayodhya has almost been achieved, it will now focus on bringing ‘samrasta’ (harmony) among Hindu communities by eradicating caste system to ensure unity among all Hindus.

Briefing reporters about the three-day Samajik Samrasta meet held at the ongoing Magh Mela, Kokje said, “Since our prime motto of construction of Lord Ram’s temple is over, we will launch samrasta campaign on a war footing across the country and will focus on new generation for eradicating caste system and bringing unity among all Hindus. We will include religious discourses (sat-sang) and stress on restoring the old glory of our culture, and will provide all kind of assistance to deprived.”

“Just holding ‘sah bhoj’ (community feast) would not bring samrasta. There is need of constructive measures to eradicate caste system,” he added.

“Ram temple had always been top priority of VHP and now since the court has ordered construction of temple in Ayodhya, we are now focusing on samrasta among Hindus. Efforts are being made since ages to break unity and we need to check such elements,” said Kokje.

“There is no conflict on the temple’s model, but hope that the trust formed by government also considers VHP model. Around 60% of stone carving for a two-storyed temple is already done and VHP model has become popular. We will give suggestions if the trust asks,” he added.

Kokje, however, demanded that only Ram bhakts (devotees) should be included in the trust.

Referring to the ongoing protests against the new citizenship law, he said, “It’s an attempt to disrupt the Union government’s functioning and many groups are behind it. Muslims are venting their frustration over recent developments like abrogating Articles 370, 35 A, banning triple talaq and court’s nod for Ram temple.”

Kokje, however, claimed “Today Muslim women are staging anti-CAA protests, the day is not far when these women would start a fight for their fundamental and moral rights which would be a befitting reply to those who have instigated them to join the agitation.”

Title: Locals protest against Shishambara waste plant at UEPPCB office
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Dehradun: The residents of Selaqui and Shishambara on Monday protested at the Uttarakhand Environment Protection and Pollution Control Board (UEPPCB) office. The protesters claimed that the Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) is running the waste plant without a NOC from UEPPCB for the past five months. They demanded that the UEPPCB close down the waste plant and sue the DMC for violating norms.

“The waste plant has made the lives of locals miserable. It was just a matter of time before we started protesting at every government office involved in the waste management plant. Our protest was at the UEPPCB because the board had given a NOC to the municipal corporation which expired in August 2019 but the waste plant continued to operate anyway. UEPPCB officials are not giving any proper explanation as to why they let this happen,” said Satpal Dhaniya, one of the protestors at UEPPCB’s office.

“We have given them (UEPPCB) a memorandum, where me mentioned that 6,000 locals staying in the vicinity of the waste plant have suffered from dengue while 8,000 have respiratory problems. Also, 12,000 locals have been affected by skin-related issues. We have warned UEPPCB officials that if they do not renew the waste plant’s NOC, we will protest on a large scale,” added Dhaniya.

UEPPCB officials confirmed to TOI that they had received the memorandum but declined to comment any further on the issue. It has been more than four months that locals have been protesting for Shishambara Waste Management Plant to be shifted.

Title: Municipal secy faces SLMC wrath
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kochi: The state-level monitoring committee (SLMC) on solid waste management has criticized Maradu municipality secretary for failure to implement direction of the committee regarding debris removal at the four sites in Maradu.

SLMC chairman A V Ramakrishna Pillai, who visited the sites on Monday, noticed that there were no sprinklers, surveillance cameras and barriers set up at the sites. Using sprinklers, installing CCTV cameras and barriers are mandatory under Construction and Demolition Waste Management Rules 2016. SLMC warned the municipality that failure to implement the directions will invite huge fines.

The chairman rapped the workers at Golden Kayaloram site for retrieving steel without sprinkling water on concrete slabs. “We had instructed them to implement certain rules during debris removal at the four sites. But nothing has been implemented so far. So, we have asked the pollution control board to monitor the implementation of directions and submit report to the SLMC every week. Using motor pumps will not solve the problem arising out of dust. If they use sprinklers, it will evenly distribute water on the debris and settle dust,” Pillai said.

A PCB official said the board had sent letters to the municipality several times directing to implement the C and D rules at the four sites. But it said it has neither received any reply from the local body nor from the debris removal agency. PCB will install air ambient quality monitoring station near the four sites on Tuesday to ensue air and sound pollution is within the limits. From Wednesday, daily monitoring would start.

Meanwhile, Prompt Enterprises, the debris removal agency, has been asked to submit waste management plan and details of land where they plan to store the debris.

Title: Govt has acquired 1.5 lakh sqm land for turtle nesting: Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Pramod Sawant

MARGAO: The forest department has acquired an area admeasuring 1,55,775 sqm at Galgibaga to facilitate nesting of Olive Ridley turtles, chief minister Pramod Sawant told the state assembly on Monday. He also said that the state government has also engaged a Bangalore-based agency, Dakshin Foundation, for preparing a turtle nesting conservation plan, and the work is under process.

Replying to a question posed by the Congress MLA Alexio Reginaldo Lourenco, Sawant said that various measures have been put in place by the government for conservation and protection of Olive Ridley turtles arriving and nesting on Goan beaches. Regular patrolling of the nesting beaches and monitoring and protection of the nesting pits are some of the measures Sawant mentioned.

Title: Water quality better in Kerala after floods: Study
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

KOZHIKODE: Kerala’s water bodies which have been heavily contaminated due to dumping of various kinds of waste were cleansed during the flooding events which hit the state in 2018. It had a positive effect on the surface water quality in the water bodies, says a study conducted by the researchers of Kochi-headquartered Central marine fisheries research institute ( CMFRI ).

The devastating floods led to increased freshwater flow into the estuaries. The surface waters were sampled from ecosystems, viz. lower end of estuaries, intertidal waters of beaches, mudbank region and inshore waters, from some districts in the state.

“We conducted the water quality assessment during August-September 2018 in a few selected coastal marine ecosystems viz. lower end of estuaries, intertidal waters of beaches, mudbank region and inshore waters from Malappuram, Thrissur, Ernakulam, Alappuzha and Kollam,” said D Prema, principal scientist, fishery environment management division (FEMD), CMFRI.

The surface waters were sampled to analyze selected water quality indicators using standard protocols and analytical methods.

The results revealed that, in comparison to the pre-flood period, there was increased content of nutrients, especially the dissolved inorganic nitrogen (DIN) in the Vembanad and Ashtamudi lakes. The major share of DIN was from the content of total ammoniacal nitrogen. Total suspended solids (TSS) was higher in Ashtamudi but not so in Vembanad lake. In both the lakes, the chlorophyll content was higher compared to the pre-flood period.

Similar trends were seen for nutrients and chlorophyll in the samples collected from the intertidal waters. The mudbank region showed increased nutrients, chlorophyll and TSS. The nearshore regions off Kochi and off Neendakara also showed increased nutrients, chlorophyll and TSS.

Prema said that the study clearly indicated that the ecology of the estuary and coastal waters is impacted by floods which can affect the fishery resources and community strictures of these habitats. The researchers compared the findings with the existing data on water quality.

“This should indicate that there would have been changes in the biodiversity of the systems. Such increase in nutrients could have helped the phytoplanktons which are food for the organic life in the water bodies, including fishes,” Prema added.

Title: Chambal canal wall cracks for third time in there months
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Agra: Following the lackadaisical approach of the irrigation department officials, boundary wall of Chambal canal in Pinahat block broke for the third time in past three months.

A major crack in the boundary wall of the unlined canal has caused water-logging in over 25 acres of farmland which has damaged wheat and mustard crop. At least 12 farmers claimed to have suffered crop loss. They are demanding compensation from the district administration.

Last month, boundary wall of Chambal canal had broken in village Rajora of Pinahat block. After the farmers complained, the irrigation department made a temporary arrangement to stop the flow of water into the fields.

On Monday morning, 25 acres of fields submerged in water after boundary wall of the canal broke again on Sunday morning. Even after the complaints of traders, irrigation department officials didn’t come forward to help. Local resident Vijay Singh said, “We had informed the irrigation department officials about the damaged canal and the water flowing into the fields. At least 12 farmers have lost their wheat and mustard crop. We will urge the district administration to provide us with compensation for the crop loss.”

Farmer Hariom said, “The irrigation department hardly does any repair and maintenance work on the canal. The canal broke thrice in the past three months. The irrigation department makes temporary arrangements but this time, we want a permanent solution to this problem.”

Executive engineer of the irrigation department Sharad Saurav Giri said, “Our team has started repairing the damaged part of Chambal canal. It will be completed by Tuesday. Required arrangements will be made to ensure the canal is not damaged again.”
