Title: Not mandatory for govt to table Justice Pal panel report: Orissa high court
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CUTTACK: The Orissa high court on Monday indicated that tabling of the Justice C R Pal Commission report in the assembly was not mandatory under the Commission of Inquiry Act, 1952, and that it was up to the state government to decide if it wanted to do so.

The Justice C R Pal Commission was appointed on March 11, 2008, to study and report on the appropriateness of setting up high court benches in other parts of the state. It submitted its report on March 31, 2014.

On January 14, a high court lawyer, Shivsankar Mohanty, filed a petition requesting the court to direct the government to place the report in the assembly. Acting on this, the court on January 20 asked the state counsel to take instructions from the government on whether it (the government) had the power to not place a judicial commission report before the assembly.

When the petition came up on Monday, Mohanty cited a Supreme Court judgment that had ruled that Section 3 (4) of the Commission of Inquiry Act, 1952, made it mandatory for the government to place a judicial commission report in the assembly within six months of the commission submitting it to the government.

However, the division bench of acting chief justice Sanju Panda and justice S K Sahoo said a couple of judgments by different high courts had held that placing of a judicial commission report in the assembly was not mandatory for the state government under Section 3 (4) of the same Act.

The bench adjourned hearing of the petition to February 10, while allowing Mohanty time till then to go through the cited high court judgments by then.

The PIL is significant as the Justice Pal Commission report on the feasibility of high court benches has been gathering dust for nearly six years. The government is yet to table it in the assembly in spite of growing clamour for high court benches in different parts of the state.

Title: Pune: IMD starts forecasts for Pashan & Lohegaon
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

File photo of joggers jogging with their dog covered in warm clothes on Pashan Road

PUNE: The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has for the first time since 1928 started issuing separate weather forecasts for Pashan and Lohegaon areas.

The IMD has been recording and maintaining temperature, rainfall, humidity and other key weather parameters measured at its Shivajingar, Lohegaon and Pashan stations since the past several years. The IMD’s headquarters, with records of all data, was shifted from Shimla to Pune in 1928.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD, Pune, said a five-day advance weather forecast was now being issued for Lohegaon and Pashan using weather information mainly gathered from its Shivajinagar weather observatory.

“Though there are minor variations in temperature values recorded at Shivajinagar, Pashan and Lohegaon (Pashan is cooler from time to time, while Lohegaon is slightly warmer than Shivajinagar), the separate forecasts will ensure accuracy in the localized forecasting,” he told TOI.

These warnings (issued at least 24 hours in advance and are updated from time to time) will help the local administration take measures and plan activities to deal with a weather-related adverse incident.

Weather forecasts through SMSs and WhatsApp from the IMD would also be available soon for these areas, in addition to its display on its website, an official said.

The IMD currently issues such weather warnings, or now updates, for 380 cities or towns in the country.

Kashyapi said the IMD has now started taking round-the-clock weather observations for Lohegaon and Pashan as well. “Earlier, round-the-clock observations were only taken for Shivajinagar in Pune. As a result, the number of daily observations for Lohegaon and Pashan has also increased,” he said.

Last year, Pune had witnessed extreme weather (rainfall) events during the latter part of monsoon, when several areas in the city were flooded with intense and heavy rainfall for many days. It was thus felt that location-specific weather warnings would help citizens and authorities deal with such adverse events better. An official said separate weather forecasts for Pashan and Lohegaon, along with Shivajinagar, were now being issued under the advice of IMD DGM Mrutyunjay Mohapatra.

Title: BJP protests cut in DPC funds
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

BJP members protesting at at Samvidhan Square on Monday

Nagpur: BJP activists led by former guardian minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule staged a protest at RBI Square against state finance minister Ajit Pawar’s move to reduce allocation to the Nagpur district planning committee ( DPC ) by Rs225 crore.

Addressing party workers, Bawankule said that if the allocation was reduced, it would severely impact the development of Nagpur District. “Every sector will be hit, including rural roads, water conservation, drinking water supply and special works of the gram panchayat,” he added.

The ex-minister demanded that Pawar increase the allocation by Rs100 crore to Rs850 crore. “The BJP government had doubled Nagpur DPC allocation in five years and this government is reducing it. I have sent a letter to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray urging him to not take this decision,” said Bawankule.

City BJP president Pravin Datke, district president Arvind Gajbhiye, MLC Anil Sole, former MLA Sudhakar Deshmukh, MLC Girish Vyas, MLA Sameer Meghe, MLA Vikas Kumbhare, MLA Mohan Mate, former MLAs Milind Mane, Sudhir Parwe, DM Reddy and Sudhakar Kohale and others were present in the protest.

Pawar’s decision has given BJP a stick to beat the Shiv Sena, Congress and the NCP. Its leaders were demoralized after the loss in the Nagpur zilla parishad (ZP) election but now have got an important issue to attack the government. They point out that the three cabinet ministers of the district — Anil Deshmukh, Nitin Raut and Sunil Kedar — could not prevent the cut in the allocation.

Pawar’s decision makes no political sense. The ZP is now controlled by Congress and NCP. The cut in funds will create problems for the leaders of these parties.

Title: CPM plans protest day against budget
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: CPM state secretariat declared February 6 as a protest day against the Union Budget. Protest marches will be organized to central government offices in all districts on Thursday.

“The budget presented by the Union finance minister on Sunday is completely pro-corporate and against the interest of ordinary citizens. The budget aims complete privatization and steps to mobilize Rs 2.1 lakh crore by selling shares of public sector companies are part of that. Even LIC is going to be sold,” said a statement issued by CPM state secretariat on Monday.

CPM also criticized the claims that the budget focusses on agriculture sector. “There are new projects to revive agriculture and industries sectors. There is a proposal to reduce subsidy for fertilizers,” said the statement.

The budget also ignores Kerala’s long standing development needs in railways and health sector and has taken a stand against cooperative sector, said CPM.

Title: Yogi calls Kejriwal a toy in hands of anti-India elements, AAP goes to EC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Yogi Adityanath

NEW DELHI: Upping the ante manifold against AAP national convener Arvind Kejriwal , UP CM Yogi Adityanath on Monday called him “a toy in the hands of anti-India anti-social elements”. He also blamed “Kejriwal and company” for trying to delay the hanging of the Nirbhaya case convicts and playing politics over the “honour of daughters and sisters”.

Yogi said that UP has much better roads than Delhi, whose infrastructure development has been obstructed by Kejriwal. He also alleged that Kejriwal was sympathising with people who work against India and raise anti-India slogans like “Afzal hum sharminda hain, tere katil zinda hain” and those who attacked soldiers in Pulwama.

“Kejriwal sympathises with people who chant Bharat tere tukde honge. You are not sharminda (ashamed) when you deprive the people of Delhi of basic amenities. Our jawans entered Pakistan to carry out a strike and this man asked for proof,” Yogi said.

A large part of Yogi’s day on Monday was spent canvassing in west Delhi. In the evening, he visited Yogmaya temple before addressing a gathering at Gorakhnath temple in Mehrauli. He said the country would have never got subjugated if it had identified “poisonous snakes” that keep inserting poison in the country’s arteries. “These traitors have divided the country on various grounds like caste, language and creed,” he added.

Remarking that the Shaheen Bagh protest was illegal and people sitting there didn’t know why they were sitting there, Yogi said, “Azadi slogans are being raised in Shaheen Bagh. This is the same JNU-wali azadi, Kashmir-wali azadi. Kejriwal is supplying biryani and doing all the work that is against the country. The real intention behind Shaheen Bagh is to prevent India from becoming prosperous and powerful.”

Pakistan yet again featured in the UP CM’s speeches during which he alleged that there was a nexus between the neighbouring country and Kejriwal. “When Article 370 was removed, Kejriwal spoke the same language as Imran Khan. Now that elections are happening, a Pakistani minister is issuing fatwas in Kejriwal support,” he said, pointing towards a tweet by Pakistan minister Fawad Chaudhary.

“Kejriwal does not trust the people of Delhi, that’s why statements are being issued by Pakistan. Is Pakistan our well-wisher? Will Pakistan decide whom we will vote for? Should we do any work that pleases Pakistan? Will Pakistan be happy with the progress of India?” asked Yogi.

Meanwhile, AAP MP Sanjay Singh on Monday met the deputy election commissioner alleging that BJP was trying to vitiate the environment before elections. Yogi’s statements were also submitted to the poll body. “The EC assured us that they will take action,” he said.

Title: ‘Eight UAPA cases under LDF rule taken over by NIA’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has said the police need no permission from the state government to register UAPA cases. It is the Centre which decides on handing over a case to national investigation agency ( NIA ) and the state government has nothing to do with this, he said.

In a reply given to MLA Parakkal Abdulla, in the assembly , the chief minister said that eight UAPA cases registered under the LDF rule have been taken over by NIA. “The Centre has the power to hand over the case to NIA if any offence come under the scheduled offence category of the NIA Act. For this the Centre need not consult the state government,” said the chief minister. The last such case taken over by NIA was against two students Allan Shuhaib and Twaha Fasal who were arrested by the state police in Kozhikode for allegedly distributing pro-Maoist pamphlets. The arrests were made soon after the gunning down of alleged Maoists by the Thunderbolt forces in Attapadi forests. The duo was charged with UAPA.

As per police statistics, 151 cases have been charged under UAPA since 2014. Initially, UAPA sections were slapped in a large number of cases but the government gave sanction to prosecute only a few of them. Investigations into many of the cases could not gather enough evidence to convince the review committee for retaining the UAPA charges against the accused.

Title: Drunk man beats mother to death after fight, held
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Allahabad: A 70-year-old woman was allegedly beaten to death by her son after an argument over dinner in Parsai Subedar village, under Nawabganj police station, in Pratapgarh late Sunday night.

The accused, Malkhan Patel, had fled after beating up his mother and was arrested on Monday afternoon.

Station officer of Nawabganj police station Ashutosh Tripathi said Malkhan was addicted to alcohol. On Sunday night, he got into a fight with his mother Prema Devi over what she had cooked for dinner. As the fight escalated, Malkhan started thrashing is mother.

On Monday morning, local residents found the elderly woman lying on the floor and informed the police. When police reached the spot, they found Prema dead. Malkhan’s sister Renu lodged a case against him.

Police said the accused was later arrested in the afternoon. Police said Prema had several injury marks on her body.

Meanwhile, a woman allegedly consumed a poisonous substance after getting into an argument with her son in Alwara village, under Mahevaghat police station, in Kaushambi district on Monday. The woman, Laxmi Devi, is undergoing treatment at Swaroop Rani Nehru Hospital in Allahabad.

Title: Pravin Togadiya attacks PM Narendra Modi on economic collapse
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Pravin Togadiya in Sant Sammelan at Gurukul , Ahmedabad on Sunday. photo Yogesh Chawda

CHANDRAPUR: Firebrand Hindutva Leader and president of Antarashtriya Hindu Parishad Pravin Togadiya on Monday launched a scathing attack on PM Narendra Modi-led Central government for its failure on economic front. Togadiya was in Chandrapur to take part in a programme.

He claimed country’s economy had collapsed and it was now on oxygen. More than 10 crore youths were unemployed, while additional six crore had lost their jobs. While half of the small scale industries had closed down, dollar had grown strong over rupee, he said.

Exports had come down and NPA of banks risen manifold, Togadiya said charging that PM Modi had not taken any concrete step to deal with these burning problems. He said Modi was not made prime minister to stage Howdy Modi show in the US but to provide employment to youths here. How would employment grow in country by staging Howdy Modi, he asked.

On Hindutva, Togadiya claimed that thanks to awakening among Hindus, it had become difficult for BJP to take their votes. That was the reason BJP lost elections in states like Haryana and Jharkhand, he alleged. On Shaheen Bagh, Togadiya claimed that the agitation had given an issue to BJP in the Delhi election. Muslims at Shaheen Bagh had awakened the Hindus and this was helping BJP gain votes. It looks like Muslims were marketing BJP through Shaheen Bagh, he said.

Speaking on ongoing protest against Citizenship law, he claimed that everybody had a right to state their stand in democracy. Some speak in favour, while others speak in opposition. However there should not be any violence, he emphasized.

Title: Illegal banners: HC orders DGP to act
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The court’s direction came after noticing that local bodies are not able to implement the ban ordered by the c... Read More

Kochi: State police chief should issue a circular within one week directing police officers to take action against illegal flex boards , banners, and flags, the high court has directed.

The order was issued by Justice Devan Ramachandran after hearing arguments on three petitions seeking action against the menace. The court’s direction came after noticing that local bodies are not able to implement the ban ordered by the court due to threats from political parties and influential persons.

Contention of the government that the state police chief does not have the power to issue such a circular was dismissed by the court. Responding to the court’s directive of January 15 that the state police chief need to issue a circular, government had informed the court that the circular was not issued as police does not have any jurisdiction or power to deal with the removal of unauthorized boards, banners, and flags. Such power is vested with the road safety commissioner, under Road Safety Authority Act of 2007, government had argued.

While disagreeing with this argument, the court cited the various legal provisions that makes it the duty of police to act against those who erect illegal flex boards, banners, and flags. The court said in the order, “I am, therefore, firmly of the opinion that… the State Police Chief must issue the circular as ordered therein within a period of one week from the date of receipt of a copy of this order.” When it issued the directive of January 15, the court was under the impression that the state police chief was aware of the statutory obligations on police, the latest order said.

It is without doubt that the provisions in Highway Protection Act, Kerala Police Act, Indian Penal Code, Kerala Municipality Act, and Kerala Panchayat Raj Act vests specific powers on police with regard to protection of streets and public places and to ensure that accidents and mishaps are averted, the court said.

Police have to maintain law and order and prevent danger as per Sections 42 and 120(c) of Police Act, the order said. Section 120(c) includes defacement of public spaces, covering of traffic signs or signboard, thus reducing its visibility or readability. Any board, banner or flag placed on public street, which is tied to a pedestrian handrail or road medians, so as to cause danger, need not only be removed by police but necessary prosecution needs to be launched against the entities or persons who have placed it illegally, the court’s order said.

The IPC provision on mischief (section 425) is wide enough to cover any action intended or causes damage to the public or any other person or property, the court said. If such mischief makes traveling unsafe, it is punishable with imprisonment up to five years as per Section 431, the court added. Sections 283, 290, and 291 of IPC also allow police to fine a person causing damage or injury to any other person in public way or public line of navigation, with subsequent offence punishable with imprisonment up to six months, the court noted.

Provisions in Municipality Act (section 550) and Panchayat Raj Act (section 252) require police officers to communicate commission of any offence under these Acts to the municipality or panchayat officials and to assist the officials in taking action, the order stated.

Title: UDF, LDF lock horns over thanksgiving motion
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Throwing to wind the uncommon camaraderie they exhibited during the initial days in the fight against Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ), UDF and LDF locked horns in the assembly on the first day of discussion, on Monday, over the thanksgiving motion on the governor’s address.

The opposition questioned the integrity of the government in the fight against BJP and Sangh Parivar forces. They cited the government refusal to stand with the demand for calling back the governor as the basis for such an allegation. “We have no personal grudge against the governor. The protest against him is symbolic. Protest against the governor is the protest against the BJP government at the Centre and its policies,” IUML leader KNA Khader said. Vengara MLA also warned the House against simplifying CAA as a minority issue. “This is not something of a concern only to a single section. It’s not a problem faced by Muslims alone. It’s rather a political issue which, if it goes unchecked, would have its pernicious impact on a large section of people in the country,” Khader said.

CPM MLA S Sharma, who presented the thanksgiving motion, termed as “unfortunate” the opposition decision to withdraw from joint protests against CAA. “Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan was the first among country’s chief ministers who spoke boldly against CAA, National Population Registry and National Registry of Citizens. The opposition should rise above parochial views and stand up with the state government for a joint resistance against the Union government’s actions and policies,” he said. CPI leader and Chadayamangalam MLA Mullakkara Ratnakaran, supporting the motion presented by Sharma, said the country was passing through an unusual state of affairs and only unusual comradeship among the secular forces could yank the country out from the danger it’s slipping into.

“We should not miss the point. Our target is not the governor, who stands affront with a piston without balls. Our target is the Modi-Shah duo who have taken a stance with a ready-to-fire Patton tank, behind foot soldiers,” Mullakkara said.

Poonjar MLA P C George, however, asked the LDF and UDF to put an end to the practice of organizing anti-CAA meetings across the state.

The discussion on thanksgiving motion over the governor’s address would continue on Tuesday.

Title: Minority panel examines probe officers
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thrissur: The state government-appointed P K Haneefa judicial commission probing the rape and death case of two sisters in Walayar, on Monday, examined the first two investigating officers of the case.

The commission recorded the statements of Walayar SI P C Chacko, who was the first investigating officer in the case. The panel also recorded CI Premanandakrishnan’s statement. The next sitting of the commission will be held on February 6.

On November 21, 2019, the state government had appointed retired judge P K Haneefa as judicical commission to probe the death case. The minor dalit sisters were found hanging in their house in Walayar in 2017. The commission will submit its report within three months. tnn

Title: PWD joins hands with IIT-R for Nainital Mall Road
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nainital: More than a year after the 20-m stretch of Nainital Mall Road collapsed in Naini Lake, the Public Works Department ( PWD ) has finally been asked to collaborate with the IIT Roorkee to come up with a solution.

On Monday, a team of district administration officials, PWD and the Nainital civic body inspected the road after which the PWD was asked to collaborate with IIT Roorkee, said a PWD official.

A press release by DM Savin Bansal said that PWD will submit a work plan of the project and further decision will be taken after that.

As reported by TOI earlier, the Mall Road had collapsed in August 2018, and the administration had put up some pillars and sandbags to prevent further damage and built a road over it as a temporary measure.

However, even after over a year, the retention wall on the stretch has not been built. Residents said that there is a constant fear that the road may collapse again.

Title: Builders still await clarity on September 20 circular
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PUNE: Many developers already in receipt of occupancy certificate are finding it difficult to register their properties in the state for the past five months for want of MahaRERA registration, in contravention of the provisions of the Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Act, 2016.

As per the rules, projects with occupancy certificates (OC) are not required to register with Real Estate Regulatory Authority (RERA). But, a revenue department circular of September 20, 2019, insists on registration of such projects with RERA before registering them with sub-registrar offices in the state.

Against this backdrop, the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) has demanded the withdrawal of the revenue department’s circular to check confusion. “When the RERA rules state that any project having completion/occupation certificate before the registration of sale deed is exempted from RERA registration, the revenue department circular is uncalled for as it only creates more confusion,” state Credai president Rajiv Parikh said.

He said the developers’ body had held numerous meeting with the ministers and government officials for the last five months, requesting them to withdraw the circular. “We will meet revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat next week, seeking the withdrawal of the circular for the benefit of developers and citizens at large. Due to this confusing circular, developers across the state are severely affected,” he said, adding that the body had raised the issue with NCP chief Sharad Pawar too.

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat said he was expecting the details within a fortnight. “I have directed them and hopefully they will revert,’’ he said.

RERA & revenue department not on same page

Basically, the entire confusion and chaos boils down to two bodies — the RERA and the revenue department. While RERA officials have clarified that projects in receipt of OC do not require RERA registration, the revenue department officials insist on RERA registration, citing the last year circular of the erstwhile state government. “Unless the circular is withdrawn, our hands are tied,” a senior official of the registration department said.

As the real estate sector is still facing challenges, the prevailing confusion is counter-productive. “We went twice to the registration department with the builder for registration of our project, but had to return empty-handed,” a homebuyer said, whose project is in receipt of OC.

To iron out issues

A senior revenue department official said there were some technical issues that needed to be ironed out. “A joint meeting was held recently and the revenue minister has directed (all those concerned) to resolve the issue at the earliest,” he said.

If a builder or developer has readied the project with his/her own funds and is in receipt of the OC, does s/he still need to register under RERA? When asked about it, he said “We have sought clarification for on this too from the housing department, which will further send it to RERA.”

Title: Fed-up with route restrictions & harassment, man burns his e-rickshaw
Content: Dehradun: Alleging harassment from police and district administration officials, an e-rickshaw owner set his vehicle on fire at Dharna Sthal near Parade Ground on Monday.The man, Amir Ahmed, claimed that while the administration has banned e-rickshaw on all major routes, the cops harass drivers both mentally and financially even when they pick passengers from interior areas.“I bought this e-rickshaw on loan three years ago and five of my bank installments are still pending. Despite the fact that my vehicle’s registration is legal, I am not allowed to ply on major routes. The police harass us both mentally and financially even when we take passengers from interior lanes,” alleged Ahmed.Maroof Raza, president of e-rickshaw union of Dehradun , claimed that the decision to ban e-rickshaws from major routes has been taken to favour the auto drivers. “Banning e-rickshaws from major city roads, that too during peak working hours, will hurt our livelihood,” he added.In August last year, the city police along with the RTO had banned e-rickshaws from eight prominent city roads from 8 am to 8 pm in order to streamline traffic movement. The ban came because officials claimed they had received several complaints of rash driving, overcrowding, and over-charging from passengers.The restriction was criticised not only by e-rickshaw owners but also by opposition leaders and environmentalists who maintained that these are cheap and environment-friendly public transport.Meanwhile ARTO (enforcement) Arvind Pandey denied the allegations made by the e-rickshaw operators. “Except for eight routes, they are allowed to ply on all other stretches. Claims that e-rickshaw drivers are not being able to earn are baseless,” he added.

Title: 4 booked for objectionable comments on social media
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Residents protest against the CAA in Roshan Bagh on Monday

Allahabad: Four FIRs were registered against four persons from two communities for allegedly posting objectionable comments about religion and deities on social media, between January 31 and February 3, in Allahabad. The four have been charged under section 153 A (attacking religion, language etc of any particular group\community) and 295 A (deliberate and malicious acts intended to outrage religious feelings) of the Indian Penal Code and section 66 of Information Technology (IT) Act.

SSP (Allahabad) Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “Police said with protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act already underway at New Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh and Allahabad’s Roshan Bagh, such posts could act as a trigger for untoward incidents. The cybercell is maintaining a close watch on photographs, posts and messages posted on social media. A 10-member team under the supervision of SP (crime) is using different software for monitoring developments.”

Police said the crime branch and cybercell have stepped up vigil and are monitoring social networking websites which might spark trouble.

The agitation against the new citizenship law at places like Shaheen Bagh, Roshan Bagh and at Lucknow’s Clock Tower have been garnering attention from across the country. Hundreds of women have managed to brave cold and police action to stand their ground at the protests.

“Police have already registered four FIRs with different police stations including Colonelganj under sections 153A and 295 of the IPC and section 66 of IT Act in the past four days,” he added.

“We would be looking for tangible information about the posts and updates made on social media through our informants. A strict warning has been issued to social media users asking them to refrain from posting objectionable comments,” the SSP said.

Title: CSIR-NCL laboratory develops inexpensive silver nanowires
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PUNE: Have you ever looked at your cellphone touchscreen and wondered how signals are transmitted by mere touch? A layer of indium tin oxide or silver nanowires underneath the touchscreen does the trick through electrical conduction.

Till now, India had almost zero footprint in the printed and flexible electronics but not anymore. The CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory has developed a technology for manufacturing precision silver nanowires at 1/12th of the cost it is currently available in the market.

Speaking about the technology, Shekhar Mande, director general, CSIR, who inaugurated the pilot plant for continuous flow manufacture of silver nanowires on CSIR-NCL campus on Friday, said, “With the help of this technology developed by a team led by senior scientist Amol A Kulkarni (from the chemical engineering and process development division), Indian industries will be able to manufacture electronic chemicals.”

The price of the silver nanowires of different sizes (20 nm to 100 nm diameter) varies from 250USD to 600USD per gram, while the ones manufactured by NCL costs $8 per gram.

“This technology development was carried out under the Advanced Manufacturing Technologies (AMT) initiative by the Department of Science and Technology (DST). We have been working on this for the past three years. The applications of this technology are huge -- from touch screen, conducting inks, thermal coatings, IR shielding sector (defence) etc,” said Kulkarni.

Stating that India was not doing well when it came to electronic chemicals, Kulkarni spoke about the need to enter the tightly controlled market. “There are a few companies which dominate the electronic chemicals market. For example, it is difficult for outsiders to penetrate the touch screen manufacturing business. We are trying to start from the basics and hope that the quality of our product, efficiency of the process along with a super attractive process economics will help our industries make headway in this field,” said Kulkarni.

Title: BPCL launches e-Drive initiative in Kochi
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

BPCL team with the e-autorickshaw in Kochi on Monday

KOCHI: Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd ( BPCL ), a Maharatna public sector company in the oil and gas sector, announced its entry into the electric vehicle (EV) space on Monday with the launch of its ‘ e-Drive ’ initiative in the city. ‘e-Drive’ is an innovative electric vehicle mobility model based on battery swapping, initially being rolled out in Kochi and Lucknow for the first time in the country.

In the model, launched in collaboration with IIT Madras for technological support and Kinetic Green as a mobility partner, around 20 taxi e-rickshaws, owned by Kinetic Green, will be deployed here. Drivers from the society formed by the drivers of Kochi Metro e-rickshaws will be driving these autorickshaws. BPCL, with support from IIT Madras, will provide smart lithium-ion batteries.

Drivers can approach the nearest BPCL retail outlets for exchanging their EVs’ discharged batteries with charged batteries. This helps drivers who are facing difficulties owing to the upfront cost of electric vehicles , vehicle’s range limitations and the time spent on charging of the vehicles. BPCL swapping stations are situated at its outlets at Edappally, Palarivattom and Kadavanthra and each battery has a mileage of 60km. More stations will be launched in future.

This model provides multifaceted benefits — the driver does not have to invest in buying a vehicle; inexpensive, clean and hassle free mode of transport is provided for the first and last mile connectivity to riders; and through battery swapping, the waiting time for vehicles to recharge is eliminated.

The project was launched by BPCL chairman and managing director D Rajkumar from Chennai through videoconference. Launching the initiative, Rajkumar said: “Electric vehicles would be having an increased share of the urban transportation canvass in the years to come. With in-depth studies on the challenges, and further taking cognizance of available technology, demand, government regulations and the overall direction of energy transition, BPCL has embarked upon a new and unique model for EV mobility, the first of its kind in the country, ahead of competition.”

Title: Maratha Light Infantry to observe 350th anniversary of Sinhagad battle
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The Tanhaji Malusare memorial at Sinhagad fort in Pune

PUNE: The Army’s Maratha Light Infantry (MLI) regiment will commemorate the 350th anniversary of the ‘Battle of Sinhagad’ through various programmes at their battalions across the country on Tuesday.

The battle was significant for the Maratha empire, which recaptured the then Kondana fort on February 4, 1670. Colonel Commandant Lt Gen PJS Pannu (retired) started celebrating the day as a ‘regimental day’ of the MLI from 2016.

Tanhaji Malusare, the military assistant of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj , fought like a mighty warrior and made supreme sacrifice in the battle. “The regiment adopted Sinhgarh the regimental marching tune dedicated to the gallant Maratha warriors who recaptured Kondana. With the regimental motto being duty, honour, courage -- the three tenets displayed in the battle by Tanhaji -- it stands as a testimony to the unparalleled courage and loyalty, which the MLI proudly upholds till date,” Pannu told TOI on Monday over the phone from New Delhi.

“The proud legacy of the Maratha empire is at the core of the MLI today,” Pannu added.

The commemorative programmes are being held under the current Colonel of the regiment Lt Gen Asit Mistri.

The fort was under the administration of then Mughal emperor Mirza Raja Jai Singh who appointed his relative Udaybhan Rathod as a fort keeper. “Rathod had placed a canon (artillery gun) on each turret of the fort. However, one turret was left unguarded as it was on the top of a steep cliff. Tanhaji and his brother Suryaji received intelligence inputs about the ‘chink’’ in the opponent’s armour. Besides, they were aware of a party, organised by the Mughal’s troops, on the night of the battle. They struck at night when the Mughal army was busy at the party and caught them off guard,” said history scholar Pandurang Balkawade .

“With the help of a monitor lizard (ghorpad), over 300 Maratha troops climbed the most treacherous cliff and reached the fort. The sudden attack caught Mughals unawares and before they could inflict a counter attack, the Marathas killed a sizeable number of them. Meanwhile, a fierce fight took place between Tanhaji and Rathod in which the former’s shield got damaged and he was seriously injured. Though this had an adverse impact on the Maratha soldiers’ morale, his brother, Suryaji, boosted their confidence and won the battle,” Balkawade said. Thereafter, they could successfully recapture the remaining 22 forts.

Sheetal Malusare, whose husband Shivraj is the 12th direct descendent of Tanhaji, said, “There was very little awareness about the battle among the people in the past. But after the Bollywood movie, Tanhaji, many have come to know about his bravery, dedication and contribution to the Maratha empire.”

The renovation work of Tanaji’s memorial at his native village Umrat in Poladpur tehsil of Raigad is in the final stages and it will be inaugurated on February 17, said Sheetal, who completed a PhD on Tanhaji in 2017 from Karnataka University.

Title: Friendly bugs to help coconut farmers fight whitefly scourge
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

COIMBATORE: The Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) is planning to use two beneficial insects to tackle rugose whitefly (Aleurodicus rugioperculatus), an invasive alien insect ravaging coconut plantations across the state.

The university plans to multiply Chrysoperla and Encarsia that will act as parasitoids (insects that eat other insects) and supply them to coconut farmers.

Director of the Centre of Plant Protection Studies at TNAU K Prabakar said the university has facilities in Coimbatore and Aliyar to multiply the parasitoids, but not enough to cover the whole state. “So, we have proposed a Rs 50 lakh-project to the Coconut Development Board to multiply the parasitoids and distribute them to farmers. We also plan to tie up with the agriculture department to train personnel for parasitoid breeding stations in all districts,” he said.

Rugose whitefly, an invasive pest from Florida, was first detected in the state in 2016. “It was first seen in Pollachi and then spread to other states,” Prabakar said. “The pest has also been reported in Kerala, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh , among other states. It has affected 15% of the 4.4 lakh hectares of coconut plantations in the state, affecting yield.”

TNAU had come up with an integrated pest management method to control whitefly. It includes placing sticky yellow polythene sheets that attract the insects and act as traps, placing light traps, releasing parasitoids as a biological control method, spraying water on the leaves to wash the pest away, and, if the attack is heavy, spraying neem oil on the affected leaves. Of these, thrust is on the parasitoids.

The presence of the pest also brings in sooty mold, which turn the leaves black, said Prabakar. “On seeing this, farmers spray pesticides, killing the parasitoids.”

Coconut farmers should grow yellow flowers that have nectar to attract parasitoids. “An increase in parasitoid population will be beneficial,” Prabakar added.

As many as 300 coconut farmers from Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh attended a workshop on whitefly control at TNAU on Monday.

Title: Rare gun found on AU campus to now grace city museum
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Allahabad: A rare 17th century single-barrel gun found in a cellar on Allahabad University campus around 15 years back would now have a pride of place in Allahabad Museum.

The Mughal era gun was found in a cellar, located beneath the stairs of AU ’s medieval and modern history department by a peon. The peon, Syyed Ali, also found two iron fireballs along with the gun. University officials handed over the antique firearms to the museum on Monday.

Ali had been taking care of the antiques ever since he chanced upon them.

The gun is around five feet in length and weighs around 20kg and its barrel is around two inches in diameter. Due to wear and tear over time, some parts of the gun like the barrel and the iron click are now covered with rust.

“The gun is from somewhere around the 17th century. The iron fireballs were portable and were used for attacking objects nearby,” said Allahabad Museum’s deputy curator OA Wankhade. Wankhede said said that the gun could help the museum officials know more about the artillery from the medieval period. “We have enough information about big cannons, small pistols and guns used, but this gun is the missing link between the two. It could tell us a lot about how heavy fixed artillery paved way for more portable firearms.”

Talking about the two iron balls, he said, “The iron balls are a rarer find than the gun because these were used to store gunpowder. The heavy and thick walls of the iron balls would protect the gunpowder from exploding if it fell on the ground accidentally,” he added.

.“The antique gun is a priceless antique and will now be kept on display in the museum for visitors,” said head of AU’s medieval and modern history department Yogeshwar Tewari

Title: Plea seeks CBI probe into CTS corruption case
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: Even as Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTS) and Larsen & Toubro (L&T) are battling charges of bribing Tamil Nadu government officials including the CMDA (Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority) in a court in the US, a lawyer has moved the Madras high court to order CBI to probe into the allegations.

M L Ravi has in his plea alleged that Cognizant had paid a bribe of Rs 23 crore to state government authorities, including CMDA officials, to obtain planning, environment and other permissions for its KITS Campus in Chennai. The petitioner submitted that he had made a detailed complaint to the DVAC and CBI to register a case and probe the allegations under the Prevention of Corruption Act. Since the agencies have failed to act on his complaint, he has approached the high court.

Admitting the plea, a division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha directed the centre and state governments to file their responses by March 9.

When the plea came up for hearing, the bench referred to the complaint lodged by the Security Exchange Commission of the United States of America with the United States district court, district of New Jersey, and an order passed by the commission dated February 15, 2019. The bench said, “It is to be noted at this juncture that the proceedings of the security commission is available in the public domain and therefore, it may not be necessary to lodge any specific complaint and that it is also open to the CBI and the DVAC to initiate appropriate inquiry.”

According to the petitioner, CTS has entered into a contract with Larsen & Toubro (L&T) for construction and operation of its KITS campus, encompassing 2.7 million square feet in Chennai.

Title: Opposition plays on voters’ woes, outgoing MLA cites central hurdles
Content:
Harsh Vardhan

NEW DELHI : For long a BJP bastion represented by Harsh Vardhan from 1993 to 2013, the Krishna Nagar constituency chose Aam Aadmi Party’s A K Bagga over BJP’s chief ministerial candidate Kiran Bedi in 2015. Bagga was certainly the giant killer of those elections and it will be interesting to see if he can reprise that triumph this year.It will be a tougher fight because the veteran Ashok Kumar Walia is in the fray on behalf of Congress. The doctor is a four-time winner from the region, thrice from Geeta Colony and once from Laxmi Nagar . BJP has also nominated a medical man, Anil Goyal, who runs the Goyal Urology Centre at Vijay Chowk in Krishna Nagar. He is well known in east Delhi for the medical camps he organises. A few cavilled about his candidature since he lives in Hargovind Enclave and not Krishna Nagar, and Goyal responded, “I work with Krishna Nagar residents every day. Only politically motivated people can make an issue of my residence.”While residents define all three candidates as accessible, they aren’t too happy about the pace of development in the area. Bansi Lal, member of the market association at Lal Quarter, said, “Kiran Bedi was an outsider against insider Bagga in 2015. We voted for the insider and expected him to work with zeal in resolving our core problems, but this did happen. For two-and-a-half years, we have been requesting the MLA in vain to look into the water logging at Ghondli Chowk. And for a year, the water supplied by Delhi Jal Board hasn’t been satisfactory.”Bagga, for his part, said, “We lived up to people’s expectation despite the hurdles created by the central government and the lieutenant governor. We got a lot of roads constructed, installed 1,000 CCTV cameras and provided free WiFi in Geeta Colony area.” He admitted that water quality was indeed poor, but claimed the problem was leakage from ageing, eroded sewage linesMany others commended AAP for concentrating on other parts of constituency rather than just Krishna Nagar. “Construction of a road from Jheel to Shamshan Ghat, which was pending for a long time, was completed in Bagga’s tenure,” said S C Gupta, a resident of Geeta Colony. “Roads were also made in Geeta Colony and, unlike other parties, AAP is more particular about addressing residents’ issues.”Goyal hotly contested this. “The roads remain pathetic, while sewage is being pumped into storm-water drains,” he alleged. “AAP’s so-called mohalla clinics have no ECG machines or testing facility for diabetes and other conditions. The MLA must have got Rs 100 crore as area development fund, but spent nothing in five years.”When TOI visited the constituency last week, road construction was under way in Jheel Chowk, Krishna Nagar, Geeta Colony and some other places. Near the damaged Jheel Chowk Road opposite Chand Mohalla, Naresh Kumar complained, “Around 15 days ago, the road was dug up to be repaired. Since then it has been in this state.”Encroachment on the main roads of Rashid Market, Khureji Khas and Jagat Puri is increasing day by day. “Though this is not a problem that can be solved by the MLA, the pace of commercialisation and encroachment is increasing here,” noted local resident Ejaz Ahmed. “I think all elected representatives need to intervene on this.”Walia, hoping to put Congress once again on the winning path, said, “I worked closely in half of Krishna Nagar constituency when I was MLA for 15 years before delimitation in 2008. Congress constructed the Chacha Nehru Bal Chikitsalaya and the road over the drain and the flyover at Geeta Colony that not only decongested the area but also connected it with rest of the city. But after the Congress government, hardly any road has been constructed here.” A little testily, he said there was a difference between ‘development’ and ‘makeshift arrangements’, and what AAP has done was makeshift work.The locals also said that the tussle between the East Delhi Municipal Corporation and the AAP government over funding adversely affected the sanitation in east Delhi areas. “We saw several strikes by sanitation workers in the past five years. Garbage was not cleared for 4-7 days,” said B S Vohra, president, Federation of East Delhi RWAs. “Despite paying property tax, we were forced to live in unhygienic conditions simply because there is no consensus between two different political parties heading the state government and the municipalities.”Obviously there are a lot of disgruntled voters and many issues that affect them in daily life. Vohra sounded a warning, “I think people should consider these factors before casting their votes.”

Title: Kochi Metro sees steep hike in ridership
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

KOCHI: The ridership data of Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) shows a steep increase in the number of riders from last year. The ridership doubled in the last five months of 2019 compared to that of 2018. During December, the ridership touched an all-time high of 21,08,108 while it was only 12,48,874 during December 2018 — an increase of nearly 69%. The trend continued in January 2020 with 20,74,430 travellers using the Metro.

Since the opening of Thykoodam stretch, there is a steady increase in ridership, said a statement from KMRL. “We are witnessing heavy rush during peak hours. To cater to the needs of commuters, we have reduced the headway to six minutes during peak hours. The trend suggests that people are happy to use the Metro for their regular commute and the growth actually accelerated in the past year,” said KMRL managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma.

“Kochi Metro is also working to increase the last mile connectivity for its passengers. Discussions with educational institutions along the Metro corridor, Infopark and corporates to provide last mile connectivity are in final stages,” he added.

KMRL had recently inked an agreement with Kerala State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) for plying electric buses as part of its feeder service to Cochin International Airport Ltd (Cial). Electric buses with a seating capacity of 32 will ply between Aluva Metro station and Cial.

KMRL is also encouraging group booking if there are more than seven passengers in the group, the statement said. The agency has also introduced minor cards to encourage schoolchildren above the age of 10 years to use the facility for daily commuting. Metro has also seen an increase in the total number of people who are using Kochi1 Card. There are 73,000 active Kochi 1 Card users and they form a healthy 29% of total ridership.

Title: Kanpur: Over 9,000 kids to be vaccinated under Mission Indradhanush programme
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: As many as 9,845 children and 1,634 pregnant women will be immunized in the third leg of the Intensive Mission Indradhanush programme which began on Monday. The programme will cover three blocks of the city and also those children who have been left from vaccination. The programme commenced by administering vitamin A drops to a child at the primary health centre at Kidwai Nagar.

District Immunization officer Dr AK Kanaujia said that around 23 children and 2 pregnant women were immunized at the Kidwai Nagar centre. There was a target to immunize 9,845 children and 1,634 pregnant women. In all, 1,643 sessions would be held to cover all children and women.

Dr GK Mishra, district TB Officer, directed the health employees to ensure 100 per cent vaccination and get vaccinated from various diseases all children up to the age of 2 years and pregnant women.

District health officer Dr Shailendra Mishra has appealed to all parents to get their children vaccinated. The Government of India has increased the coverage area of vaccination up to 90 per cent, he said. Dr Aparna Singh (WHO), Devkant Sharma (Unicef) and a representative of UNDP were present in the programme.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Chinese students at Savitribai Phule Pune University cancel holidays
Content:
Savitribai Phule Pune University

PUNE: The students from China enrolled in the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) and its affiliated colleges have cancelled their annual holidays to celebrate the Chinese New Year back home in the wake of the novel coronavirus outbreak There are nearly 10 Chinese students in the city, enrolled in departments including botany, commerce, hotel managements, among others.The students said the Chinese New Year started on January 25 and around this time they would travel to their hometowns to celebrate with family and friends. However, this time they decided to stay back because of the novel coronavirus outbreak in China.Hang Zhou, a student of the SPPU’s botany department pursuing his master’s degree, said, “We have been in touch with our near and dear ones over the phone and have been taking updates regarding the situation. Our new year is definitely not quiet like this. People go out on a holiday and enjoy the celebrations. Some of my friends studying here have also decided to stay back.”Another student Zhou Chong from the SPPU’s economics department said, “The fear of the virus spreading has kept many away from visiting their hometown. I did not plan to go back anyway as I did not get many leaves because of the assignments. I am in touch with my folks and taking updates of their health.”The International Students Centre at SPPU has 10 Chinese students in various departments of the university and they all have stayed back.Satyendra Upadhyay, who formed a group of Indian teachers in Maharashtra for the Chinese language, said there were over 50 students from China who where studying in different universities and colleges in the state. He said, “It’s not just the students who are studying here. But, those in China have also cancelled their trips to Mumbai. An Indo-Chinese conference was scheduled in February and many delegates informed of their unavailability because of the outbreak.”Yogesh Kale of Pune had taken admission in the Tianjin University of Finance and Economics in Tianjin, China. He came back to Pune in mid-January, “After appearing for the first semester, I cancelled my admissions as I had to come back because of some personal reasons. When I came the situation was fine. There was little news of the virus. At the airport, the authorities were conducting health screenings. But, I thought it was routine. When I reached Pune, the news about the outbreak came in and that’s when the situation became more serious.”Vidya Yeravdekar, principal director of Symbiosis Society, said there were no students in the university from China.

Garbage was not cleared for 4-7 days,” said B S Vohra, president, Federation of East Delhi RWAs. “Despite paying property tax, we were forced to live in unhygienic conditions simply because there is no consensus between two different political parties heading the state government and the municipalities.”Obviously there are a lot of disgruntled voters and many issues that affect them in daily life. Vohra sounded a warning, “I think people should consider these factors before casting their votes.”

Title: Arrest CM if he is indeed a terrorist, Sanjay Singh dares BJP
Content:
Sanjay Singh

NEW DELH i: Slamming BJP for repeatedly calling chief minister Arvind Kejriwal a “terrorist”, senior AAP functionary and Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh on Monday challenged the party to arrest the CM and put him behind bars if he was indeed a terrorist Talking to reporters, Singh said BJP was distraught because of the prospect of certain defeat in the assembly and the party’s functionaries were making objectionable statements in desperation.“First, a BJP MP called Arvind Kejriwal a terrorist, then the Haryana CM called him a monkey. UP CM Yogi Adityanath then made fun of his health. Today, Union minister Prakash Javadekar again referred to Kejriwal as a terrorist,” Singh said, adding that such statements should attract strict penal action and an FIR should be filed against them.Singh said, “It’s unbelievable that such remarks are being made while Parliament is in session. Despite there being an entire constitutional set-up in place and an Election Commission, how can a Union minister be allowed to make such a statement?”“And if Arvind Kejriwal indeed is a terrorist, I challenge BJP to put him behind the bars. They have crossed all limits of decency,” the AAP MP added.Earlier, while addressing the press, Javadekar had said, “Kejriwal is making an innocent face and asking if he is a terrorist. You are a terrorist, there is plenty of proof for it. You yourself said you are an anarchist. There is not much of a difference between an anarchist and a terrorist.”The AAP parliamentarian also slammed BJP MP Ananth Hegde for calling Mahatma Gandhi’s struggle for Independence a “drama”. He said an AAP delegation will meet the Chief Election Commissioner and submit a complaint against Yogi and other BJP functionaries for giving provocative speeches. He said that AAP will demand a ban on campaigning, lodging of FIR and arrest of those giving such speeches.“We have seen continuous incidents of firing. A tamancha (gun) culture is being promoted. People of Delhi are watching very carefully. They are worried about what the capital is being turned into. Efforts are being made to cause a distraction from the real issues of electricity, water, education and health. The more we dwell on these issues, the more they will try to fan communal sentiments and spread hatred,” said Singh.In the last phase of campaigning, all frontal organisations of AAP will hold 15,000 meetings across the 70 assembly constituencies over the next three days. “No matter how much they provoke, we will remain focused on real issues. We will release our manifesto tomorrow. Over 500 representatives of our frontal cells, which pertain to Poorvanchalis, women, youths, SC/ST communities and minorities, will hold 10 meetings each daily over the next three days in all nooks and corners of the city,” Singh said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: ‘Isolate & test every Wuhan traveller’
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Citizens with a travel history to Wuhan in China will be mandatorily isolated and tested for the novel coronavirus infection in Maharashtra even if they do not show any signs of the illness, state health department’s new guideline stated on Monday.Earlier, only travellers with flu-like symptoms were quarantined and their throat swab samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for testing.“Only those travellers who had been to Wuhan, which is the epicentre of novel coronavirus outbreak in China, will be isolated and tested for the contagion even if they do not complain of any illness. The travellers who had been to other parts of China, excluding Wuhan, will only be quarantined and tested when they develop any illness,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.Besides, China-returned people will be followed up to 14 days now to see if they develop any illness. “Earlier, travellers with a travel history to China were kept under observation for 28 days as there were doubts about the exact incubation period of the virus. Now, data suggest that a person after being exposed to the virus may develop illness within 14 days,” Awate said.

Title: For young parents, it’s a double search for school, home
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: It’s the time of the year where parents of three-year-olds are busy hunting for the best primary school . This year, they are also looking for the right house, finding which is becoming a struggle.

“School authorities have firmly told us children living near the campus will be preferred,” said T Sathya, a software professional who resides in KK Nagar. She has applied to a popular school in Adyar, but the need to find a home closer to the school is giving her sleepless nights. “It has been four months now. Either the rent is too high or the amenities are inadequate. I have promised the school to move nearby soon. Let’s see.”

As the admission season draws to a close, parents are getting increasingly anxious, withy most schools insisting that children live within a 3 km radius. “It’s mainly for safety and children get tired travelling long distance,” said S Raja, principal of Hindu Primary school.

The expectation of new-age parents is also high. “They do not want their children to carry any book, they want no homework at all,” said L Hemalatha, a teacher at Indus International Primary School, Neelankarai.

Most parents want their children to study in schools that are centrally air-conditioned. “We were also asked to install air-conditioners in school buses, so children don’t sweat or get tired,” said C Bharati Lakshmi, principal of Vael's Vidyashram.

They look for fewer children in classrooms, so their child gets individual attention. Parents want playgrounds, a variety of extracurricular activities and also foreign faculty. “It is good to have diverse cultures in the teaching faculty because they provide innovative and creative methods. And children gain more exposure,” said Suresh Karat, who moved from Ambattur to Thiruvanmiyur because he found a school that had all the facilities he looking for. He now travels 22 km to his workplace. “We got the admission by sheer luck, and distance was the only issue, so we moved. I want my son to have the most comfortable and luxurious learning experience.”

“We hear this a lot. Parents today want luxury, convenience, no homewor or hard work for their children, because most are travelling. They want the schools to take all the responsibilities of raising their children,” said Bharati Lakshmi, from an educational institution.

“The education scene today is changing. There are many schools providing easy, convenient education, making our children all rounders. They match our expectations. We see no reason to settle for anything less,” said Yamini Muthu, another parent.

Title: Compensatory planting scheme nearing completion
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state’s largest ‘ compensatory planting scheme’ is getting completed on the premises of the Sainik School in Kazhakkoottam. The social forestry department will hand over the forest to the school in May, said chief conservator of forests P K Kesavan here on Monday.

The saplings that were planted as a compensation for 4,500 trees, which were axed for the widening of Kazhakoottam-Mukkola national highway stretch in 2016, have grown up, turning the area into a forest.

Kesavan and other senior forest officials visited the site on Friday. Forest officials said that it was the largest compensatory planting project in the state. The forest has rare varieties of fruit trees, medicinal plants, etc. Around 38 varieties of trees and plants are growing up in this area.

The trees include Lakshmitaru, Kambakam, mango tree, neem, tamarind, Malabar tamarind, red sandalwood, cassia fistula, mahogany etc.

As per the agreement for compensatory planting, NHAI had given around Rs 1 crore to the forest department. Ten saplings were planted as compensation for every tree felled. Forest officials said that initiative has also helped in replacing acacia trees in the area.

The forest department had divided the area into three segments and made large pits to plant saplings. Saplings suited for the local weather were selected. “Once we hand it over to the Sainik School, responsibility of the maintenance will be with them,” said Kesavan.

Another compensatory planting scheme in connection with Vizhinjam port works is getting ready in 35 acres in the same campus. As many as 15,540 trees were axed for the works of Vizhinjam port. Already 1,250 saplings were planted in 12 acres in 2018.

Title: Cybercrimes in Kerala drop by 3.8%
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The focus of police towards new-age crimes have started yielding results. Crime rates in state, in 2019, witnessed a 3.8% dip compared to the previous year, according to data registered under the Information Technology Act.

While 2018 had witnessed 51% more cases compared to 2017 under the I-T Act, the figures of 2019 were much lesser. The number of cases registered under the I-T Act in 2017 was 290. It had increased to 439 in 2018, but dropped to 422 in 2019. “The state police had observed 2019 as the year of cyber security and also had strongly implemented its policy of zero tolerance towards child pornography and crimes against children. Several awareness campaigns and preventive measures were undertaken in this regard. All these seemed to have had its impact,” ADGP (administration) Manoj Abraham, who is also the nodal officer of Cyberdome said.

The drop in the cases were more visible in cities. Number of cases in Thiruvananthapuram city dropped by 14, Kochi city by nine and Kozhikode city by six. Districts also followed a similar trend. Number of cases in Idukki dropped by 10 and Kannur by six. However, some places like Thrissur city and Palakkad showed a reverse trend where cases increased by 16 and 13, respectively.

Cybercrime cases in the state fall under three major categories — banking frauds, child pornography and cyber harassment (against women). With these three areas in focus, police, last year had launched several initiatives like ‘stop bank frauds’, ‘kids glove’ (creating awareness among teachers, parents and children about cybercrimes) an ‘P Hunt’ (crackdown on child pornography). Cybercells were strengthened and a team to act against child sexual exploitation was constituted. More than 70 officers were deputed to investigate cases related to child sex abuse on online platforms. As many as 210 searches were conducted against paedophilia and child pornography and several devices including laptops, hard disks, pen drives and similar devices with such abusive materials were confiscated. Police had also registered 38 cases and arrested 42 people in this regard last year.

Title: Tamil Nadu government allots Rs 38 crore to form eco clubs in 37,000 schools
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Eco clubs are aimed at creating awareness on various social and environmental issues, including bio-diversity,... Read More

CHENNAI: State school education department has sanctioned Rs 38 crore for constituting ‘Eco and Youth’ clubs in 37,000 government schools. This includes 327 schools in Chennai. These clubs are aimed at creating awareness on various social and environmental issues, including bio-diversity, climate and local ecology, nutrition, health and hygiene.

In elementary and middle schools, the club will have five members and higher standards will have 15-member clubs.

Principals or vice-principals will head the clubs and interested teachers will be chosen by the school headmaster to coordinate activities on a rotational basis. These teachers, in turn, will select students to be members of the clubs.

The clubs have been authorised to use idle school resources like auditorium, libraries and art rooms for activities after regular working hours and on holidays. All the clubs will have three wings — literary, awareness, arts & culture. Those in the literary wing will conduct activities such as essay writing, elocution and poetry competitions on environmental issues for students in their respective schools. The second wing has been given the responsibility of conducting awareness campaigns on special days such as ‘Earth Day’ and ‘ World Environment Day ’, cleaning and maintaining parks, playgrounds in their vicinity. The art and culture wing will organise tree plantation drives, help set up drip irrigation systems, reverse osmosis (RO) and rain water harvesting projects in the school premises.

Money spent towards this will be monitored by Parents Teacher Associations or the School Management Committee and later uploaded to the government portal for scrutiny.

Experts, parents and retired government school teachers and staff can be roped in to guide students, said the order released in connection with this on January 30.

Title: Board exam for Class V, VIII: No need for panic, says education department
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: In view of strong opposition to Class V and VIII board exams in the state, commissioner for school education Sigy Thomas Vaidhyan on Monday said the board exams are being conducted for “uniform and fair assessment of learning outcomes of students.” Asking parents and students not to panic, she said the results would help the department impart additional training to teachers.

“As per the government order, students will not be detained for the first three years based on the exam results,” she said in a release.

The Directorate of Government Examinations (DGE) will prepare common question papers for 60 marks for schools across the state to improve the quality of question papers and for fair assessment, while the remaining 40 marks will be from formative assessments at the school level.

“Evaluation will be done at Cluster Resource Centres (CRC) level in districts,” the commissioner said. The answers sheets would be evaluated in different schools within the CRCs.

Citing board exams would create stress for young students, educationists, teachers and political parties have been opposing the move to conduct board exams for Classes V and VIII.

Title: Cops seize Rs 1 crore unaccounted cash
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vizianagaram: The Salur police on Monday seized over Rs 1.1 crore in cash (said to be unaccounted cash and black money ) and some bank cheques and demand drafts worth Rs 1.67 crore from two persons at a vehicle checkpoint in Saluru Town in Vizianagaram district

Sumit Garud, additional superintendent of police of Parvathipuarm said that Salur police led by inspector S Simhadri Naiduintercepted a car coming from Jeypore in Odisha, for a routine vehicular check. During the check they found two bags in the car containing Rs 1.1 crore in cash. The passengers—Rachakonda Varahala Rao (82) and Meena Rao (63), both native of Jeypore and residents of Delhi—failed to produce any valid documents to claim the money and could not disclose the source of their money.

The police seized the cash citing it was unaccounted for. Some bank cheques and demand drafts were were also seized from the duo.

The ASP said that their investigation revealed that the couple had sold their house in Jeypore Town, Odisha. However, in the agreement, they mentioned that the house was sold for Rs 2.2 crore and they received an advance of Rs 50 lakh in a cheque.

As per the sale deed, the house was sold Rs 2.2 crore and the owners—Varahala and Meena Rao—received the full amount. But the sale agreement actually showed a lesser amount to avoid paying taxes. The sellers of the house received the remaining amount in cash.

Salur police registered a case against the duo and they have written a letter to the Krishna Rao, assistant commissioner, income tax department further investigation.
