Title: Eatery sealed after food poisoning incident
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Food inspection officials of the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation sealed a restaurant , Majlis Darbar, on Monday following the report of a food poisoning incident at the restaurant.

According to the GVMC officials, on January 31, four Inter students of a private college developed vomiting, diarrhoea and severe stomach ache after a meal at the restaurant. They were treated at a private hospital.

Speaking to TOI, GVMC food inspector AV Apparao said that the hotel was sealed on Monday. “We conducted an inspection at the hotel and found the kitchen unhygienic. We collected samples of various food items, which were sent to the state food laboratory in Hyderabad. We recorded the statements of the hotel’s representatives and registered a case against the hotel under Section 59 in the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006. The restaurant cannot be reopened till appropriate corrective measures are taken and a report is submitted to the GVMC. The future course of action will also depend on the results of the food samples sent to Hyderabad,” Apparao said.

Four Inter students of a private college vomiting, diarrhoea and severe stomach ache after a meal at the restaurant on January 31

Title: Cops arrest 4 kidnappers, rescue medicine agent
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kanpur: Police rescued medicine agent Pintu Gupta (35) and arrested four kidnappers following an encounter at the CPC Malgodam area under Collectorganj police station in the wee hours of Monday.

A kidnapper and a police constable sustained gunshot wounds in the encounter.

According to police, Pintu, who lives with his family in the Collectorganj area of the city, and works as a medicine agent in the medicine market, was kidnapped from near his house on February 1 afternoon under Collectorganj police station.

"An FIR was lodged under section 364 of IPC following a complaint filed by his brother Shri Krishna, who received a ransom call of Rs 7 lakh from the kidnappers for his safe release.

A police team from the Collectorganj police station was formed, and a hunt was launched to rescue Pintu from the kidnappers. During the wee hours of Monday as the team was zeroing in on the kidnappers close to the CPC Malgodam area, the kidnappers started firing. The police team retaliated in self-defence and nabbed the four kidnappers. One of the kidnappers Satendra Kumar Chauhan was injured after a bullet hit his leg. Similarly, constable Ravindra Kumar also sustained gunshot wounds in his hand. The other kidnappers arrested by the police were identified as Faisal, Bachcha and Suraj," said SSP Anant Deo. "Kidnapper Satendra and constable Ravindra have been admitted to a hospital where doctors stated their condition to be out of danger", the SSP added.

"A case under the Arms Act and Indian Penal Code was registered against the four kidnappers at the Collectorganj police station on Monday," said a police official.

Police said that two country-made pistols, several live cartridges and two motorcycles, besides a scooty belonging to victim Pintu, were recovered from the possession of the kidnappers. Further investigations are underway, the police added.

Title: Maharashtra: Auto driver pushes elderly woman on road, robs Rs 25,000, cellphone
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An autorickshaw driver took an elderly woman passenger in another direction from her destination before snatching her cellphone and Rs 25,000 from her purse near Ajanta Avenue society, off Paud road, on Monday afternoon. The driver ran over the woman’s leg while escaping but she fortunately did not suffer a fracture.

Senior inspector Pratibha Joshi of the Kothrud police station told TOI that they have obtained the registration number of the autorickshaw through CCTV footage from establishments in the vicinity.

Joshi said the 65-year-old woman, who did not wished to be named, had hired the autorickshaw from her residence on DP road in Kothrud at 2.30pm to go to the State Bank of India branch at Anandnagar to collect her pension. She asked the driver to wait for her outside the bank as she wanted to return by the same vehicle.

On the way back, the driver deliberately took her in another direction and stopped the autorickshaw near Ajanta Avenue society around 3pm. “He forced the woman to get out of the vehicle. Even as she did so, the driver pushed her hard and she fell on the road. The driver grabbed her cellphone and pulled out the cash from her purse,” Joshi said.

The woman sustained injuries on her shoulder and head after falling. “Even as the woman was on the ground, the driver started his vehicle and ran over her leg. The woman screamed in pain and local residents rushed to the spot. However, the driver managed to escape. The woman suffered bruises on her shin after a metal part of the autorickshaw scraped against it,” Joshi said.

The woman was admitted to a private hospital located on Paud road. She was given a discharge late in the evening. She later lodged a complaint with the Kothrud police. Police have registered a case under sections 392 (robbery) and 323 (causing hurt) of the Indian Penal Code.

TOI on Monday evening tried to contact the woman but her family said she was again taken to hospital for another check-up and would not be available for comment.

Title: Prakash Javadekar: Anarchist & terrorist almost same
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: Just days after the Election Commission issued a show cause notice to BJP MP Parvesh Verma for calling Arvind Kejriwal a “terrorist”, Union minister Prakash Javadekar on Monday said the the CM had called himself an “anarchist” and that there is “not much difference between an anarchist and a terrorist”.

“Kejriwal masoom chehra karke poochhte hain ki kya main aatankwadi hoon ... aap aatankwadi ho, iske bahut sabut hain. Aapne khud kaha tha ki main arajakwadi hoon. Aatankwadi or arajakwadi mein bahut zyada antar nahi hain” (With an air of injured innocence, Kejriwal has been asking whether he is a terrorist. You are indeed a terrorist , and there is plenty of proof for that. You yourself said you are an anarchist. There is not much difference between an anarchist and a terrorist),” Javadekar told a press conference where he was flanked by Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari and Union minister Anurag Thakur.

Javadekar also raised the issue of Kejriwal “staying a night at the Moga residence of Khalistan Commando Force chief Gurinder Singh during the Punjab Assembly polls”. “You knew it was a militant’s house. Still, you stayed there. How much more evidence do you need?” he said.

The minister said AAP was supporting Shaheen Bagh, where slogans of “Assam ko azadi”, “Jinnah wali azadi” were being raised. “Supporting such slogans is also terrorism,” he said. He also referred to Delhi government avoiding taking a call on whether Kanhaiya Kumar, Umar Khalid and others should be prosecuted for allegedly raising anti-India slogans. He said Kejriwal stood with JNU, where “anti-India slogans were raised, and did not grant sanction to prosecute (those who raised the slogans)”.

“On January 26, you threatened that you would stop their prosecution. How much more proof do you need? The people of Delhi now know that you are the chief of liars, you are an anarchist and sympathise with terrorists,” he said, adding, “You are supporting Shaheen Bagh, JNU, the slogans being raised there and all such anarchists...then you are definitely a terrorist. This is your identity, no matter how innocent face you make.” After Verma called him a “terrorist”, Kejriwal had said it was for the people of Delhi to decide whether they consider him their son, brother, or a terrorist.

“How have I become a terrorist? I’ve arranged for medicines...did so much for the needy. I’ve never thought of myself or my family... am ready to give my life for the nation,” he had said.

Title: Artistes gift a ‘Melodious Monday’ to music lovers
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Killing the Monday blues with retro hits for many music lovers was the programme ‘Melodious Monday’ by Unforgettable Moments at Scientific Soceity Hall, Laxmi Nagar.

The atmosphere possessed the right vibe as anchor Nasir Khan kept the audience in the know about the details of the songs being presented.

Artiste Kaushik Pujari and the choir group welcomed the audience by praising Lord Ganesha with the song ‘Moraya Moraya’. The song enchanted in the hall and mesmerized one and all.

Turning on to the theme of the evening ‘retro music’, Sanjay Borkar and Sawati Khadse rendered the song ‘Dil bekarar tha’.

Another super hit song ‘Madhosh dil ki dhadkan’ by Pujari and Anjali Wankhede brought back the glimpse of Salman Khan and Twinkle Khanna’s on-screen romance from ‘Jab Pyaar Kisi Se Hota Hain.’

Duets like ‘Aisi deewangi’ from the movie ‘Deewana’ by Ravindra Paranjape and Khadse, the evergreen romantic song of the 90s ‘Tujhe dekha to yeh jaana’, ‘Keh do ki tum’, ‘Aap ke aajane se’, ‘Ashwini, ye naa’, ‘Hame jab se’, ‘Ho jaata hai kaise pyaar’ and ‘Baahon ke darmiya’ gave a trip down the memory lane. Other sings including Anushka Kale, Nitin Zade and Rupali Roy gave a reminiscing retro ride to the listeners.

Singles like ‘Namak ishq ka’, ‘Chal chal mere sang’, ‘Zindagi maut naa ban jaaye’, ‘Tu iss tarah se’, ‘Ab mujhe raat din’, ‘My name is Anthony’ compelling the gathering to tap their feet to the tunes. Anisha Pabbraju was the chief guest on the occasion and presented a song ‘Chaand jaise mukhde pe’ which was well received. Unnikrishnan Nair was the guest of honour. The programme was organized by Kaushik Pujari and Aqueel Ahmed.

Mug shots and quotes :

I never miss such musical programmes. I enjoyed the evening as the selection of songs was fabulous and the event was well-coordinated

Praveen Patil | Businessman

All the songs were perfectly sung. I expect more young artistes to participate and showcase their talent through such events

Bhimrao Kamble | Advocate

It was a treat to listen to all the wonderful singers. Many songs that went unheard all these years were relived today with this programme

Sanjyot Herwadkar | Doctor

Title: Anarchist & terrorist almost same: Prakash Javadekar
Content:
Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: Just days after the Election Commission issued a show cause notice to BJP MP Parvesh Verma for calling Arvind Kejriwal a “terrorist”, Union minister Prakash Javadekar on Monday said the the CM had called himself an “anarchist” and that there is “not much difference between an anarchist and a terrorist”.“Kejriwal masoom chehra karke poochhte hain ki kya main aatankwadi hoon ... aap aatankwadi ho, iske bahut sabut hain. Aapne khud kaha tha ki main arajakwadi hoon. Aatankwadi or arajakwadi mein bahut zyada antar nahi hain” (With an air of injured innocence, Kejriwal has been asking whether he is a terrorist. You are indeed a terrorist , and there is plenty of proof for that. You yourself said you are an anarchist. There is not much difference between an anarchist and a terrorist),” Javadekar told a press conference where he was flanked by Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari and Union minister Anurag Thakur.Javadekar also raised the issue of Kejriwal “staying a night at the Moga residence of Khalistan Commando Force chief Gurinder Singh during the Punjab Assembly polls”. “You knew it was a militant’s house. Still, you stayed there. How much more evidence do you need?” he said.The minister said AAP was supporting Shaheen Bagh, where slogans of “Assam ko azadi”, “Jinnah wali azadi” were being raised. “Supporting such slogans is also terrorism,” he said. He also referred to Delhi government avoiding taking a call on whether Kanhaiya Kumar, Umar Khalid and others should be prosecuted for allegedly raising anti-India slogans. He said Kejriwal stood with JNU, where “anti-India slogans were raised, and did not grant sanction to prosecute (those who raised the slogans)”.“On January 26, you threatened that you would stop their prosecution. How much more proof do you need? The people of Delhi now know that you are the chief of liars, you are an anarchist and sympathise with terrorists,” he said, adding, “You are supporting Shaheen Bagh, JNU, the slogans being raised there and all such anarchists...then you are definitely a terrorist. This is your identity, no matter how innocent face you make.” After Verma called him a “terrorist”, Kejriwal had said it was for the people of Delhi to decide whether they consider him their son, brother, or a terrorist.“How have I become a terrorist? I’ve arranged for medicines...did so much for the needy. I’ve never thought of myself or my family... am ready to give my life for the nation,” he had said.

Title: Market committee supervisor held on graft charge
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: The Vigilance Bureau here on Monday arrested an auction recorder-cum-supervisor of a market committee for accepting a bribe of Rs 15,000. The accused has been identified as Hari Ram. A complaint was lodged by an arhtiya, Sajan Wadhwa.

The complainant told the bureau that the accused was appointed as supervisor at the New Vegetable Market near Jalandhar bypass. The accused used to intimidate arhtiyas that he would show more weight of vegetables in the record books and then would make double entry of their vehicles if he was not Rs 10 per sack of vegetables. He added that the accused demanded Rs 17,000 from his as bribe for not doing the same. The deal was fixed for Rs 15,000 and on Monday the complainant had to give him the bribe money. The arhtiyas have to pay 4% fee to the government per quintal.

However, Wadhwa informed the VB. Vigilance SSP Rupinder Singh said on receiving the complaint, the vigilance bureau laid a trap for the accused and caught him while accepting Rs 15,000 in bribe. A case under Section 7 of the Prevention of Corruption Act was registered against the accused at the bureau office here and investigation has been initiated.

Title: Multiplexes, cinema halls too can stay open round the clock in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The Uddhav Thackeray-led Maharashtra government expanded its pet project of a 24x7 lifestyle by allowing multiplexes and cinema halls to remain open round the clock .

A notification was issued on January 31, allowing cinema halls to be added to that section of the amended Maharashtra Shops and Establishments (Regulation of Employment and Service Condition) Act, 2017, that lets shops, including restaurants (that do not serve alcohol), salons, hyper malls and businesses such as banks, medical establishments and tax consultancies, to remain open 24 hours in the state. Till the notification, theatres could not run beyond 1am.

Manoj Desai, executive director of G-7 Multiplex and Maratha Mandir , plans to adopt a wait-and-watch attitude.

“Of course, we welcome the notification permitting us to function all night long. But we will observe other malls, multiplexes, single screens and take a decision once we feel the nightlife journey is safe for everybody,” he said.

The spokesman of a south Mumbai cinema hall said their last show starts around 11.15pm and winds up by 1.00-1.30am. “Officially, we have welcomed the government’s announcement permitting us to function day and night because it offers the viewer more flexibility and choice,” he said. However, business districts are deserted at night, and there are often few taxis. It is largely patrons with cars who prefer the late shows.

Besides the safety issues, there are also questions of viability. Since the 24x7 policy began on the Republic Day weekend, the response to late night shopping or eating out has been, at best, lukewarm. A cinema hall in Worli tried out the extended timings last week, but discontinued the extra shows for lack of patronage. “We are located inside a mall. We will have to wait and see whether the extended business hours succeed. The opinion of the residents of the neighbourhood also plays a part,” said the spokesman.

The 24x7 initiative, a brainchild of Sena leader and cabinet minister Aaditya Thackeray, was launched from January 24 and is currently being implemented in non-residential areas and in gated premise like malls, mill compounds. Shops can remain open in three shifts. However, one-day leave has to be given to employees every week. Cinemas are now in the category that can stay open day and night, but liquor-serving establishments, clubs and pubs have to still shut shop by 1:30am.

Title: Maharashtra: 500 metres of metro tunnel ready, will touch Shivajinagar soon
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The tunnel-boring machine (TBM) that was pressed into service in December has finished excavating a 500m stretch of the underground Metro tunnel .The machine, which is digging at the rate of 8-10 metres per day, is expected to reach the site of the Shivajinagar station by the end of this month.In fact, officials of the Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) are optimistic that the TBM would do better than that. “The TBM could even reach the site before the end of the month, if all parameters are in our favour,” a senior MahaMetro official said.Meanwhile, the other TBM, which started excavating a parallel tunnel in the first week of January, has dug around 150 metres. Both TBMs were lowered at the College of Agriculture site. Two more TBMs will eventually be pressed into service from the Swargate end.The location of the Shivajinagar station is about 750 metres from this site.While stating that the tunnelling work was progressing as per their expectations, MahaMetro officials said the excavation had, in fact, gained momentum in the past few days.The machines started digging tunnels 18 metres underground. “However, the depth of the tunnel will vary depending on the rock formation. It could go as deep as 25 metres underground,” the official said, adding that both machines have covered a cumulative distance of 600 metres.Officials further said they have started the civil work for the Shivajinagar station, which is aligned exactly below the existing Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) terminus. Bus operations have already been shifted to a temporary facility in Wakdewadi.From Shivajinagar, the machines will bore the tunnel towards the Civil Court Metro station.To facilitate work at the Shivajinagar site, MahaMetro is planning to introduce some changes to the vehicular traffic movement in the area, The plan is still under consideration, officials said.

Title: Nine months before Andheri-Dahisar Metro 7 deadline, contractor axed over work delay
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The Simplex portion of the civil work is stuck at the 75% stage

MUMBAI: Nearly nine months before the deadline for the Andheri-Dahisar Metro 7 , the MMRDA has terminated the contract awarded to infrastructure major Simplex for the construction of the Andheri-Goregaon portion , citing extensive work execution delays.

Fears that the delay on the stretch would jeopardise the October deadline for the Metro 7 project began to be expressed about six months ago, when the MMRDA sent the first of several notices to Simplex Infrastructures Ltd to speed up work.

The Rs 6,208 crore Metro 7 project will connect the 16.5 km between Andheri (east) and Dahisar (east) with an elevated line running largely along the Western Express Highway.

Simplex was finalised to execute civil works on the 5.5 km stretch between Andheri and Goregaon in April 2016 for Rs 348 crore. Officials said the work here had remained virtually stuck at the 75% stage for some months now when it should have been finished by now. “The MMRDA has terminated the contract and fresh tenders have been invited to appoint a new contractor to complete the balance work of Simplex Infrastructures Ltd,” an MMRDA official said.

The MMRDA has also encashed the bank guarantee of Rs 35 crore given by Simplex.

Title: ITC to pump in Rs 2k cr in Bhadrachalam unit by ’25
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bhadrachalam: Diversified multinational conglomerate ITC Ltd has drawn up plans to invest Rs 2,500 crore in its PSPD (paperboards & specialty papers division) business as part of plans to hike capacity to 1 million tonnes per annum (mtpa) by 2025.

A chunk of this investment — Rs 2,000 crore — will be pumped into its integrated pulp and paper manufacturing facility at Bhadrachalam, Telangana. ITC Bhadrachalam, which is spread over 500 acres and is touted as the largest site for pulp and paper production in India, procures 15 lakh tpa of pulp wood from nearly 8,000 farmers in the two Telugu states and has created over 1,800 direct and 3,000 indirect jobs.

“At present our overall PSPD capacity is 7.5 lakh tonne per annum, out of which 6.5 lakh tpa alone is at Bhadrachalam. As part of our plan to reach 1 mtpa over the next 5 years, Bhadrachalam’s capacity will be increased to over 8 lakh tpa,” Vadiraj Kulkarni, chief operating officer, PSPD, ITC Ltd, told TOI.

Pointing out that ITC has already invested Rs 1,250 crore in its PSPD business over the past three years, Kulkarni said Rs 1,500 crore will be pumped into Bhadrachalam by the end of 2021-22.

“The Rs 1,250 crore investment went into setting up a 1 lakh tpa bleached chemi-thermo mechanical pulp (BCTMP) mill, which contributes to import substitution and captures larger value in India, and a new paperboards machine line with production capacity of 1.5 lakh tpa at Bhadrachalam.

The ongoing Rs 1,500 crore investment is being utilised for setting up a high-pressure recovery boiler, expanding the pulp mill capacity to 4 lakh tpa from 3.5 lakh tpa and augmenting the production capacity of board machines from 1 lakh tpa to 1.5 lakh tpa at Bhadrachalam,” Kulkarni explained.

He said another Rs 1,000 crore will be invested over the next five years for expanding the pulp mill capacity at Bhadrachalam to 4.75 lakh tpa at Rs 500 crore. Another Rs 500 crore will be pumped into Kovai (Coimbatore) facility to add a 1.5 lakh tpa paper board machine to enhance capacity at the plant to 2.5 lakh tpa. “We will be taking the necessary approvals for this Rs 1,000 crore investment plan in due course,” the ITC-PSPD COO said.

He said the investments in the PSPD business are aimed at driving growth and competitiveness of the business through an indigenous sustainable paper value chain anchored on an afforestation programme that has greened over 7.5 lakh acres across the country.

Title: Police goes on FB to help you get back stolen vehicles
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: If your vehicle has got stolen and it has not been recovered yet, there are chances that you may get it back through Facebook. The city police have asked residents to reply on their post uploaded on official page of Ludhiana police with details of such vehicle to get the same back.

Ludhiana police on Sunday night had uploaded a post on Facebook. “We have many abandoned vehicles at the police station and Police Lines. Some vehicles don’t have registration number plates on it due to which the police are finding it difficult to trace the owner. If your vehicle was ever stolen and has not been recovered yet, kindly comment in the reply with the information about the vehicle. The police will try to trace it.”

Further, the police have asked residents to reply in a particular format, including information like vehicle type, vehicle brand, colour, engine number (if known), chasis number, date and time when the vehicle was lost, place where you lost it, FIR no, date of FIR, under which section and police station the FIR was registered and your mobile number.

Commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal said, “Importantly, there are piles of abandoned vehicles outside police stations and in the Police Lines, which have not been claimed by anyone. The police have failed to trace their owners as the vehicles do not have registration number plates.

He added that, “The police have now asked people to share details of their stolen vehicles , so that the it could trace these vehicles.” He further said those who could not share information on Facebook, could also approach cops in the respective police stations of their areas.

Title: Chennai: Eight Chinese flyers test negative for coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The eight Chinese nationals admitted to the infectious diseases ward of Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital have tested negative for the novel coronavirus, health minster C Vijayabaskar said on Monday. Tests were done at the King Institute of Preventive Medicine and Research in Guindy.On Sunday, after they arrived at the city airport and one of them was found suffering from fever and cold during screening, they were admitted to the isolation ward in Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital. All the eight, who came here on business, are from China’s Guangdong province that is nearly 800km from Wuhan, the epicentre of coronavirus outbreak. Throat and nasal swabs along with blood samples were drawn for the tests. “We don’t have an infected patient in the state. The health condition of the patients is stable,” Vijayabaskar told reporters. “We will be discharging them soon and have encouraged them to return home as soon as possible. They are looking at flight options.”The patients were placed in tower 2’s isolation ward where 10 doctors, 18 staff nurses and around 20 paramedics have been posted . Care givers have been given personal protection equipment including special masks and gloves. “The only challenge we had in handling them was the language,” said hospital dean Dr R Jayanthi. None of them spoke English. “We serve as a quarantine hospital for the airport. Passengers from Kenya and Nigeria have been quarantined here when they entered our country without taking shots for yellow fever. But they knew English,” she said.For the last two days, a translator hired by the the hospital coordinated with the patients and helped doctors explain the treatment plan and Union ministry’s health protocol. But when the translator was not around, doctors used google translator. “We found we should say Yàn shì zi for throat swab and Xiěyè yàngběn for blood sample,” the dean said, smiling. While they took boiled eggs, milk, bread and some clear soup from the hospital kitchen, they preferred ready-to-eat soups and noodles for lunch and dinner. Finally, what brought smiles to their faces was when they heard the computerised voice from the duty doctors’ mobile say, “Nǐ kěyǐ huí jiā”. It meant “You can go home”.

Title: Kanpur: Class IX student found hanging in classroom
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: A class IX student allegedly committed suicide in the classroom at a CBSE affiliated college in Nawabganj area of Kanpur on Sunday night.

The student, Ashutosh Kumar, son of a primary school teacher Kamta Prasad, was a native of Gonda. He lived in a hostel on the college campus.

On Monday morning, his body was found hanging in a classroom on the second floor of the college. “He used to share the room with a student Pawan. On not finding Ashutosh in the bed, Pawan informed the hostel warden. Later, he was found hanging in a classroom which was opened by a peon on Monday morning,” police said.

The peon informed the college authorities, who in turn alerted the police. The police thereafter rushed to the spot along with a team of forensic experts. Though no suicide note was recovered from the spot, however, during the preliminary inquiry, it came to fore that the boy had committed suicide, police said. The body was shifted to the mortuary.

“The postmortem examination will be conducted once his family members arrive from Gonda. His local guardian, who resides in Bara Sirohi area of Kalyanpur, has also been informed,” said DIG Anant Deo. “Police are investigating the case and scanning the CCTV footage”, he added.

“Ashutosh was good at studies. In fact, some of the students who knew him told us that these days he seemed to be a bit disturbed. At around 9 pm on Sunday, he was spotted taking a stroll in the gallery,” said a college source.

Title: 500 NRIs fly in to volunteer for AAP’s campaign
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chief minister of Delhi, Arvind Kejriwal (C), waves to supporters during a road show for the upcoming Delhi Le... Read More

NEW DELHI: Kamal Garg, a software engineer based in Vancouver , Canada, is in Delhi for three weeks. The visit is not to spend time with his friends and family, but to work as a volunteer for AAP .

Garg, also a social media manager of AAP working from Canada, is one of the nearly 500 NRIs who are in Delhi to help the party in the elections. Many have been volunteering from the days when chief minister Arvind Kejriwal was a part of India Against Corruption and AAP was yet to be born.

“In Canada, priority is given to education and health. And that is what Kejriwal has followed. I have visited some Schools of Excellence in Delhi and they are as good as the best schools in the world. I will go back to Canada after the swearing-in ceremony of the AAP government,” said the soft-spoken Garg with a confident smile.

Prithvi Reddy, a Bengaluru-based entrepreneur, who is the convener of AAP Overseas and a member of the party’s national executive, said, “This is a party that works 24x7 because of the different time zones in which our supporters reside. Our IT edge is thanks to these volunteers. Every election, NRIs have come to India and supported the party.” Reddy said nearly 20% of all donations received by AAP come from overseas supporters. They had a target of Rs 50 crore for the assembly elections . Apart from NRIs, nearly 8,000 AAP supporters from other states have come to Delhi to help in the election campaign.

The co-convener of AAP Overseas, Preeti Sharma , said that volunteers have come from countries like Canada, US, UK, Singapore, Malaysia , Philippines and UAE. Reddy said many volunteers based in the Middle East are also helping in taking calls from people. Charanjit Garewal, who is from the UK, said that Delhi and other cities will become like New York or California and AAP has started working towards that goal.

Title: December 2019 warmest in five Maharashtra cities since 1901
Content:
The warming trend this winter indirectly suggested copious moisture incursion into Maharashtra (File photo)

PUNE: An India Meteorological Department (IMD) winter analysis has revealed that December last year had the warmest night temperatures since 1901 in at least five cities in Maharashtra — Pune, Ratnagiri , Malegaon , Kolhapur and Dahanu.The December 2019 nights were the fourth warmest for Mumbai in the IMD’s recorded history (1901) and second warmest for Aurangabad and Solapur. The data revealed that the average night temperature in Maharashtra was the highest after 1967.At least 11 cities in the state broke the minimum temperature records for experiencing one of the warmest Decembers since 1901. All these cities have recorded the warmest December nights during recent decades, especially after 1960.Arvind Kumar Srivastava, head of the Climate Research Division (Climate Research and Services) IMD-Pune, told TOI that not only Maharashtra, but the entire south peninsular India experienced the second warmest average minimum temperature in December 2019 in recorded history.He said, “The average minimum temperature for Maharashtra in December 2019 was 17.5ºC, which was the warmest December average the state has seen in the past 52 years or after 1967 when the average December night temperature was 17.95ºC. Maharashtra, meanwhile, recorded the third highest December average minimum since 1901 this winter.”Srivastava said to have such warm night temperatures during winter was rare but not incredible, considering the larger climate change and global warming scenario. “Climatologically, we have noticed a trend that when north India is cool during the season, south India tends to record relatively warmer minimum temperatures,” he said.The warming trend this winter indirectly suggested copious moisture incursion into Maharashtra, as well as south peninsular India. “But long-term humidity data will have to be studied to see if there has been an unprecedented increase in humidity levels in the last few months,” Srivastava said.“This winter, the anti-cyclones from the Arabian Sea were constantly blocking the flow of cold and dry northerly winds originating from the snow-clad regions of the Himalayas. While these winds could enter north India, their entry to south peninsular India, including Maharashtra, was blocked,” he added.The wind regime was also such that the moist westerlies from the Arabian Sea or warm and humid easterlies were influencing the minimum temperatures in Maharashtra during most of winter. “As far as the high night temperatures witnessed this winter in many cities of Maharashtra and south India are concerned, there was an influence of local factors like soil topography and vegetation that also played a role in pushing up minimum temperatures in those stations,” Srivastava said.

Title: Students urged to become curious in quest for knowledge
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

C D Mayee, Former Vice-Chancellor, Marathwada Agricultural University inaugurated the ‘JIGYASA: Student-Scient... Read More

Nagpur: “Curiosity is the foundation of any kind of invention or discovery. It helps in one’s quest for knowledge,” said Dr CD Mayee, a former vice-chancellor of Marathwada Agricultural University, while addressing students at the inaugural function of JIGYASA – Student-Scientist Connect Residential Programme on Monday.

At the outset, Prakash Kumbhare, senior principal scientist (CSIR Neeri), gave a brief introduction of Mayee. Regarding‘Jigyasa’, Kumbhare said, “NEERI has organized this five-day programme for school-going children to make them aware about researches and scientists. As students only retain what they learn in textbooks, this programme will connect them directly to

scientists and various research programmes and that’s why we have called it called it the Student–Scientist Connect programme.”

Some activities are themes and experiments on water quality research, water audit, lab visits, on-site experiments and interactions with Neeri scientists.

In his inaugural address, Mayee informed students about the importance of innovation, invention and research. He said the ‘Green Revolution’ has great significance.

While explaining the importance of accidental inventions, Mayee spoke about the discovery of penicillin in particular. He also educated students about Dadaji Khobragade, a humble farmer who invented HMT rice. Despite his invention, Khobragde remained poor, but people around him became rich because of the high quality of his rice. “All these inventions and discoveries were a result of curiosity. Apart from textbook knowledge, students must develop curiosity and should ask more and more questions. This programme will encourage students and help them to get good exposure,” said Mayee.

Dr JS Pandey, chief scientist, climatic change and skilling division (CSIR Neeri) felicitated Mayee with a memento. Dr Pradeep Salve, principal scientist, proposed a vote of thanks while Samruddhi anchored the programme.

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod)

Title: ‘Timeless Melodies’ wins hearts and touches souls
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Fans of Gulzaar and Ludhianvi were in for a musical treat on Sunday evening at a programme organized by Sannidhi at Deshpande Hall, Civil Lines. The event titled ‘Timeless Melodies of Two Legendary Poets — Gulzar and Saahir Ludhianvi’, saw well known singers from the city perform their evergreen hits.

Maharashtra Times Culture Club was the official partner of the event which started with the song ‘Jaane woh kaise’ sung by Arvind Patil. Isha Ranade crooned the popular ghazal ‘Mera kuch saaman’ originally sung by Asha Bhosale, from the movie ‘Ijaazat’.

‘Mere dil mai aaj kya hai’, an evergreen Kishore Kumar number from the movie ‘Daag’ by Sagar Madhumatke left the audience spellbound.

The other classy numbers that made the audience sway their head to the rhythm included ‘O maanjhi re’, ‘Kesariya Baalma’, ‘Maine tere liye hi’, ‘Ek akela iss sheher main’, ‘Kabhi kabhi mere dil main’, ‘Woh shaam kuch ajeeb thi’, ‘Mai pal do pal ka shayar hoon’ and ‘Yeh raat yeh chandani’. Duets as well as solos made the evening melodious for the large gathering. ‘Tere chehre se nazar nahi’ by Madhumatke and Ranade energized the atmosphere. The repeated applause by the audience was a deserving honour for the talented singers including Sarang Joshi, Arvind Patil and Manjiri Vaidya besides Madhumatke and Ranade.

Accompanying the singers on instruments were Raja Rathod (keyboard), Rugwed Pande (lead guitar), Robin Williams (bass guitar), Prashant Nagmote (tabla), Ashok Tokalwar (dholak) and Nandu Gohane (octapad). Vrushali Deshpande was compèred the event.

Title: Seoni girls top CA Foundation from city
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Seoni girl Tanvi Agrawal emerged probable topper with All India Ranking (AIR) of 25 from the Nagpur chapter of Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) after results of the Chartered Accountants Foundation exam, held in November 2019, were announced on Monday.

Another Seoni resident Simran Ahuja, AIR 40, and Hrishik Daga, AIR 41, are the next probable toppers from the region.

The ICAI also announced the results of the Chartered Accountants Intermediate (IPC) and Intermediate (new course).

Of the 91,405 students admitted in CA Foundation course, 87,084 appeared in the exam at 458 centres across the world. Only 30,563 managed to clear the exam, registering 35.10 pass percentage in the country.

Title: Exporters want appointment of nodal officer for faster GST refunds
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: Irked over the slow speed of processing of GST refunds, city exporters are demanding appointing of a nodal officer in the central GST and customs departments for faster processing of the same. According to businessmen, a huge amount of GST refunds of theirs get stuck every month on their export consignments due to which they have to face various problems.

Giving more information, Harish Dua, president of Knitwear and Apparel Exporters Organisation, said, “The problem of delay in GST refunds of exporters is taking a very serious turn now. For the last one year the refunds are being processed very slowly and it sometimes takes months to settle the entire refund pertaining to a particular period. The worst part is that this is happening even after completion of all formalities by us and proper filing of our returns.”

“From this year we are hearing that the Union ministers and officials are making false claims that the refunds are being processed at a very fast pace and all genuine claims are being settled on time by the central GST department but the story is the other way round. Sometimes, the GST department officials claim that our documents are not complete, sometimes they claim that they have not received necessary clearance from the customs department. This is a never-ending harassment and at the end of the day it’s the businessmen who suffer badly and incur huge losses due to their hard-earned money getting blocked. This problem of delay in processing of GST refunds cannot be solved until there is an appointment of a nodal officer for exporters who can coordinate with both GST and customs department for processing of GST refunds.”

According to Harish Kairpal, cashier of Knitwear Club, Ludhiana, “GST refunds of exporters from lakhs to several crores are getting stuck with the taxation departments and people do not have money to carry on with their business. When GST was to be launched the central government had made several tall claims that this taxation system is going to improve doing of business but the reality is the other way round and exporters are turning out to be biggest victims. Huge amounts of our GST remains pending with the departments for months, which is taking a toll on the exporters. The central government should take a serious view of this problem and get it resolved at the earliest by appointing a nodal officer for GST refund issues of exporters.”

According to Subash Bajaj, an engineering component exporter from the city, “The GST refunds problem is the biggest problem of the exporters’ fraternity and until this issue is tackled seriously, the exports from India will keep falling as businessmen are getting fed up with the system and many of them are considering quitting this business as one’s capital gets stuck with these departments. Therefore, appointment of a nodal officer, who could coordinate between both GST and customs department for refunds of exporters, should be considered by the central government.”

Title: Majority of Maharashtra schools complete self-evaluation
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Around 80% of the total of over one lakh schools in the state have self-evaluated themselves under the “Shala Siddhi” programme for academic and infrastructure development.

Gondia emerged as the top-most district to cover maximum (98%) schools that have completed their progress report. “The objectives of the evaluation system are to critically analyze the present practices to identify its strengths and areas that need immediate action for improvement,” state director of primary education Dattatray Jagtap said.

In Pune, 70.29% schools have completed the evaluation.

The “Shala Siddhi” programme was introduced by the National University of Educational Planning and Administration of the Union ministry of human resource and development in 2015. The exercise is conducted annually.

The schools have to evaluate their infrastructure with respect to school premises, playground with sports, equipment and materials, classrooms and other rooms, electricity and gadgets, library, laboratory, computer, ramp, mid-day meal, kitchen and utensils, drinking water, hand wash facilities and toilets. The evaluation has six more parameters for assessment.

Jagtap said, “The schools need to give a plan for improvement by identifying the areas. A school can collectively select some areas that it wishes to work on and leave out some, depending on its present limitations. It may then prioritize the chosen areas in three degrees — low, medium and high — and decide to work on them in a phased manner over time. Decisions related to prioritization would depend on the immediate needs of the school, demands from policies, local context, school specific issues, among others.”

The programme was implemented in the state form the 2016-17 academic year. The state government has targeted to make 100% schools compliant with “Shala Siddhi”.

Title: Manuu students to intensify anti-CAA, NRC agitations
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Maulana Azad National Urdu University ( Manuu ) students union has decided to intensify its agitation against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) by inviting eminent personalities to interact with the protesters.

The decision was taken during a general body meeting conducted by the students union on Monday. “We will form a managing committee that will organise talks by experts from various fields on key issues that are plaguing our country. These lectures will help us spread awareness among the students at large,” said Umar Faruq Quadri, president of Manuu students union.

During the meeting, students also discussed various issues pertaining to the university. “Many issues related to internal bus facilities, internet on the campus, shortage of books in the library and delay in disbursal of scholarships were raised by the students. We have decided to represent all theses issues to the vice-chancellor seeking solutions,” said Quadri.

Title: Another suspected coronavirus tourist in Udaipur
Content:
Representative Image

UDAIPUR: Another suspected coronavirus tourist in Udaipur had the health department on alert mode as it rushed to screen the hotel staff where the woman had stayed for a day.According to sources, a Chinese woman had come to Udaipur with three friends from Delhi on January 31. They stayed in a hotel in Lalghat area here for a day. They flew back to Delhi the next day. However, the woman complained of high fever at the Medanta Hospital counter at Delhi airport and was admitted in a hospital there. Her blood samples have been sent for investigation.The medical department was alerted here and asked to screen people at the hotel where the Chinese tourist stayed. CMHO Dinesh Kharadi and his team screened the staff on Sunday. According to sources, blood samples of some of the staff have been collected who had come in close contact with the suspect.Earlier, two passengers who came to Udaipur after having travelled with a medical student who tested positive for the virus in Kerala, had been kept in isolation ward here at the MB Hospital. One of them was a Chinese woman while another was from Bharatpur . Both left the hospital and went to Jaipur without seeking discharge which has been taken as a serious security flaw at a time when the virus outbreak is causing global panic.

Title: Women vow to continue protests
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

By: Omer Bin Taher

CHARMINAR: Protests by women organisations against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) in Old City on Monday saw women vowing to carry on their agitation till the government rolls back on the Act.

The speakers at the meet urged all women to come forward and raise voice against CAA, NPR and NRC. International karate champion Syeda Falak said an ideology of hatred was being promoted to divide people .

“We want all women to be part of this movement and all possible efforts will be made to make the city another Shaheen Bagh,” Falak said, adding, “The CAA is against the constitution which creates hatred among the people. An ideology is being followed to promote hate between Hindus and Muslims. We have decided to raise our voice and fight against such an ideology.”

The meeting was organised by Secular and Women Welfare Association led by Syeda Falak. The speakers include social activist Arshia Ayub, AIMPLB convener Asma Zehra , vice president of Tanzeem e Niswant Syeda Aquila Khamooshi, and others.

Title: Cops seek legal opinion on statements
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A day after alleged provocative statements were made by some speakers at a pro-CAA meeting organised by Akhand Bharat Sangarsh Samithi (ABSS) in the Old City, police have sought legal opinion on the utterances. Police are also analysing video footage to check if the statements were in violation of the law.

A video of a group of men shouting slogans against MIM leader and Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi, CPI leader Kanhaiya Kumar, students of JNU and Jamia Millia Islamia saying “Thok ke denge aazadi (will shoot and give you freedom) has gone viral on social media.

The meeting was attended by BJP state president K Laxman, MLC N Ramchander Rao and party spokesperson Raghunandan Rao.

During the meeting, an advocate from Delhi and a local political leader reportedly made statements like “Desh ki gaddaronko... goli maro saalonko (shoot the traitors). “We have sent the details of the slogans given by the advocate and local politician for legal opinion,” a cop said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Passengers at railway stations, airport to be tested
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The isolation ward at JP Hospital in Bhopal

BHOPAL: With 19 cases of suspected coronavirus patients coming to light, health minister Tulsi Silawat held an emergency meeting to take stock of the situation and assess the health department’s preparedness in the state. Later in a press release, it was announced that screening of all people who have been to coronvirus-hit countries would be conducted. Doctors from government and private sectors also took part in the meeting.

In the city, the latest case of patient being tested for Novel coronavirus is a resident of Mandideep and has a travel history to China. The suspected patient with high fever was spotted at the Bhopal international airport by team of doctors. It would be the second suspected coronavirus case in Bhopal in the last week. Other patients have been screened at Indore , Ujjain, Mandsaur, Chattarpur and Gwalior.

Doctors are testing patients for symptoms of the virus on exit from the airport. Teams would also be deployed at railway stations, said officials. They would be actively screen patients coming on Shatabdi and Rajdhani trains. The first case of coronavirus was reported from Ujjain on January 27. Since then, about two dozen patients have been screened.

Meanwhile, chief minister Kamal Nath urged the people to remain calm, but cautious. In a tweet, the CM said, “The state government is fully equipped to deal with coronavirus. There is no need to fear unnecessarily from the coronavirus. Being cautious and alert is important. MP government is with you, fully alert and is actively monitoring the situation. We are ready to control coronavirus infection”. After the health minister reviewed the Coronavirus scare, the district administration on Monday set up an isolation ward for suspects at the district JP hospital in Bhopal. Medical personnel have been advised to strictly follow the protocol on treatment, diagnosis and isolation of any suspect.

All suspected patients will be under observation and 24x7 vigil of doctors till their blood reports are received from the National Virology Laboratory in Pune. The CMHO Bhopal met the doctors and reviewed the facilities at the hospital.

The health minister said there was no need for panic and said the health infrastructure was fully prepared to meet any eventuality.

Title: Invite RLP for poll role: Panchayati raj department
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

JAIPUR: The state’s rural development and panchayati raj department on Monday directed the district officers not to ignore the Rashtriya Loktantrik Party (RLP), which has already got a state party status, during the lottery process (to reserve seats), meetings and other panchayat election-related activities. It also asked the officials to keep the party in the loop and invite it in future.

The department took cognisance of the matter after Khinvsar ( Nagaur ) MLA Narayan Beniwal ’s letter to the state election commission (SEC) citing neglect by the election officials during election-related activities. Beniwal blamed the state government for absolute “mismanagement” during panchayat elections in the state and called for suspension of a few officials.

According to the department’s directions, the district election officers have been directed to invite RLP for all the panchayat election-related activities and meetings, along with other political parties, by mailing them on their email id rlpindiaorg@gmail.com.

“I had to write this letter to the SEC when RLP was not invited during the lottery to reserve the seats of zila pramukhs and zila pradhans in Jaipur. They invited all other political parties except ours,” Beniwal told TOI.

“The state government is not at all serious about the panchayat elections. Due to this, they have to conduct lotteries in various places twice. In many places, the candidates were made to file nominations, but the outcome of it has not been declared yet and is kept under sealed cover. Who should be held responsible for this mismanagement? I believe 3-4 officials should be suspended. People have lost trust in the entire election process,” he added.

Title: Rajasthan government to rent out its data centre
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

JAIPUR: The Rajasthan government is reaching out to other states and corporates to rent out its extra space for ‘data storage’ at the Bhamashah State Data Centre ( BSDC ). The centre already stores data of all the departments but utilises only 30% of its capacity. Madhya Pradesh has shown interest in taking the storage facility on rent for its departments, while Jharkhand is considering the proposal. Officials said that Adani group too has shown interest in the proposal.

“The department has written a letter to the chief secretaries of all the state governments inviting them to consider using secure storage facility. We are receiving response from several states while talks with MP are at an advanced stage. Several corporates including the Adanis have been approached for taking the services of the BSDC,” said Pramod Agarwal , in charge the centre. The BSDC is country’s first and only tier-4 government-owned data centre meant to fulfil the data storage demand for 30 years of the state.

The facility at present provides data storage service to all the state departments, schemes for free. Officials realised that state-of-the-art facility can generate revenue to make the centre self-sustainable. It is also in talks with government agencies like corporations, industries and individual startups. The department is targeting a revenue of Rs 4 crore by renting out the space in the first year which is sufficient to make it ‘self-run’. “The pricing for the services is highly competitive as the land and building cost which belongs to the government is not included in the offerings,” said Agarwal.

The eight storey data centre facility was launched two months before the model code of conduct in 2018. Its existing capacity is 10 petabytes which further can be expanded to meet the growing needs. It is spread in 25,000 square feet area and offers seven-layered data security check.

Title: Vendors meet CP over cops not allowing access to some sites
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: Even though the city municipal corportion mayor, Balkar Singh Sandhu, had announced a list of 100 vending zone sites for providing relief to roadside vendors, but the latter are complaining that at a few locations the police is not letting them to do their business. They met the commissioner of police (CP) Rakesh Agrawal on Monday and handed over a memorandum to him.

The commissioner of police, however, has asked for the list of tentative vending zones announced by the civic body. The vendors also claimed that some of the locations mentioned in the list of vending zones were being used as parking lots and unless the civic body does not stop parking of vehicles there, they will not be able to do anything.

The president of the Rehri-Farhi Union, Punjab, Bal Krishan Pappi, said, “We have got the list of vending zones from the municipal corporation but at these locations cops are not allowing the vendors to run their business, so we met the commissioner of police in his office.” He further said they had requested him to direct the cops to allow the vendors to do their business at these sites. He also claimed that there were many locations like the underway road, Benzamin Road, the road adjoining civil hospital, etc, were being used for the parking of vehicles. He said they would meet the mayor and MC commissioner K P Brar on Tuesday about this as well. He said they would ask the authorities to stop parking of vehicles at these locations.

It was after the police and MC had conducted a joint anti-encroachment drive on 12 roads in the city that the vendors were made to vacate these locations. Following this, the vendors staged a protest and forced the civic body to announce vending zones.

Title: Rahul, Priyanka Gandhi to address four joint rallies in two days
Content:
Rahul and Priyanka Gandhi

NEW DELHi: Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi will embark on a whirlwind campaign on Tuesday, seeking votes for party candidates in the Delhi assembly elections. The duo will address four joint rallies in two days.On Tuesday, rallies will be held at Sunlight Colony in Jangpura at 2pm and near Jamia Hamdard in Sangam Vihar at 4pm. Congress has fielded Poonam Azad , wife of party’s campaign committee chief of Delhi, Kirti Jha Azad, from Sangam Vihar seat. Another two rallies will be held at Kondli (3pm) and Matia Mahal (5pm) on Wednesday.Congress functionaries have, meanwhile, claimed that the party is running “a very effective campaign, which will bring surprising election results on February 11.”Congress has promised 300 units of electricity and 20,000 litres water for free, unemployment allowance of Rs 5,000 for graduates and Rs 7,500 for postgraduates and layoff compensation up to Rs 5,000 every month. The party has also promised to open 100 Indira canteens, free Delhi Metro and bus ride for people aged above 65 and subsidised fare for women, students and senior citizens. Punjab CM Amarinder Singh, Chhattisgarh CM Bhupesh Bhagel, Congress functionary Shatrughan Sinha and several other party leaders have thrown their weight behind the party candidates.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 7,000 screened at Chennai airport, samples tested so far negative
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: More than 7,000 people, including 1,150 from China and surrounding regions, were screened for symptoms of novel Coronavirus at the city airport until Monday.

Patients are screened as per the standard screening protocol and advised 28-day home quarantine with or without blood test. Ten people have been admitted in various government hospitals across the state. Of the 1,150 in home quarantine, 319 are from Chennai, 72 from Coimbatore, 38 from Madurai and 50 from Trichy. “Blood tests and nasal/ throat swabs are taken for patients who come from Wuhan or patients showing symptoms such as cold, fever or breathing difficulty,” said health minister C Vijayabaskar. While a dozen of the 18 samples sent to the King Institute of Preventive Medicine tested negative, results of four samples being tested by the National Institute of Virology in Pune are awaited, he said.

While one patient with travel history to China was admitted to Villupuram Medical College with symptoms of the virus, a 35-year-old man, native of Needamangalam in Tiruvarur, who returned from China was admitted to Tiruvarur Medical College Hospital. The man who worked as a cook came home on January 31. “He came to the primary health centre near his house with fever, cold and cough. Doctors there referred him here,” said the medical college principal Muthukumaran. His condition is stable and test results are awaited, he said.

On Monday, health department officials held meetings with district collectors, heads of social welfare department, school and higher education department for drawing up an action plan against the virus. “Our aim is to prevent the infection in the state. We are asking schools to ensure personal and hand hygiene. All public places should be disinfected,” said director of public health Dr K Kolandaisamy. The state has also asked all schools to provide students with soap and running water. The state is also in touch with the Centre about the quarantined 53 students who returned from China, he said.

Earlier, deputy CM O Panneerselvam said hospitals and border areas were being closely monitored to prevent the spread of coronavirus in the state. Farmers of the border districts have been advised not to shake hands or talk without covering their mouth and nose, specially while sneezing or coughing.

Deputy director of health services, Trichy, Dr A Subramani said health inspectors were visiting quarantined passengers to check for symptoms of the disease. “We have asked the inspectors to bring patients showing symptoms to the hospital as per protocol. They should be given a mask and transported in an ambulance. They will be kept in an isolation ward of the medical college hospital,” Subramani said.

Title: Maharashtra: February 6 date to respond to plea of NIA
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A special UAPA court on Monday granted the state prosecution and the defence time till February 6 to file their say on the application of the National Investigation Agency (NIA) for transferring the Elgar Parishad case to the NIA court in Mumbai.Public prosecutor Ujjwala Pawar filed a plea seeking time for filing her say when the Elgar case came up for hearing before the special judge, S R Navender. She told the court to give a short date because she required time for seeking instructions of the investigation officer, assistant commissioner of police Shivaji Pawar.She also filed a copy of the letter sent by the Pune police to the office of the state director-general of police for seeking necessary instructions over transferring the investigations to the NIA.Defence lawyers Varun Kumar and Gaurav Jachak told the court that the activists lodged in the Yerawada central prison had not received the court notice till February 1, directing them to file their say on the NIA plea. After the court said the notice was sent to the jail, the lawyers submitted that they had visited the jail, but their clients had not received it. The activists also complained of not receiving the notice.After the NIA officials served copies of the notice to the eight out of the nine activists produced before the court, the lawyers complained that even they had not received copies of the notice. The judge then asked the lawyers to go through the NIA plea and notification, and file their say. Activist P Varavara Rao could not be produced before the court because he is undergoing treatment in a government hospital.Defence lawyer Shahid Akhtar argued that the activists were facing two prosecution agencies — the Pune police and the NIA — and requested the court to also provide the copies of the say filed by the investigation officer and the prosecution for enabling him to oppose the NIA plea. He also sought time to understand the procedure for transferring the case to the NIA.Responding to the submissions of the prosecution and the defence lawyers, NIA’s senior public prosecutor Namdev Taralgatti argued that his application was filed on a limited point and prayed to issue directions to the police to hand over investigations to the NIA and transfer the chargesheets among other documents to the NIA court in Mumbai.The judge advised the lawyers to file their say while making it a point to refer the NIA Act. The judge clarified that he would not defer the hearing because the legal aspects involved in deciding the NIA plea cannot be ignored.(GRAPHIC)HL: ELGAR CASE SHIFTOn January 24, the Union ministry of home affairs issued a notification for transferring the Elgar Parishad case to the NIA to unearth the pan-India conspiracy involving the banned CPI (Maoist)The NIA registered FIR against nine arrested activists and two others under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act on the same day and filed copy of the complaint before the NIA court, MumbaiIt also filed a copy of the FIR registered by the Vishrambaug police on December 31, 2017On January 29, NIA filed a miscellaneous application before the special UAPA court in Pune for transferring the case records and seized properties etc to the NIA court, Mumbai

Title: IG felicitates 14-yr-old Anjali for saving life of abducted kids
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kanpur: In a novel initiative, IG Kanpur Mohit Agarwal on Monday visited Karthia village of Farrukhabad and felicitated 14-year-old Anjali, one of those 23 children, who were abducted in Farrukhabad. She had saved the life of the abducted children by disconnecting the wire from the explosive and then closed the door from inside.

The IG also felicitated other villagers who assisted the police in saving the lives of 23 children. He also distributed gifts to all the village kids , including 23 kids, who were held hostage.

The IG said the initiative will also inspire others. “We have felicitated Anjali and other villagers with ‘Prashastra Patra’ as a token of appreciation as their heroic act will inspire others,” the IG said and added, “Little girl Anjali showed exemplary courage to save 22 kids.”

The villagers have welcomed the initiative.

The IG said he has also asked the district administration to recommend Anjali’s name for a bravery award.

Earlier, villagers of Karthia organized a grand welcome of the IG. They arranged for a band party and took out a procession across the village on Monday.

Gauri’s father Subhash Batham, who had taken 23 children hostage in Katheria village of Farrukhabad, was shot dead during the police operation on Thursday night. Her mother Ruby, too, was killed after she was assaulted by angry villagers. Subhash had invited the children on the pretext of celebrating Gauri’s birthday and held them hostage in the basement of his house.

Facing four criminal cases, Subhash had served a 12-year sentence in a 2002 murder case. He was recently in jail in a theft case and was released a few weeks ago. Police said that Subhash had plotted the hostage drama to settle scores with those he accused of framing him in the murder case.

On Sunday, UP Police has come forward to adopt their one-year-old daughter. IG Mohit Agarwal had told TOI that the police department would bear Gauri’s educational and all other expenses till she became self-reliant.

Title: Ramky enters Dubai with recovery unit
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: City-based environment management services provider Ramky Enviro Engineers Limited (REEL) on Monday announced its foray into the Dubai market with the launch of FARZ, a fully automated material recovery facility (MRF) that leverages Artificial Intelligence, in the Public Private Partnership (PPP) mode with Dubai-based Imdaad group.

Spanning an area of 45,322sq m, the MRF can process 1,200 tonnes per day of municipal as well as commercial and industrial (C&I) waste, which is nearly 13% of the total waste generated daily in Dubai, with a recovery rate of 25-30% of waste, the company said in a release.

The company also pointed out that in addition to recycling waste, FARZ will help reduce emissions caused by trucks that collect and carry waste to landfill. The MRF, touted as one of the largest fully-automated ones in the region, incorporates magnetic, optical, and ballistic separators and smart recovery technologies to segregate and reclaim valuables.

Goutham Reddy, MD, Ramky, said the MRF rollout is part of REEL’s vision of delivering sustainable solutions at scale around the world. “FARZ has the most efficient recovery rate of any materials recovery facility with two separate lines, one to deal with household waste and the other focusing on commercial and industrial waste. The innovation and launch of the Farz facility is core to our transformation into a fully integrated global circular economy company,” he said. TNN

Title: Ludhiana: Three years on, only 25,000 houses get UID plates
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

A UID plate affixed outside a house in Model Town

LUDHIANA: Almost three years are gone since the drive to install unique identity (UID) number plates had started in the city and only 6.25% of properties have been covered so far. Contrary to this, the civic body has made UID numbers compulsory in 33 blocks of the city. Now, to overcome the slow pace of installation of these plates the officials have started writing the UID numbers outside households with paint and in some areas they have done it twice as the first time the paint faded. There is no clarity as to when the procedure to install the number plates at other properties will complete.

According to Geographic Information System (GIS) survey conducted by the MC officials, there are more than 4 lakh properties in 37 blocks. The survey was conducted with the help of Punjab Remote Sensing Centre (PRSC) and it was started in 2014. First of all, the civic officials had to struggle hard in getting the complete data of the survey from the centre because they had not cleared the dues.

The installation of the number plates was proposed in 2014 but actual installation of UID number plates started from block 26 in Model Town area on June 23, 2017, and till now plates have been installed outside 25,000 houses only. Areas like Model Town, Model Gram, Shastri Nagar, Pakhowal Road, Ghumar Mandi, Gurdev Nagar, Rishi Nagar, Kitchlu Nagar, Maya Nagar, Maharaj Nagar, Sarabha Nagar, BRS Nagar, etc. have been covered as of now.

A businessman and resident of Naughara Mohalla, Tribhuvan Thapar, rued that he was not aware that UID numbers were compulsory in his block now and came to know about this when he went for depositing the property tax. He said nobody told about UID numbers when he argued, then one employee said every house had a UID number outside the house and he may not have checked it. He said, “I had to first get a UID number for the property and only then I could file my return. This is sheer wastage of time.”

Another resident from Shivpuri Ajay Walia said, “Sometime back, I had heard about the number plates but in our area nobody ever came to even inquire whether residents wanted to install these or not.” He said now people have to first go to the MC office for getting UID numbers because when civic employees wrote these numbers outside houses they did not bother to tell the owner of the house that now this number was compulsory for every work in the MC.

One of the representatives from the private company involved in the work of fixing number plates shared that when they went from door to door for collection of Rs 110 (fee for the UID plates), people did not give any response and they did not get support from the civic officials as well. He revealed that the MC officials did not support this project as they had neither advertised the same and its importance among people, nor they imposed it strictly, so people did not respond.

The superintendent of MC, Vivek Verma, said the pace of the project no doubt had remained slow but the company had been asked to increase the speed because in many blocks now the UID number was compulsory, so people would require these plates. The MC commissioner, K P Brar, admitted to the delay at the end of the company and claimed that very soon they would take some decision about this firm.

Title: Economists question Budget transparency
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PUNE: Five economic experts from different institutes on Monday flayed the Union budget for “being least transparent” and not acknowledging the economic problem that the country faced.

“The government is not able to collect the taxes it has been vwing to collect for the past three years. Yes, the overall tax collections have always been low. But at least the government was earlier able to collect the taxes it had proposed to,” National Institute of Public Finance and Policy director Rathin Roy said at the Budget discussion organized by Pune International Centre (PIC).

He added said the government has “dangerously deviated” from the fiscal consolidation path without explaining why it did so and the path it would take to come back. Roy was a part of the expert panel that had constituted the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) roadmap.

Shubhashis Gangopadhyay, research director, India Development Foundation (IDF), said that earlier people were talking about why the fiscal deficit needed to be in check and now they were saying that “we should deviate”. He said, “Five years since the announcement on doubling of farm wages, the government is still working out how this needs to be done.”

Pradeep Apte, professor, Gokhale Institute of Politics and Economics, said the government has been speaking about the electronic National Agriculture Market (e-NAM) for farmers, “yet the progress remains dismally low”. He said, “In all successive budgets, there is only a single line on e-NAM…the ease of doing business concept has always missed out on the agriculture sector.”

K L Dhingra, director of National Institute of Bank Management (NIBM), said the ease of business rankings has improved, prompting fellow panelists to ask: “Why hasn’t (private) investment come along with it?”

Dhingra said the government also did a lot of things outside the Budget and some of these, like the bankruptcy code, has helped banks contain bad loans.

The host of the event and economist Ajit Ranade said each successive Budget over the past four years has been presented at the backdrop of 1% drop in GDP over the previous years and stagnant capital formation. “While credit has collapsed to much of the industry, the banks still park Rs 3 lakh crore of excess money with the RBI every day,” he added.

Economist Vijay Kelkar said there was no acknowledgement in the budget that we are in a “major growth recession”. He said, “This is the first year, when I did not watch the Budget.”

Title: Four more arrested in TNPSC Group II-A scam
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The CB-CID on Monday arrested a policeman and three others in connection with the scam surrounding the 2017 TNPSC Group II-A exam. So far, nine people have been arrested for the 2017 scam.

A probe began after the special team of CB-CID officers probing the fraud found that as many as 42 people who appeared for the examination from the Rameswaram centre had scored high marks and joined various government departments. Earlier, in relation to the scam in the 2019 Group IV examination, the CB-CID arrested 16 people.

Investigators have found that S Jayakumar, a Chennai resident, played a key role in both the scams, and is now on the run. “We hope to nab him soon,” said an officer. His mobile phone has remained switched off. The main agent, Jayakumar collected anywhere between Rs 7 lakh and Rs 15 lakh from candidates seeking ‘high’ scores.

Of those arrested on Monday, Tirunelveli-based policeman M Muthukumar, 35, paid Rs 8 lakh to Jayakumar to help his wife clear the exam in 2017. Muthukumar’s wife Mahalakshmi bagged the 24th rank with a ‘score’ of 276 and is now an office assistant in a government department functioning out of the Ezhilagam complex in Chennai.

Another accused, P Vadivu, 44, is an assistant in the Kancheepuram registrar’s office. She had managed a rank of 29 with a score of 271.5 marks after paying Rs 12.5 lakh. The third accused, R Gnanasambandam, is an assistant in registration department’s headquarters in Chennai’s Foreshore Estate area. He secured the 54th rank after he paid Rs 15 lakh to clear the examination. The fourth accused, M Anandan, is an assistant in the registration office in the Red Hills area. He had paid Rs 13 lakh to the agent and ‘bagged’ 19th rank in the 2017 examination, a press release from the CB-CID said.

Title: Illegal portion of building razed after complaint
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: Amid strong resentment expressed by the owners of a property, municipal corporation officials razed an illegal portion of a building in Dugri here on Monday. The officials blamed the property owner for using abusive language against them and added that they would also file a police complaint against the person. A resident of area had complained against the illegal construction work after which the civic body officials took action.

A resident of the area, Sukhwinder Singh, in his complaint submitted that the land was common land and now the civic body was its owner. But Gurinder Singh by using his political influence constructed a building on this piece of land. He said now he was continuing with the construction of the third floor. He said he had complained about this encroachment in 2005 as well but the civic body officials did not take action at that time.

Meanwhile, the MC officials claimed that they had stopped the construction work earlier also but the owner started the work again on Sunday and as soon as they came to know about the ongoing work, they dismantled the same. They alleged that Gurinder tried to interrupt the drive and also used abusive language against the MC team.

However, Gurinder denied using abusive language against anybody and claimed that the complainant, Sukhwinder, was holding some old grudges against him and by giving such complaints he was trying to settle old scores with him.

Title: T to set up Blockchain focussed incubator
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana government is planning to set up a dedicated incubator for startups working in the area of Blockchain technology in partnership with some of the premiere educational institutes in the city such as IIIT-Hyderabad as well as Indian School of Business in the coming days, said a senior Telangana government official here on Monday.

“We have developed 12 use-cases wherein Blockchain technology can be used to solve some of the issues faced by citizens… in the coming days we are coming up multiple initiatives such as setting up incubator,” Rama Devi, officer on special duty (OSD), ITE&C department said on the sidelines of the launch of T-Block, an accelerator programme.

The Telangana government has joined hands with Tech Mahindra to roll out the T-Block that will nurture startups having strong blockchain use-case to scale up their operations.

The registrations for T-Block, which opened on Monday, will be followed by a one-week boot camp and a four-week training programme. The participating startups will receive mentorship and guidance from experts in the startup and blockchain space.

According to the Nasscom Avasant India Blockchain Report 2019, Indian startups have only tapped 0.2% of the investment surge in Blockchain. T-Block aims to bridge this gap and take seed and validation level startups with strong business and blockchain use cases, and get them to an investible stage.

Rajesh Dhuddu, global practice leader (Blockchain), Tech Mahindra, said that Tech M would also be open to collaborating with selected startups at a later stage.

Jayesh Ranjan, principal secretary ITE&C department said, “T-Block Accelerator will be a torch-bearer to multiple future Blockchain accelerators in the country and we are excited to partner with Tech Mahindra to identify and promote innovative Blockchain-based solutions to solve real-world problems.”

Title: Maharashtra: Brace for huge hike in water charges in Pimpri Chinchwad
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: People with residential water connections in Pimpri Chinchwad may soon have to pay twice the rate of water tax if their consumption ranges from 41-100 litres per capita per day (LPCD) and nearly 10 times the prevailing rate if usage is between 101 and 135 LPCD.A proposal in this regard has been prepared by the civic water supply department, which will come up for discussion before the standing committee on Wednesday.The proposal aims to control the overconsumption of more than 100 LPCD. “The aim behind the proposed water tax hike is to provide equitable water supply to all areas of the city. The department spends Rs 100 crore per year on water supply but only earns Rs 50 crore in revenue,” Makrand Nikam, chief of the civic water supply department, said.Besides, the water supply department is seeking approval for automatically increasing the water tax for residential consumption by 5% every year.
