A rise of Rs 2.5 per 1,000 litres is proposed for commercial properties like hotels, restaurants, shops and others. Private educational institutions, hostels, government or semi-government offices, railway stations, and others will also face marginal hike of Rs 2 per 1,000 litre.The move has failed to find favour with social activists. Maruti Bhapkar, an activist, said, “The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation must first reduce the 35-40% water losses due to leakages. Once this is done, it will negate the need to hike water tax.”

Title: Mamata Banerjee: BJP turning the country into killing fields
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chief minister Mamata Banerjee at Trinamool Chhatra Parishad’s dharna mancha on Rani Rashmoni Avenue on Monday

KOLKATA: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Monday questioned how BJP leaders holding constitutional posts were instigating people to open fire.

Speaking to reporters, she said, “I have seen the Uttar Pradesh chief minister asking to open fire. I am respectful to him, as I am also a chief minister. But how can a CM say that if you do not hear, then will open fire? Even an Union minister is saying the same words. How can they say so?”

Banerjee said whenever there are polls, BJP plays the card of hatred and divisive politics as it does not believe in development or humanity. “They are uttering words of hatred and playing communal politics during polls. They should not insult the people of Delhi,” the CM said, replying to queries related to the firing on anti-CAA protesters at Jamia University.

“The Supreme Court has also said that there can be peaceful agitations. Even in Park Circus there are agitations. If they have the guts, they should play the political card instead of indulging in vandalism. They aim to divide the country. We are also Hindus and Swamiji had stated that Hinduism is universal. We honour Bhagat Singh, who hails from Punjab, and we also honour the people of Tamil Nadu, who prefer to speak in their own language. We respect all regional languages,” she added.

“Whoever is trying to raise a question is being termed a terrorist, while they are the opportunists. They try to showcase that they are the biggest nationalists of the country. But they cannot deliver goods to the people,” Banerjee said. She added that “they are often taking to vandalism, hooliganism and goondaism, which was not the ideology of Gandhi or Tagore”.

“We our proud of our nation and they are making it killing fields. Government machinery is being used to spread hatred. We dislike it. We feel ashamed the way the country is being governed. They are turning the country into killing fields and encouraging divisive politics by using state machinery. They have no political programme and they aim at riots and goondagari. So, we will not learn politics from them. Bengal has its own culture and history and we have a long history of freedom movement.”

Banerjee said she heard the PM criticising the Delhi chief minister. “You should think of the people and trust them.” The CM added that the budget was a big zero for the people, with no roadmap for development. “The entire speech is of no value.”

Title: Hyderabad: Man held for insurance fraud
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 23-year-old man was nabbed by cyber crime police on Monday for cheating people and insurance policy holders on the pretext of providing 10% rebate on their existing premiums. The accused was identified as Vineet Singh, a resident of UP’s Baliya district.

On January 3, a person received a call from Singh, who claimed to be an agent of a private life insurance company, and was told that if she paid her premiums through nationalised banks she would get a 10% discount. Believing the accused, she deposited the money in the bank account given by Singh. But a few days later, she received a message from the insurance company that her premium was pending. When she called the customer care, she realised that she had been cheated and approached the police.

Title: Pune: Rainwater harvest tax sops after groundwater check
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The civic body will from now allow tax discounts for rainwater harvesting to properties only after checking if groundwater was recharged.A Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) official said the administration would inspect the groundwater levels near the properties getting the tax discount.He said while many properties were enjoying the discounts though the rainwater harvesting systems were lying defunct, the facility has been installed at some units “just as a formality” to enjoy the benefit.PMC commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad “We will get an exact idea about the status of the rainwater harvesting systems in the city through the inspections. If the discounts given to the ineligible properties are scrapped, it will increase the PMC’s revenue.”He said the PMC would tie up with the Groundwater Survey and Development Agency and other authorities for the inspection. The survey would include physical inspection of the systems fitted in the properties and whether the rainwater was being properly discharged into soak pits or not. The technical study of groundwater level would also be done.Gaikwad said there would be surprise checks that would cover all types of properties, including private houses, commercial buildings and housing societies.“The findings will be out in a couple of months. The new rates for properties without a proper rainwater harvesting systems will be implemented from the next financial year,” he said.The Pune District Cooperative Housing Societies Federation has welcomed the step and demanded awareness be created simultaneously. “Rainwater harvesting is important. But many societies are not doing it scientifically. Some builders have set up these systems just to get building permissions,” the federation’s chairman Suhas Patwardhan said.He said the residents should be educated about the need of rainwater harvesting. The smaller and old societies should also install rainwater harvesting systems.A PMC official said the civic body was contemplating financial help to old properties to fit such systems. The PMC’s standing committee had given a green signal to the proposal in 2019. It had stated that the societies built before 2002 would be eligible for financial aid.

Title: Maharashtra: 20 pleas against attachment of D S Kulkarni properties
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

D S Kulkarni

PUNE: Special judge Jayant Raje on Monday received 20 applications from different parties, including the Enforcement Directorate, opposing the proposed attachment of 463 movable and immovable properties worth over Rs1,500 crore of jailed developer D S Kulkarni alias DSK and his relatives in connection with the alleged economic fraud by the DSK group .

Special public prosecutor Pravin Chavan told TOI, “All the applicants have opposed the attachment of the properties. The court has directed the prosecution and the competent authority — the sub divisional officer of Vadgaon Maval — to file written submissions on February 15.”

The court will pass a common order after examining and hearing the objections and claims. Confirmation of attachment will pave the way for raising money via auction of all these properties and clearing dues payable to banks and depositors, among others.

S S Narkar, assistant director of the Enforcement Directorate (ED), Mumbai, filed an application to drop the proposed attachment of the properties seized by the ED on February 14, 2019. It read that the adjudicating authority in its order on August 5, 2019, had confirmed attachment of the properties by holding that it was involved in money laundering.

Lawyer Prakash Rajopadhye filed an application on behalf of suspect Shirish Kulkarni to stay the auction because the eight cars seized by the Pune police did not belong to his client (Shirish). His application said the cars were registered in the name of DSK Developers Private Limited and DSK Motors Limited, presently undergoing liquidation and resolution process under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.

Prosecutor Chavan said the suspect (Shirish) had no independent right to stall the auction of the properties. “The DSK companies have not filed the application,” he said.

Title: Group IV scam: New system to check malpractice in TRB exams
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: Following malpractices in Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission’s ( TNPSC ) Group IV exams in select centres, the Teachers Recruitment Board ( TRB ) has decided to allot exam centres randomly to candidates in future exams.

As per the existing system, candidates can list cities where they prefer to appear for the exams. A majority of the candidates were allotted centres in one of the preferred locations.

“Now, candidates will be intimated about districts just 10 days before the exam and they will know their exam centres just three days before the exam,” TRB said in a release on Monday.

“The move will prevent malpractices like the one that occurred in Group IV exams. Though the board has moved to computer based online test for recruitment, we want to maintain confidentiality of the exam process. Hence, the board is also planning to shuffle officials on examination duty,” an official from TRB said.

The new system will come into force for block education officers’ recruitment test scheduled to be held on February 14, 15 and 16.

Expressing concern about the feasibilty of the new system, P Rajalingam, state secretary, TET Qualified Graduate and Secondary Grade Teachers’ Association, said, “It will be difficult to identify exam centres if we get random allotment just three days before the exam. If candidates are allotted exam centres in districts faraway from their native places, they may not be able to appear for the exam.”

For example, a candidate from Tirunelveli district can write exams in Tirunelveli, Thoothukudi and Virudhunagar districts. But, if allotted a centre in Erode or Coimbatore, travelling there will take longer and most candidates cannot afford an extra day’s accommodation in the new town, he added.

“The move will help prevent malpractices. But, women candidates and differently abled candidates will face issues if they are allotted exam centres in other districts,” said J Robert, general secretary of Secondary Grade Seniority Teachers Association.

Some candidates also demanded the board to release full details of selected candidates, including their marks, caste and exam centres, after the exam to bring transparency.

In TNPSC’s Group IV exam, brokers had asked the candidates involved in the scam to pick Rameswaram and Keelakarai in Ramanathapuram district as exam centres. They were then given special pens with evaporating ink and later, correct answers were shaded in the answer scripts in collusion with a TNPSC official. Of the top 100 rank holders, 39 were from these two centres, shedding light on the scam. Police have so far arrested 16 people in connection with the scam.

Title: Traders protest Boulevard street construction
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bhopal: Affected by smart city development, some of the city traders raised black flags and shouted slogans here on Monday. They allege that the master plan was not followed during construction of smart city road — a claimed denied by Bhopal Smart City Development Corporation Limited in a press release on Monday.

Traders and displaced vendors protested over the construction of Boulevard Street, a Bhopal smart city project. Due to road widening, street vendors were displaced during anti-encroachment operation carried out by BSCDCL last month. Affected traders and vendors are now threatening to carry out a stir until the project is stopped.

BSCDCL press release, however, clarified that road widening is taking place for development of only Boulevard street; the drive has been undertaken by the corporation. This road widening is limited to only Jawahar Chowk. BSCDCL release mentioned that rumours are being spread that widening of about 10-metres of the road from Jawahar Chowk to Roshanpura would also take place. BSCDCL said it is not a project undertaken by the corporation. The road widening is proposed for development of Bhopal metro development and is not part of BSCDCL.

Sources said road construction was affected for some time during the vendors’ protest on Monday. According to smart city officials, 147 vendors have been relocated after the displacement. The recent protests come in the backdrop of halted work at road connecting Polytechnic to Bhadbhada. The twin projects are estimated at over Rs 80 crore. Polytechnic smart road is delayed by over two years. Boulevard street, of which about 300 metre remains incomplete, is also delayed by over a year.

Title: Coronavirus Hyderabad: Osmania University makes nCoV tests mandatory for Chinese students
Content:
Osmania University

SECUNDERABAD: With coronavirus spreading its tentacles in India, Osmania University (OU) has asked students from China, many returning from vacation after the Chinese New Year or seeking admission for the 2020-21 academic year, to undergo mandatory screening tests either at Gandhi Hospital or Fever Hospital.Currently, there are 26 Chinese students pursuing courses, including B.Com, MBA and law, in Osmania University and its affiliated colleges. Of them, a few students went home in January. Following the outbreak of novel coronavirus (nCoV), the university issued an advisory.“Any student with symptoms of coronavirus is advised to visit Gandhi or Fever Hospital as they have special isolation units and screening kits. Any Chinese student visiting India/Osmania University for admission is advised to undergo the screening test mentioned above so as to avoid communication of this disease,” the Osmania University said in an advisory issued to all foreign students. The university has also restricted the Chinese students from visiting their country in the immediate future.However, a few Chinese students, pursuing courses at Nizam College, are worried over their return to the country. A BCom student of Nizam College, who returned to New Delhi on February 2, has been asked to stay put in the capital for the next two weeks. “As per schedule, I returned to India on February 2. However, I has been asked not to travel to Hyderabad for the next two weeks and self-report if I develop any symptoms of coronavirus,” a student of Nizam College, who has been living in Hyderabad for the last six years, told TOI.Many Chinese students, who skipped the annual holiday to their country, fear spreading of the virus following return of their friends after the vacation. “I have a friend who had to cancel the ticket as he was unable to come back following coronavirus outbreak. There are many others who have to undergo screening even after they return,” a Chinese student, pursuing sociology at Osmania University, said.The varsity has also decided to put in place measures for Chinese students. “If students are unable to return on time, we will hold special classes and ensure their academic schedule is not affected,” Osmania University foreign relations officer Prof GB Reddy said.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: 800 passengers being screened for coronavirus at Hyderabad airport daily
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose. (Photo: AP)

HYDERABAD: Scaling up of the thermal screening system for novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) has helped health officials cover flights arriving from Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, and Thailand apart from China. They are able to screen as many as 800 passengers daily.One new suspected case of coronavirus was reported in the city on Monday, while reports of 19 suspected cases out of 28 have been confirmed negative.The state health department has also issued orders to increase surveillance testing of all passengers who have arrived from Wuhan since January 15. Also, any passenger with a travel history to other parts of China and coronavirus-affected countries or showing symptoms of the virus will be tested.“In Telangana, 2,733 travellers have been screened at Shamshabad airport so far and 27 passengers are under home quarantine for the past 28 days. One passenger admitted at Nallakunta and another admitted at Gandhi hospital are currently under observation in isolation wards. Till now, 19 samples have been taken from passengers and sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, and all were found to be negative. All passengers under observation in homes and hospitals are stable,” said a medical bulletin by the state health department.In a detailed memo issued by the state government late in the day, officials were asked to trace all passengers who have arrived from Wuhan since January 15, quarantined and tested for the virus even if they do not have any symptoms. “Even if their tests are negative they are to be kept in quarantine for another 14 days. Passengers who have arrived from other parts of China and affected countries too have to be followed up,” said the memo. Also, it was decided to do contact tracing (test all immediate family contacts) of all suspected cases.Meanwhile, state health minister Etela Rajender inspected the ICMR laboratory of Gandhi Medical College before operations began. He visited other state-run hospitals to review the preparedness and facilities to deal with a possible outbreak.

Title: Parking fee row: Transgenders back Sanjay Place traders’ protest against AMC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

AGRA: A group of transgenders on Monday came out in support of the traders of Sanjay Place who have been staging a protest for the past 21 days against Agra Municipal Corporation ( AMC ) administration for levying parking fee in the market.

Raising slogans and singing songs as a mark of protest against the civic body administration, a team of five transgenders declared that they would deal with the mayor, Naveen Jain , “in their own way” if the demands of the traders were not fulfilled.

Transgender Kajal Rathore said, “We are committed to supporting traders in every possible way. The AMC administration will not be allowed to exploit them. We will not let the parking mafia operate in Sanjay Place.”

On January 14, traders in Sanjay Place launched a protest against AMC administration for charging a parking fee at 38 places in the market. They claimed that it violates norms as they had already paid a fee for parking at the time of purchasing the property.

Secretary of Sanjay Place Market Association Heeren Agarwal , said, “The AMC administration is trying to exploit traders by illegally charging the parking fee. We have already paid for the parking space. To muzzle the voice of traders, a fake FIR has been registered. We will continue our fight against the parking mafia backed by the mayor.”

The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) is sub judice. The traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final order in the matter.

Association’s treasurer Vinay Mittal alleged that despite the ongoing case at the sessions court, the AMC administration had issued parking contracts for three years to “people associated with BJP”. “AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected from the market. We will not withdraw our protest till the AMC rolls back its decision,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: Four detained for firing at businessman over old enmity
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Tension gripped Tukainagar in Vadgaon Budruk on Monday afternoon, after the owner of a car wash and repair centre was fired upon. Later in the day, the Sinhagad Road police detained four of the six involved in the incident.

The suspects also damaged windshields of three cars parked at the spot, police said. Pandurang Khandu More (42) of Narhe, who escaped with no injuries, lodged a complaint with the police.

Police said all four detained were members of a local gang run by one Bunty Pawar, who has a criminal record of robbery, extortion and other body offences. Police said the suspects believed that More was a police informant.

According to the complaint, More arrived at his service centre at 2.20pm and was standing in front of it, when the six suspects came there on motorcycles. Five were armed with sharp weapons, while one brandished a firearm.

The person with the gun abused More and shot at him. More managed to duck in time. The bullet pierced the service centre’s tin enclosure. The other five men then charged at him, police said.

The complainant managed to give them the slip. “Enraged, the suspects damaged cars parked nearby,” police said. They have been booked under the charge of attempt to murder and relevant sections of the Indian Arms Act.

Title: Rajasthan liquor ban key demand of SC & ST communities
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

JAIPUR: The Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe communities in Rajasthan will organise a ‘ Nyay Sabha ’ on February 5 during which they will ask the government to ban liquor among other demands.

The other demands include reservation for SC/ST in private sector, timely release of compensation for those who are victims of atrocities, setting up of Indian Judicial Services and making provision for SCs and STs in the service.

The conference will be organised under the banner ‘SC/ST Samajik Sangathano Ki Nyay Sabha’.

“Consumption of liquor should be prohibited in Rajasthan for social uplift of SCs and STs as people belonging to these communities are the worst victims of it,” said B L Bhati, national general secretary of Rashtriya Meghwal Samaj Sangh .

“The victims of atrocities are supposed to receive 25% of the total compensation within seven days of registering an FIR, but they seldom get that. This is also one of the main issues. Despite bringing the SC/ST Prevention of Atrocities Act, it is not being implemented properly,” he added.

Bhati further said, “The state government recruits a lot of employees on contractual basis, but there is no provision for giving jobs to SCs and STs. There are about 2 lakh contractual workers in Rajasthan, but there is no reservation for SCs and STs in it.”

“Moreover, the reservation for the SCs and STs is proportional to their current population. They are still being given reservation as per 1971 census. They revised this provision for the MLAs and MPs, but they should do it for the service holders as well. The lands of SC and STs captured by the upper castes should be freed by the government. Scholarships to the SC/ST students should be provided timely,” he added.

Title: Chopper vandaliser behaves like unstable man, salutes cops
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

State hangar

Bhopal: A day after Gandhi Nagar police arrested a 22-year-old youth for trespassing at Raja Bhoj Airport and vandalising a chopper, cops on Monday produced him before the court from where he was sent on police remand for five days. The accused entered the airport through state hangar gate, posing as an under training CISF commando. The on-duty security guard of special armed forces took him to be a cop and allowed entry.

Acting on a complaint filed by chief security officer of Raja Bhoj Airport, Vinod Soni, Gandhi Nagar police registered a case against the accused Yogesh Tripathi, a resident of 1100-Quarters, Arera Colony. Yogesh is pursuing BCA final year at a private college in Kolar.

Police sources said that the accused behaved like an unstable man in police custody and shouted, ‘Jai Hind’, Jai Shri Ram, Jai Mata Di with a salute to each and every police officer, who came to interrogate him. He told the cops that he had done a course in NCC. Senior officers of district police, crime branch and intelligence are interrogating him.

When the cops asked him questions, he gave bizarre answers. He said his name is blue sky, he is a bird and so on. A police officer, requesting anonymity, said that when Yogesh's father Vishwamohan Tripathi gave him green peas to eat, he ate them without pealing them. The father told police that Yogesh is quite religious. He has two sisters. His eldest sister resides in South Africa while the younger one is pursuing MCA at a Pune college. Yogesh's friends also reached Gandhi Nagar police station to meet him, but he refused to identify them. In the evening when Yogesh was tired, he sat quietly as if he was meditating, informed the sources.

Interestingly, the accused has been associated with a theatre group also and wants to take part in TV reality shows. When he entered the state hangar, his appearance was like that of a soldier. He had given himself a military haircut and was wearing camouflage trousers; it was his appearance that helped him gain entry at the airport .

Title: Infosys techie murder trial to start today
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The trial in the Infosys techie Rasila Raju murder case will begin before the court of additional sessions judge R M Malwankar on Tuesday.

Bhaben Bharali Saikia, a security guard, stands accused of murdering 24-year-old Rasila on January 29, 2017. He has been charged under sections 302 (murder) and 201 (attempt to destroy evidence), among others, of the Indian Penal Code.

“The state prosecution is expected to record the evidence of the complainant and another witness on the first day of the hearing. The prosecution has provided a list of the witnesses to the defence and we will cross-examine them,” defence lawyer Biju Aloor told TOI.

Special public prosecutor Ujjwal Nikam told TOI, “I may not record evidence of the witnesses because I have to reach the district and sessions court at Sangli.”

Title: Anti CAA Protest in Mumbai: No CAA, NRC in Maharashtra, home minister assures ‘Mumbai Bagh’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Armed police teams conducted flag marches across several localities like Bandra, Sakinaka, Jogeshwari and Gore... Read More

MUMBAI: Even as Mumbai police on Monday carried out flag marches in parts of the city to show they were in control of the law and order situation , the Maharashtra government tried to persuade the organisers of the anti-CAA stir at Mumbai Central’s Mordell Road to withdraw their eight-day-long agitation.

State home minister Anil Deshmukh of NCP requested a delegation of ‘Mumbai Bagh’ representatives that they should take back their protest as it did not have any permission. He also gave them a written assurance that not a single citizen of the state would lose citizenship. “I have requested them to take back their protest as they have been sitting there for eight days without any permission. Also, I have said this multiple times that CAA and NRC will not be implemented in the state and not a single citizen of Maharashtra will have to lose citizenship,” he said.

The government has also assured the protesters it will not file any cases against them if they move out. The Nagpada police in the past week had issued notices under the preventive Section 149 of the Criminal Procedure Code to seven persons, all locals, warning them that if any untoward incidents took place, they would be booked.

A delegation of former and present MLAs and women representatives of the protestors met the minister on Monday after certain issues cropped up at the protest site from Saturday. Police had on Saturday tried to get the group to withdraw, without any success.

Former MLA Waris Pathan said they had asked Deshmukh to take back the notices issued to eight persons. “We will meet the core committee of the protestors and take a unanimous decision about the next step,” Pathan said. He said a decision on the manner in which the protest has to be taken back or if it can be shifted to another location would be taken in a meeting scheduled at night at the protest site outside Arabia hotel in Mumbai Central.

The women who form the core committee of the protest were closeted in a meeting on Monday night to determine their next course of action. However, the men backing the agitation said they had no plans of winding up the stir or of moving it elsewhere, and demonstrators at the site staged their sit-in well into the night.

Samajwadi Party MLA from Bhiwandi Rais Shaikh, who was also part of the delegation, said they did not want anyone to take advantage of the protest and the situation at the site, so an appropriate decision would be taken.

For their part, Mumbai police began preparing themselves for the worst by conducting flag marches in various parts of the city, which will be repeated on Tuesday. Police also revised and updated their Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for communal riots. Former IPS officers said they do not remember such an occurrence since the Mumbai riots of 1992-93. Routine flag marches are carried out before elections or prominent events. But seldom do police anticipate communal riots to break out at such times.

Monday’s flag marches came hot on the heels of violence in JNU and firing outside Jamia Milia Islamia University in Delhi and at Shaheen Bagh. The protests going on at Govandi, Madanpura and Mumbai police have prompted Mumbai police to take the preventive step, sources said.

Police remained tightlipped when asked if there was any high alert or anticipation of any untoward incident in the backdrop of anti-CAA-NRC protests at Nagpada and Deonar. “Anything can happen. We are preparing for the worst,” said an officer. “The march was carried out at the level of local police stations across the city for peace. The idea is to show visible police presence and prevent any untoward incident, particularly in sensitive pockets,” Mumbai police spokesperson, DCP Pranay Ashok said. Meanwhile, Nagpada police have deployed two CCTV vans at both ends of the ‘Mumbai Bagh’ protest to capture images from all directions. The cameras are linked to the server at the police control room.

A flag march resembles patrolling by armymen in full gear in an area where curfew has been imposed. The objective is to show presence of forces in the area in order to prevent a law and order situation.

Former Mumbai police commissioner D Sivanandhan said, “I had heard about police flag marches only during December 1992-January 1993 after the Babri Masjid demolition.”

Former Navi Mumbai commissioner KL Prasad said, “I have never heard any such flag march during the last decade in Mumbai. Even after 26/11, no flag march was carried out. The march is carried out for reassurance and to restore confidence among people who are scared of untoward incidents. Secondly, the idea is to spread fear in the minds of miscreants.”

IPS officer-turned lawyer YP Singh said, “The march could be in anticipation of any volatile situation.”

In the western suburbs, police from Bandra, D N Nagar, Meghwadi, Nirmal Nagar, Oshiwara, Sahar and Sakinaka carried out marches in vulnerable pockets on Monday. “We got instructions from the police commissioner’s office to conduct the march. It was carried out for an hour from 11.15am to 12.15pm,” an officer said.

In Mumbai North, flag marches were conducted at 5 to 6 locations including Aarey Colony, Goregaon East, Malwani etc. “The revised and updated SOP mentions what should be the line of action if a communal riot breaks out,” said Dilip Sawant, additional commissioner, north region.

(Inputs by Bella Jaisinghani, S Ahmed Ali and Mateen Hafeez)

Title: To relief of homebuyers, TNRERA restrains sale of under-construction plot
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: In an order that protects homebuyers ’ rights over the land of an incomplete housing project, the Tamil Nadu Real Estate Regulatory Authority ( TNRERA ) has restrained the registration department from facilitating any deed over the property . The issue pertains to an apartment complex at Pudupakkam on Vandalur — Kelambakkam High Road on the outskirts of the city, for which two landlords gave Power of Attorney to a developer but withdrew it later over delay in completing construction.

The complaint filed by Padmalaya Apartments Buyers’ Association said ABC (India) International, a partnership firm, was the owner of the land parcel developed by Real Value Promoters Pvt. Ltd. According to the complainants, the landlords executed a deed of General Power of Attorney in favour of developer in 2011. The construction work did not reach 40% despite the homebuyers paying substantial money towards the project nor was the proportionate undivided share in the land conveyed to the buyers, the petitioners alleged.

Meanwhile, the partnership firm in 2019 issued a notice to the promoter intimating about the cancellation of Power of Attorney on various grounds including undue delay in construction. Terming the cancellation of Power of Attorney illegal, the homebuyers said they were also stakeholders of the property. “In view of the cancellation, there is ample chance of disposal of the property. If they are allowed to proceed further in this regard, it would cause grave, irreparable prejudice and hardship to homebuyers,” the complainants said.

In the order delivered by TNRERA on Thursday, the realty regulator restrained the partnership firm from selling, mortgaging, leasing or parting with the physical possession of the property. “Further, considering the urgency and plight of the homebuyers, the authority directs the concerned sub-registrar office not to register the property until further orders,” it added.

Title: Recruiting faculty with fake certificates to cost JNTU dearly
Content:
Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: Beginning the new academic year, recruiting faculty without verifying the genuineness of their certificate, might cost a college management dearly. As per the draft Affiliation Procedure and Regulations released by the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad ( JNTU H), for 2020-21, colleges can even lose their course recognition or affiliation for recruiting ‘fake faculty’.The varsity has made managements solely responsible for appointing faculty with fraudulent or unrecognised degree certificates and said that this can be reason enough for initiating punitive action against any college. “Punitive action can include rejection/suspension/withdrawal of grant of affiliation,” read the draft affiliation rules.Reacting to this norm, college managements said JNTU must put in place a mechanism to verify certificates, instead of putting the onus on colleges. “When candidates mention that they completed their PhD from some obscure college in Rajasthan or Chhattisgarh, we are very careful as these colleges have a reputation for issuing fake certificates. But in the recent past, we even come across candidates who have furnished fake certificates from institutes like IITs or other reputed colleges. There is no way we can verify the genuineness of these certificates,” said K Ramadas, convener, Telangana Private Colleges Managements Association adding that JNTU should take the responsibility of verifying such gaps.

Title: New B tech course at some JNTU colleges
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: New B Tech courses-- Artificial Intelligence, Computer Science & Information Technology, Computer Science & Business Systems, Information Technology and Engineering — will be introduced from the academic year 2020-21across some top colleges affiliated to the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad ( JNTU H).

“Before permitting colleges to introduce these courses, we will evaluate their facilities, admissions, placements, among other criteria. Only if we the varsity feels that the colleges if fit to offer the course, we will accept their request,” said A Govardhan, rector and registrar (in charge) of JNTU-H.

The varsity also said that prior permission from the state government is mandatory for it to start a new course, increase its intake or change site or location of the existing college or institute,.

While no new courses will be implemented in M Tech, four courses will be implemented in M Pharmacy. Pharmacy Practice, Pharmaceutical Analysis, Pharmaceutical Regulatory Affairs , and Pharmaceutical Quality Assurance will be introduced at the post-graduation level from the academic year 2020-21.

The varsity has also decided to discontinue P Pharma in Hospital and Clinical Pharmacy, Pharmaceutical analysis, Pharmaceutical management and regulatory affairs, and quality assurance from the new academic year.

“The grant of approval by the relevant statutory bodies does not automatically entitle the institutions for the grant of affiliation for the same intake, but is subject to the satisfaction of the university that all the parameters for grant of affiliation are fulfilled by the institution,” read the draft Affiliation Procedure and Regulations released by the varsity.

Title: Pune: Violation of traffic norms costs two lives
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 27-year-old helmetless scooterist died on Sunday morning coming under the wheels of a PMPML bus after he fell on the road following a collision with a scooter just after crossing the Bund Garden bridge.The Yerawada police identified the deceased scooter rider as Akash Krishna Pillai of the Queens Garden area. A case of rash and negligent driving was filed against the PMPML bus driver after Pillai’s father, Krishna (45), lodged a complaint with the Yerawada police.The bus driver did not stop at the accident spot and sped away. The police are trying to track down the PMPML bus and the two-wheeler rider involved in the accident.Sub-inspector S R Karpe of the Yerawada police said, “Pillai was heading towards Yerawada from the Queens Garden area around 10.30pm. Just after crossing the bridge, a two-wheeler rider collided against Pillai’s scooter and the latter fell on the road.”The driver of the PMPML bus trailing Pillai’s scooter failed to apply sudden brakes after the victim fell on the road, Karpe said. He came under the front wheel of the bus, he said.Pillai was a painter and worked for a private contractor, he said.

Title: Collector suspends official
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

JAIPUR: District collector Joga Ram on Monday suspended Bhawani Singh , inspector of land records in Harmada (tehsil Amber), for negligence towards his duty and on issues related to integrity.

Another patwari of Amarpura village in Chomu tehsil, Sagarmal Jat, has been issued awaiting posting order (APO), for administrative reasons, till further orders.

Title: Chennai: Plea opposes anti-CAA protests in educational institutes
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madras high court

CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Monday ordered notice to the Centre and state governments on a PIL seeking to prohibit students from resorting to anti-CAA protests and dharnas inside schools , colleges and universities.

A division bench of Justice M Sathyanarayanan and Justice R Hemalatha passed the order on the plea moved by R Varaaki.

According to the petitioner, though the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) has been passed by both the houses of the Parliament and approved by the President, agitations are ongoing across the country, causing law and order situation.

“It is unfortunate that the student community, which is supposed to set an example of development of the country, has fallen prey to certain organisations backing the protests,” the petitioner said.

He further alleged that organisations including All Tamil Nadu Students Association (ATSA), Ambedkar Periyar Study Circle (APSC), and Students Federation of India(SFI) are backing such protests inside educational institutions affecting the day-to-day activities of such institutions.

Title: They defeated cancer, but could not defeat myths
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: When this 35-year-old teacher (name withheld) was diagnosed with breast cancer two years ago, she was devastated like any other person. But she took heart when her husband, a professor in a renowned college, supported her in fighting the disease. He used to take great care of her during the six-months of chemotherapy and radiation cycles.

She endured the painful treatment helped by rediscovery of her husband’s love. She emerged victorious and was the happiest woman with a caring husband and thinking of a new life ahead. But, what welcomed her when she reached home was a bunch of divorce papers.

“My husband requested me with folded hands to sign them. He said he did his duty as a husband in the last six months. In return, he was asking me to free him from this relationship. He said it was not possible for him anymore to see his wife in me,” she said.

Many women like her who have won their battle against cancer have lost their families, marriages and are suffering from psychological problems due to stigma prevailing even among the educated.

Cancer is second most common non-communicable disease (NCD) after cardiovascular diseases. Health community concentrates on early detection and treatment of cancer. But experts hardly speak about its after-effects.

Cancer counsellor at Nagpur’s RST Hospital Manjiri Joshi said after-effects were often neglected. “A 27-year-old cancer survivor is fighting a divorce case in court. Her husband and in-laws don’t want her to be a part of their family. As she is not agreeing to divorce, her husband once even tried to kill her in court premises,” she said. As cancer cannot be the ground for divorce, in-laws have levelled many derogatory allegations against such women in courts which is even more painful for them, Joshi added.

On the eve of World Cancer Day, three women cancer survivors undergoing psychological rehabilitation treatment spoke about their trauma to TOI. An art graduate in her mid-30s said she was thrown out of the house on the night her breast cancer reports came positive. Joshi said many of these women went into depression due to such behaviour of family members.

“These are some extreme cases. In many families though, relatives either start giving special treatment or neglecting cancer survivors which makes them lonely and isolated. The need is to educate family-members as well,” she said.

This phenomenon is not restricted to India. according to figures from Macmillan Cancer Support, one in seven relationships break down after a cancer diagnosis.

Title: Path cleared for Shapoorji Pallonji firm to work on south Mumbai’s priciest SRA project
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The vast slum sprawl at Cuffe Parade

MUMBAI: Three years after the SC paved the way for authorities to approve one of the most valuable slum redevelopment projects at Cuffe Parade in south Mumbai , the apex grievance redressal committee under the Slums Act on Monday upheld the initial permissions granted to real estate giant Shapoorji Pallonji ’s wholly owned subsidiary, Precaution Properties Pvt Ltd, in 2017.

The project on a 28-acre sprawl south of the World Trade Centre—subject to further approvals for plans and commencement certificate from SRA—will mark the launch of Mumbai’s most valuable slum rehabilitation in recent times. There are over 6,000 hutments and 45,000 slumdwellers estimated to reside in the densely packed slum.

Under the project, the developer has to pay 25% of the ready reckoner value as land premium to the state. It is estimated to work out to in excess of Rs 1,100 crore, said the developer’s lawyer Cherag Balsara.

The letter of intent (LOI) of November 2017 issued to the developer put the eligible hutments for rehabilitation at 2,670 in the slums of Ganesh Murti Nagar, Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Nagar and Colaba Rajjak to the south of the World Trade Centre on Sadhu D L Vasvani Marg at Cuffe Parade.

In 2018, developer Dyna Estate Pvt Ltd through its director Naveed Siddiqui and Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Nagar Cooperative Housing Society spread over 7,000 metres (under two acres) had filed an application before the apex grievance redressal committee to challenge the acceptance of a proposal by Precaution Properties in 2013 to implement the SRA project and the letter of intent in November 2017 to the Shapoorji Group company as being “illegal.’’

The committee was originally appointed under the orders of the Bombay HC to address grievances of slumdwellers and builders against planning authorities such as Slum rehabilitation authority (SRA), Maharashtra Housing and Area Development Authority (MHADA), civic body and MMRDA. It was later brought under the Slum Act.

The company claims to have 84% support of the eligible slumdwellers. The land belongs to the state government, says the LOI.

The Shapoorji Pallonji group said its proposal was pending since 2012. The lawyers for Dyna and the Slum society, Mayur Khandeparkar and Arun Panicker, argued that the LOI was “illegal’’ and granted without the requisite 70% consent of slumdwellers and cited several other grounds including reduction in number of slum dwellers and lack of survey by the authority. Balsara who appeared for Precaution, refuted the allegations and questioned the other developer’s locus to be heard when he said the matter had already traversed all the way to the Supreme Court earlier.

The committee had in February 2018 observed that there was no case made out for any interim relief to Dyna Estate but noted there was an urgency and hence it “requested the CEO of SRA to scrutinize and submit a factual report on the Slum scheme within a month.’’

Two years later, the committee headed by Sanjay Kumar, additional chief secretary of the state housing department, dismissed the applications finding “no substance’’ in them. It also dismissed another application filed by Prashant Ghadge, president of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Nagar CHS and Shree Ganesh Murti Nagar. The committee also had as its members Deepak Kapoor, chief executive officer SRA; Milind Mhaiskar, ex vice-president of Mhada; A Jarhad, additional municipal commissioner; and Sanjay Khandare, additional commissioner, MMRDA (who was absent).

The project has had a chequered history with another developer having taken the dispute with Precaution Properties to the apex court in 2013 where an order was passed in 2017. The committee was of the view that the “bona fides of Precaution Properties is clear from the records with which it prosecuted the matters before the Supreme Court…’’ and the committee said it did not concur with a report of the SRA, CEO submitted in December 2018, before it.

Panicker, when contacted, said, “We will study the order and consider challenging it.’’

Title: Facelift for Sanganer Airport to handle international flights
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Civil work at the Sanganer Airport is on and authorities plan to provide international-standard facilities

JAIPUR: With the increasing congestion and passenger load at terminal 2 of the Jaipur airport , the Airports Authority of India ( AAI ) is planning to utilise the Sanganer airport for handling international flights.

By July, the Pink City is likely to have separate airports — terminal 2 and Sanganer airport, to handle the domestic and international flights. Civil work at the Sanganer airport is on and authorities claim to cater to international-standard facilities. Also, the airport authorities have written to the Jaipur Development Authority ( JDA ) for the extension of the road in front of Sanganer airport to have smooth traffic for international passengers landing in the city.

Authorities close to the development at the Jaipur airport on TOI said the civil work at the Sanganer airport is in progress and the airport is going to get a facelift.

“We are aiming at completing the work by April so that we may further apply for various clearances and commissioning from the Director General of Civil Aviation (DGCA). We are handling 72 flights per day and by December we had handled at least 4.75 lakh passengers. Thus, we had aimed for the bifurcation of domestic and international flight operations,” said Jaideep Singh Balhara on Monday.

Sanganer airport, which had an area of 5,000 square metres will have an area of 11,750 square metres and 10 check-in counters, eight immigration counters, divyang-friendly, two boarding gates and other passenger amenities. “The use of two airports for separate flights will also enable us to handle more flights as we may have more than 100 flights operating from the two airports in total after the opening of the Sanganer airport,” said a senior officer of civil engineering wing of the Jaipur airport.

The AAI officials are also in touch with the Jaipur Development Authority to plan the expansion of the road in front of the Sanganer airport. “The width of the road needs to be increased and we are in touch with JDA and other departments so that international tourists coming to the city get smooth traffic,” said an officer.

Title: Speeding motorcyclist crashes into public transport vehicle head-on, dies
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The bus driver immediately stopped his bus after the collision but could not save the youth

PUNE: The thrill of overtaking vehicles at high speed cost a helmetless motorcycle-borne man his life on Sunday noon.

The 24-year-old milk supplier, Akash Vidhate of Baner, was killed after his speeding motorcycle collided head-on against the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) bus on the busy Tilak Road after he lost control of his vehicle following an attempt to overtake an autorickshaw.

“Vidhate was speeding on his motorcycle on Tilak Road towards Swargate. He first hit the rear portion of an autorickshaw in an attempt to overtake it. After the collision, he lost control of his vehicle and skidded for a few metres before colliding against the PMPML bus coming from the opposite direction near Durvankur Hotel on Tilak Road. The bus driver immediately stopped his bus after the collision but could not save the youth,” an officer from the Vishrambaug police said.

Eyewitnesses rushed Vidhate to a nearby hospital, but he was declared dead on arrival.

The autorickshaw driver, Arun Kadam (45), who was hit by the motorcycle lodged a complaint with the Vishrambaug police.

“A CCTV camera of a shop on Tilak Road recorded the entire accident. A case of rash and negligent driving under different sections of the Motor Vehicle Act (MVA) and the Indian Penal Code (IPC) was lodged against the deceased,” the officer said.

Title: State, ICMR Bangalore to ink pact for cancer registry
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: Soon, each and every case of cancer will be registered in the state as the health department is planning to sign an MoU with Indian Council of Medical Research ( ICMR ), Bangalore, which will provide a software to the health department to register each case of cancer along with other details such as part of body, stage of cancer at the time of diagnoses.

Cancer has emerged as one of the non-communicable diseases, which has attracted attention of the health authorities. The state-of-the-art government’s cancer hospital is all set to get inaugurated.

At a time when studies suggest that 70% of cancer cases are diagnosed at an advanced stage, the state government does not have the actual figures of cancer cases and actual burden of disease in the state.

In the state, there are only six hospitals including government and private, which have their own hospital-based registry of cancer. However, the health department is planning to prepare a population-based registry to find out the actual burden of different kinds of cancers in the state, said a health department official.

The health department has no details of the actual number of patients suffering from different kinds of cancers such as cervical, gall bladder, oral, head and neck, lung, stomach, colorectal, and oesophagus whereas in females, breast cancer, cervix cancer and ovarian cancer in the state. With the new cancer registry, the health department will be able to find out the actual number of patients of each kind of cancer in the state.

The official said that cancer has been declared a notifiable disease but as they want a paperless registry (online registry), they are taking the help of ICMR, Bangalore.

All those patients, tested positive for cancer through histopathological examination will get registered. The health department is planning to get the details of all the cancer patients online from hospitals who are diagnosed with cancer through histopathological examination to find the actual burden of the disease, which would help in preparing policies for benefitting cancer patients in future.

Talking about the prevalence of cancer in the country, Dr Divesh Goyal , senior consultant, medical oncology , of a private hospital, said, “Eighty per cent people in the country consult with a doctor when recovery is difficult, also 71% death caused at the age of 32-69 years. Due to late detection of cancer 70% of the people die in the first year, whereas 15% die because of lifestyle factors, obesity and tobacco use, and other 15% cancers in minors.”

Title: Quotas strip office-bearers of seats
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: The draw held to fix category of wards on Monday did not bring good news for many office-bearers in the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) including the mayor, deputy mayor, standing committee chair and former deputy mayor. These bigwigs have already started looking for other wards for themselves.

Over the past five years, the office-bearers have tried to ensure maximum development in their respective election wards — to solidify their re-elected chances. However, their aspirations received a jolt with the ward reservations.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele’s current ward of Itkheda has now been reserved for women (general). This means Ghodele cannot contest from Itkheda. It is being speculated that Ghodele may field a woman family member from the ward.

Rajendra Janjal, who was elected deputy mayor in December, has lost his existing Shivaji Nagar ward to SC reservation. When asked about his future strategy, Janjal said, “I am also an office-bearer of Yuva Sena, the Shiv Sena’s youth wing. So, even if I do not contest, I can work for the party’s seats,” he said.

The Jawahar Colony ward, from where standing committee chairperson Jaishree Kulkarni is a corporator, has now been reserved for the backward class of citizens (BCC). Vijay Autade, who had quit the post of deputy mayor in December, had also suffered due to the reservations allotted to wards. His current ward of Mayur Park got SC-women reservation. AMC House leader Vikas Jain cannot contest from Vedant Nagar as it has been kept for women (general.

Title: Official transferred after Gwalior coronavirus suspect was sent home
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: The civil surgeon of Gwalior district hospital was transferred on Monday, three days after a suspected coronavirus patient was asked by doctors at the hospital to go home.Gwalior chief medical and health officer Dr Mridul Saxena confirmed that the civil surgeon has been shifted but didn’t give any reason. “Dr KD Sharma has been made civil surgeon in place of Dr BK Gupta. The orders have been given by higher-ups and I am not aware of the reasons,” Saxena told TOI. When TOI contacted Dr Gupta for comment, he only said, “I am no longer the civil surgeon.”The patient had returned from China a fortnight ago and went on his own to Gwalior hospital OPD on reading news reports about the coronavirus risk. Only a day earlier, health minister Tulsiram Silawat had ordered a statewide alert on coronavirus, but doctors at the Gwalior OPD prescribed some medicines and asked the patient to come back after two daysStill anxious, the patient went to another government hospital, Jai Arogya, and then returned home. He was traced later in the night, after senior officials came to know about the incident and sought clarification from the OPD doctors.The Gwalior CMHO said the suspected coronavirus patient was brought to hospital. “He is under quarantine and in observation. He is stable. Samples have been sent for laboratory tests,” he said.

Title: 20k birds sighted in 2-day Haiderpur Wetland bird festival
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bijnor: Close to 20,000 birds were counted during the two-day bird festival organized at Haiderpur Wetland. Besides, 267 species were also identified. Apart from the birds, swamp deer and otters were also spotted in wetland areas. Bird watchers from Delhi, NCR and nearby districts participated in identifying various avian species and in the bird census.

Last year, as many as 238 bird species were sighted in Bijnor and neighbouring wetland areas. Of the total bird species, 96 were migratory birds and 139 were resident birds. This time, said officials, more than 20,000 birds were counted comprising 267 species, 29 more than last year.

Giving details, VK Jain, forest conservator, Saharanpur, claimed, “We have sighted 29 more species than last year. What is also encouraging is that we have spotted otters and swamp deer in the wetland. The rare Orphean warbler, White tailed eagle, Brahminy kite and Penduline tits were spotted in the wetland for the first time.”

UP Singh, secretary of water resources UP Singh, Ravi Singh, CEO, WWF of India, Sanjay Kumar, divisional commissioner of Saharanpur, Suraj Kumar, Muzaffarnagar DFO, M Semmaran, Bijnor DFO, and other officials took part in the two-day event.

Haiderpur is a floodplain wetland formed by Madhya Ganga Barrage in Muzaffarnagar, adjoining Bijnor Ganga Barrage. It is a part of Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary. It is fed by rivers Ganga and Solani.

Of late, the UP government has also taken steps to transform a part of this area into a biodiversity park by installing watchtowers and paving trails. According to officials, at present, Haiderpur covers more than 3,000 acres and comprises 15 km of nature trails, 12 viewing points and one watchtower.

Last year in February, the first bird census was conducted here. A total of 19,784 birds were counted in the wetlands and backwaters of the Ganga. The three-hour census had involved seven teams that counted the avian species in Haiderpur and its surrounding wetlands, which is part of the 2,074 sq km Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary.

Title: Lottery fixes reservation of wards for municipal election
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: The draw of lots to fix the reservation of candidates, who can contest from each of the 115 wards of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) in the upcoming civic elections, was held on Monday under the guidance of the state election commission.

The drawing of lots was held publicly at the auditorium of the Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) by the AMC in presence of municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey and EC observers Avinash Sanas, Atul Jadhav and Pradeep Parab.

The total population of the city is 12.38 lakh. Of them, 2.38 lakh people account for the scheduled caste (SC) category and 16,000 for the scheduled tribe (ST) category. Based on the population, of the 115 AMC wards, 22 have been reserved for SC candidates, 2 for ST, 31 backward class of citizens (BCC or OBC). The remaining 60 seats are open. There are a total of 58 seats reserved for women — 11 for SC women, 1 for an ST woman, 16 for OBC women and 30 in the general women’s category.

Municipal commissioner Pandey said the draw of lots was held impartially and in accordance with the rules.

The EC had already fixed which of the wards will be reserved for the SC and ST candidates. Based on the women’s reservations in the last three AMC general elections — in 2005, 2010 and 2015 — six of the 22 SC wards and 1 of 2 ST wards were reserved for women under these categories. The remaining 5 SC women wards were decided by drawing of lots.

As many as 23 wards were directly reserved for BCC/OBC candidates, as they were not reserved for them in the past three polls.

The draws were held to decide the remaining 8 OBC wards. 16 of the BCC women wards were decided based on their reservations in the previous elections.

The remaining wards went to the general category candidates. The general women category was decided based on reservations of the previous three elections and on the draw.

AMC officials A B Deshmukh and Sanjeev Sonar moderated the draws.

Title: Police permission sought for protest against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

File photo of protest at Saudagar Park in Tandalja

Vadodara: A day after a pandal was removed and electricity connection snapped at the protest site in Tandalja, an individual wrote an application to city police informing about gathering of women at a private plot to protest the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The office of police commissioner received the application on Monday morning informing that women from Saudagar Park and neighbouring residential societies of Tandalja will be gathering at a private common plot. Police said that the application has not been moved by any group or an organization but an individual and it is currently under process.

However, sources among the protesters told TOI that the application has not been done to seek permission for gathering but only to inform cops. “Since it is private premises and we will not be using loudspeakers, we do not need any permission from the police. The application is a way of informing them that the women are going to gather in a private premise so we should not be harassed this time,” said a person involved in mobilizing the women.

“We have received the application of the gathering at the private plot and it is being evaluated,” said inspector D K Vaghela of JP Road police station.

On Sunday, police had said that the organizers who had held protests on Saturday will be facing action as they had not sought permission for the sit-in. The pandal was removed on Sunday morning by the supplier as he was asked for the facility only for a day and that too for a private program and the electricity was also disconnected.

The women, however, continued with their sit-in when the cops began looking for the organizers, no one claimed responsibility for the dharna.

Title: Back from China, Chhatarpur student quarantined for three days
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The youth was kept in the special ward for swine flu patients at the civil hospital in Chhatarpur

BHOPAL: A suspected patient of corona virus was quarantined in Chattarpur for three days from February 1 to 3 after which he was advised to go home and remain in isolation. A medical student in China, the boy is suffering from cold and other related symptoms. He was kept in the special ward for swine flu patients at the civil hospital of Chattarpur which was later converted isolation ward for suspected cases of coronavirus.

A resident of Naugaon , Abhishek Rajput had returned from China on January 14. “After I returned on January 14, I caught cold. As I had returned from China, I thought it better to get myself medically examined in Naugaon. The doctors in my city sent me to the Chattarpur civil hospital,” he told the local press.

Almost after 24 hours of isolation, Rajput went missing from the ward on Sunday triggering panic in the hospital. However, few hours later he returned to the isolation ward.

A student of final year MBBS in China, Rajput said ,”First of all, this is not an isolation ward, but swine flue ward and is so dirty that humans can’t stay here. I am absolutely normal but I have been forced to live here because of the government norms.”

The civil surgeon of Chattarpur Dr RK Tripthi said, “He seems to be fully fit, but as precautionary measure he was kept in the isolation ward. Nasal and throat swabs and blood samples were sent to a the medical college in Sagar, which would send the samples to NIV, Pune. We kept him in isolation because we have to follow the protocol”. However, he denied that the ward is dirty. Since it is located in the old building, the whitewash on the wall may look bad but the room is clean.”

On Monday evening, Rajput was allowed to leave the hospital with an advise to remain in isolation at his home.

Title: Anti-CAA stir about constitutional values, BJP arrogant in power: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress on Monday accused the BJP leadership of provoking firing incidents in the capital to polarise the electorate to win the assembly elections, asserting that anti-CAA-NRC protests were about constitutional values while BJP’s actions were about arrogance of power.

Gaurav Gogoi, Congress’s lead speaker in the debate on the motion of thanks to the President’s address, demanded that Union minister Anurag Thakur, who was briefly barred by the EC from campaigning in the Delhi polls for his rally cry “desh ke gaddaron ko...”, be booked under relevant laws and banned from contesting elections.

He said young boys had suddenly surfaced in Delhi, firing at protesters and students. “Who is pulling the trigger? Is it the boy who held the gun? I don’t think so. The persons who pulled the trigger are the ministers provoking that boy,” he added.

Gogoi alleged that provocative ministers and Delhi Police , which had failed to curb violence in the election campaign, were under directions from the BJP leadership. He said police could not prevent the firing incidents but had earlier entered university campuses and beat up students and professors. He said the culprits behind the violence in JNU had not yet been arrested.

“You may threaten us or shoot us, but people will not be afraid,” he said, referring to BJP.

DMK’s T R Baalu alleged that CAA was brought because the government wanted to discriminate among people. BSP’s Ritesh Pandey called CAA-NRC “divisive” and accused BJP of realising the dream of Jinnah.

While BJD steered clear of the CAA-NRC debate, its MP Pinaki Misra demanded that OBCs should also be enumerated in the upcoming Census.

Trinamool Congress's Mohua Moitra dubbed CAA-NPR-NRC the “biggest betrayal” of Indians. P V Midhun Reddy of YSRCP said his party was opposed to the NRC-NPR, and the government should not create insecurity among minorities. P K Kunhalikutty of IUML accused BJP of playing the “communal” card in Delhi.

Title: Jaipur: Over 5,000 air passengers screened for coronavirus
Content:
A signboard at the Jaipur airport

JAIPUR: The health authorities in the state have stepped up monitoring of people coming from China after two persons were tested positive for novel coronavirus (nCoV) in Kerala At least 5,000 people have been screened for nCoV at Jaipur airport in the past eight days.The health department has advertised that those people who have reached any city of the state from China should undergo screening. Reacting to it, one person each from Jaipur, Ajmer and Sikar and three from Jhalawar contacted the health department officials as they had travelled to China recently. Four among them were found suffering from influenza-like illness. The health officials collected their samples and sent to Sawai Man Singh medical college laboratory for nCoV test Since the health department started the facility for nCoV test at SMS medical college , six reports of six suspected people have already been released by the SMS Medical College. All of them were tested negative for the disease, said Rohit Kumar Singh , additional chief secretary (health), health department, who is regularly monitoring the situation daily.People who have returned to the state from China are being visited by the health department officials on a daily basis. There are at least 50 people in the state who are under the watch of the health authorities. The health department officials are going to residences and houses to each of these persons. Each of them will remain under watch for 28 days from their return. They have been asked to remain isolated at their residences taking proper precautions. So far, more than 10 people have been quarantined in different districts of the state.A presentation was made at the health directorate in which doctors from private and government hospitals were briefed about the guidelines issued by the Centre on nCoV.

Title: Vadodara: Sepoy smuggling SIM card in jail caught
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hardik Kher

VADODARA: A jail sepoy at Vadodara Central Jail was arrested on Monday for smuggling a SIM card inside the jail premises for Rs 500.

The accused Hardik Kher had taken the money from wife of an undertrial prisoner to pass on the SIM card to him. Police said that Kher’s name was revealed during interrogation of the undertrial Yogendra Mahida’s wife Priyanka Mahida.

According to police, Kher had approached Priyanka when she had come to jail to meet her husband. He had told her that he can smuggle a SIM card inside the jail for her husband and will charge a nominal amount of Rs 500. Cops could reach till Priyanka while they were going through call detail records of the SIM card which was found with a mobile phone in November last year.

“The undertrial had borrowed phone from another accused inside the jail and he only needed a SIM card to talk to his wife and other family members from the jail so an understanding was reached with the jail sepoy to bring in the SIM card,” said a police official. He added that Kher is being interrogated if he had smuggled any more sim cards or any other prohibited items inside the jail in the past.

Kher worked in the Group IX of state reserve police force at Lalbaug for 18 months before being selected for jail sepoy’s post a year ago.

Title: Students hold expo to support differently-abled children
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thrissur: Sixty young aspiring artists of Hari Sri Vidya Nidhi School at Punkunnam in Thrissur put a smile back on the faces of differently-abled children through a special drive.

The students of the school who were recently exposed to the world of design, used their artistic skill to produce finely designed garments as part of a fund raising programme which was aimed at supporting their fellow children with special needs. Designer sarees imprinted with students’ creative strokes in various shades of colours were displayed and organized an exhibition by the students at the school on Monday.

Kerala Sahitya Akademi president Vaisakhan, inaugurated the event. Hari Sri Vidya Nidhi School founder Nalini Chandran, Sushama Nanda Kumar and social activist Sheeba Ameer also took part.

The event ‘Weaving Smiles’ was curated by designer Anjali Varma in association with the Hari Sri school. The selected students from school were given special training in fabric painting by a group of designers from various fashion designing schools including National Institute of Design . Students showcased their artistic talent on garments designed by Anjali Varma.

The students managed to raise more than two lakh rupees in short time through this event. All the funds raised from the event has been handed over to Solace, a Thrissur based organization works for autistic, mentally and physically challenged children, said officials.

“The goal of the event was to introduce children to the design process and give them the resources and confidence to inspire curiosity and creative thinking,” said Anjali Varma. TNN

Title: AMC unlikely to collect user fee for waste before polls
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: With the elections just around the corner, the civic administration is likely to defer the drive of collecting a user fee from citizens for waste collection.

Incidentally, the municipal corporations are authorised to collect a user fee from residents and commercial establishments for doorstep waste collection. In August 3, 2018, the general body of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) passed a resolution to impose user fee on those availing the benefit of the civic body’s waste collection service.

The resolution mandates households to pay Re 1 a day i.e Rs 365 a year to the civic body for waste collection. Small commercial units are to be charged Rs 730 a year and hotels and bigger commercial units Rs 10 to 100 every year depending on the quantum of waste produced.

A decision was taken to implement the collection of user fee after the private agency engaged for waste collection began its services. The agency started its work in February 2019. Subsequently, the AMC had decided to appoint an agency for collecting user fee.

During his budget presentation for the fiscal 2019-2020 in June 2019, former municipal commissioner Nipun Vinayak had enunciated that collecting a user fee from waste producers was one of the key measures to improve the financial situation of the civic body.

Incidentally, user fee for waste collection is one of the parameters on which cities are scored in the nationwide cleanliness survey Swachh Survekshan. The civic administration aspires to finish in top 100 cities in the cleanliness survey this year.

The decision had evoked mixed reactions from residents. The Maharashtra Navnirman Sena protested against the civic body for putting ‘financial burden on residents’. According to residents, apart from Swachh Bharat cess of 0.5%, they were also paying for cleanliness charges along with property tax. However, in the wake of the forthcoming general elections of the AMC, the imposition of user fee seems unlikely before April.

Since taking charge of his office in December, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey has repeatedly stressed on taking steps to improve the financial condition of the civic body. When asked, assistant commissioner and tax officer Karan Chavan said that he was not aware of the user fee collection and that he would seek the details of the resolution passed by the general body.

Title: RSS chief focuses on youth to drum up support for CAA
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Mohan Bhagwat in Bhopal on Monday

BHOPAL: Aiming to make its presence felt on social media to attract more youths who could play a crucial role in generating social awareness, Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sanghh (RSS) chief Mohan Bhagwat began his three-day interaction here in the state capital on Monday.

During three-day convention, Bhagwat is likely to make youths aware and review the impact of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, abrogation of Article 370 and Ram Temple construction in Congress-ruled states of Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh , considered as nurseries of saffron ideology.

“Sarsanghchalakji, held interactions with the pracharaks (publicity in-charge) from MP and Chhattisgarh on the first day and discussed on issues related to youths, their active participation on social media and role as Sangh Parivar volunteers. Bhagwatji will focus on various other issues during deliberations with the ‘vibhag pracharaks’ and members of BJP and other frontal organisations on the second and last day of his stay,” said Omprakash Sisodia, regional publicity in-charge of RSS’s Madhya Bharat region.

Sources in BJP disclosed that during interaction with workers and BJP leaders, the RSS chief is most likely to discuss public response to the decisions taken by the Narendra Modi government and the ongoing protests against the CAA.

The Sangh’s three-day programme is being seen as an effort to quell dissent among people against the new citizenship law and ramp up support for the decisions taken by the Union government. The pracharaks will be handed over district-wise plans to reach out to youths, sources added.

The Sangh Parivar is also concerned about growing influence of Congress through its ‘soft-Hindutva’ agenda in the Madhya Bharat region. “There is an impression in the public about the ‘soft-Hindutva’ propagated by the Kamal Nath government in MP. The decisions on constructing cow shelters, funding Sita Mata temple in Sri Lanka, organising Ramleelas in villages, construction of Ram Van Gaman Path through a trust and the development of the Narmada Yatra route have created a deep impact among the public about Congress’s religious sentiments. They need to be discussed,” disclosed a senior RSS cadre.

The Sangh Parivar is also upset over declining BJP base in MP and other neighbouring states. Discussions on BJP leadership and growing resentment among grassroots workers would be held on the second and third day of the convention.

Bhagwat is also likely to review the work and roadmap of RSS affiliates, including the students’ wing Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP). A similar meeting of RSS pracharaks of Madhya Bharat region was held here five years ago, sources said.

Title: As swine flu cases rise to 9 in dist, authorities set up awareness camsp
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Meerut: Meerut health department is on its toes as swine flu cases rose to nine in the district on Monday, with two more patients testing positive for H1N1 virus. Both patients are girls, aged 10 years and four years. They are residents of Samrat Palace area and Shastri Nagar, respectively.

With the detection of new cases, health department has set up awareness camps and is distributing medicines to those who came in contact with the patients and taking other necessary precautions.

“As many as nine cases of swine flu have been reported in Meerut so far. Recently, a 66-year-old resident of Soorajkund area and a 60-year-old from Kishanpura tested positive for swine flu . Earlier, a 41-year-old man from Krishna Vihar, a 17-year-old from Zaidi Farms, a father-son duo aged 62 years and 28 years respectively from Sadar and another one from Phool Bagh Colony were confirmed as suffering from swine flu,” said Dr Rachna Tandon, Meerut district epidemiologist.

The health department is spreading awareness among residents, urging them to report to doctor if they or anyone else is suffering from any symptoms of swine flu. Meanwhile, private hospitals have been asked to set up isolation wards for patients of swine flu to ensure that other patients or hospital staff are not infected.

“We are conducting health awareness camps, and distributing medicines to those who have come in contact with swine flu patients to ensure that there infection is contained,” said Dr Tandon.

In areas where swine flu cases have been detected, surveillance is being conducted to check if there are more cases in proximity. Awareness camps are also being organized there so that people in those areas can exercise caution. Also, epidemiological study and travel history of patients is being checked, health department authorities said.

In 2019, a total of 399 cases of swine flu were reported in contrast to 24 cases in 2018.

According to doctors, the period between January and March is considered the “peak period” for the disease caused by H1N1 virus. The main symptoms are fever, cough, runny nose, bodyache and headache. In case of shortness of breath or vomiting, the patient must contact the doctor.

Title: Drugs worth Rs 4 crore seized in Jaipur, Jodhpur
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: Three persons were arrested and drugs worth Rs 4 crore was seized during joint operations by the drug controller office and narcotics department in Jaipur and Jodhpur between January 31 and February 2.
