Title: Citizens urged to participate in ease of living perception survey
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Puducherry: Puducherry smart city development limited (PSCDL) has appealed to people of Puducherry to participate in the ‘ease of living’ perception survey between February 1 and 29. People can participate in the survey by visiting https://eoi2019.org/citizenfeedback.

PSCDL chief executive officer Arjun Sharma told reporters that the government targets to involve one out of every 100 citizens in the survey.

"The survey starts from February 1 and it ends on February 29. Hence all the citizens of Puducherry city are requested to participate in the ease of living perception survey without fail," said a note from PSCDL.

The survey includes 24 simple questions on the ease of living in the city. The survey will capture the quality of city life based on several parameters such as governance, healthcare, education, security, economy, pollution, water supply, transport, power, housing, wastewater and solid waste management among others. Overall, the ease of living index will study 49 indicators through 97 data points.

"This would imbibe a culture of data-driven governance in cities to effectively plan, implement and monitor city services in future," said the release.

The ease of living is a transformative initiative of the Union housing and urban affairs ministry, which aims to help cities to assess their livability standards with respect to national benchmark and encourage them to move towards an outcome-based approach in urban planning and management.

The Union government approved Puducherry smart city proposal in June 2017. The total cost of Puducherry smart city project is Rs 1,828 crore. The Puducherry government formed PSCDL in September 2017 under the Companies Act, 2013.

The smart city proposal includes area-based development projects at Rs 1,633.64 crore and pan-city projects at Rs 194.19 crore. The tourism promotion initiatives included in the project are the rejuvenation of grand canal, setting up of urban entertainment village at the old port, construction of art and culture complex at the old distillery, upgrading Goubert market and extension of the beach promenade.

The projects on improving urban mobility include establishing a dedicated public corridor-feeder system, smart integrated bus terminal, and multilevel parking at old jail complex, iconic cycle track and cycle sharing system besides making Jawaharlal Nehru Street pedestrian-friendly.

The infrastructural projects include laying a dedicated underground corridor for cables, augment sustainable water source, introduce smart metering for water and electricity, establish a plant to generate energy from waste, construct 1,750 housing units and redevelop Swadeshi mill complex.

The project involves developing a city app for the municipality to extend various services and establishing an integrated command control centre.

Title: Citizens’ get opportunity to rate VMC’s performance
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vadodara: Residents of Vadodara city will for the first time get an opportunity to express their opinion regarding various services provided to them by the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC). The civic body has initiated the process of gathering citizens’ opinions for the Ease of Living Index (ELI), 2019 and the Municipal Performance Index (MPI), 2019.

The surveys will be digital in nature where details for both the indexes will be gathered in the same survey form. The URL of the survey as well as a QR code that can be scanned on smartphones to take the survey will be circulated widely by the civic body. VMC will use the social media, advertisements and outdoor displays for creating awareness about the survey which has deadline of February 29.

Deputy municipal commissioner S K Patel said that the two indexes were a part of the Smart City initiative. In all, 114 cities and town are participating in the survey. These include all those that were picked up to be developed as smart cities and some that opted for it voluntarily.

ELI is based on three pillars that include quality of life, economic ability and sustainability. It will examine 50 indicators in 14 categories like education, health, housing and shelter, mobility, safety and security, recreation, level of economic development, economic opportunities, environment, green spaces and buildings, energy consumption and others.

MPI will look into indicators in 20 sectors that include registration and permits, infrastructure, revenue management, expenditure management, fiscal responsibility, fiscal decentralisation, digital governance, digital access, digital literacy, transparency and accountability, human resource, participation, effectiveness and others. These sectors fall under the verticals of services, finance, planning, technology and governance.

Patel said that after the data for the surveys is analysed the union ministry for urban development and housing will give rankings to cities. “It will also give us details regarding aspects where we may be lacking so that we can improve on them,” he added.

VMC is eyeing to have at least 10,000 responses for the survey. Patel said that five lakh responses were being eyed from the 114 cities where the survey will be conducted.

Title: Ahmedabad: Customs now profiling international flyers
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The seized gold

AHMEDABAD: Travelling abroad frequently? The Ahmedabad customs department has its eyes on you! In a bid to curb gold smuggling, Ahmedabad customs has begun profiling of passengers through a new system, wherein the officials will analyze travel patterns of individual passengers to identify potential smugglers. The new system, known as Advanced Passenger Information System (APIS), has been put in place.

Sharing more details, Kumar Santosh, principal commissioner, customs, said, “Since September 2019, we have begun profiling passengers using APIS. This system is operated by the Central Board of Indirect Taxes and customs. As part of this, a list of passengers is obtained from the airline and fed into the system. Based on the passports, the system helps us identify passengers who go abroad frequently and returning within five to seven days.”

“Most smugglers take the foreign trip for a fixed duration to bring gold illegally into the country, having evaded duty and taxes. If it is a businessman or tourist, the duration of the trip will vary and it will not be frequent. Based on this information, we map suspicious passengers and interrogate them,” he further added.

Following primary investigation, the customs officials will be able to segregate the suspects.

“Based on spot intelligence, the suspects are identified. This system has been highly successful as it helps detect suspects more efficiently. We have been able to catch several smugglers,” he added.

According to senior customs officials most passengers caught with smuggled gold come from Dubai and Sharjah in the UAE in addition to Muscat in Oman, Kuwait and Bangkok .

At Ahmedabad airport alone, some 97 cases of gold smuggling were reported from April 2019 to January 2020, as part of which some 70 kg gold was seized. According to estimates by Ahmedabad customs, the seized gold was valued at Rs 24.8 crore.

Title: Over 8 lakh new farmers linked with online crop loan system
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

JAIPUR: More than 8 lakh new farmers have been linked with the online crop loan system to disburse cooperative loans in the last one year in the state.

The system was introduced to end discrimination in cooperative crop loan disbursement by adopting a uniform and transparent system so that new farmers can get crop loans on 0% interest and free them from the clutches of moneylenders.

Implementing the policy, the Apex Cooperative Bank had launched online crop loan disbursement and registration scheme-2019 under which crop loans were disbursed to eligible farmers based on their biometric verification, department of cooperatives said in a statement.

“So far, over 21 lakh farmers have been linked to cooperative crop loan in the state, including 8 lakh new farmers and crop loan of more than Rs 8,244 crore has been disbursed,” it said.

According to them, 13 lakh old farmers were also linked with the new crop loan system.

More than 25 lakh farmers have applied for crop loan till date in the state. Of these, 21.20 lakh farmers were disbursed loans of Rs 4,583 crore in Kharif season and Rs 3,661 crore in Rabi season, an official said.

Title: Probe against child panel member for abusing boy
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

KOTA: Superintendent of police, Bundi, Mamta Gupta, taking cognisance on the complaint against Child Welfare Committee (CWC) member and ASI for allegedly terrorising 7-year-old boy during counselling in the school on Saturday, ordered inquiry on Monday by an RPS-level officer. The report will then be submitted.

A few video clips, where one of the members of CWC, Bundi, Shobha Kasat along with investigating police officer Kurshed Khan is counselling the boy of a private school in Bundi have gone viral. The boy’s parents on Friday last week had alleged that one of his class teachers had beaten him with a stick and thrown him into a water tank as punishment. The video has triggered controversy and raised questions on the way of counselling the minor boy by the CWC member.

After the video surfaced, the boy’s father, Chandradeep Singh alias Sonu Singh, submitted a report against Kasat and Khan alleging them of severely torturing and terrorising his son in the name of counselling. He has demanded that a case be lodged against them under appropriate sections of IPC.

“We have asked Hindoli circle officer to look into the matter,” said Mamta Gupta. However, she defended the investigating officer Khurshed Khan and said that the video shows him to be present, he is not saying anything.

ADM (administration) Rajesh Joshi also reportedly ordered inquiry into the complaint against CWC member and the ASI for allegedly terrorising the boy during counselling.

Title: Increase in most charges, fees struck down
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vadodara: The standing committee of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) cleared the draft budget proposed by the municipal commissioner after striking down most proposals of increasing various charges and fees.

The committee passed a budget of Rs 3769.17crore for the year 2020-21 against the draft budget of Rs 3,770.54crore.

The VMC administration had refrained from raising taxes and other major options it had for increasing revenue in the draft budget. While the administration had claimed that the decision as taken as the finances of the civic body were manageable without any hikes, it is widely believed that this was done as civic polls were scheduled later this year and because the civic body had a poor track record in delivery of services in the current financial year.

The standing committee too stayed away from doing so as it was also eyeing to do away with hikes in various fees and charges proposed by the commissioner. The committee, however did not reduce any of these.

Committee chairman Satish Patel said the fees and charges were turned down as they would not affect the budget in a major way. The committee imposed hikes in the licence fee for water as well as drainage plumbers, architects, surveyors, site engineers, developers and others. Charges for drainage connections to cottage industries have been doubled as compared to last fiscal, but the committee did not agree to the hike proposed by the commissioner that was three times as compared to 2019-20.

Title: Day after gas leak, residents of five villages evacuated
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kakinada: Residents of five villages close to Uppidi village in East Godavari were evacuated on Monday, a day after a gas leak from a rig well, owned by PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited, there was reported. The leak was not arrested till Monday evening.

An ONGC crisis management team has been pressed into action to arrest the leak. Police have been deployed to ensure no inflammable material is used in the area. Power supply in the area has been cut off and the use of mobile phones suspended. Persons and vehicles are prohibited from enterting an area within a three-kilometer radius of the leakage spot.

Speaking to TOI, officiating asset manager, Rajahmundry Asset, and group general manager, ONGC, Adesh Kumar said an ONGC crisis management team is trying to arrest the gas leak, which is gushing out from the depth of 2,200 meters, but it is difficult to access the leaking valve through the thick vapours. “Right now high capacity water pumps are being used to arrest the gas leakage. But mud will be pumped into the well as part of Plan-B if efforts to curb the leak fails,” he said, adding that besides the ONGC crisis management team, two experts are being brought from Ahmadabad for support. He explained that the well used to be drilled by ONGC in the past, but it was abandoned owing to the low pressure in the well. It was closed in 2007. He said the PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited obtained the well in an auction and had started operations when the gas leak began. He expressed hope that the gas leakage will be arrested by Tuesday

East Godavari SP, Adnan Nayeem Asmi said that 300 police personnel have been deployed at the site and a DSP level officer has been appointed to monitor the situation round the clock.

Meanwhile, Amalapuram MP Chinta Anuradha said that the well was closed in 2007 by the ONGC and alleged that the incident took place when PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited tried to reopen the well. She observed that the gas leak took place due to human error and expressed doubt that the private operator might have failed to deal with the dead well in a proper manner. She revealed that one person from the private company was injured who was carrying out activity at the well when the gas gushed out on Sunday.

Title: Nashik Road rly station among 9 chosen for makeover
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Road railway station has been chosen by the Railway Board for modernization and upgrade as per city’s cultural and heritage importance.

A letter issued by Bhusawal’s divisional railway manager (commercial) RK Sharma on January 29 states that the Nashik Road is one of the nine stations chosen by the board for the makeover. “The local railway officials have been asked to submit the manner in which the stations can be developed,” the letter said.

According to a railway official, Nashik Road station is among the nine stations attached with pilgrimage tags across the country. Others include Dwarka, Gaya, Puri, Kashi, Prayag, and Rishikesh.

The authorities have asked the officials to carry out joint surveys as per the theme and submit their plans at the earliest. The aim is to get the frontage of the railway station and the entrance designed keeping in mind the pilgrimage and the tourist importance of the city.

“At this point in time we have got some ideas, but are still getting more inputs from the citizens in general as well,” the official said. He added that they were open to suggestions from citizens, historians and artists in particular to design the frontage of the railway station and the premises.

A Railway Board letter, dated December 2, 2019, stated that modernization and upgradation was to be taken at the select stations.

“Lack of funds had put the beautification process on the back-burner. But the new move by the board has inspired hopes for the same. In couple of weeks the proposal will be worked out and sent to the divisional railway manager’s office for refinement,” the official said.

Title: Kiran Bedi hails Centre's move to set up police university
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kiran Bedi

PUDUCHERRY: Lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi welcomed the centre’s move to establish a national police university. She said the move will meet the research needs of vital security concerns and serve as a single platform for academicians in policing.

Bedi said an institution like this was always in the pipeline and was much needed but was not given much focus earlier. Recalling her tenure as DGP of the Bureau of Police Research and Development she said announcements never were seen to match available resources. "They were mere announcements. These lacked the financial muscle. Indian policing concerns all along needed a common platform to bring together authors, researchers, creative thinkers, scholars, interns and fellowships and more. Most of all it needs today a common repository of actionable research studies, scattered at several places and any number of disciplines of law enforcement and management," she said.

Bedi also expressed optimism that the institution will be in a better position to advise policymakers, feed the law enforcing managers, regionally and nationally, time to time and provide academic and practical knowledge to prepare the law enforcement officials for the evolving challenges.

She said the institution can work with police universities overseas to enlighten the officials on international law enforcement practices and learn the good practices. "Setting up of the university was long in need of adequate resources to be born and grow. We thank the Government of the day. It's interesting to see the current Government gifting the police service a Police Memorial inaugurated by the Hon'ble PM (last year?) (which was languishing for years) to now a Police University by Hon'ble Union Finance Minister, (a project of Union Home Ministry )," she said.

Title: HC orders CID to look into missing Dhule man case
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court has asked the state crime investigation department (CID) to inquire into the case of a man missing since 2016 and submit its report within three months.

Murlidhar Bandu Nyahalde (75), father of the missing man, had moved court seeking directions to hand over the case to the CID.

On September 15, 2016, his son, Gokul, had gone to Krushna Garden Hotel where he had an altercation with the staff and since then, he has been missing.

Nyahalde, a farmer from Jaitana in Sakri taluka of Dhule district, said he suspects that the hotel staff had done something to Gokul. He had also approached the state government for transferring the investigation to the CID as the Nijampur police in Dhule district had been unable to find any clue about his son’s whereabouts.

AM Gholap, who represented the petitioner, pointed out to the court that that some statements were recorded during a detailed inquiry with the staff of the hotel. He said that the petitioner has suspicion that no inquiry has been made with the staff members who were working at the relevant time in the hotel as some of the members had left the hotel after the incident and the police have taken no interest to trace them.

While allowing the petition, the bench comprising justices TV Nalawade and MG Sewlikar observed: “As the father of the missing person is not satisfied with the present investigating agency and there are aforesaid circumstances, this court holds that investigation needs to be transferred to other investigating agency like CID.’’

The court ordered: “Investigation of both the aforesaid matters is transferred to C.I.D. the head office of which is situated in Pune. The officer in-charge of that office is to see that some senior officer is appointed to make investigation and inquiry into aforesaid matters.”

While disposing of the criminal writ petition, the bench observed that “this court hopes that new investigating agency makes proper investigation like collecting information of servants who were working in the hotel at the relevant time. This Court expects from the new investigating agency to file report within three months from today (January 28, 2020)”.

Title: 108 PFI members held in 4 days for inciting violence
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

statewide crackdown

Lucknow: In a statewide crackdown, UP Police arrested 108 members of the Popular Front of India (PFI) in a four-day operation for their alleged role in violent protests against amended citizenship law in the state since December 19. Most of the arrests were made from Lucknow, Varanasi, Meerut, Kanpur, Ghaziabad, Sitapur, Shamli and Bahraich.

The government had written to the Centre in the first week of January seeking a ban on PFI on the ground that its members had instigated violence during anti-CAA protests in December. Talking to reporters on Monday, ADG law and order PV Ramashastry said, “We are collecting evidence against the arrested people. We are also in touch with central agencies like Enforcement Directorate.”

Police arrested 14 PFI members from Lucknow, 20 from Varanasi, 5 from Kanpur, 21 from Meerut, 9 from Ghaziabad, 3 from Sitapur, 16 from Bahraich, 7 from Shamli, 6 from Muzaffarnagar, 4 from Bijnore, and one each from Gonda, Hapur and Jaunpur.

Lucknow cops, who made 14 arrests, were also the first to nab three PFI office-bearers on December 23 in connection with violent protests in the city on December 19. Additional deputy commissioner of police, west zone, Vikas Chandra Tripathi said 14 more arrests were made from Hussainganj, Thakurganj and Saadatganj areas of the city. “We had evidence against the accused persons. We are in touch with intelligence agencies for verification,” Tripathi said.

SSP, Varanasi, Prabhakar Chaudhary said all 20 arrested PFI members were involved in violence during protest in Beniyabagh.

DIG Devipatan range Rakesh Singh said at least 16 people from various parts of Bahraich were nabbed for their role in violent protests.

Title: Suspense prevails on political ties
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: As the AMC election campaigns gain pace, rumours of possible political alliances have intensified. With reservation allocated to 115 wards, both the BJP and the Sena on Monday expressed readiness to contest the elections independently.

The Sena-BJP relationship weakened within the AMC after the former cut ties to form a government with Congress and NCP. The relationship ended in December when Vijay Autade quit as deputy mayor over a proposal to felicitate Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray.

The AMC election — set to be held in April — is likely to see intense battles between the Sena and the BJP.

When asked how the Sena plans to face the polls alone, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said the party is now used to winning. “Even when it was part of the alliance, Sena had to fight on its own capacity,” he said. However, he did not confirm whether Sena will go to polls in alliance with the NCP or the Congress.

The BJP also stayed mum on rumours of a possible alliance. Party’s group leader in AMC and former deputy mayor Pramod Rathod said ward reservation has ensured justice for all.

MIM corporator and former group leader Naser Siddiqui said his party will field candidates for 60 seats and will likely win 40.

Title: Centre moots 32 road, 21 rail projects to boost port connectivity in Andhra
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The central government has identified 32 road and 21 rail projects in Andhra Pradesh to improve port connectivity as part of its Sagarmala programme. The roads and rail projects would help connect various ports in the state.

Minister of state for shipping, Mansukh Mandaviya, in a reply to YSRC’s Rajya Sabha member V Vijayasai Reddy, said the government has identified 91 road projects and 83 rail projects to improve port connectivity in the country. “Of the 32 road projects in AP, four have been completed and five are under implementation. Two project proposals have been submitted to the ministry of road transport and highways for inclusion under Bharatmala Pariyojana while 20 projects, including the ones linking Gangavaram port to Gajuwaka, NH-16 and other areas, are at detailed project report (DPR) stage,” the minister said.

He added that out of 21 rail projects in the state, five have been completed and one proposal pertaining to various signalling works at Vizag port trust has been submitted. “Two DPRs are under preparation stage for electrification of VPT rail lines for direct connectivity to Mindi yard,” Mandaviya informed.

Replying to another query, the Centre said nine industrial clusters comprising khadi, coir and village industries would be set up in five districts under the fund for regeneration of traditional industries scheme. Micro, small and medium enterprises minister Nitin Gadkari said Rs 1 crore to Rs 4.5 crore will be invested for each cluster.

Title: CM hails finance commission recommendation
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Dehradun: CM Trivendra Singh Rawat on Monday announced that the recommendation of 15th finance commission to increase weightage of forest cover from 7.5% to 10% in states and other devolution criteria will help Uttarakhand to get approximately Rs 2,000 crore from the central government.

The finance commission had given its recommendation of the devolution formula for fixing the state’s share of central tax collection. Speaking with media, the CM hailed the finance commission recommendation by saying that the increase in forest cover weightage can be termed as the green bonus for the states. “Uttarakhand provides invaluable ecosystem services for across the country. In the devolution formula, the increase from 7.5% to 10% can be termed as a green bonus which would increase Uttarakhand’s share of the central tax collection,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus: Demand for N95 masks rises
Content:
N95 masks provide protection against the viruses. Some people also buy pollution masks, but they don’t provide... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The scare for coronavirus infections has pushed up the demand for N95 masks , especially among non-resident Indians (NRIs) and travellers who are going abroad. Estimates by chemists suggest that the stock of masks has eroded with high demand from travellers and currently, only pollution masks are available in the market.“The demand for N95 masks has shown a sharp rise in the city, especially from NRIs, foreigners and those travelling abroad. N95 masks are more in demand because they provide protection against the viruses. We are already out of stock and have placed order for the new stock, but it will take at least a week to be delivered,” said Dashrat Patel, owner of a city-based medical store.“Some people also buy pollution masks, but they don’t provide protection against viruses,” he added.Chemists said that the shelf-life of the N95 mask is about six hours and each family that is travelling procures a significant stock from the market. Industry sources also revealed that several of these masks are being sold in black market as well. “Masks that cost Rs 110 per mask are procured in bulk and are sold at more than double the price at Rs 250. Currently there is a major shortage in the market, even with wholesalers,” said a source.“Use of N95 masks – protecting inhalation of very small airborne particles – is advisable both for the persons having any signs and for protection. For the infected person, it prevents spread of the virus whereas for the persons close by, it prevents accidental exposure,” said city-based critical care specialist Dr Manoj Singh.

Title: CM offers special puja at Vaarshik Mahotsav
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Special prayers were offered by Chief Minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy at the Sarada Peetham on Monday. The chief minister along with TTD chairman, Y V Subba Reddy, performed Srinivasa Chaturveda Havanam, which was sponsored by the TTD.

Earlier in the day, the TTD chairman along with other YSRC leaders welcomed the chief minister at the airport after which he headed straight to the ashram, where special annual celebrations were being held. The cheif minister also performed go-puja and jammi-chettu puja. Sarada Peetham pontiff, Swami Swaroopanandendra was present throughout the occasion.

Following the pujas, Jaganmohan Reddy unveiled a plaque at the ashram premises in Chinnamushirvada and participated in the Rajya Syamala Yagam. He also felicitated vedic pandit, Sriman Tangirala Viswanadha Sastry, of Kaplieswaram in East-Godavari district.

Other VVIPs who attended the programme and conducted special pujas at the Peetham were Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy, Telangana minister of animal husbandary, fisheries and cinematography Talasani Srinivas Yadav, senior YSRC leader V Vijayasai Reddy and state minister for agriculture Kurasala Kannababu.

Meanwhile, members of the CPI (M) tried to block the CM’s convoy, when it was on its way to the Peetham, and many of the local CPI(M) functionaries along with their cadre were taken into custody by the Pendurthi police. The blockade was conducted in protest against the land pooling underway in the district.

Title: 40% of road accident deaths in Hyderabad self-hits: Cops
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Over 40% of fatal road accidents in the Hyderabad police commissionerate limits in January were ‘self-hit’ (caused by the motorist), establishing that fatalities were due to victims’ negligence. Ironically, all fatalities were of two-wheeler riders or pillion-riders, according to an analysis of the road accidents in the city.In the first month of 2020, 22 deaths occurred in road accidents in the city, Hyderabad traffic police said. A police team analysed the accidents and found that nine of those deaths were ‘self caused’. “The analysis done by our team indicated that nine of the 22 road accident deaths were self caused as the mishaps occurred due to negligence of the rider. Drunk driving, riding without helmet, speeding and overtaking from the left were the reasons for the nine deaths,” Hyderabad additional commissioner of police Anil Kumar told TOI.All the deceased in the nine accidents were two-wheeler riders or pillion riders and eight of them were not wearing helmets. In four cases, the victims were drunk, while in two cases the riders did not have driver’s licence. Of the 22 victims, 12 were not wearing helmets. “We have been doing awareness campaigns about speeding, seat belts, helmets, wrong-side driving, signal jumping and drunk driving. The accidents have come down and our aim is to reduce them further,” the additonal CP said.

Title: Engineer from Portugal dies in wall collapse at Sriperumbudur
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 51-year-old engineer from Portugal was killed when a wall collapsed on him while he was working on a chimney at a private glass factory in Sriperumbudur on Monday. Police said Carlos Simmons was wearing all the mandated safety gear, but he was buried alive under debris when a wall attached to the chimney collapsed.

Simmons was senior engineer in a team of 28 people that had come from Portugal last week to service the factory’s chimneys, which had been imported from that country. The team was staying in the glass company’s accommodation for the annual maintenance work.

Police said the chimney six workers, including Simmons, were servicing on Monday afternoon was surrounded by a 20-foot-high concrete wall, a portion of which suddenly gave way. Five of the workers managed to escape to safety. That’s when they realised Simmons was missing.

Police said the Portuguese workers themselves found Simmons under the debris and managed to pull him out. He was rushed to a nearby private hospital where he was declared brought dead.

“The structure of the wall was weak,” said an investigating officer. “We are probing further into the case. He was stuck underneath a huge pile of debris and was unable to breathe,” the officer said quoting eyewitnesses.

The Sriperumbudur police sent the body for post-mortem to the Chengalpet government hospital. Police have registered a case of accidental death and are investigating.

Title: Game orders inspection of illegal constructions
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

SLUG: 36 NMC-Owend properties

Nashik: Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has taken strong note of the alleged illegal constructions carried out in 36 civic-owned properties.

Game, on Monday, directed an inspection of these properties to ascertain whether any civic official was responsible for these illegal constructions or the parties to whom these properties were leased to had carried out the illegal constructions without the knowledge of the civic administration.

As per Development Control and Promotion Regulations (DCPR) of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ), 15% constructions on open or amenity spaces are permissible — 10% is permissible on ground and 5% on first floor.

Recently, a survey was carried out by the town planning department and Public Works Department (PWD) of the municipal corporation. During the survey, officials of both the department found violation of the norms while carrying out construction on open and amenity spaces.

Following this, Game told TOI that he has directed the PWD department to inspect the properties and find out who is responsible for the illegal construction .

“Responsibilities about the illegal constructions are to be fixed first. Action will be taken against municipal officials if they are found involved for illegal constructions. Notices will be sent to the parties to whom the properties have been leased out if they are found involved in illegal constructions,” Game said.

Meanwhile, the civic administration has decided to table the proposal of increasing the lease rates for its properties from 2.5% to 8% at the coming general body meeting.

The decision has been taken after the urban development department of the state government has directed all civic bodies to increase the lease rates on civic-owned properties. The state government has also sent a letter to the NMC asking it to levy new lease rates.

There are over 2,500 properties of the NMC, including 1,900 commercial outlets and remaining 900 study halls, community halls, libraries, laughter clubs, gymnasiums that have been leased out to different parties.

Title: 2 signals to start operations from February 15
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Slug: Smat Road

Nashik: Two traffic signals are set to come up at the junctions in Meher and Central Bus Stand on the smart road , which is being developed from Ashok Stambh and Trimbak Naka, and will be made operational from February 15. High masts are also being installed at all the three junctions on the smart road.

Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation (NMSCDCL), which allowed vehicles to ply on the smart road from January 26, has started completing remaining works like installing high masts, e-toilets and other facilities along the stretch.

CEO of the smart city development corporation Prakash Thavil said, “We have will make two traffic signals on the smart road operational from February 15. These two traffic signals are to be monitored through command and control room.”

“The two traffic signals are equipped with advanced CCTV cameras, which can detect number plates and also record if anyone is violating traffic rules and regulation,” said Thavil.

Interestingly, many elected representatives of the civic body and local residents have been questioning the quality of the road due to its unevenness. The smart city corporation carried out a riding quality check of the entire stretch recently and detected the lacuna.

“The road is uneven at some places. We are seeking help of experts to find out solutions through new technology,” added Thavil.

He further said that minor works on the road like setting up bus shelters, underground cable work of MSEDCL, installation of e-toilets would be completed soon.

Title: Average household income in Telangana among the highest but so is its spend on a thali
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nepali Thali meal set with mutton curry from top angle

HYDERABAD: An average industrial worker in Telangana spends almost all of his daily income for his family to consume two non-vegetarian thalis in a day. As per the Thalinomics survey conducted by Centre, the average household income for a family of five in the state is close to Rs 480 per day while the cost of one non-vegetarian thali is said to be around Rs 40.

Telangana is said to have one of the highest household incomes but with a non-vegetarian thali priced at Rs 40, it almost spends all of it to consume two thalis a day. In case of a vegetarian thali, the average household in Telangana spends between 50-75% of its daily income.

While the survey shows that the percentage of income spent on a non-vegetarian thali is similar states such as Kashmir, Bihar, Assam and Tripura, the daily incomes in these states is also lower. For example, in Assam, the price of a non-vegetarian thali is around Rs 40 but the daily household wage is just above Rs 280. Meaning: a family has to spend over its daily household income to afford two non-vegetarian thalis for a family of five.

When it comes to the affordability of a vegetarian thali, the survey shows that a household in Telangana spends between 50 to 75% of daily income on a vegetarian thali. Jharkhand fares well in this regard with a household spend of up to 25% for two vegetarian thalis a day.

The survey revealed that affordability of vegetarian thalis improved by 29% from 2006-07 to 2019-20 while affordability for non-vegetarian thalis improved by 18% across India. The survey has considered the price data from consumer price index of workers for around 80 centres in 25 states and Union territories from 2006 to 2019. The fiscal year 2015-16 was considered as the year when there was a shift in the dynamics of thali prices .

Title: TRS with Centre in Delhi but criticises it in Hyderabad: K Laxman
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Telangana BJP president K Laxman

HYDERABAD: Telangana BJP president K Laxman on Monday said that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should reveal to the people the funds allocated to the state when he was a cabinet minister in UPA-2 government. Addressing media, Laxman said that even when the UPA-2 was in power, Gujarat – then under chief ministership of Narendra Modi – had developed faster than the state.

“The state government has a two-pronged approach. In Delhi, they try to lobby with Centre but criticise it in Hyderabad and blame it for their own failure,” Laxman said. He also slammed minister KT Rama Rao’s statement on allocation towards Telangana.

“Being an educated person, KTR should understand that the central government allocates funds ministry and department-wise on the basis of projects taken up for the welfare not to fill up your pockets,” Laxman said. He said that despite people giving the mandate to TRS in the state, the Modi government has implemented several welfare schemes in Telangana.

“Several central government schemes are not implemented in the state as the TRS government failed to allocate its share which has deprived people of the benefits of schemes initiated by the Centre,” Laxman said. Throwing KTR a challenge, the state BJP president said that his party is ready for a debate on funds allocated by Centre to Telangana.

Title: Locust Attack: Locusts enter Punjab farms, eliminated in 13-hour nightlong operation
Content:
Government officials spray insecticide at locusts on a tree

BATHINDA: A swarm of locusts, measuring 3km in width and 1km in length, entered Punjab through Fazilka district on Sunday night, prompting the state government to carry out a nighlong, multi-department, 13-hour-long operation to control the pest.The insect had been ravaging fields in neighbouring Rajasthan and Pakistan. Though a few flying insects were being spotted across the region for many days, this was the first time that they entered Punjab in such a huge number. The swarm flew into Bakenwala and Roopnagar villages of Fazilka, which are situated near Rajasthan and Pakistan borders, following which worried farmers approached the state agriculture department.The dead insects on groundTop officials of the agriculture department on Monday claimed that the swarm could not cause any loss to crops and the threat had been neutralised. The agriculture department conducted the operation by involving officials from Punjab Agricultural University (PAU), Border Security Force (BSF), fire department, police, civil administration, horticulture and farmers. “About 400-500 tonnes of insecticides were used to eliminate locusts,” Punjab agriculture department director Sawtantar Kumar Airi said, adding that locusts came from the Pakistan side.Punjab additional chief secretary (agriculture) Viswajit Khanna said it was ensured that the whole swarm of locusts was eliminated. “Boomer sprayers, tractor-mounted high-velocity sprayers and a fire department vehicle were used to control the locusts. The operation was concluded with completely wiping out the locust swarm,” he said.Farmer Joginder Singh of Roopnagar said they first spotted a large number of locusts on trees at night. “Though several locusts have been killed, we are worried more swarms may enter our villages and damage crops,” he said.Punjab agriculture secretary Kahan Singh Pannu said the entire state machinery was put into motion after they came to know of the swarm of locusts entering Roopnagar. “When we got the information, we held a meeting with officials in Chandigarh about 9 pm and sounded a high alert. We deputed all officers concerned on emergency duty. The director and joint director of agriculture were immediately sent to Abohar. Fazilka deputy commissioner was alerted. He held a meeting of all district-level stakeholders at 11pm. The joint operation coordinated at state level started at 10pm on Sunday and continued till 9am on Monday,” he said.Even as officials said they were ready for any situations farmers continued to be worried. One of them, Mukhtiar Singh, said they were not in a position to bear damage to crops. “The state government must make arrangements to control the locusts,” he added.

Title: Release pending GST arrears, TRS MP Nama Nageshwar Rao tells Centre
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: TRS Lok Sabha MP Nama Nageshwar Rao has demanded the Centre to release about Rs 5,000 crore pending GST and IGST arrears to the state government. Raising the issue during question hour in Lok Sabha on Monday, the floor leader said that the Centre has not been releasing pending arrears of taxes and mandatory taxes share.

“The state government has expressed its concern on pending GST and IGST arrears on several occasions. Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has met the prime minister and other union ministers earlier seeking release of funds but there has been response from Centre,” Rao said. He said several welfare schemes are getting affected due to the lack of funds from Centre. Rao urged the Centre to release pending funds to the state immediately.

Title: Bengaluru students land seats in premier universities like LSE, MIT
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Title: Nimhans training ITBP education counsellors in stress management
Content:
TimesView This is a welcome development. People who serve the country, especially in high and cruel terrain, are subject to a variety of pressures and need all the help they can get. Periods of working with hostiles alternating with those of inaction, and separation from family take a heavy toll on them. While training counsellors is the first step, it needs to be backed up by larger deployment of mental health personnel, at least at the base-camp level. The problem needs to be approached from the other end too as families of serving personnel also suffer from stress.

BENGALURU: After having trained Tamil Nadu police in stress management, National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences ( Nimhans ) has now begun training ‘education and stress counsellors’ of the Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP) on how to manage loneliness, boredom, environmental pressure at high altitudes, smartscreen related issues and suicidal tendencies among their personnel.ITBP counsellors are expected to hold workshops in managing stress and other related issues for their personnel.The nation’s premier mental health institute signed an MoU with Union home minister Amit Shah on ‘Stress Management and Counselling for ITBP Personnel’ on December 30, 2019. Though talks were going on since 2017, workshops began only last month.“Mobile phone penetration has made work tougher for ITBP personnel. They get worried over phone calls from home. Also, regular exercises cannot be done at their places of deployment given the oxygen saturation levels. A special yoga module has been designed for them after hazard vulnerability risk analysis,” said Dr K Sekar, registrar, Nimhans.Each batch is being trained for two weeks. A batch has 30 ITBP stress counsellors, who work largely at base camps. The plan is for them to trek with their personnel and engage them in stress management at high altitudes.“There are 5-6 major issues that bother ITBP personnel. They work at high altitudes and are prone to loneliness and alcoholism. They battle family issues. With mobile phone penetration, they get to know about what’s happening back home but can’t help. Boredom sets in as they can only stare at the mountains and the sky,” said Dr C Jayakumar, assistant professor, co-principal investigator of the project.Two batches have already undergone training and it began for the third batch on February 3. In all, 450 ITBP personnel will be trained. The average age of the participants is 40-45.An ITBP education and stress counsellor currently undergoing training in Nimhans said the major issue bothering their personnel is separation from family. “Things have changed now as compared to the pre-mobile era. Though phones are not allowed at work, everyone accesses them once back in their accommodations,” said the counsellor.The first two batches had two women each and the third batch has three. The 90,000-strong ITBP has about 4,000 women.“Women in ITBP have their own challenges, including psychosomatic issues, stigma pertaining to working far away from home, marital issues and biological issues arising out of the tough terrain,” Nimhans authorities said.

Title: HC to govt: Rehabilitatethose evicted in Bellandur
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bengaluru: The high court on Monday indicated it will pass necessary orders if the state doesn’t take a decision to rehabilitate or compensate those who were evicted in Bellandur last month. Shanties/sheds on a private property were razed on the presumption that the occupants were illegal immigrants from Bangladesh.

“It all began with a letter from a police officer, and the government will have to rehabilitate those who were deprived of their shelter,” a division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka observed while posting the matter to February 10.

During the hearing, Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) claimed it had no role in the demolition and police informed the court that the inspector concerned who wrote a letter to the private property owner had been transferred and they didn’t take part in the exercise.

“Illegal Bangladeshi migrants are residing in the temporary sheds put up on your plot. Related videos have gone viral on social media. Please clear the illegal sheds once you receive the notice,” then Marathahalli inspector had written.

‘Vacated premises on their own’

During the hearing, counsel for owners of the land in question told the court they didn’t conduct demolition and in fact, the occupants vacated the premises with their belongings on their own following a polite request to them. However, the bench refused to accept this, asking who would believe such a claim.

Advocate general Prabhuling K Navadagi told the court the central government had issued an advisory to all states regarding illegal immigrants. However, the bench, which perused the October 3, 2019 advisory issued by the Centre, noted police were only told to identify illegal Bangladeshis and asked whether any identification exercise was conducted in the case at hand.

The bench added it will not approve of police action in evicting people, a power vested with a civil court. It also termed the police inspector’s action of writing to a property owner a dangerous trend and wondered how police acted in such a way.

The court is hearing a PIL filed by the People’s Union for Civil Liberties, Karnataka. The petitioner organisation has claimed occupants of the sheds/shanties demolished are not from Bangladesh but from poor families of North Karnataka, West Bengal, Assam, Tripura and Bihar, and they are being victimised because of their vulnerable social-economic status. It says the evicted people are migrant labourers and possess valid IDs to show they are Indian citizens.

Unbelievable claim

A squatter vacating the premises on his own based on a polite request? Who will believe this in a city like Bengaluru? Unless backed by police power, this can’t happen. If that is the case, BBMP and the state can avail the services of these landlords to get all illegal encroachments cleared. There will be no work for courts as well

-High court bench

Title: Gangsters who shot Jawahar Nagar man held in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: Ten days after they gunned down hotelier and financier Harjinder Singh Jindi, the Ludhiana Police, in a joint operation with their Uttarakhand counterparts, arrested Sukhwinder Singh Moni and his aide Sumit Choti from Haridwar on Monday.

The city police would bring them here on Tuesday, said commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal.

On January 23, Moni and Choti, who is from Saharanpur, had shot Jindi at a doctor’s clinic in the busy Jawahar Nagar market. CCTVs installed in the clinic and the market had captured the duo. Both Moni and Jindi were residents of Jawahar Nagar.

The car — a Maruti Suzuki Wagon R — used in the crime was robbed from Haridwar.

“To execute the murder, the duo first robbed a car from Haridwar on January 19. They then affixed a fake registration number plate on it to avoid getting traced,” Agarwal added.

Roorkee Police had arrested Moni in an April 2019 case of robbery of Rs 25 lakh from SBI’s cash van. “Moni along with his gang members had robbed the cash van. He was arrested in the case and jailed, but he jumped bail and went into hiding. Since then Haridwar Police had been on his lookout,” said a cop.

About the motive behind Jindi’s murder, Agarwal said, “The two accused would be interrogated on Tuesday. That will make the picture clear.”

Haridwar SSP Senthil Krishna Raj said, “During interrogation, the accused said they met in Roorkee Jail. On coming out on bail in October 2019, the two hatched a conspiracy to kill the Ludhiana man, as Moni believed that he was implicated in a theft because of him. To execute the crime, they stole a motorcycle from the venue of a wedding function on January 1. Later, they went on that motorcycle to rob a car. That car was used in the Ludhiana murder.”

The Haridwar police had released sketches of Moni and Choti in the carjacking case. “But the accused managed to reach Ludhiana after affixing a fake registration numberplate on the car. Haridwar police have arrested the accused with the stolen car, fake number plate affixed on it, two pistols, seven live cartridges and RC of the stolen bike,” he added.

Title: City residents easily fall prey to illegal travel agents
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: As per the latest data of National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), Ludhiana is ranked second in the country in the Emigration Act, 1983, violation cases.

According to the NCRB data released recently for mega cities for 2018, as many as 52 cases were registered in the Ludhiana commissionerate, earning it the second spot. Delhi is at number one with 143 cases. Chennai, Kochi and Lucknow stood at number three, four and five with 11, five and four cases, respectively.

Among the commissionerates and districts of Punjab, Ludhiana rural police district is at number two position with six cases registered in 2018 and Hoshiarpur at number three with one case. Cases under the Emigration Act in Ludhiana comprise 88.14% of the total cases in the state.

The data for the past many years suggests that the cases in 2018 were the highest in the recent years, with 31 filed in 2017 and 43 in 2016. In 2016, Ludhiana was at number one position in the country, with Kochi and Ernakulum sharing second spot with 21 cases each.

Police officials said five districts in Punjab, including Jalandhar, Hoshiarpur, Nawanshahr, Kapurthala and Ludhiana, are known for large number of such cases.

“Many in these districts want to go abroad and some of them are not educated enough for the work they apply for. So, they fall in the trap of travels agents. We try to get their money refunded,” said Ludhiana police commissioner Rakesh Aggarwal.

Assuring strict action, he said, “In the past four months, we have booked 100 such agents and in a single day on January 1, we lodged 30 cases against agents who didn’t have a licence. Those willing to go abroad should look for authorised agents and apply on the basis of their qualifications or look for better avenues in their own country.”

Social activists say there is a need to monitor the working of emigration companies. “People arrange money after selling their land and other valuables, but fall prey to illegal agents. Police must watch the working of such companies and act as soon as a fraud is reported,” said social activist Keemti Rawal.

FOREIGN DREAMS GO AWRY

Delhi 143

Ludhiana 52

Chennai 11

Ludhiana Rural 6

Kochi 5

Lucknow 4

Mumbai 3

Title: Gas leak: Five villages evacuated
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kakinada: Residents of five villages close to Uppidi village in East Godavari were evacuated on Monday, a day after a gas leak from a rig well , owned by PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited, there was reported. The leak was not arrested till Monday evening.

An ONGC crisis management team has been pressed into action to arrest the leak. Police have been deployed to ensure no inflammable material is used in the area. Power supply in the area has been cut off and the use of mobile phones suspended. Persons and vehicles are prohibited from enterting an area within a three-kilometer radius of the leakage spot.

Speaking to TOI, officiating asset manager, Rajahmundry Asset, and group general manager, ONGC, Adesh Kumar said an ONGC crisis management team is trying to arrest the gas leak, which is gushing out from the depth of 2,200 meters, but it is difficult to access the leaking valve through the thick vapours. “Right now high capacity water pumps are being used to arrest the gas leakage. But mud will be pumped into the well as part of Plan-B if efforts to curb the leak fails,” he said, adding that besides the ONGC crisis management team, two experts are being brought from Ahmadabad for support. He explained that the well used to be drilled by ONGC in the past, but it was abandoned owing to the low pressure in the well. It was closed in 2007. He said the PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited obtained the well in an auction and had started operations when the gas leak began. He expressed hope that the gas leakage will be arrested by Tuesday

East Godavari SP, Adnan Nayeem Asmi said that 300 police personnel have been deployed at the site and a DSP level officer has been appointed to monitor the situation round the clock. He mentioned that awareness is being created among public not to use flammable objects in the region.

Meanwhile, Amalapuram MP Chinta Anuradha said that the well was closed in 2007 by the ONGC and alleged that the incident took place when PFH Oil and Gas Private Limited tried to reopen the well. She observed that the gas leak took place due to human error and expressed doubt that the private operator might have failed to deal with the dead well in a proper manner. She revealed that one person from the private company was injured who was carrying out activity at the well when the gas gushed out on Sunday.

Title: Telangana cooperatives commissioner quizzed in contempt case
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Monday questioned state cooperatives commissioner M Veerabrahmaiah as to why he failed to respect the order of the court on the election conducted to the executive committee of the Hyderabad district NGOs cooperative housing society.

The commissioner along with two of his subordinates appeared before a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy in a contempt case filed by G Prabhakar, a member of the society who questioned the alleged failure of the officials in following the order of the court.

The bench questioned the commissioner and ordered him to show proof that he had understood the court’s order and its implementation.

“Did you issue notice to the aggrieved persons before notifying election to the society? Where is the proof of such notices? You were directed by the high court to first hear the aggrieved persons. You issued election notification on December 5 but you did not refer the order of the court. It is not clear whether you went ahead without hearing the aggrieved persons,” the high court bench said.

Though the state counsel tried to defend the commissioner by trying to explain the circumstances pertaining to the case, the bench said that this is a contempt case and hence they wanted to hear only the “relevant answers” so as to ascertain if the commissioner had followed the direction given by the court.

The commissioner then sought time to explain his case through an additional affidavit..

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Kidnapped for marriage, BSc student burnt alive by youth
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: The 21-year-old missing BSc student whose unrecognizable, badly-burnt body was found on Saturday evening from Harchandpur in Rae Bareli, three kilometres away from her college and identified on Sunday, had been kidnapped for forced marriage and set ablaze for resisting, alleged her father in his complaint to police on Monday.

The family members and relatives staged a protest by keeping her corpse on main road in Bachhrawan. The girl, a resident of Bachhrawan, had gone to college on Saturday, but her body was recovered from thickets in Harchandpur area of Lucknow-Allahabad highway.

The girl’s father has accused one Atul Gupta (25), saying he had proposed to his daughter few days ago while she was returning from college. “Despite my daughter’s clear refusal, Atul misbehaved with her on many occasions, after which we took up the matter with his family, but 15 days ago he threatened her with dire consequences if she didn’t marry him,” he alleged.

Acting on the complaint, Rae Bareli police lodged an FIR against Atul Gupta on charges of murder, concealing evidence, criminal intimidation, and causing hurt. SP, Rae Bareli, Swapnil Mamgain told TOI, “Atul, a distant relative of the girl, has been nabbed but is denying charges. He runs a cloth store in Shivratanganj, Amethi. We have detained four other persons also and are questioning them.”

“The post-mortem report of victim rules out rape and mentions burns as the cause of death. We will recreate the crime scene to ascertain the sequence of events since kidnapping a 21-year-old and setting her afire cannot be done by one man,” Mamgain said.

A source privy to probe, however, said the victim had told a friend to carry her bag home and tell her parents that she had been kidnapped, but they did not report it to police and complained a day later.

Title: Centre must declare emergency over locust attacks: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Locust attacks took place in Jaisalmer and Barmer on Sunday

Jaisalmer: After Pakistan declared national emergency over locust attacks, state revenue minister Harish Choudhary has written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi to declare the same in 12 locust-affected districts in Rajasthan.

In a letter to the PM, he stated that 12 districts in Rajasthan are affected by locusts and swarms of these insects are still coming from Pakistan. He demanded a solid action plan to avoid such crises in future and to buy latest equipment to deal with such attacks. On the other hand, fresh locust attacks took place at many villages in Jaisalmer and Barmer on Sunday.

Choudhary said he has urged PM Modi to declare the locust attack a national emergency looking at the losses. Around 20 countries in the world have been affected by locusts. Somalia and Pakistan have already declared it a national emergency. Rajasthan, Punjab and Gujarat were the most affected states. In Rajasthan, locust attacks started from March 2019 and is continuing. Twelve districts, including Barmer, Jaisalmer, Jalore, Bikaner, Sriganganagar , Hanumangarh, and Pali, have witnessed damage of crop in a big way. Two farmers have died in Barmer due to the losses they suffered by locust attack.

Crops in an estimated 3.52 lakh hectares have been damaged and at present locusts are damaging rabi crops. The department is unable to get prior information of the arrival of locusts. Affected farmers must be compensated, he wrote in the letter.

On Sunday, fresh locust attacks took place in Jaisalmer and Barmer. In Jaisalmer’s Ramdeora, locusts attacked crops causing heavy losses to farmers. In Chauhatan of Barmer district , locusts damaged bajra, moong, gwar and other crops.

It is said that the wind blowing from north to south is a reason that locusts are coming from Punjab state in Pakistan into India.

Title: Two criminals with Rs 1 lakh bounty each arrested
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Haridwar: Two criminals carrying a bounty of Rs 1 lakh each for their involvement in a murder were arrested by Haridwar Police on Monday. The accused were wanted by Punjab Police. According to police, the accused met in Roorkee jail, where they hatched the plan to murder a man who had registered a case of robbery against one of them. Police recovered a gun and bullets from their possession.

The accused have been identified as Sukhvinder Singh alias Moni, a resident of Labour Colony, Dusmalla, Ludhiana, Punjab and Sumit alias Choti, a resident of Gagalhedi, Saharanpur, Uttar Pradesh.

Haridwar SSP Senthil Abudai Krishna Raj S told TOI, “Both Sukhvinder and Sumit have criminal backgrounds and have several cases against them in Punjab, Uttar Pradesh and Uttrakand.”

Title: High court issues contempt notice to Punjab chief secretary
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Karan Avtar Singh

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab and Haryana high court on Monday issued notice to Punjab chief secretary Karan Avtar Singh on a plea claiming that despite HC order, the state was not hearing the victim’s family before premature release of accused convicted in any case.

A bench headed by Justice Surinder Singh issued the notice after hearing a contempt petition filed by advocate H C Arora. Petitioner has stated that on October 31, 2019, HC had disposed of a PIL filed by the petitioner, by directing the Punjab government to take a decision on petitioner’s representation dated June 25, 2019, at earliest.

In his representation, the petitioner had demanded that before releasing a life convict (murderer) by granting him pardon, or releasing him prematurely under the prevalent policy, the competent authority must give a hearing to the victim’s family, and the state must pay adequate compensation beforehand to the dependent family members of the victim (of murder) in all such cases.

The petitioner has alleged that on one hand, the Punjab government had not decided the representation of the petitioner, and on the other hand, the cases for granting pardon by the governor, were being expedited by the state authorities. Petitioner has referred to the cases of former SP Preetpal Singh, former ASI Harbhajan Singh , former SI Ajit Singh; and former inspector Amrik Singh. Lifer Manjit Singh Dhaner had also been released by granting him pardon during the intervening period.

“The respondent is deliberately sitting over the petitioner’s representation, and has thus, committed contempt of the directions issued by the HC. The chief secretary is therefore, liable to be convicted for commission of contempt,” the petitioner has contended.

Title: BRS Nagar man, 38, dies of heart attack behind the wheel
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: A 38-year-old man died while he was at the wheel near Lodhi Club Road on Monday morning.

Prateek Kawar, a resident of J-Block, BRS Nagar, was a second-hand car dealer.

Sarabha Nagar police station additional SHO sub-inspector Jaswinder Singh said, “Prateek was a heart patient. He was unwell from the past some days and had an appointment with a cardiologist on Monday. As his wife, who works in Chandigarh, could not come to Ludhiana on Monday, the couple decided to go to the doctor on Tuesday. Around 10am Monday, Prateek left his house in a Maruti Suzuki Swift car. He stopped at an ATM kiosk near Hotel Keys and withdrew cash. After driving for a few metres, he pulled over at a roadside.”

On spotting a motionless man inside the car that was parked for long, commuters raised the alarm. “As the car was not locked, we easily brought him out. He was taken to a hospital, where doctors declared him brought dead. It is suspected that Prateek died of heart attack. His family has been informed. They told that Prateek had been delaying visiting the cardiologist from the past some days,” the sub-inspector added.

The police have initiated proceedings under Section 174 of the CrPC.

Title: Beware of ‘Aus charity’ phishing mails: Cyber cell
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aurangabad: The cyber cell of the city police has issued a warning asking citizens not to respond to an email claiming to be from a charity and approved by the “Ministry of Health Australia”. The alleged phishing attempt surfaced recently.

Authorities asked citizens to avoid sharing any bank details or personal information with senders of the email.

The purported charity email was sent to recipients by one Mrs Donna Harrison from Australia who claimed to be "a childless widow of a business tycoon". The mailer claims she is suffering from cancer and wants to donate $21.8 million dollars she inherited to the poor, orphanages and widows. In its concluding paragraph, the email asks recipients to write back to dhi94299@gmail.com for details.

The cyber cell said similar communications were found to have been used by fraudsters to steal personal information of people. “Users should avoid clicking on links, downloading attachments or replying with personal information to phishing emails. Users can also report such emails to the service provider as phishing attempts,” Kailash Deshmane, in-charge of the cyber cell at the Aurangabad police commissionerate, said.

Authorities added that emails, online advertisements and entire websites are now being used for phishing purposes. “Phishing mails try to give an impression that they are from credible individuals or firms communicating on behalf of banks. These attempts of cyber-attacks seek usernames and passwords, bank details, PIN, numbers of debit/credit card among other details,” an official said.

As per the official portal of the state government, India is now the third biggest source of malicious activity online and every sixth social media scam today impacts an Indian.

Title: Oppn motion on guv recall defeated
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The assembly on Monday defeated by vote the motion moved by UDF seeking to favourably reconsider the notice of opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala to recall governor Arif Muhammed Khan for taking a stand against state assembly’s resolution against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

The assembly rejected the UDF motion by 74 against 36 votes of the total 111 votes, while one member — P C George — remained neutral. Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said that even though the government does not endorse any of the stand of the governor in the subject, it does not think that a motion to recall should be moved because the governor aired his opinion. The chief minister said that the governor is trying to act as Centre’s spokesperson here and the government neither agrees to his views nor his opinion against the assembly resolution in the matter. But, the chief minister quoted UDF leaders like K Karunakaran, Oommen Chandy, K M Mani and M M Hassan in the assembly on various occasions in the past, to say that just because the governor aired his views, it need not be discussed by the assembly.

Citing Chennithala’s request before the governor not to sign the ordinance for increasing the number of seats in local self-government institutions, the chief minister slammed the opposition for using the governor against the government.

Justifying his decision to come up with a notice to recall the governor, Chennithala said that the governor is part of the legislature and is bound to remain with the unanimous resolution of the assembly against CAA.

Chennithala said that if the governor had a different view, he should have conveyed it to the speaker and not hold a news conference and speak against it.

The opposition leader said that there have been instances when the assembly had discussed against actions of the governor in 1969 and 1989. IUML legislative party leader M K Muneer said that the governor had insulted the government and not the opposition. He said that when the opposition is standing in support of the government, the government is favouring the governor against the opposition.

UDF MLA Thiruvanchoor Radhakrishnan said that the governor has crossed the limits by intervening in the day-to-day administration of the government and the government should introspect if it should oppose the notice to recall the governor, just because the opposition moved it.

MLAs P T Thomas, M Ummer and Anoop Jacob spoke from the opposition demanding that the notice should be reconsidered by the business advisory committee (BAC). After the demand was voted out, the report of the BAC was accepted by the assembly.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Flying squads to inspect centres an hour before exam to prevent paper leak
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

LUCKNOW: To eliminate the possibility of question paper leak from sensitive districts, Uttar Pradesh Secondary Education Board (UPSEB) has made it mandatory for the flying squad to inspect the seal of question paper packets an hour before the start of board examination.

A minimum of eight squads will be constituted in each district to conduct multiple checks in each session. Five separate teams would be formed at the divisional level. The teams would comprise district inspector of schools, Government Intermediate College principals, retired teachers and police personnel.

“The squads will have to ensure that secrecy is not breached by leaking the papers before the start of the exam. They will check the question paper packets randomly in each centre,” said UPSEB director Vinay Kumar Pandey.

Besides, members of the flying squad will also apprise the centre superintendents of their authority as “working magistrates” within the boundary of the examination centre. This authority gives them power to take action against any suspicious person or activity. The board has found that a majority of superintendents, in the past, have failed to exercise the power at the crucial stage due to lack of knowledge about it.

With copying mafia graduating from the conventional method of copying and leaking papers to hi-tech methods, the teams have been asked to focus on electronic devices too, said Pandey.

“Apart from copying through papers, new methods involve use of electronic gadgets and devices by students,” he added. The board has already imposed a blanket ban on taking smartphones inside examination centres. The ban also applies to invigilators, centre superintendents as well as inspecting teams.

This year, inspecting teams also have the added responsibility of checking CCTV cameras, routers and audio devices to ensure real-time monitoring of exams from a monitoring cell in all districts.

Title: Aurangabad zilla parishad schools to have half day on Saturdays
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The schools under the aegis of the Aurangabad zilla parishad will have a half day on every Saturday.

The move has been taken to maintain uniformity in the functioning of these schools, which are around 5,000 in number. Earlier, the half-day rule was observed on different days by the school managements.

An official communication notifying the reduced working hours on Saturdays was issued by the ZP authorities on Monday and it will be implemented with immediate effect.

“There was no uniformity in observing the functioning of half day by the ZP schools earlier. Different schools used to observe half day as per their convenience.” according to an official communication issued by Aurangabad ZP .

ZP authorities said that the non-uniform half days of the schools were allowed in keeping with the weekly bazaars in rural areas.

“It was in the interest of the students and their parents. ,” authorities said.

The standing committee of Aurangabad ZP had passed the resolution on December 24 last year. It was ratified by the ZP administration on Monday.

Title: Kulwinderjit Singh proclaimed offender: NIA court
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

MOHALI: The special court of National Investigating Agency (NIA) here on Monday declared alleged Babbar Khalsa International terrorist Kulwinderjit Singh alias Khanpuria as a proclaimed offender. He is wanted in multiple cases of terror acts in Punjab.

During the resumed hearing in the terror module case, the NIA judge made the declaration on hearing prosecution arguments. A chargesheet in this regard was filed in a special NIA court in Mohali on November 22, 2019, against four lleged Babbar Khalsa International terrorists for planning and conspiring to carry out terror acts in Punjab, officials said.

Apart from Khanpuria, the accused included Ravinderpal Singh of Moga , Jagdev Singh alias Sonu of Fatehgarh Sahib, and Harcharan Singh of Delhi.

The NIA said Kulwinderjit was suspected to have fled to Malaysia in January 2019 and had been operating the network from there. “Kulwinderjit is absconding. As per available information, he is in Malaysia. NIA has got a look-out circular issued against him,” a senior NIA officer told TOI.

Punjab Police had arrested Ravinderpal and Jagdev in May 2019. The NIA, during its probe, found that Khanpuria was the chief conspirator and had conspired a planned terror strike. The accused wanted to carry out serial blasts in public spaces, the officials added.

NIA said Khanpuria and his associates were planning to target a few places in Punjab, adding that the accused had even done a reconnaissance of the people and places they wanted to attack by way of explosions.

Title: U’khand lost 1,258 leopards in 19 yrs, 94 big cats killed in 2019
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Haridwar: The Himalayan state has lost 1,258 leopards ever since the state was carved out of Uttar Pradesh in 2000, suggests data of the forest department accessed exclusively by TOI.

Rampant urbanisation in and around forest areas and unchecked solid waste which attracts felines are major causes of man-leopard conflict and deaths of big cats in the state.

Uttarakhand lost 94 leopards in 2019, followed by 105 in 2018 and 102 in 2017. In 2016 and 2015, the hill state lost 88 and 54 leopards respectively.

The top three reasons of big cat deaths have been attributed to natural causes (603) followed by unknown reasons (183) and mutual fights (143). The state also lost 55 leopards to road and rail accidents while 37 animals were poached and 22 were trapped in snare.

Senior scientist at Wildlife Institute of India (WII) S Sathyakumar said, “Leopard is one of the most versatile species as it can adapt to any habitat. Uttarakhand needs to focus on ensuring that villagers are not dumping solid waste in and around forest. Livestock should also not be left unsupervised.”

Experts agreed that the number of man-animal conflicts is increasing due to poor civic habits of residents. Sathyakumar said, “Incidents of leopard and human interaction have increased over the years in Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh due to poor solid waste management systems. The problem needs to be addressed on priority. Abandoned agricultural land has also turned into a secondary forest for leopards.”

The forest department data also suggests that in 2019, maximum 11 leopards each were killed in Pauri, Haridwar and Pithoragarh forest divisions.

A study by WII had last year suggested that abandoned houses in the villages are turning into safe havens for leopards in Pauri Garhwal district. In Haridwar forest division, a killer 30-km stretch of NH-74 that cuts through Shyampur, Rasiyabad and Chidiyapur forest ranges of Hardiwar Forest Division, also claimed maximum four leopards last year.

In Pithoragarh, a combination of reasons has been cited as reasons such as territorial fights and aging behind the deaths, said Vinay Bhargav, DFO of Pithoragarh forest division.

Reacting on the high number of leopard deaths in three forest divisions, chief wildlife warden of Uttarakhand forest department Rajiv Bhartari, said that the department is looking into reasons behind the deaths are trying to figure out solutions.

Title: Ludhiana Zoo to be abuzz with new inmates
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ludhiana: A month after two Royal Bengal tigresses joined the Ludhiana Zoo family, preparations are afoot to welcome another member. A tigress, the third one this year, will join the zoo this week.

With this, the tiger safari, which is a part of the zoo, will have three female and one male big cat.

“Chhattisgar’s Bilaspur Zoo has agreed to give a tigress to the Ludhiana Zoo. Efforts are being made to bring a healthy male tiger, too, for breeding. Besides, there are plans to bring gharials, deer and two new species of birds. We will first make enclosures for gharials and deer and then bring them here,” said a zoo official.

“We have received an approval from Central Zoo Authority of India to bring here more animals. We have also received permission for zoo expansion. Two Himalayan black bears, a male and a female, will be shifted to the Ludhiana Zoo soon,” said a senior wildlife official.

Divisional forest officer Khushwinder Singh said, “Chirag and Ichra, the two tigresses that were brought here in January, are lodged separately and released in the safari in turns daily as they are not friendly with each other. Since they belong to different families, they lack compatibility. If left together, they may end up killing each other.”
