Wildlife officials said Chirag and Ichra were shifted by the wildlife department from Mahendra Chaudhary Zoological Park in Chhatbir, near Zirakpur, to Ludhiana Zoo on January 10. The two had to be quarantined for sometime, so that they could acclimatise to their new habitat before getting released in the safari.

“Initially, Chirag showed aggressive behaviour and attacked a bus ferrying wildlife department officials and guards. But now, she is adapting well. Her aggressiveness too has abated,” said a zoo employee.

The officials are hopeful that increase in the number of big cats would bring more footfalls to the zoo.

“Veterinarians will be working on improving compatibility among the big cats. We are yet to introduce the three of them to each other. Hitherto, they are being lodged separately,” said forest guard Narinder Singh.

Wildlife officials said Mani, 17, the lone male tiger in the safari, was kept in a separate gallery and not released in the safari as a precautionary measure. “He is too old and may hurt himself on coming out. Therefore, it has been decided to keep him in a separate gallery,” a wildlife official added.

Chirag was born in 2008 to Paras and Chorni (both now dead) in Ludhiana tiger safari. She was later shifted to Mahendra Chaudhary Zoological Park. Ichra was born in Bannerghatta National Park, near Bangalore, in 2006.

Of the five big cats Ludhaina Zoo had, three tigresses, Mohini, Elaichi and Shanti, had died in 2013.

Title: Oppn parties send in names for select panels
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Amaravati: Notwithstanding the YSRC’s objection to the formation of select committees to scrutinise the three- capital bill and CRDA repeal bill, opposition parties in the legislative council have sent in names of MLCs to be part of the select committees to the council chairman. TDP, BJP and PDF on Monday submitted their list to the legislative council secretary.

Sources said, TDP named Nara Lokesh, P Ashokbabu, Tippeswamy, BT Naidu and G Sandhya Rani for the panel on three-capital bill, while it suggested Dipak Reddy, Bachula Arjunudu, Bida Ravichandra, Gaunivari Srinivasulu and Budha Venkanna for the CRDA repeal panel. Similarly, BJP put forward the names of both its MLCs for the two committees — PNV Madhav for three-capital committee and Somu Veerraju for CRDA repeal committee. And Progressive Democratic Front (PDF) wants KS Lakshman Rao to be part of the three-capital cities committee and I Venkateswara Rao of the CRDA committee.

Interestingly, YSRC is yet to respond to the chairman’s call. It has objected to the very constitution of the select committees. YSRC chief whip Ummareddi Venkaeswaralu asked the legislative council secretary not to initiate any process with regard to the constitution of the select committees as, he said, the chairman’s decision violates set norms. Similarly, the leader of the House in the council, Pilli Subhash Chandra Bose said they would not be part of the select committees.

As per the rule, finance minister Buggana Rajendranath should head the three-capital cities committee and municipal administration minister Botsa Satyanarayana should head the CRDA repeal bill. In addition to the ministers, YSRC would get one more slot in the committees. Sources said the chairman of the legislative council has authority to name the chairman of the committee in case the ministers choose to abstain from the committees.

Title: SC/ST scholarship scam: Fresh cases registered against 17 institutes
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Roorkee: Haridwar Police at the behest of the SIT registered cases of cheating, forgery and other crimes against the management of 17 private educational institutes on Monday at different police stations of the district, for their involvement in the multi-crore SC/ST scholarship scam .

Six of these institutes are in Haridwar alone, whereas the rest are in Uttar Pradesh, Haryana and Rajasthan. These institutes allegedly siphoned off Rs 10 crore from the social welfare department by faking admissions of SC/ST students from 2011 to 2017.

The SIT, which is investigating the fraud committed by private institutes of Dehradun and Haridwar, has arrested over 20 persons so far and registered over 56 cases against errant institutes.

“The owners of these private institutes will be arrested very soon,” said Manjunath TC, head of the SIT Dehradun and Haridwar.

The six Haridwar institutes were booked under sections 420 (cheating), 409(criminal breach of trust by public servant), 467(forgery of valuable security), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and 471 (using forged document as genuine one) of Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Title: Nashik grapes fetching higher price in Europe
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nashik: Farmers exporting grapes from the district to Europe are fetching good price for their produce as selling price has increased by Rs 25 per kg.

During the same period last year, farmers were getting Rs 70 for per kg of grapes in Europe, but this year the price has increased to around Rs 100 per kg. With grape production in the district affected due to unseasonal rain, the supply has also taken a hit that led to the price rise.

“We are getting good rates for grapes that are being exported to European countries. The rise is around 25-30%,” Manik Patil, senior member of Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh (MRDBS), said.

“There is rise in demand for India grapes in Europe, but supply of export quality grapes is not adequate. The unseasonal rainfall that had lashed the district vineyards in September and October last year have led to decline in grape production. There will be drop in export of grapes, but exact figure can be estimated after February-end,” he added.

Meanwhile, the district has so far recorded 26% drop in registration of vineyards meant for export during the grape season 2019-20 (Dec-April). As per government norms, it is mandatory for the grape farmers to register to export their produce.

According to state agricultural department, around 28,500 farmers have registered their vineyards on a total of 18,000 hectare. Last year, a total of 38,400 grape farmers had registered their vineyards on 24,575 hectare across the district.

“The district, till Sunday, has exported 720 containers with 9,528 tonne of grapes to European countries. During the same period last year, the district had exported 994 containers with 13,247 tonne of grapes,” a state agriculture department official said.

Of the 9,528 tonne of grapes, 6,300 tonne have been exported to The Netherlands, while 1,500 tonne have been sent to Germany.

Title: In a shambles, Linke-Hofmann-Busch coaches an apology for cosy rail travel
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Inner walls in some of the coaches have come off

CHENNAI: The new Linke-Hofmann-Busch (LHB) coaches being introduced for most of the trains may have improved travel comfort but interiors of some of the coaches which are nine months old have already started to come off.

Inner walls and cladding around windows made of fibre-reinforced plastic (FRP) have started to come off since they are fixed with small screws that gets damaged fast. The plastic coating on the doors of toilets is peeling off, while taps and doors of waste bins are broken. These give coaches a shoddy and unclean look, making travel unpleasant.

Last week, food waste was overflowing from stainless steel bins on the Chennai-Thiruvananthapuram Express that started from MGR Central. The scene was no different on the return trip on Saturday. A tap which was broken was found welded with a crude piece of metal to make it usable.

While railways tend to blame irresponsible use and vandalism by passengers for such mess, a railway official said the quality of interior furnishing was not of consistent quality. “The coaches are safer as they do not topple during accidents and are also silent when compared to the conventional coaches of Integral Coach Factory design. But the walls are made of FRP which is not durable for Indian conditions. Since manufacturing is outsourced to multiple agencies, each firm produces materials of varying quality,” he said. “The toilet is a mess because the design is adopted from abroad. It is a dry toilet and not meant for water intensive usage,” he said.

A staff of a firm hired for onboard housekeeping said it was a struggle to meet passenger complaints. “There are often complaints about windows getting jammed,” he said.

“Some of the coaches have expensive toilet fixtures. But the maintenance funds sanctioned are very less and it is not possible to replace taps with the same quality fixtures. So patchwork is done,” the official said.

Indian Railways is in the process of replacing all conventional coaches with LHB design coaches and ICF has stepped up production. It is making around 2,000 coaches a year.

Title: Post on Telegram threatens Tamil Nadu, Delhi cops
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu police are probing a post on the Telegram app in the name of ‘Al Hind Brigade’ threatening to strike against the Tamil Nadu and Delhi police for the recent crackdown on Islamic State modules.

The post has an image of a letter written in Tamil surrounded by guns and grenades. The letter reads: “To the ....(expletive deleted) of Delhi special cell and Q branch, we are watching you and shall respond soon. Keep waiting.”

The post appeared a couple of weeks after the Delhi police arrested suspected TN IS module head Khaja Moideen and two others early in January. A day earlier, the Tamil Nadu police Q branch had apprehended three men suspected to belong to an IS module in Bengaluru. Investigators believe special sub inspector Wilson was gunned down in Kanyakumari district on the night of January 8 by two men angered by the arrest of Khaja Moideen.

A senior TN police officer said various teams are at work trying to identify the people behind the Telegram post. “It was written in Tamil and it naturally indicates the possibility of a Tamil speaking group behind the threat. The group may not be from Tamil Nadu, but can be from anywhere around the globe. But one thing is definite, the group believes in the IS ideology,” said an investigator who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Police sources said the ongoing crackdown against IS modules in south India seems to have irked many groups and their anger is being manifested through some posts.

Not many have heard of the ‘Al Hind Brigade’, except when it claimed responsibility for killing Kamalesh Tiwari, a Hindutva activist in Uttar Pradesh three months ago. Investigators suspect the outfit facilitated travel of many IS sympathisers cross the globe to Syria to join the fight to create an Caliphate since 2014-15.

Title: Centre must revisit budget to revive economy, says PC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chennai: Former Union minister and senior Congress leader P Chidambaram on Monday urged the Centre to revisit the budget that was presented on Saturday if it is keen to revive the ailing Indian economy. Otherwise, the nation has to gear up to face trouble and the year 2020-21 too will turn out to be another wasted year, he said.

Terming the budget presented by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman as a movie that “bombed” after the first show, Chidambaram said despite delivering a marathon speech, people have been left in the dark.

“Unless and otherwise they revisit the budget, as they did last year, we are faced with a situation of very, very moderate growth and there cannot be a revival of economy. But they continue to live in denial,” Chidambaram said, participating in a budget analysis programme organized by the Southern India Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI).

“We are in a situation, where there is an ill patient and a rather incompetent doctor. It is not difficult to predict the repercussions and we will go through a very difficult time in 2020-21. They have to recognize and take radical measures, but there are no signs of behavioural change,” Chidambaram said.

Listing out “demand constraint” and an “investment-starved” economy as two major issues, he said the budget should have addressed them. “While people are not buying, no fresh investment is happening too. Hence, the question should have been – how to stimulate demand and promote investment,” he said.

“The budget should have put money into the hands of crores of people. Instead of increasing MGNREGA allocation to Rs 1 lakh crore, it cut that to Rs 61,500 crore, from earlier Rs 71,000 crore. It could have increased funds to farmers under PM-KISAN scheme. This way, more money would be in the hands of poor and farmers, who will go out and spend, thereby increasing demand,” Chidambaram said.

If there are financial constraints, government should divert funds allocated to long gestation projects like cleaning rivers and building new UDAN airports. Clean rivers and new airports are needed. But, the immediate concern should be to revive consumption demand, he said. He blamed lack of private investment on breakdown of trust, as agencies, vested with extraordinary powers, are harassing everyone to identify the black sheep.

“Exports is another segment that the government should focus. If there are products that others are willing to buy, we can even subsidize it. Of course, WTO will intervene, but that can be tackled,” he said.

Title: SAD Punjab leaders yet to bolster BJP in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

After deciding not to contest Delhi assembly polls, SAD had announced to support BJP

BATHINDA: Having reluctantly lent support to BJP for Delhi assembly elections, Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) leaders from Punjab are refraining from campaigning for their ally.

Only three days are left for campaigning, but no party leader from Punjab, including party president Sukhbir Singh Badal, has campaigned in support of BJP candidates so far. Leaders of SAD’s Delhi unit, including president Manjinder Singh Sirsa, are campaigning for candidates of the alliance partner.

SAD, which had announced to not contest the February 8 elections over Muslims’ exclusion from CAA and fewer seats being left for it by the BJP, took a U-turn on January 29, that it would support the right-wing party as their tie-up was emotional.

The absence of leaders from Delhi campaigning is said to be a fallout of a tension growing between the two parties. SAD leaders said they would take part in campaigning, but expenses incurred on campaigning could be counted in the name of the candidate instead of the party. “To save this expense, SAD leaders have not been invited for campaigning,” said one of the SAD members.

With BJP not paying any heed to SAD’s demand for leaving some seats, the nearly 24-year-old alliance had come under threat. With its demand not being met by BJP, Akalis decided not to contest the Delhi polls and took many days to extend support to alliance partners. Senior party leader and Rajya Sabha member Balwinder Singh Bhunder and SAD Delhi unit head Sirsa had given different versions about not contesting the polls. Bhunder claimed that there was problem on allotment of tickets, Sirsa claimed that as SAD had a different stand on the CAA, they had decided against fighting the elections.

When contacted, Delhi SAD chief Sirsa said they were campaigning aggressively for BJP candidates. “As it is the election for Delhi, leaders from here are into campaigning. Party leaders from Punjab too will jump for campaigning.”

An aide of SAD president Sukhbir denied reports of any trouble between both alliance partners. He said, “The SAD Delhi unit leaders are actively campaigning for the BJP candidates at various constituencies. Whenever the BJP will call Sukhbir, he will go for campaigning.”

Title: Citizens to take ‘Ease of Living’ survey
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) on Monday urged the citizens to participate in ease of living survey launched by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs.

The survey is being held in 114 cities across India, which fall under the ‘smart cities mission’, and rank them according to different parameters. The objective of the survey is to help cities assess their liveability vis-a-vis global and national benchmarks. It also encourages cities to move towards an outcome-based approach to urban planning and management.

As part of the ‘Ease of Living’ Index Assessment, a citizen perception survey is being conducted on behalf of the ministry. “This is a very important component of the assessment exercise as it will help indirectly capturing perception of citizens concerning the quality of life in their cities” said Prakash Thavil, CEO, NMSCDCL.

The survey is being administered both online and offline and has commenced from February 1. The residents have to give their feedback online on — Eol2019.org/citizenfeedback. They can also use the QR code to scan and register their vote. The residents can give their feedback by February 29.

“Nashik has participated in ease of living survey, which examines the liveability of the city for the citizens. 1% of the total population of the city must have to give their feedback,” Thavil said.

The citizens have to give feedback based on 24 subjects, including governance, education, health, cleanliness, water supply, safety, and security, economic opportunities, employment, availability of affordable housing, power supply, transportation, recreation, environment, public services, and life style.

Meanwhile, the municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game on Monday instructed the officials to continue their cleanliness drive even though the Swachh Survekshan 2020 is over.

The teams of centers had visited the city for Swachh Survekshan in the second half of December last year. They visited various parts of the city to ensure that the garbage is not being dumped in the open. They had also taken feedback from the residents about cleanliness in the city.

Title: After Sidhu Moosewala, complaint against Punjabi singer Afsana Khan for indecent song
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Afsana Khan

BATHINDA: Punjabi singer Afsana Khan has landed in trouble by singing songs allegedly singing obscene songs at the government senior secondary school in Badal village of Muktsar district. This happened just a day after a case was registered against Punjabi singers Sidhu Moosewala and Mankirt Aulakh for allegedly promoting violence through a song uploaded on social media.

Punjabi language votary Panditrao Dharenvar has filed a complaint with Muktsar police seeking action against Khan, who lives at Zirakpur in Mohali district, but hails from Badal. On Saturday, she had visited the village school where she made students sing with her briefly. A video clip of her singing at the school had gone viral on TikTok.

Dharenvar told TOI said, “In its order on July 22, 2019, the Punjab and Haryana high court had observed that glorification of violence has given rise to culture of gangsters. The court also took notice of the fact that glorification of liquor, drugs and violence in the songs in Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh has increased in the recent times. These songs affect the children of impressionable age. The DGPs of Punjab and Haryana were directed to ensure that no songs were played glorifying liquor, wine, drugs and violence in any song even in live shows.”

Muktsar district education officer (secondary) Malkit Singh said a show cause notice had been issued to the school principal to clarify why the singer was allowed to sing such songs. “Any action will be taken after getting reply from the principal,” he said.

Muktsar SSP Raj Bachan Singh Sandhu said, “We have got the complaint through e-mail from Dharenvar and are looking into the matter. Action will be taken after thoroughly investigating the issue,”

Earlier, Moosewala had questioned the Punjab government and censor board. He said that if the government blamed songs for drugs and weapons then it should ban liquor shops and stop giving arms licences.

Title: Huge water reservoir found in Barmer
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

JAIPUR: After oil, now another discovery is set to change the lives of people in Barmer. A vast reservoir holding approximately 480 billion cubic meters of water stretching across Barmer and Jalore districts, has been discovered.

Seismic surveys, petrophysical data, and detailed hydro-geological investigations conducted during the hydrocarbon exploration by Cairn Oil & Gas led to the discovery of these huge aquifers in the Barmer Basin. These aquifers are a part of Thumbli water reserves and can fulfil drinking water requirements of the region for many decades to come.

The projected annual domestic and drinking water demand for India is just 55 billion cubic meters (BCM) by 2025 and 90 BCM 2050.

The latest water discovery is spread over the blocks of Baitu, Shiv, Barmer, Gudamalani, and Sanchore Kurd (Jalore) with a depth that ranges from 350 meters to 1,500 meters.

However, the only challenge to this project lies in the salinity of the water in the reservoir. The quantity of salt in the water from the Thumbli reserve ranges from 5000 mg per litre to 20,000 mg per litre while the permissible limit of salt in drinking water is 1,000 mg or less.

The silver lining to this cloud is that many desalination plants are operating successfully in India and other countries. The government in partnership with private companies and with the latest technologies can overcome this obstacle to ensure that this parched land is once again transformed into a land of plenty.

Title: Punjab: Car crash in fog, Badshah unscathed
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Aditya Pratik Singh Sisodia

PATIALA: Rapper Aditya Pratik Singh Sisodia, known as Badshah, had a narrow escape at an under-construction overbridge on an intersection of National Highway 44 near Rajpura on Monday morning as the high-end car he was travelling in crashed into concrete slabs kept along the road by workers of the company that has undertaken the project.

While the car was badly damaged, Badshah wasn’t hurt. The driver could not see the slabs kept on the road due to thick fog. The slabs had been kept near the diversion at the intersection with no safety signs in place. Even as the deadline to complete the four-laning of the Panipat-Jalandhar stretch of the NH-44 ended in March 2011, the project has not been completed at various points along the 291km section. The construction company could not be contacted for comment.

Title: Bathinda society told to stop langar at Bikaner hospital
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

This is the second time in seven months that Shri Harikrishan Welfare Society has been asked to stop

BATHINDA: After nearly seven months, the Bikaner district administration has again restrained a society from a Bathinda village from cooking and serving langar for patients and their relatives on the premises of Acharya Tulsi Dass regional cancer hospital and research centre.

The hospital authorities and Bikaner deputy commissioner on Sunday stopped Shri Harikrishan Welfare Society of Koreana village from preparing and serving langar and asked its functionaries to get permission for the same from the state government.

In July 2019, the hospital administration had stopped the society from serving langar after which the society members along with former Talwandi Sabo MLA Jeet Mohinder Singh Sidhu of Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) had met Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal , who had asked them to continue the langar.

Now, the society members have decided to meet the Rajasthan chief minister to seek permission to continue with their welfare activity.

Aiming to provide healing touch to patients and their relatives, the society had been preparing and serving langar for the past six years at Bikaner. The society used to collect ration from 15 villages in Talwandi Sabo sub-division in Bathinda. Sources said some persons having eateries had put pressure on the administration to stop the langar so that local people could make a profit by feeding persons visiting the cancer hospital.

Acting principal of Acharya Tulsi Dass institute Dr H S Kumar said, “The society was running langar without permission from the state government. The society has been asked to get proper permission in writing to restart the langar and till then it has been asked to stop the operations.”

Title: Tension over Ranjit Singh Dhadrianwale's Sangrur event
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

PATIALA: Tension gripped Gadiani and adjoining Kanakwal Bhanguan villages in Sangrur district on Monday after a few members of some Sikh organisations gathered to oppose a religious congregation by Sikh preacher Ranjit Singh Dhadrianwale .

Dhadrianwale had planned to conduct a three-day ‘dewan’ in Gadiani village starting Monday. However, at around 1pm, individuals owing allegiance to some Sikh organisations started gathering in Kanakwal Bhanguan village gurudwara. They said they would oppose the preacher and not allow him to hold event as “his preachings were not aligned with the teachings of the Sikh Gurus and he was spreading misinformation in the name of religion”.

Hearing about the gathering, police reached the durdwara and detained the individuals inside till 4pm. They were let off only after the event at Gidiana got over. However, the protestors claimed that they would attempt to stall the dewan on Tuesday.

Sangrur SSP Sandeep Garg said the situation was being monitored and no one would be allowed to disturb the law and order situation. He said the Sikh preacher had sought all required permissions to hold the congregation and police teams had been asked to thwart any attempts to disrupt the event.

Title: Centre readies draft DPR for river linking exercise after Jagan’s request
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Amaravati: In a boost to the state government’s plans to link rivers Godavari , Krishna , Penna and Kaveri, the Centre has readied the draft Detailed Project Report.

Following chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s request, the Centre has got the study completed by National Water Development Agency (NWDA). The river linking of Godavari, Krishna and Penna would help tap nearly 247 tmc of water going waste into sea and divert for feeding of drought-hit Prakasam, Nellore and four Rayalaseema districts.

Union Jal Shakti Abhiyan minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawath said the report has been sent to the states for their comments. In response to a question posed by Rajya Sabha member V Vijaysai Reddy during the ongoing Budget session in the Parliament on Monday, the minister said that the chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy had requested the Centre last August to consider linking the four rivers and requested financial support for the big project.

While Godavari will be linked either at Itchamapalli or Janampet, the second link would come at Nagarjuna Nagar and Krishna would be linked with Penna at Somasila. In the final lap, Penna would be linked with Kaveri near grand anicut.

According to DPR, linking of Godavari, Krishna and Penna would help provide irrigation water to about 3.5 to 5 lakh hectors of agriculture fields in Guntur, Prakasam,Nellore and Chittoor districts. It also said that the linking would help stabilization of ayucut under Nagarjuna Sagar Right Canal (NSRC).

The minister said the Centre would initiate action on the final DPR after getting responses from respective states. He said that the Centre would take statutory clearances before launching the project.

In response to another question raised by Vijayasai Reddy, shipping minister Mansukh Lal Mandaviya said that the Centre granted 32 road and 21 rail projects to AP under Sagar Mala project.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Three co-flyers of Kochi woman in Kolkata hospital
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Masks have been made compulsory in ID Hospital’s emergency and isolation wards

KOLKATA: Three novel coronavirus suspects have been put under observation in the isolation ward of Infectious Diseases & Beliaghata General Hospital (ID&BG). All three had flown into Kolkata from Kunming on January 23 on the same flight that carried the medical student from Kerala who tested positive for the virus.

“Currently, we have admitted three persons in our isolation ward and they are under observation. Their swab samples were taken on Monday and sent to NICED Kolkata for confirmatory tests,” said ID&BG medical superintendent and vice-principal Ashish Manna. While one of the passengers is from Kolkata, the other two are from Jhargram and North 24 Parganas.

Sources in the health department said none of the three showed any prominent symptom of the virus but since they travelled on the same plane as the medical student, who tested positive for the virus—she is the first coronavirus patient in the country—they had been admitted to the state’s referral hospital for infectious diseases as a precautionary measure.

Health department officials, who have started tracking down passengers from Bengal who had travelled by the same flight from Kunming, have so far zeroed in on four flyers. While three have been admitted to ID Hospital, the fourth person is in home isolation.

“The health department is constantly in touch with the fourth person who is in home isolation. We expect to get results of the three samples from NICED by Tuesday,” said Ajay Chakraborty, director, health services.

Two other male patients, both from Kolkata, also turned up at ID&BG Hospital on their own on Tuesday. One of them, who landed here from South Korea via Beijing on January 10, said he had cold and cough and so, wanted to get the test done. But when the hospital authorities said he had to be admitted to the isolation ward if his samples were to be taken, he returned home. The second person had returned from China on January 29. Sources said the man was asymptomatic but he initially had gone to a private hospital off EM Bypass out of anxiety. From there, he was referred to ID Hospital. Doctors examined him at the emergency and sent him home with the advice of home isolation.

All medical and non-medical staff members at the hospital’s emergency wing and isolation ward have been directed to wear masks while on duty.

“The masks are meant as a precautionary measure. These should be no reason for panic. At the same time, we have to take all preventive steps to stay on the safe side,” said Anima Halder, principal at ID&BG Hospital.

Title: Maharashtra schools to start anti-tobacco drive
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Schools in Maharashtra have been asked to carry out awareness activity to inform students about the ill-effects of tobacco consumption to mark the World Cancer Day , on Tuesday.

As part of the initiative, educational institutions will carry out a symbolic ‘Holi’ of different tobacco products.

The state government has issued directives to the office of Education Commissioner and directorate of both primary and secondary education.

Salaam Mumbai Foundation, a Mumbai-based NGO working on the mission of creating a tobacco-free Maharashtra, has joined hands with the government for the special initiative.

Prashant Redis, leader of the state-level association of principals, has appealed to the school authorities to support and encourage students to take part in the activities.

“Young minds are ideal to inculcate necessary information about the ill-effects of tobacco consumption. The teenage population is one of the most vulnerable groups which can fall prey to the consumption of different types of tobacco,” he said. The World Cancer Day is organized by the Union for International Cancer Control.

Title: Kusumagraj award to Sai Parajapye
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

NASHIK: Kusumagraj Pratishthan , a cultural organisation, has declared its list of awardees for the year.

Noted film-maker Sai Paranjapye, Padma Shri awardee and noted Manipuri dancer Darshana Jhaveri, Arjun Award winner wrestler Kaka Pawar, sculptor Bhagwan Rampure, who has sculpted the bronze Bull at Dalal Street in Mumbai, transgender activist Gauri Sawant and renowned ecologist Madhav Gadgil are the awardees.

The award will be given on March 10 at the hands of the president of the organisation, Chandrashekhar Dharmadhikari, who is an ex-justice of Bombay HC.

Makarand Hingane, executive member of the organisation, said “The organisation is pleased to recognise these great personalities, who have contributed extraordinarily in various fields. The awards were initiated by V V Shirwadkar himself.”

Since 1992, the organisation recognises the exemplary work done by the artists in six branches – dance, sculpture, sports, social service, film and science every alternate year. The award includes the prize money of Rs 21,000 and a memento.

State cabinet ministers Subhash Desai and Chhagan Bhujbal will release the documentary on Kusumagraj titled ‘Godakathcha Mahakavi’ made by organisation on February 27, the poet’s birth anniversary.

Chandrakant Kulkarni, director of the documentary, said they worked for a year to make the Marathi documentary, which has three parts(poems, plays and a biographical compilation).

The organisation has decided not to put the documentary on its website and instead will showcase it every weekend at its auditorium after the ceremony.

Title: Leopard, tiger spotted near collectorate in US Nagar, forest dept begins search using drones
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nainital: The forest department has started an all-round search operation near the collectorate building in Rudrapur area of US Nagar district after residents spotted a leopard in the area on Friday evening.

Speaking to TOI, officials of the forest department said that though the operation had started on Saturday morning but they failed to spot the leopard. However, in the evening, a tiger was also seen in the area after which the officials came with drones and JCB machines on Sunday and began their search.

“We were informed by the locals that a tiger was also spotted in the area. After this we started the search operation using drones to locate the animals safely,” said UC Tiwari, SDO of Teria Central Forest Division.

Gaurav Pant, a resident, said, “The area has several government offices, including the collectorate. The tall grasses and bushes pose a threat to locals, including several officials of SIDCUL.”

Tiwari, meanwhile, said that they have not been able to locate the animals using drones therefore the bushes and grass are being cleared. “We could not find the animals therefore we started a controlled fire and then cleared the bushes from one side. Now that the area has been cleared locals need not worry about the animals,’ he said.

Title: Man, kin booked for giving poison to wife, kids in Budaun
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bareilly: An FIR has been lodged against a man and eight members of his family on Monday for giving poison to his 35-year-old wife and two children on Sunday evening. Police said prima facie, it appears that after fight with her husband Vijnesh, Premvati committed suicide by consuming poison. Her two sons aged six and five were also given poison.

Premvati and her sons died during treatment on Sunday night. However, the woman’s father on Monday gave a police complaint alleging that Vijnesh along with his eight family members killed Premvati and the children. Police said the accused were absconding.

According to police, Premvati and Vijnesh, a farmer and resident of Alauaa village under Wazirganj police station, were married around eight years ago. The couple had two children - Mohit (6) and Rohit (5). The locals took the trio to a private hospital where doctors declared the children as dead. Premvati was referred to higher centre in Bareilly, but she died on way to hospital.

On Monday, station house officer, Wazirganj, Pradeep Yadav, said, “On the complaint of Premvati’s father, we have lodged an FIR against Vijnesh, his brothers Rakesh and Swaraj, his mother Ganga Devi, his sister Susheela, his father Amarpal, his uncles Nahne, Ramveer and Sukhchain under IPC section 302 [murder]. All the accused are absconding. The complainant alleged that Premvati’s in-laws used to harass her. Initial probe suggests that Premvati committed suicide and gave poison to her kids after fight with Vijnesh over marital dispute. We are investigating the matter.”

Title: Arvind Kejriwal's ‘shifty character’, did nothing exceptional: Punjab CM Amarinder Singh
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Amarinder Singh during a road show with Shivani Chopra in Delhi on Monday

CHANDIGARH: On the first day of his campaigning in Delhi, Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Monday slammed his Delhi counterpart and AAP supremo Arvind Kejriwal on his “tall claims of providing cheap power to Delhiites”, calling him a “shifty character”, who had mastered the art of “deceit and lies to mislead the people”.

Capt Amarinder also accused BJP of converting the entire country into Shaheen Bagh and using it to polarise elections in Delhi and, in the process, “destroying India’s foundations”.

Taking on Kejriwal, the CM said the AAP leader had done nothing exceptional by providing cheap power and setting up mohalla clinics, as all chief ministers of the Congress-ruled states were doing the same. “Some people will surely be happy with these freebies but what has he really done for the development and progress of Delhi? What has he done for creating jobs for your children?” he said, while questioning Kejriwal on how many jobs had AAP given to youth in Delhi.

Amarinder, who was addressing a public meeting in Hari Nagar in favour of Congress candidate Surinder Setia , said there had been virtually no progress in Delhi in the last five years. “In Punjab we have given jobs to 11 lakh youths,” he said adding that what Delhi needed was economic and industrial development. He, however, regretted that both AAP and BJP had sacrificed the interests of Delhiites in their turf war.

Castigating BJP, Capt Amarinder said, “They are attempting to polarise the elections here with Shaheen Bagh but they will not succeed, as people have seen through their game.” He said the entire country had in fact become Shaheen Bagh with protests against CAA and NRC happening across the nation.

“There is unrest in universities. Students are on the streets across the country, and are being shot at,” he alleged, adding that this was not the India for which so many had sacrificed themselves. “In contrast to the divisive politics of BJP, which had weakened the nation, the Congress had always worked towards strengthening India,” he claimed.

Amarinder said in Assam, names of 19 lakh people had been included in the NRC. “Will they put them all in detention camps that they have built,” he asked adding that where would all those people, who are being brand as non-citizens, go?

In an informal chat with mediapersons, Amarinder said, “Kejriwal is giving subsidy on power to only a section of residential consumers and spending Rs 1,600 to Rs 1,700 crores on it, while my government spends Rs 9,000 to Rs 10,000 crores on electricity subsidy to all sections of society. He is subsidising power only to a section of residential customers and making commercial and industrial consumers in Delhi pay through their nose by cross subsidising them.”

While the CM refused to predict how many seats the Congress would win in Delhi, he said the party was in a strong position. He said the claims of an AAP wave in Delhi were a myth, as it was in Punjab in 2017.

Title: Protesters on alert, start checking at entry points
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

NEW DELHI: The second round of firing at Jamia on Sunday night has put the protesters at Shaheen Bagh , too, on alert . Compared to Sunday, more protesters stood at the entry of each lane and checked everyone entering and said, “Aap ki suraksha ke liye kar rahe hai, cooperate kijiye (We are doing this for your own safety, please cooperate).” There were also instructions to check the two-wheelers parked close to the protest site.

On entering the area, like the walls in Jamia, the walls of the protest site at Shaheen Bagh are also being adorned with graffiti. With the protest being led by women, the graffiti on one of the walls shows two women in hijab holding the Constitution. Not just art, the protest site against CAA/NRC will also witness participation and solidarity of artists like Prateek Kuhad, Subha Mudgal and several others till February 7.

The Fearless Collective is decorating the walls at the site with graffiti. The artist Shilo has been adorning the walls for a week now. A local of the area, looking at the graffiti, said, “We should take permission from other building owners too and get it painted.”

While from the stage, songs of “Inquilab Zindabad” and “Halla bol” rang, Ishrat Jahan, a regular at the protest, asked, “Has police presence increased here too or it is just in Jamia? But police itself facilitates the entry of such people, so we cannot trust them.”

Meanwhile, PTI reported that a plea was filed in the Supreme Court on Monday seeking a direction to authorities to remove the protesters from Shaheen Bagh.

Title: Mutt properties to be listed
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Tirupati: Officials from the state endowments department, in the presence of revenue department staff, broke open locked rooms and inspected several documents at Sri Swamy Hathiramji mutt in Tirupati on Monday.

Last week, the state government sacked Arjun Das, the mahant (chief priest) of Sri Hathiramji math on grounds of irregularities and appointed Srikalahasti temple EO C Chandrasekhar Reddy as the mutt’s in-charge.

Speaking to reporters, Chandrasekhar Reddy said “I assumed charge of Hathiramji mutt on January 29, as per the directions of commissioner of Dharmika Parishad. We found that some rooms in the mutt were locked and informed the same to the commissioner. Further, with the directions of the commissioner we broke open the locks in the presence of the revenue inspector, tahsildar and other officials. We will list out the records and properties of the mutt and send the list and relevant documents to the commissioner.”

Meanwhile, BJP functionaries, led by state spokesperson Samanchi Srinivas, staged protests at Hathiramji mutt premises in Tirupati on Monday. Speaking to reporters, Samanchi Srinivas demanded the government hand over the administration of the math to the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams executive officer.

“Hathiramji mutt was the administrator of the Lord Venkateswara temple for 90 before the TTD was formed. It was during this period that the mutt received several donations. Protection of the properties are the prime responsibility of the state government. There should be a list of lands and other property, including jewellery in the possession of the mutt,” Samanchi Srinivas demanded.

Title: Expatriates demonstrate in front of UN
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kolkata: On Saturday afternoon, nearly 150 people from India, residing in Europe, staged a protest in front of United Nations in Geneva against CAA , NRC, NPR and the police brutalities meted out to students at JNU, AMU and Jamia Milia. They also condemned the recent attack on the Jamia student.

The demonstration started by explaining why they were against NRC and CAA, followed by a reading of the Constitution’s Preamble. Singing Varun Grover’s ‘Hum Kagaz Nahin Dikhayenge’, reciting Faiz’s ‘Hum Dekhenge’ and ‘Where the mind is without fear’, students and professionals raised their voices to protect the democratic and inclusive idea of India. Several from India, including JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh, sent out statements which were read out by the protesters.

Title: Former Congress MLA Ramesh Singla joins AAP
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ramesh Singla

CHANDIGARH: Congress functionary and former MLA from Nabha, Ramesh Singla, joined Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) in the presence of Sangrur MP Bhagwant Mann in Delhi on Monday.

Taking a dig at Congress government in Punjab, Singla said it had disappointed every section of society by reneging on the promises made ahead of the state assembly elections.

He also drew a comparison with the AAP government in Delhi, claiming that the latter had done better.

Formally inducting him in the party, AAP Punjab chief Mann said Singla played his political innings in various capacities spanning over decades and did not succumb to any political pulls and pressures of the Congress leadership and stood by people of his area during the militancy period.

With Singla’s exit, it was proven that leaders with clean image were being ignored while sycophants were being promoted to meet their petty political ends in Congress. Leader of opposition in Punjab assembly Harpal Singh Cheema said Singla’s political experience would be utilised to strengthen the party to the fullest.

Title: Coronavirus Kolkata: CISF distributes masks to personnel at Kolkata airport to guard against coronavirus
Content:
The CISF personnel at the airport have been told to wear the masks throughout their duty hours

KOLKATA: Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) personnel deployed at Kolkata airport have been issued protective masks to guard against the spread of coronavirus from passengers.Sources in the force told TOI the decision to provide masks to all personnel at airports was taken after the coronavirus scare . Initially, the decision was to provide masks to all personnel deployed at international wings, where the chance of dealing with a coronavirus carrier was high, particularly flyers arriving from China. Later, it was decided that masks would be provided to everyone on duty at airports.According to a senior CISF official, the order came last week. “We were told to wear masks as a precaution. We had initially approached the airport director for masks but as we were told that they would need some time to get them, we got them on our own. As told, all CISF personnel, especially those at the international wing, have been wearing masks since last Saturday,” said the official.Another official said CISF dealt with passengers at close quarters, first at the time of entry, then at security check-in, leaving them at high risk of catching the infection. “That is true not only among those on duty in the international section but also those at the domestic wing as international passengers can also fly on the domestic network after arriving here,” he said. Personnel at the terminal entry gates and frisking points at security check have been particularly asked to don the masks all the time as they are the most vulnerable due to their proximity to passengers. “We would like to introduce a regimen in which the personnel wear the masks throughout their duty, even after the coronavirus scare is over as, given the huge number of people they deal with daily. The habit is yet to set in. So some of them, like those screening cabin bags and away from direct passenger contact, are still reluctant to wear masks,” said another official.In November 2019, when the air quality in the Delhi-NCR region had plummeted drastically, CISF had issued N-95 anti-pollution masks to its personnel at IGI Airport, Delhi Metro, government buildings, Special Service Group (SSG) and other units, directing them to wear them till the AQI improved. The masks distributed for protection against coronavirus are also N-95, where respirators are thicker, making it difficult for some to wear them for prolonged periods. Those wearing the mask need to fit the respirator around the nose, cheeks and chin to ensure that they don’t breathe around the edges of the respirator. “If the mask is not worn properly, it is difficult to breathe and so, the reluctance to use it at a stretch. It will take getting used to,” a jawan said.

Title: Port City 4th in Swachh survey’s feedback block
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Port City has ranked fourth in the feedback component of Swachh Survekshan 2020, with over 4 lakh people, which amounts to nearly 23% of the city’s population, submitting their responses both online and offline. The citizen feedback component carries a 25% weightage in the survey. The final rankings of SS-2020 is likely to be released in the later half of March.

Apart from Visakhapatnam, the other four cities which made it to the top-5 list in citizen feedback are from Uttar Pradesh. Ghaziabad leads the pack with more than 13 lakh responses (76% of city’s population). Agra secured the second highest responses in the country (11.5 lakh or 60% of city’s population), followed by Lucknow (12.33 lakh feedbacks or 44% of city’s population), Visakhapatnam (4.02 lakh responses) and Varanasi (2.2 lakh responses or 18% of city’s population).

When it comes to citizen engagement on social media, Visakhapatnam stands second. The other leading cities in social media engagements are Lucknow, Hyderabad, Tirupati, Ghaziabad and Roorkee.

GVMC additional commissioner III V Sanyasi Rao said the 2020 survey received an unprecedented response from the citizens. “The response can be gauged from the feedback submission of nearly one-fourth population of the city. We are expecting a better rank this time,” Rao told TOI.

Both Vijayawada and Tirupati got about 1.22 lakh responses each in the citizen feedback component. Other than Visakhapatnam, Vijayawada and Tirupati, no other city from Andhra Pradesh has garnered 1 lakh responses.

Vizag leading the SS feedback is not a new phenomenon as the city outscored all other Indian cities in the 2018 Swachh Survekshan by receiving nearly 1.61 lakh responses. South Delhi municipal corporation, which was then in second place, garnered about 1.2 lakh responses.

Even though the feedback component carries only a 25% weightage, it reflects the interest among and participation of residents in the city’s cleanliness and sanitation activities.

Title: Millennium Towers get ready to house secretariat
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Millennium Towers, at Rushikonda, will also house the CMO and other key offices

Visakhapatnam: With the Millennium Towers and nearby structures in Rushikonda likely to house the chief minister’s office, secretariat and other key offices after the executive powers are branched out to Visakhapatnam, the state government on Monday released a budget of Rs 19.7 crore towards the construction of the Millennium Tower-B at Rushikonda. The tower, which is almost complete, will have a built-up area of nearly 1 lakh sq ft.

Tower-A, located next to Tower-B, was constructed at the cost of about Rs 150 crore about a year ago and has a built-up area of nearly 2 lakh square feet. A leading business process services company is currently operating out of the Tower-A, with about half the built-up area lying vacant in Tower-A. The state government is also considering utilising the nearby Incubation Tower to house some key offices. Several senior bureaucrats visited these towers during their recent visit to the city to take stock of the location, amenities and logistics.

On the other hand, some officials are in the process of identifying several buildings and apartments in and around Rushikonda, Bheemili and Tagarapuvalasa to locate possible locations for government offices and for the accommodation of senior officials.

Title: ‘Withdraw hike in NCCD on cigarettes’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Guntur: The Federation of All India Farmers ’ Associations (Faifa) has demanded that the Centre withdraw the increase of National Calamity Contingency Duty (NCCD) on cigarettes, proposed in the Budget, as it would cripple the domestic market.

In a representation to the Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, sent on Monday, Faifa said the hike in NCCD on cigarettes has shocked farmers as they were expecting concessions.“After fighting torrential and unseasonal rains this year, (FCV) tobacco farmers from AP and Karnataka are worried about facing an unfavourable market. The Centre has stunned us with the hike in NCCD,” said Faifa. And this comes in the wake of FCV farmers already battling crop damage and stiff competition from illegal cigarette market, said the body’s national spokesperson Jaswanth. tnn

Title: Women coach for women sports teams in Haryana: Sandeep Singh
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Haryana government will also write to the federations to depute more women coaches with women teams

KURUKSHETRA: In a decision that will be primarily applicable to state-run sports academies, the Haryana sports ministry has said it would ensure only women coaches and managers for all women’s teams representing the state.

Haryana sports and youth affairs minister Sandeep Singh on Monday said, “The women players will feel more secure if they have women coaches and managers and their families too will be less anxious during their travel.”

“If for some reason, a male coach or manager accompanies a women’s team, he will be given strict instructions not to stay with the team at night and he will have to make arrangements for his stay at some distance from the women’s team,” the minister said.

Asked about the sports federations or associations which are under no obligation to depute same gender coaches, Sandeep said, “We will recommend, suggest and write to the federations to depute more women coaches with women teams and male coaches with male teams of Haryana. Normally, when a Haryana team goes to a tournament, our coaches accompany them as the federations do not have their coaches.”

“It will be beneficial for everybody if the federations and state sports department work in tandem to bring better results. If we recommend something and the federations don’t accept the same, this will only hamper the outcome,” the minister added.

Asked if federations do not accept directions or recommendations, Sandeep said, “In that case, we will take action against the respective sports federation or association.”

“Letters will also be sent to state sports federations of school, junior, senior levels for deputing same-gender coaches for players, so that we can boost the confidence of female players at all levels in Haryana,” the minister said.

Asked if there are enough women coaches for different levels, the minister said, “In Haryana, we have the best women sports coaches and their number is also good. In case, we struggle to provide women coaches, we will ensure stay arrangements for male coaches away the women players. In those cases, we will try to send women managers with the teams.”

Title: Michael Lobo’s demand: Reshuffle cabinet after ZP elections
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Michael Lobo

PANAJI: Waste management minister Michael Lobo on Monday demanded for a cabinet and portfolio reshuffle to “increase the performance of the government”. Lobo also said that the cabinet would be reshuffled after the zilla panchayat elections scheduled on March 15.

“New MLAs, who are capable of being ministers , should be made ministers, and those who need to be dropped should be dropped. I have made these demands. The time has come for portfolio reshuffle,” Lobo told reporters on Monday.

The cabinet comprises 12 ministers, including chief minister Pramod Sawant, and was last reshuffled in July 2019, after ten Congress MLAs joined the BJP . Sawant had dropped three ministers from GFP and one independent MLA to pave the way for four of the newly inducted MLAs.

He also said that senior party functionaries will assess the performance of the minister and then take a decision.

‘After ZP election, the cabinet would be reshuffled. If this correction is done, it would be better,” he said.

The Sawant-led BJP government is scheduled to complete its first year next month. Sawant had taken over the reins of the state two days after the death of former chief minister Manohar Parrikar on March 17, 2019.

“Our BJP leaders in Goa and Delhi knows about this issue. To increase the performance of this government, this (reshuffle) should be done,” Lobo said.

Stating that he too could be dropped if the chief minister felt he was not performing, Lobo said that the need of the hour was to have in place ministers who can generate revenue for their departments.

Lobo said he had made a similar demand during the tenure of then chief minister Laxmikant Parsekar. Parsekar had refused to effect a cabinet reshuffle except for changing the portfolio of a minister of its then ally, MGP. In the assembly election that followed in February 2017, BJP was pushed to second position with just 13 seats in the house of 40.

“When we were 13, we had to give away some of our portfolios to GFP. Two of them did not even know how to get the work done,” Lobo said.

Title: Himachal Pradesh: Israeli national conceals 2.5kg charas in bowls, held
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Specially designed bowls that were used to conceal the drug by Jerusalem-based Shaul Borov

MANALI: An Israeli national, who came out with a new idea to smuggle charas (hashish) out of Kullu , was arrested with 2.5kg of the contraband.

Intending to sell charas in Varanasi at higher prices, Shaul Borov, 42, of Jerusalem, Israel, spent a month to conceal 2.5kg charas in 10 small and large size bowls, police said.

While the inner layer of bowls was metallic (copper), the outer shell was of other material and had designs. The accused managed to fill the gap with such a large quantity of charas. He rented a room at Vashisht village near Manali to execute the job, police added.

Kullu superintendent of police Gaurav Singh said the accused was here on a tourist visa and lived in a rented room at Vashisht village. “He was trying to ferry the consignment to Varanasi. He spent a month in concealing the contraband in his room. He had filled charas in empty gap and sealed it properly. A police team had stopped a private Volvo bus plying on Manali-Delhi route for checking and recovered the contraband on Sunday night,” he said.

In the past two months, police have arrested eight foreigners allegedly involved in supplying chitta to Kullu and other regions of the country or for charas smuggling. “Five Nigerians, two Ivorian and a Russian have been arrested in the past two months under the NDPS Act,” the SP said.

Police sources said the smugglers have become a headache as they have adopting new techniques to conceal charas. On an average, Kullu police foil a bid to smuggle charas or chitta in every two days, but some still manage to go out of Himachal .

The prices of charas, especially Malana cream, are many times higher in other states.

Not just roads, the smugglers at times trek for days to smuggle charas. Concealing charas in shoes, body, books, apple cartons, backpacks, tyres of vehicle, seats, and under dashboard had been a conventional method, sources said. Smugglers also use Nepalese persons as carriers on a commission basis.

Sources said while the smugglers are coming with more innovative ideas, the police force is also getting smarter in order to check smuggling of drugs.

Title: Police conduct flag marches, Maharashtra says won’t file case if stir called off
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

MUMBAI: The Maharashtra government has urged anti-CAA protesters at "Mumbai Bagh" to withdraw their eight-day-long agitation and assured them that it will not file any case against them if they move out. Nagpada police, in the past week, had issued notices under the preventive Section 149 of the Criminal Procedure Code to seven locals, warning them that if any untoward incidents took place, they would be booked.

A delegation of former and present MLAs and women representatives of the protesters met the minister on Monday after certain issues cropped up at the protest site from Saturday. Police had on Saturday tried to get the group to withdraw, without success.

Former MLA Waris Pathan said they had asked Deshmukh to take back the notices issued. “We will meet the core committee of the protestors and take a unanimous decision about the next step,” Pathan said. He said a decision if the protest has to be taken back or if it can be shifted to another location would be taken in a meeting scheduled at night at the protest site outside Arabia hotel in Mumbai Central .

The women who form the core committee of the protest were closeted in a meeting on Monday night to determine their next course of action. However, the men backing the agitation said they had no plans of winding up the stir or of moving it elsewhere, and demonstrators at the site staged their sit-in well into the night.

Samajwadi Party MLA from Bhiwandi Rais Shaikh, who was also part of the delegation, said they did not want anyone to take advantage of the protest and the situation at the site, so an appropriate decision would be taken.

On their part, police began preparing themselves for the worst by conducting flag marches in various parts of the city, which will be repeated on Tuesday. Police also revised and updated their standard operating procedure for communal riots. Former IPS officers said they do not remember such an occurrence since the Mumbai riots of 1992-93. Routine flag marches are carried out before elections or prominent events. But seldom do police anticipate communal riots to break out at such times.

Monday’s flag marches came hot on the heels of violence in Jawaharlal Nehru University and firing near Jamia Millia Islamia University and at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi. The protests going on at Govandi and Madanpura have prompted Mumbai police to take the preventive step, sources said.

Police remained tightlipped when asked if there was any high alert or anticipation of any untoward incident in the backdrop of the anti-CAA/NRC protests at Nagpada and Deonar. “Anything can happen. We are preparing for the worst,” said an officer. “The march was carried out at the level of local police stations across the city for peace. The idea is to show visible police presence and prevent any untoward incident, particularly in sensitive pockets,” Mumbai police spokesperson, DCP Pranay Ashok, said. Meanwhile, Nagpada police have deployed two CCTV vans at both ends of the “Mumbai Bagh” protest to capture images from all directions. The cameras are linked to the server at the police control room.

A flag march resembles patrolling by Armymen in full gear in an area where curfew has been imposed. The objective is to show presence of forces in the area in order to prevent a law-and-order situation.

Former Mumbai police commissioner D Sivanandhan said, “I had heard about police flag marches only during December 1992-January 1993 after the Babri Masjid demolition.”

Former Navi Mumbai commissioner K L Prasad said, “I have never heard of any such flag march during the last decade in Mumbai. Even after 26/11, no flag march was carried out. The march is carried out for reassurance and to restore confidence among people who are scared of untoward incidents. Secondly, the idea is to spread fear in the minds of miscreants.”

IPS officer-turned lawyer Y P Singh said, “The march could be in anticipation of any volatile situation.”

In the western suburbs, police from Bandra, D N Nagar, Meghwadi, Nirmal Nagar, Oshiwara, Sahar and Sakinaka carried out marches in vulnerable pockets on Monday. “We got instructions from the police commissioner’s office to conduct the march. It was carried out for an hour from 11.15am to 12.15pm,” an officer said.

In Mumbai North, flag marches were conducted at 5-6 locations including Aarey Colony, Goregaon East, Malwani etc. “The revised and updated SOP mentions what should be the line of action if a communal riot breaks out,” said Dilip Sawant, additional commissioner, north region.

(Inputs by Bella Jaisinghani , S Ahmed Ali and Mateen Hafeez)

Title: Sikar police bust gang involved in printing fake currency
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative Image

JAIPUR: A gang consisting of meritorious students, student leader and sports medal winner has been busted by Sikar police, which was allegedly involved in printing fake currency and possessing it. Acting on a tip off, the police searched pockets of seven students and recovered notes of Rs 200 denomination from their possession, which were allegedly fake. The arrested accused are in the age group of 18 to 26 years.

“The seized notes have the same serial number –OLF933094,” superintendent of police (Sikar) Gagandeep Singla told TOI. The fake currency was almost replica of the original notes. One of the arrested accused, Ramawatar Jat, was elected as president of students’ union of science college in Sikar in 2017-18. He also won karate championship in a state-level tournament, the police claimed. The other arrested accused were identified as Vijendra, Abhishek, Ajay, Ankit Kumar , Rakesh Kumar and Rafiq.

According to the police the accused told them that they had learnt the art of printing fake currency from an internet search engine. “They used fake currency to fulfill their daily requirements. They also printed excess fake currency and used it in the nearby areas of Sikar district,” said the police.

When the police inquired about their education, they were shocked to hear that they all were good in academics.

The police seized one printing press that was used for printing fake currency notes at Kalyan Circle, Sikar. The police arrested two accused at the printing press identified as Surendra and Subhkaran.

Title: Himachal government busy in Delhi polls: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

SHIMLA: With chief minister Jai Ram Thakur along with his cabinet colleagues busy in the campaigning for BJP candidates in Delhi assembly polls, the opposition Congress has accused the BJP government of leaving the state’s functioning at the mercy of god.

Congress MLA Vikramaditya Singh, son of former chief minister Virbhadra Singh, said for the past one week, the entire cabinet and senior officials had been missing from the state secretariat, which is very unfortunate.

“While on one hand, the entire government is busy in Delhi election campaign, on the other officials of state government are also missing from the state secretariat which is quite surprising. The entire functioning of government has been left at the mercy of god for the past one week,” he said.

Vikramaditya, who is Congress MLA from Shimla (rural) constituency, said the current situation prevailing at the secretariat shows that BJP government has no concerns for the people of state. He said people are facing problems due to frequent snowfall, the official machinery has completely failed to provide relief to people.

“Upper Shimla area is still cut off from the main roads. Power supply too has been disrupted. At a time when people are staring at shortage of daily used commodities, the state cabinet is busy in Delhi polls,” he said.

He said the way entire cabinet is busy with election campaigning in Delhi, it shows as if they themselves are going to form a government in Delhi.

He said under the BJP regime at the Centre, people of country are feeling unsafe. He said CAA and NRC have triggered such a situation in the country that people are wielding guns and opening fires at protesters, after being instigated by politicians and ministers.

He said Himachal Pradesh had failed to get any benefit despite having BJP government in the state and Centre. “The hill state was completely ignored in the Union Budget even as Union minister of state for finance and corporate affairs Anurag Thakur represents the state,” he said, adding that all four BJP MPs from the state had also failed to utilise MPLAD funds, showing that they had nothing to do with the development of state.

Title: City’s Shaheen Bagh begins under guard and cop watch
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: The city’s first full-fledged Shaheen Bagh-style all women protest against the controversial CAA-NRC-NPR began with the participation of about 4,000 women after organizers agreed to limit the days to five with the timings being 10am to 6pm at Farooq Nagar ground at Teka Naka on Monday.

The organizers have decided to renew the permission through a new applicant after every three days to keep the indefinite protest going.

Women continued to sit under the two big domes set up at the venue till around 8pm. Organizers said the activities wound up by 6pm while the women held a meeting for over two hours. A similar protest was held from Jan 19 to 23 at the Eidgah ground in Jaffar Nagar but it faced issues pertaining to police permission.

Muslims women had planned an indefinite protest on the almost one-acre land owned by ‘The Weavers’ Cooperative Housing Society’ in the locality dominated by the same community.

The police were initially reluctant to allow any kind of protest at the venue apprehending law and order issues. The organizers, comprising sitting and former corporators from the area, were instructed to shift activities regarding the protest to Samvidhan Square.

On Monday, the organizers, led by Hafiz Abdul Basit, assured the cops about the safety of women and also deployed over 1,100 volunteer guards to keep a watch on the crowd and if need be, to control it.

To prevent any untoward incident or incidents, separate groups of cops and volunteers stood guard at regular intervals along the boundaries of the ground which was sealed with the shamiana. The stick-wielding volunteers — posted everywhere at the venue — guided women to the dome and ensured their entry path remained clear.

Around 200-300 men, who also came to support the cause, were given a separate enclosure outside the dome to sit.

Speeches, patriotic poems, songs and satire were presented by women who were for the first time in full control of the stage as well. Men weren’t allowed on the stage. It was strictly an all-woman affair — for the women, of the women and by the women.

Homemaker Tarranum Firdos joined the protest to condemn the Delhi police’s excesses on students and inaction against the Jamia shooter. “We will continue to sit here till the government holds a dialogue with our Shaheen Bagh sisters,” she said.

Firdos finished all her household chores, including preparing dinner, before coming to the venue around 2pm. “Some of us have come with kids, while some came with their beddings and belongings to stay overnight, assuming we would get 24-hour permission,” she said.

Teka resident Zakia Ansari has participated in all the protests held in the city so far. “I’m unwell today, but that won’t stop me from continuing my fight against the CAA and the NRC,” she said.

Ansari said Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union minister Amit Shah should not have taken such a decision which has forced

mothers and sisters to hit the streets. “We don’t like to sit without food or water but given the precarious situation, we are left with just one choice — to protest,” she said.

Razia Parveen, a resident of Mominpura, said the country’s earlier leaders never took such a step which has created such a divide.

Student Zeba Khan said she has all the documents but was fighting for others. “What about the others who are living here but may not have documents,” she asked.

Lecturer Farkunda Jabeen said the law is basically a ploy to divert attention from core issues.

Title: ‘Lawrence Bishnoi’s interrogation led to Raju Basodi’s arrest’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

CHANDIGARH/BATHINDA: With its Haryana counterparts arresting gangster Raju Basodi in Thailand last week, Punjab Police has started paper work for getting the accused on production warrant for interrogation into the murder of another gangster, Manpreet Singh Manna , at a shopping mall in Malout on December 2 last year.

Basodi had taken responsibility for Manna’s murder in a Facebook post. Muktsar senior superintendent of police (SSP) Raj Bachan Singh Sandhu said they were in touch with Haryana Police and were planning to take Basodi’s custody on production warrant in Manna’s murder case.

Basodi is wanted for a number of murders in Rajasthan , Delhi, Haryana, Chandigarh and Punjab. His name also figured in the murder of gangster Sonu Shah in Chandigarh on September 28, 2019.

A source said police had come to know of Basodi’s whereabouts through the interrogation of gangster Lawrence Bishnoi.

Basodi’s close associate Sandeep Jathedi was freed by his friends who opened fire on a police party in Faridabad on January 31.

A Haryana Police officer said, “This is certainly a major catch for us. Our officers were continuously in touch with Interpol after red corner notice were issued against him.”

Raju hails from Basodi village of Sonipat. He first shot into news after he killed two persons and pumped 19 bullets into a person in police custody. He had come out on bail in 2017.

After that he was working with gangster Lawrence Bishnoi who is lodged in a jail in Jodhpur of Rajasthan.

His most recent involvement was in the murder of Sonu Shah, who was shot dead in his office in Burail of Chandigarh, in the broad daylight.

Title: Delhi: Wrestler held for selling pistol to juvenile shooter
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative Image

NEW DELHI/GREATER NOIDA: Delhi Police’s Crime Branch has arrested a wrestler for allegedly selling a country-made pistol for Rs 10,000 to the 17-year-old youth who had shot at a student outside Jamia Millia Islamia on Thursday. The accused, Ajeet , was arrested from his house in Shahjahanpur near Aligarh .

“We will interrogate Ajeet to know the source of the weapon. It will also be probed whether he is involved in arms dealing,” said DCP (Crime) Rajesh Deo . Ajeet has a BA degree and was enrolled in a BEd course at a university in Uttar Pradesh.

Police are yet to take any action against the juvenile’s relative. An officer said that the relative had no knowledge if the shooter actually bought the weapon or he was going to fire it at Jamia.

The shooter, who is to take his Class XII exams next month, told police that he was dropped off at Jamia Nagar and mistook the protests there as the Shaheen Bagh sit-in. He claimed that he got scared seeing the students and others approach him and fired in panic.

Sources said the shooter’s links with Deepak Sharma, who calls himself the leader of a fringe outfit called Rashtriya Swabhiman Dal, were being investigated as the youth had uploaded a photo showing him and Sharma together on Facebook. Sharma is known to police as National Security Act was invoked against him following clashes between Indian and Afghan students at Sharda University in 2018.

Asked whether he knew the shooter, Sharma claimed he barely knew him. “The picture is of a protest where the juvenile had participated,” he added. He said he didn’t support the youth’s act of shooting at a protester.

The controversy over the shooter’s age continued on Monday when a second image of an electoral slip was uploaded on Twitter.

Title: Fed up of alcoholic husband, woman hangs self
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bareilly: A 35-year-old woman allegedly committed suicide by hanging herself at Oel area of Lakhimpur Kheri district on Sunday night, hours after she quarreled with her abusive alcoholic husband. The woman was found hanging on Monday morning, when she did not open the door of her room even as her children could be heard crying.

This is the third incident when a married woman was either killed by her husband or committed suicide in Lakhimpur Kheri in the past one week.

When police arrived, the door was broken and Susheela Devi was found hanging. Her saree was used for the purpose. Police have sent the body for an autopsy to ascertain exact cause of death.

Neighbours said on Sunday evening, her husband Miththu had come home drunk as usual and the two had quarreled. Later, Susheela locked herself in her room with her children, aged three and two years old.

According to police, Susheela was married to Miththu nearly 10 years ago. Differences cropped up between them because of Miththu’s drinking habit.

Earlier, Susheela had gone to her maternal home and stayed there for nearly six months. Then, Miththu had promised to control his drinking habit. Over the next few years, the couple had two children. However, Miththu again started drinking heavily and would return home drunk every day.

Chandrakant Singh, SHO of Kheri police station, said, “After receiving information, sub-inspector Rajbali rushed to the spot and found a woman hanging in a room. Prima facie it looks like suicide but we have sent the body for an autopsy to ascertain reason of death. The woman’s husband is a drunkard and has been called for questioning. We are yet to receive any complaint from the parents of the deceased.”

On January 27, a man allegedly hacked to death his 35-year-old wife in Lakhimpur city as he suspected that she was having an affair with his younger brother. He also killed his brother.

On February 2, a 28-year-old woman was allegedly strangled to death by her husband, who later hanged himself in Tikunia area of Lakhimpur Kheri district. He suspected that his wife was cheating on him.

Title: KMC reclaims Dhapa for scientific waste disposal
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The portion of Dhapa that has been turned into a green zone after dumping of waste was stopped there

Title: ‘When memes spread faster than coronavirus’
Content:
Representative image

Meme on coronavirus

TRICHY: ‘When coronavirus memes are spreading faster than coronavirus’ is a meme that sums up how the online world is treating the contagious virus so cool for the past few days.While efforts are expedited by the governments to screen the passengers at the airports for preventing the outbreak of novel coronavirus ( nCoV ), meme makers here have used the contagious virus as a humour material.Featuring cartoon characters and famous Tamil comedian Vadivelu , the funny memes on coronavirus doing rounds have indeed kept the netizens free from panicking. Ever since the coronavirus has made it to the breaking news of news channels, meme creators have been working overtime to counterbalance the fear over the virus.Soon after the novel coronavirus outbreak became global, meme makers were quick to respond by choosing humour to deal with the virus. Several memes were rolled out on Facebook, Twitter and other social media platforms using the templates of famous movie scenes, mostly featuring the comedian Vadivelu.Meme makers were also early birds to target Nilavembu Kashayam (herbal drink) that was extensively used in the state to combat dengue fever. Most of the memes on coronavirus commonly conveyed that the deadly coronavirus will not enter the state fearing Nilavembu Kashayam.“Through the memes, unwanted fear and panic are being allayed as people prefer to laugh and share the memes with friends. Many of our followers shared us that they feel relieved on seeing the funny memes on coronavirus,” a 30-year-old meme maker said.

Title: Lt General SS Mahal is Kharga Corps GOC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Lieutenant General SS Mahal in Ambala Cantonment

CHANDIGARH: Lieutenant General S S Mahal assumed the charge as the General Officer Commanding (GOC) of the elite Kharga Corps, having headquarters at Ambala Cantonment , on Monday from Lt Gen M J S Kahlon who has moved to Delhi.
