It is considered to be the most formidable of the Army’s three strike corps. Lt Gen Mahal brings a plenitude of experience from his previous tenure in the military operations directorate.

He hails from Qila Kathgarh village in Nawanshahar district in Punjab . His forefathers helped in signing of the famous ‘Rupnagar Treaty’ of 1831 between Maharaja Ranjit Singh and Lord William Bentinck on the banks of the Satluj.

The Ambala-based 2 Corps, popularly called as Kharga Corps, possesses 50% of the Indian Army’s offensive capabilities and has the mandate to launch offensive attack, in case any conflict or war broke out with neighbouring Pakistan . Integrated with multiple military formations, Kharga has proved an effective weapon in various wars. Kharga Corps is stationed at Ambala since 1985.

Title: CJ defends justice Haq’s transfer to Aurangabad: Lawyers
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Even as a growing number of legal fraternity members are coming out in support of Justice Zaka Haq, and protesting his sudden transfer to Aurangabad, Chief Justice of Bombay high court Pradeep Nandrajog defended the decision, said some city-based lawyers.

Justice Haq, however, is yet to take charge of his new assignment at Aurangabad bench, where he was supposed to take charge from Monday, and is currently on leave till further notice. Justice NB Suryawanshi, whose headquarter was transferred from Mumbai to Nagpur, has joined the bench here.

The lawyers had told TOI that the judge may resign if his transfer is not cancelled, terming the entire episode as an ‘insult’ and ‘humiliation’ to the city’s bar, which has produced many legal luminaries.

Meanwhile, heaping praise on the city-based judge, the CJ told a delegation of Nagpur High Court Bar Association (HCBA) that he wanted a dynamic lawyer at the Aurangabad bench to effectively look after Public Interest Litigations (PILs), besides regular civil and criminal cases.

According to the lawyers, justice Nandrajog patiently gave a hearing to HCBA delegation led by senior counsel Shreehari Aney and including president Gauri Venkatraman and secretary Prafulla Khubalkar. The delegation handed over a representation signed by over 300 lawyers, who strongly protested sudden transfer of Justice Haq to Aurangabad bench, and even orally warned they would boycott court proceedings.

“The CJ welcomed lawyers’ delegation and explained the decision to transfer the judge to Aurangabad. He told them that he wanted a judge held in high esteem by lawyers. He was also impressed with the working style of justice Haq, who’s known for quick disposal of cases. He was of the opinion that justice Haq’s stay there would significantly help reduce the pendency of cases,” the lawyers told TOI on condition of anonymity.

According to them, the CJ, who is to retire later this month, also clarified that he hadn’t acted on anyone’s complaints against the judge, nor acted over his action of sending a notice to the registrar for alleged negligence on the part of HC registry officials, as speculations had been swirling.

“He told the HCBA delegation that as a CJ, he needs to make some adjustments to maintain the balance and justice Haq’s transfer was a routine affair without any prejudice. The CJ also shared his own experiences with senior lawyer Aney. Their entire conversation lasted for over an hour, which is rare, as the CJ is busy due to administrative work besides judicial duties,” the lawyers said.

They, however, pointed out that no discussions took place on justice Haq losing out his seniority at the Aurangabad bench. “The HCBA members should have stressed on maintaining the judge’s seniority, as he’s currently at fourth position in Nagpur bench and will eventually retire at second position in May next year. At Aurangabad, he will be at fifth position, and would retire at same position, which is an injustice to him,” they said, adding that there was otherwise nothing wrong in transferring the judge, which is the sole prerogative of a CJ, as the administrative head.

Title: Work on smart road with RWH kicks off in Srirangam
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

For residents of flood-prone Veereswaram Melatheru of Srirangam , even a moderate rain is a source of dread. But with Trichy Corporation now launching civil work on a smart road equipped with stormwater drains in the locality, the fear could soon be a thing of the past.

Estimated to cost `80 lakh, the smart road project is expected to change the face of the locality, bringing in rainwater harvesting (RWH) system, covered cable ducts and stormwater drains-cum pedestrian platforms on either side of the road.

The move came on the success of smart road project established at Veerswaram Keelatheru on a pilot basis last year. The scheme was effective in preventing inundation in recent northeast monsoon, encouraging the corporation to sanction second smart road.

As a requirement, the civic body said that all the houses and shops located on the road must have underground drainage connection and piped water supply. The eligibility criteria were set to avoid the need for digging up the road again to install pipes.

As per the smart road proposal, the 275-metre-long Melatheru road in Veereswaram will get one-foot wide stormwater drain on both sides. The drain will be covered with reinforced cement concrete (RCC) slabs so that vehicles and pedestrians can walk on them.

"The provision for stormwater drains will be provided next to the compounds of houses. Parallel to the drains will be covered cable ducts on either end of the road leaving a space for telephone cables to pass through without disturbing the road space," a corporation official said.

By covering the stormwater drains with RCC slabs and making use of the space, the overall width of the road will increase from 5 metres to 6. "Completion of piped water connections to households has delayed the commencement of civil work for the smart road. Concrete road laying will also start shortly," the official said.To drain the rainwater on the low-lying road, the corporation has dug three 20-foot deep borewells near PDS outlet and Anjaneyar temple in Veereswaram to collect the rainwater and rejuvenate the groundwater table. Officials said Veereswaram Melatheru will get a smart concrete road within a couple of months which will serve as a model for emulating smart roads in other parts of the city.

Title: Amravati-Mum regular flights from next year
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Vidarbha is going to get its second fully operational airport at Amravati soon. With this, the city will get air connectivity with Mumbai next year if everything goes according to the Rs110 crore expansion plan.

The present airstrip at Belora, 15km from Amravati, was constructed by public works department in 1992.

Gaurav Upshyam, Amravati airport manager of Maharashtra Airport Development Company (MADC), said work on expanding the runway is going on.

“At present, the length of the runway is 1,300 metre. We are lengthening it to 1,850 metre, suited for small aircraft like ATR 72. After the expansion, aircraft with 72 or 90-seat capacity will be able to operate from Amravati. The length of the runway for Boeing 737 or Airbus 320 aircraft is over 3,000 metre,” he told TOI. Upshyam further said that tender for construction of the terminal building had been floated and it would be ready after an year.

“On the technical side, a team of Bureau of Civil Aviation Security (BCAS) had visited Amravati. A team from Director General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) is slated to inspect the airport. We will need green signal from these two authorities before starting the operations,” he added.

Alliance Air has already promised to start an air service to Mumbai. A team of SpiceJet too visited the airport. Upshyam said that talks would be held with other players too.

Presently, the airport is used by only chartered aircraft. The airport was originally spread over an area of 74.86 hectares. Later, another 336 acres was handed over to MADC in January 2015 for expansion.

The airstrip was taken over by Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC) in August 1997 and later transferred to MADC. There were plans to hand it over to Airports Authority of India (AAI), but the state government changed its mind.

Nagpur Flying Club had applied to DGCA for permission to shift its flying operations to Amravati airport, but the club closed down and hence the shifting did not take place.

Amravati airport had been included under UDAN (Ude Desh ka Aam Nagrik) and regional connectivity schemes of the central government in 2019. The demand for an operational airport in the city is an old one.

Title: Himachal Pradesh tax revenue collection up 17.2%: Jai Ram Thakur
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Jai Ram Thakur

SHIMLA: Chief minister Jai Ram Thakur has claimed that despite global economic sluggishness recession and slowdown in India, his government in Himachal Pradesh succeeded in ensuring increase of overall tax revenue collection by 17.2% till January 31. He said the state had collected taxes of more than Rs 600 crore in financial year 2019-2020, compared to the corresponding period in the financial year 2018-19, which was a healthy sign of economic growth of Himachal.

Thakur said the state government had taken several steps to increase the revenue and tax collection. The government was regularly reviewing the tax revenue collections in the state and taking necessary steps to keep the momentum going, he added.

The CM said the results for current year were encouraging, as the overall GST collection has registered a growth of 50.76%. He said the government was also ensuring effective enforcement of GST in tourism, construction and hydro-electric projects.

Title: Each Haryana district to get old age home
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Haryana government has decided to set up old age homes having a capacity of 150 persons in every district of the state by 2024.

The government had earlier set a deadline of 2028 to establish these homes, but decided to complete the project by 2024 after the Punjab and Haryana high court expressed dissatisfaction over the same.

“The state government has revisited the scheme for establishment of old age homes with a capacity of 150 persons in each district of Haryana. Keeping in mind the welfare of senior citizens, it has been decided to reduce the timeline from 2028 to 2024 to set up these old age homes in each district and start work as early as possible,” the social justice and empowerment department has informed the high court.

After hearing Haryana’s stand on the issue, the HC has disposed of the public interest litigation (PIL) filed on the issue.

The Punjab government has already informed the HC that the state would complete construction of 21 old age homes, one in each district, by 2022. As far as UT Chandigarh is concerned, it has already got two old age homes.

Earlier, when the Haryana government had informed the HC about setting up of old age homes in every district by 2028, the high court had termed the state’s deadline as “highly unreasonable and unrealistic.”

Title: Quizzing suspects over 69 days, cops crack murder case
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Persistent follow-ups and sustained interrogation of suspects over 69 days finally helped cops solve the mysterious disappearance of 35-year-old Monesh Thakre. On Monday, the suspects led cops to a nullah in the forest adjoining Jamtha village, where they had dumped the remaining bones of the victim after murdering him and burning his body. The cops were able to recover four burnt bones, including the lower jaw, from the spot.

Akshay Yeole (25) and Nilesh Agre (19) have confessed to stabbing Thakre to death at an abandoned property at Bhawani Nagar on November 28, 2019, over gang rivalry. Yeole, facing one more murder charge and one attempt to murder among four earlier offences, had lured Thakre to the desolate place from a liquor bar at Pardi. Agre too had gone with them on the bike.

Yeole and Agre’s friend Soham Biloriya (30) too has been named an accused, but is on the run. They had taken Thakre’s body on scooter to a 22 acre abandoned plot behind their houses at Bhawani Nagar, Pardi, and left it there after the murder.

In the wee hours of November 29, Yeole, Agre and Biloriya returned there with petrol taken out into bottles from their scooters and bikes. Thakre’s body was burnt over the next couple of hours. The three then washed themselves, and burnt their own clothes too to destroy evidence.

The following day, Yeole and Agre roped in Amol Hirapure to arrange a car. The three wrapped the last remains of Thakre in a sari and threw the bones into a nullah near Jamtha on Nagpur-Jabalpur Road. Later, they burnt the sari too.

Police said most bones had been washed away, but four bones stuck in the mud were recovered by the police after the accused three admitted to the crime and led them there.

It’s learnt Thakre had tried to lure Yeole away from the liquor bar by claiming he had found a place with hidden silver coins. However, Yeole turned the tables on Thakre, by taking him on his bike and asking Agre to join them.

Yeole had feared that Thakre and his friend Vinod Wagh, who was in a rival group, may eliminate him. Wagh had earlier thrashed Agre over Rs2,500-Rs3,000 he had lent him, when Yeole was in jail. Planning to avenge the humiliation, Yeole had asked Agre to wait for him to step out of jail on bail.

On November 28, Thakre was enjoying liquor with two friends, and was later joined by Yeole and Agre. After the two friends left, Thakre continued consuming liquor with Yeole and Agre. They were seen at the bar at Pardi by many, and also captured in CCTV cameras.

The cops had seen the footage, and had questioned Yeole and Agre, separately and together, numerous times over the last two months. But the two had not revealed anything. Apart from Pardi police, where Thakre’ family had filed a missing complaint, crime branch too had been repeatedly questioning Yeole.

Recently, Agre had taken ill, and spilled the beans about the murder while being questioned rigorously in his weakened state.

Additional CP Nilesh Bharne said DNA test of the bones would be conducted to confirm the identity of the victim, and prove the murder and destruction of evidence by the accused.

The team which cracked the case comprised ASI Shreeniwas Mishra, constables Pankaj Lande, Vijay Yadav, Umesh Khobragade, Sunil Choudhary, Sachin Andhale and others under PI Vinod Patil and API Amol Kachore.

Title: HC slaps Rs 5.80L cost on 29 for ‘frivolous’ petition
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court slapped a cost of Rs5.80 lakh on 29 persons calling their petition a frivolous one. While dismissing their plea, the HC asked them to deposit the amount within four weeks and asked Amravati collector to recover it in case of default.

“In spite of such conduct on judgment debtors (petitioners) part, if this court is to lend its helping hand to them, a litigant would lose faith in country’s legal system and would start resorting to ‘Courts of Men’ and not ‘Courts of Law’,” a division bench of Justices Sunil Shukre and Milind Jadhav observed.

“If HC helps petitioners, it would be doing great disservice to law and justice administration system. In that case, what was said about more than 100 years ago by the Privy Council, would continue to hold the field. It famously says that in India it is very easy to obtain a court’s decree, but it’s very difficult to execute it. The ordeal of a litigant in India really begins after he obtains a decree from the civil court and it happens when the decree holder is compelled to initiate execution proceeding,” the judges said adding they find this petition as “frivolous and vexatious” which deserves to be dismissed with exemplary costs.

Chandrashekhar Rathi, managing trustee of Fattehlal Saligram Trust in Dhamangaon, had filed a civil suit before the civil court at Telhara in Akola for getting possession of agriculture land from petitioners Devidas Gavai and 28 others. The judgement went in Rathi’s favour on July 3, 2010, which directed Gavai and others to return land’s possession. Thereafter, he filed an application for executing court’s orders while seeking directives to police authorities to provide protection to facilitate sowing operations on disputed land, as it was in petitioners’ possession, which they challenged in HC.

The judges pointed when a court passes a decree against judgment debtor to vacate land and hand over possession to the applicant, the former is obliged under the law to obey it. “S/he should voluntarily hand over the possession within stipulated period without requiring a decree holder to file execution proceedings. Ordinarily, a judgment debtor should not create a situation wherein an applicant would be required or compelled to once again knock at court’s doors for enforcing a decree, else it will only be reduced to a paper having no meaning.”

The judges added petitioners enjoyed the possession of disputed land for about a decade and even today, they are desirous of perpetuating their illegal possession. “A judgment debtor must respect the law by showing wilful and voluntary compliance. If they refuse and seek refuge in some technicality of law, they don’t deserve any help from HC exercising its extraordinary jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution of India,” they said.

What HC said:

* Petitioners’ enjoyed possession of disputed land for about a decade

* Even today, they were desirous of perpetuating their illegal possession

* Litigants lose faith in legal system if courts help such frivolous petitions

* If court helps such petitioners, it’s great disservice to justice administration system

* Situation shouldn’t be created where litigants are compelled to knock court’s doors again

Title: Interior roads crying for attention
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

While the roads in Veereswaram locality of Srirangam are set to turn heads for their smart appearance, the pothole-riddled, interior roads in the residential areas are crying for attention.

Residents complained they constantly give their vehicles for repair after driving on the uneven roads in Vasantha Nagar near Kollidam flood bank road, leaving a hole in their pocket.

Situated near the eastern entrance to Arulmigu Ranganathaswamy Temple, Vasantha Nagar has around 150 houses and has a road to reach Kollidam flood bank road. However, the approach road connecting Vasantha Nagar has been in disrepair for at least 5 years, the residents said.

With the top surface of the bituminous road coming off frequently, two-wheeler riders frequently skid off the approach road. "It is difficult to travel during peak hours on the road with our children riding pillion. We frequently spend a significant sum to repair our two-wheeler as the tyres go flat often,"

K Revathy, a resident of Vasantha Nagar said.

As the approach road is the only way for the residents of Vasantha Nagar to reach the core area of Srirangam island, the residents have asked the local body to rebuild the road.

Residents said that two-wheeler riders often crash into the pedestrians commuting on either end of the Vasantha Nagar approach road. When contacted, a corporation official said that roads of Vasantha Nagar, Indira Nagar and Rajagopal Nagar all falling under ward number 3 will be refurbished within the month.

"Through Tamil Nadu Urban Road Infrastructure Fund (TURIF), the residential roads in ward number 3 will be rebuilt with paver machines," an official from Srirangam zone of corporation said.

Title: Why no ban on those who cheated in TRB exam, asks AIPCEU
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Trichy: The All India Private Colleges Employees Union (AIPCEU) has questioned credibility of Tamil Nadu Teachers Recruitment Board (TRB) for not acting against candidates who were found guilty of malpractices in the recruitment of lecturers to government polytechnic colleges in 2017.

While TRB had notified afresh for 1,058 lecturers recently as the recruitment notification was cancelled after malpractices surfaced, no action has been taken so far against 196 erring candidates.

This is unlike TNPSC which has banned 99 erring candidates for life after finding them guilty of malpractices in the TNPSC Group 4-2A examination.

AIPCEU founder K M Karthik said that all the 196 erring candidates who were responsible for cancellation of the TRB recruitment will be applying for the post again along with those who had passed the exam in 2017. “But for not fault on their part, the passed candidates have to appear again and clear the test to secure job.”

“While the High Court had asked not to collect exam fee from the students applying again, TRB is collecting the fee against in contempt of the court order,” he said.

He also questioned the move from TRB to seek experience certificate and conduct certificate at the time of applying for the post. “While such details should be asked during the certificate verification, such move would lead to malpractices,” he said.

Title: Intense cold in HP, Keylong at -15.6°C
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Shimla: There is no respite from the intense cold condition in Himachal Pradesh.

While the minimum temperature was recorded 2 to 3 degrees below normal, maximum temperature was 1 to 2 degrees below normal.

Keylong town of Lahaul-Spiti district recorded the lowest minimum temperature of -15.6°C and a maximum of -3°C.

Officials of Shimla Meteorological Centre said a feeble western disturbance was likely to affect the western Himalayan region from the night of February 6. They said rain and snow would occur at isolated places at middle and high hills on Tuesday. The middle and high hills might also witness rain and snow on Thursday and Friday. The weather would remain dry on Saturday and Sunday, officials said.

Title: Hisar man in hospital with coronavirus symptoms
Content:
Representative image

HISAR: One of 21 Hisar-based residents, who had arrived from China in the past 42 days, was admitted to the isolation ward of the general hospital here with suspected symptoms of coronavirus on Monday.The 35-year-old patient’s father said his son was pursuing MBBS in China. He had come to the village in early December last year and went back to China on December 25. As the coronavirus toll went up, he returned to his village on February 1.District malaria officer Dr Jaya Goyal said the man with symptoms like coronavirus came for treatment on Monday. His blood sample has been sent to the lab for test. He has been admitted to the isolation ward, she added. Dr Goyal said an advisory has been issued for the community health centres (CHCs) and primary health centres (PHCs) of the district. “Instructions have been issued to set up isolation wards in Barwala, Narnaund, Adampur, Hansi and Agroha,” she added. Hisar civil surgeon Dr Sanjay Dahiya said teams have been formed to investigate the remaining 20 persons and whoever gets symptoms of coronavirus will be investigated and caution will be taken as per WHO guidelines.

Title: Akola Cong neta shoots ‘criminal’ son to death
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: A 73-year-old Congress neta in Akola shot dead his youngest son after the latter tried to attack him over a property dispute at their residence in Irvande Plot on Monday. The deceased, identified as Manish Bharti, had several serious offences, including assault and robbery, registered against him.

Assistant police inspector of Civil Lines police station, Vishal Nande, said, “We rounded-up the father, Harilal alias Baba Bharti, but he complained of chest pain and high blood pressure so we had to shift him to hospital. We will arrest him after his health becomes normal.”

Just two days ago, an order was issued against Manish externing him from Akola district limits for three months. Police had not arrested him before he could be relieved outside the district limits.

Political sources in Akola Congress said that Baba is a well-known party neta while his eldest son Rajesh is a member of the party. Rajesh is also a former Youth Congress president.

According to police, Baba owns huge property in Akola and also runs a bar and an education society. Manish and Baba often got into quarrels as the former used to harass his father for money.

On Monday, Baba and his wife were in the house when Manish came there. Baba suspected Manish might attack him, so kept his licenced gun in his pocket.

It is learnt, Manish started demanding money and asked Baba to transfer a plot in his name, over which the father-son duo got into a quarrel. Manish allegedly pulled out a knife from his pocket and started running towards Baba who then fired a shot from his revolver. Manish sustained bullet injuries in the chest and fell on the ground.

After some time, Baba called police control room to report the incident. Civil Lines police along with the local crime branch team took Baba into custody. Cops sent the body to government hospital where the post-mortem was conducted.

It is learnt that police have seized the revolver and an empty cartridge from the spot. Baba has been booked for murder under sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Arms Act.

Title: Thanjavur comes under police surveillance
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thanjavur: Police have brought the entire Thanjavur city under their surveillance blanket ahead of the consecration ceremony of the Brihadeeswarar Temple (Big Temple), on Wednesday, in which more than five lakh devotees are expected to congregate to witness the event.

Speaking to reporters after inspecting security arrangements here on Monday, director general of police (DGP) J K Tripathy said that more than 5,500 police personnel headed by the inspector general of police (central zone) A Amalraj, have been pressed into service. DIGs J Loganathan (Thanjavur range) and 10 superintendents of police are guarding separate police teams at various points to closely monitor and control the crowd to facilitate smooth traffic movement.

“Entire police have been segregated into 15 separate teams and they have been asked to take control of their areas where they have been assigned. We have given required instructions on how to move with people and manage crowd to all the police teams. Fifteen crime control teams, 15 bomb squads are also put in place,” Tripathy said.

Entire city including the temple is being monitored by 300 CCTV cameras. Twelve temporary police outposts have been established in the city along with 12 check-posts to inspect all the vehicles coming inside the city. Devotees are allowed to enter the city after thorough verification of their details and frisking of their belongings.

Title: Kerala: Bypolls in 4 years based on 2015 voter list
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: While the state election commission (SEC) faced flak from political parties for using 2015 electoral roll for 2020 local body elections , SEC has conducted elections in 810 wards since 2015, based on the ward level voters list prepared in 2015. No complaints were received by SEC for making use of 2015 voters list to conduct bypolls in the state in the past four years.

There is a difference of 9.93 lakh voters between the final electorate published in 2019 for Lok Sabha elections and the draft voters list published by SEC on January 20. SEC officials said that around 50-60 voters will be added in each ward by the time the final list is published on February 28.

“We could successfully conduct byelections in over 800 wards making use of the first ever ward level voters list, prepared in 2015. We did not receive any complaints in the past four years for relying on 2015 voters list. Addition of new voters will not be a challenge this time as well,” said a SEC official. Political parties had demanded making use of voters list published in 2019 for the 2020 local body elections.

SEC had undertaken a massive exercise in 2015 mainly making use of HVOs (house verification officers) to prepare a ward level based voters list in the state for the first time. It had involved an elaborate process beginning with field verification, compilation of list based on field visit, completion of data entry by electoral officers, arranging ward based lists at booth level and publication of draft voters list.

The process resulted in aligning assembly booth level lists to each ward. SEC has been keen on sticking to the 2015 ward level based voters list mainly due to two factors: the cost involved in conducting house level verification and the fact that making use of assembly level booth list will only furnish partial data for three to four wards. According to officials, 24,970 assembly booths will have to be redistributed among nearly 20,000 local body wards if the 2015 voters list is not used. SEC is now in the process of updating voters list in 19,498 wards across gram panchayats, municipalities and corporations.

The draft voters list in panchayats and municipalities was published on January 20. The complaints regarding draft voters list may be submitted to electoral registration officer till February 14. The final voters list will be published on February 28.

Those who have attained 18 years on or before January 1,2020 can add their names to the voters list. Applications for corrections, addition, change of polling station and ward can be submitted online. Applications for deletion of names from electoral roll (Form 5) will have to be applied by post. Online applications can be submitted on www.lsgelection.kerala.gov.in.

Voters list will be available for scrutiny in all local bodies and village offices and taluk offices. Secretaries in gram panchayats, municipalities and additional secretaries in corporation are the electoral officers.

Title: China returnee taken to hosp with fever
Content: Tiruvarur: A 35-year-old man, native of Needamangalam in Tiruvarur, who returned from China last week has been admitted to the special ward to treat coronavirus patients at the Tiruvarur medical college hospital, after he came for a check-up with fever and cold.According to hospital sources, he was working as a cook in China and returned to his home town on January 31. As he was down with fever along with cold and cough, he approached the primary health centre near his home town. As he had returned from China recently, doctors there informed medical college hospital authorities and was rushed there.“As of now we found there is no Coronavirus related symptoms during screening. It seems common flu-like symptoms. However, we have sent his blood samples to a lab located at Guindy in Chennai. Now his condition is stable. Even then he should be under supervision at hospital at least for 30 days,” medical college principal Muthukumaran said. TNN

Title: Fire department: Lack of awareness led to tragedy at Hotel Arpit
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The fire department told the high court that the deaths didn't occur due to inadequacy of fire protection arra... Read More

NEW DELHI: Deaths in a raging fire in a city hotel last year was due to lack of awareness about safety arrangements and not due to failure of fire safety systems, the fire department on Monday told Delhi high court .

In a reply filed before a bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar , the department has argued that during the fire-fighting operations on February 12, 2019, when the tragedy occurred, it was found that “the incident took place due to the lack of awareness among occupants and hotel staff, not due to inadequacy of fire protection arrangements.”

The blaze killed 17 persons and resulted in the court initiating suo motu hearing into the tragedy after it received a letter from two persons claiming that the hotel, located in Karol Bagh , had failed to comply with the Supreme Court directions to have more than one exit and entry point.

The department, however, told the court that the hotel has two exit staircases and a fire safety system was also provided on the building premises.

In their letter that led the court to act, the petitioners had alleged that the hotel is located on a narrow road as against the requirement in the Master Plan that such establishments be set up near roads with a minimum width of 80 feet. They also questioned how a licence to operate was granted to the hotel by the North Delhi Municipal Corporation and Delhi Police despite these limitations.

The fire department, in its affidavit, stated that it conducts inspections of buildings referred to it by the local authorities and that unauthorised constructions and encroachments do not come under its purview.

Last year, the court had sought response of Delhi government, police and the fire department on the basis of the letter asking it to look into the fire.

The court has now listed the matter for further hearing on April 14.

Title: March-end deadline set to allot land of tainted cooperatives
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: District administration will organize a public court to cancel plot registrations of ineligible members of different housing cooperative societies while eligible members, who failed to submit entire amount against allotment of plot to them, will be given a second chance.

Divisional commissioner Akash Tripathi, who on Monday reviewed complaints and applications filed by hundreds of claimants against as many as 35 ‘tainted’ Griha Nirman Sanstha, issued the instructions. In presence of IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh, ADM Dinesh Jain, IDA CEO Vivek Shrotriya and Indore cooperative joint commissioner Jagdish Kannoj, Tripathi set a deadline to allot plots to eligible members of different housing cooperative societies by end of March.

“After impressive implementation of phase-I to allot plots to 767 eligible members of different housing societies , at least 2,000 claimants will be benefited in phase-II,” divisional commissioner said.

He instructed that seniority list of eligible members of housing cooperative societies, records of which are being scrutinized, should be prepared with complete transparency. “There are some housing cooperative societies, which have made members in excess but do not have plots to allot them. As per rules, such members will be returned their deposited money,” he said.

Tripathi added that a chance will however be given to members of different Griha Nirman Sanstha, who are eligible to be allotted plots but could not deposit due amount. “Some cases have come to fore where housing cooperative societies have registered plots against ineligible members. A public court will be held to cancel such registrations,” the divisional commissioner said.

He added that second phase of ongoing campaign to allot plots to eligible members will start from last week of March while third phase, in which around 2,000 claimants will also be benefited, will be started by June end.

Title: One-year-old girl crushed to death under a crane
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: A one-year-old girl was crushed to death under a crane wheel at a construction site in Ahinsa gram of Ratlam district on Monday morning. The crane ran over her in reverse mistaking it to be a piece of cloth lying on the ground.

Ratlam SP Gaurav Tiwari said that her parent had swaddled the girl and kept her at an open space about 100m away from the construction site. “Her parents were working in the area, when a crane reversed for shifting drainage lines, catching the minor under one of its front wheels,” Tiwari old TOI.

Identifying the deceased as Kalpana (1), daughter of Ashu Devda, a resident of Rawti , police said that deceased’s parents – labourers by profession — were working at a construction site in Ahinsa gram. The incident took place at around 10.15am.

The cop said that there were around 10-15 people including her parents at the time of incident, they heard the cry out loud, but did not realize that the girl was caught under the crane’s wheel.

“Her parents rushed to spot and found the girl lying in pool of blood. She died on spot and the driver managed a quick escape,” said Tiwari.

Police said that the crane has been seized on basis of an initial complaint lodged by aggrieved parents and body was sent for postmortem exam and was later handed over to family.

They said that driver’s identity could not be ascertained and a hunt has been launched to nab him.

Cops are in process of recording parents’ statements.

Title: Foreigners to face coronavirus screening at Big Temple fest
Content:
Representative image

THANJAVUR: As foreign tourists are expected to participate in the consecration of Big Temple on February 5, the public health department has sought the list of foreign tourists from the tourism department in order to set up screening protocols for novel coronavirus (nCoV).“As per the standing order issued by the union health ministry, the number of foreign tourists has been restricted to 50 from 100,” district tourism officer Jayakumar said.“With prior approval from the HR&CE department, 100 foreigners had registered to participate in the consecration ceremony in Thanjavur. However, as per the district administration instruction, we have limited the number to 50. However, all of them are from western countries,” Jayakumar told TOI.When contacted, Government Medical College dean Kumutha Lingaraj told TOI all foreign tourists would be allowed after proper screening protocol. When asked about providing masks to devotees, the dean said she did not know how feasible it was. As five lakh people are expected to attend the consecration, the health department has made elaborate arrangements to maintain public health. Collector M Govinda Rao said five bike ambulances will be in motion around the temple while seven advanced ambulances would be stationed nearby. This apart, 16 ambulances will be stationed at various spots, he said.“A total of six medical camps have been established at various places around the temple along with the team of doctors and drugs. Twenty-six mobile medical units are also in place. Moreover, two emergency wards have also established – one at the Government Raja Mirasudar Hospital and Government Medical College Hospital . Private hospitals are also instructed to be alert to house patients if any need arises,” he added.DGP J K Tripathy visited Thanjavur Big Temple and inspected the security arrangements and gave various instructions to higher police officials in the evening.

Title: Kolkata: Towing vehicle damages book fair visitor’s car
Content:
The damaged portion of the car

KOLKATA: A young film-maker from Baruipur, who visited the International Kolkata Book Fair on Sunday evening, has sought compensation from Bidhannagar police, alleging that his car was damaged while being towed by cops from a no-parking zone in Salt Lake on Sunday. In the complaint, Sanchayan Chakraborty stated that he had parked the car behind Bidyut Bhavan at DJ Block in Salt Lake around 4.15pm and moved towards the book fair.Around 7.45pm, when Chakraborty and his friend, Palash Haq, came back, they found the car was missing. “We had not found any ‘no parking’ board in the area where we left the car. We first thought that the car had been stolen and ran to the nearby police outpost at Karunamoyee, where we came to know that it was towed by cops. We found the car on the roadside in CJ Block, but its front portion was severely damaged,” said Haq who posted their ordeal on the Facebook page of Bidhannagar Police on Monday.“We ran to the Bidhannagar East police station and sought an explanation from cops about the damage of the car. Initially, they refused to take our complaint and sent officers to check the car. They blamed us for parking the vehicle at a no-parking zone. Later, they accepted our complaint as a general diary,” said Haq.Showing photographs of the damaged vehicle, TOI sought an estimate from an expert dealing with Honda cars. He said the repair would cost from Rs 70,000 to Rs 80,000.“The front bumper, hood, grille, moulding, radiator, condenser and bumper beam need to be replaced and this would cost approximately Rs 80,000,” said the expert. Cops said they have started a probe into the case on the basis of the complaint.“As per the Motor Vehicles Act, if any car is parked in a no-parking zone, obstructing traffic movement, police are authorized to tow it away. Sometimes cars get damaged while being towed. The same thing may have happened to this car. However, it was the fault of the car owner who had kept it in a no-parking zone,” said a senior police officer. He added that no illegal parking challan was issued against the complainant on Sunday. “We noted down his offence but have not issued any challan yet.”

Title: Cyclists pedal to Kumbakonam to explore heritage spots
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Trichy: ‘Cycling Yogis’, a group of cycling enthusiasts, who cycle their way to historical places to create awareness on Unesco heritage sites, recently visited the temple town of Kumbakonam as part of their three-day tour covering 235km to explore heritage spots in Tamil Nadu.

Keeping Kumbakonam as base, the team covered Alangudi near Kumbakonam and Thirunageswaram by cycling 55km on the first day. The team covered seven temples including Thirunallar on the second day, pedalling 117km. Airavatesvara temple, Darasuram was the last destination - a Unesco world heritage site on the last day. Stating that it is the first such cycling tour in the central districts by Cycling Yogis, founder Ramanujar Moulana, a Chennai-based historian said that they take out tours to commemorate Republic Day every year and this year, as part of their ninth founding year, they decided to tour Navagraha temples.

Cycle is a medium to connect to these places in an eco-friendly manner while propagating healthy practice, he said.

Title: When world looks at India now, it sees hatred and violence: Rahul
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

New Delhi: Hitting out at both BJP and AAP at his first public meeting ahead of the assembly elections , former Congress president Rahul Gandhi on Tuesday alleged that both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal came to power by telling lies and would do anything to stay in power.

“Modi had promised two crore jobs and improvement of the economy. Kejriwal told lies about Congress and came to power. Those who come to power by telling lies can’t bring development,” Gandhi said at a public meeting in Sangam Vihar. “They only think about their own power and nothing else. They will say whatever you want to stay in power,” he added.

Rahul said the entire world wants to invest in India, but the Prime Minister doesn’t want that. “Modi says that he doesn’t need to provide employment. He says I want to divide Hindu, Muslim, Sikh and Christians. I want to destroy the unity this country has,” he alleged.

“When the world looks at India now, it sees hatred, violence, rapes, goondaism and killings. In the past five years, one Indian has started talking to another with hatred. This is not our history. This is a country of love,” Rahul said in his first public meeting at Sunlight Colony in support of Congress candidate from Jangpura, Tarwinder Singh Marwah.

Accusing the Centre of “selling” state enterprises like Indian Oil, Air India, Hindustan Petroleum and railways and Red Fort, Rahul claimed, “He (Modi) may even sell the Taj Mahal.”

“Be it BJP or AAP, they have only one target — to spread hatred in society. This is something that Congress can never do even if it tries. They talk about patriotism. Go to any person in this country, you will find patriotism in their blood, no matter which religion they belong to,” he said.

Alleging that both BJP and AAP were making one Indian fight with another to stay in power, Rahul asked, “Can a person who makes patriots fight among each other be a patriot himself?”

“Congress doesn’t divide people or spread hatred. Modi and BJP might be benefitting, but the people are not. If you want progress, development, economic growth and employment, you have to remove violence and hatred from your heart,” he said.

Rahul said, “They talk about Hindu dharma, they talk about Islam, they talk of Sikhism. They have no knowledge of religions. In Hinduism, Islam, Christianity and Sikhism, where is it written to attack people and suppress them? What kind of Hindu dharma is this of Modi and RSS? Hinduism talks about taking everyone along.”

Stating that demonetisation and GST, which he termed as “Gabbar Singh Tax”, had broken the backs of traders, Rahul said, “The finance minister is not ready to tell how many youngsters got employment. The Budget speech by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in Parliament was hollow. In my next speech, I will list how many projects Adani and Ambani have been given by Modi.”

At Sangam Vihar, Rahul was joined by his sister, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra. Hitting out at the PM for his Shaheen Bagh jibe “sanyog nahi prayog”, Priyanka said that 3.5 crore people had lost their jobs and unemployment rate was highest in 35 years. “The Congress government had pulled 14 crore people out of poverty. In the past five years, they (BJP) have pushed people back to poverty,” she claimed.

Title: Minor boy arrested for sexually assaulting girl
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A 17-year-old boy was arrested on Saturday on charges of committing sexual assault on a 10-year-old girl. The incident took place in K K Nagar area in the city on January 31.

In his complaint to the all women police station, Cantonment, the girl’s father said she is studying in a local school while the boy is studying in a college in Trichy . The girl, along with few other students were taking private tuitions from the boy’s mother in their house.

On Friday, after finishing the class, the boy took the girl and some students in his car to drop them at their house.

After dropping all of them, except the 10-year-old, he parked the car in Sundar Nagar area and forced the girl to kiss him. He also molested her. Since she refused to budge, he dropped her at her house and left.

The girl told this to her parents. Acting on the complaint on Saturday, police registered a case and arrested him.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Students develop eco-friendly sanitary napkin, awaiting patent
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Trichy: Four botany students and an assistant professor from St Joseph’s College here have developed an eco-friendly sanitary napkin with plant-based fibre as the principal element. The college is awaiting patent for their napkin which can be produced for just Rs 2.

Terming it a path breaking innovation which will help marginalised sections of the society, T Francis Xavier, assistant professor of botany department, who guided the students, said that the napkin has double the absorption capacity than ordinary napkins.

“We found that the fibre has phenol and hydroxyl group of chemicals which ensures high absorption. Another advantage of phenolic compounds was its anti-bacterial property making it ideal as napkin. We have used two more plant fibre as anti-bacterial agents,” he said.

“Direct expose of this fibre to skin may cause rashes. To prevent this, plant fibre is treated in sodium hydroxide and covered with a thin layer of cotton to give it the final shape of a napkin,” said Bhubaneswari, a student member of the team.

While the team did not divulge the name of the plant as they are in the process of getting a patent for their eco-friendly napkin, Francis said that the team stumbled upon the plant during their visit to the tribal hamlets of Kolli hills last year for ethno-botany study.

They found tribal women in the village using a dry land weed from aloe vera family during menstruation after covering it with a cloth.

Francis said that their product could be an alternative to conventional napkins as it does not have dioxin - a bleaching agent used in many conventional napkins is cancer inducing. “Besides, petroleum products used to convert the liquid to gel form also leads to rashes. The napkin produced by us could prove ideal especially for being very economical,” said Francis.

St Joseph’s College Principal M Arockiasamy Xavier congratulated the team for their efforts. Apart from the napkin, students have also come up with napkin making machine at a cost of Rs 15,000 to produce napkins in a safe manner, Francis said.

Title: Kolkata: Young designer goes missing for 20 days, kin say ‘trafficked by colleagues’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Sulakshana Singha Roy has not attended office since January 10

KOLKATA: A young woman employed with a top designer’s firm at Topsia has been missing from her PG accommodation for the last 20 days.

The woman, Sulakshana Singha Roy (22), a government art college graduate hailing from Alipurduar, had returned from a Darjeeling trip, but had not joined office after that. On Sunday, her family lodged a complaint with Chitpore police station, alleging that she might have been “trafficked” and her colleagues might have something to do with that. Her sister, who stays in the same PG accommodation on a different floor, lodged an FIR with the police, claiming that some unknown office employee abducted Sulakshana and trafficked her for sexual exploitation.

Earlier, on January 11, a missing complaint was lodged with the police. Following the FIR on Sunday, police amended the case under IPC sections 366 (kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage) and 370 (trafficking).

Police sources said the woman could not pursue higher studies owing to financial constraints.

She took up the job but was not happy with the remuneration. She had visited her home at Kuarpara in Alipurduar last month. She had come back to Kolkata but it seemed that she had skipped the office on January 10 and 11. She had reportedly left the PG accommodation on January 11 and called up her mother, saying that she could not speak to her because the battery of her mobile was dying out. Her last presence in the city was traced close to her office on Topsia Road, said police.

Cops have spoken to the woman’s colleagues and checked the CCTV footage of the Park Circus area, but they got no lead in the case so far. A colleague of Roy said that they had no idea about where the woman might have gone and that there was no allegation against her. “All that we can say is no colleague could have harmed her,” he added.

Title: Health dept calls for personal hygiene to fight coronavirus
Content: Trichy: The public health department has insisted the public, especially those arriving from China, Thailand, Hong Kong, Singapore at the Trichy International Airport, to maintain personal hygiene and treatment to prevent any symptoms of coronavirus.“About 45 passengers (not patients) are being closely monitored by the health inspectors in Trichy. Besides, our department has sent the list of passengers from other districts and neighbouring states like Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Puducherry. None of them have the symptom but they are home quarantined,” deputy director of health services (DDHS), Trichy Dr A Subramani told ToI on Monday. Health inspectors of the respective areas have been assigned the task of getting in touch with the quarantined passengers at their house to check if they have any symptoms like fever, sneezing and breathing difficulties. “They are advised to inform the health inspectors if they are running fever which is one of the main symptoms. As soon as we get the information, the passenger will be masked and brought to the isolation ward where the patient will be treated as per protocol,” said Subramani.“The common advice from the health department is to maintain personal hygiene like hand washing. If someone feels they are having fever, he or she should stay back at home. In case of breathing difficulty, the person should be admitted to the isolation ward,” he said adding that he/she will be given oxygen and administered IV fluids and tested for lung infection.DDHS also said that fatalities could be completely avoided if the person is treated early.As far as Trichy district is concerned, the Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) is equipped with a 12-bedded isolation ward for treating patients with coronavirus. Reiterating that no one has been diagnosed with symptoms of coronavirus, Subramani said that a 27-year-old passenger from Madurai was running fever when he landed from Singapore on Sunday night.“His health condition is stable. Since he had fever, we admitted him at MGMGH. The blood samples have been sent to the King Institute in Chennai for testing,” said the DDHS.

Title: Work begins on escalators for footbridge at railway station
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

TRICHY: Trichy railway division has commenced work on constructing two escalators on each end of the footbridge at the railway station at a cost of Rs 2.5 crore. The project is expected to be completed within three months, officials said.

The escalators will be installed at the main entrance near the parcel office and the second entry at Kallukuzhi on the opposite side of the station.

“Trichy railway station already has seven platforms and construction of the eighth one is nearing completion,” officials said. “However, the movement of the escalators will only be upward. Passengers cannot use them for stepping down from the footbridge”, officials added.

Till 2016, passengers who arrived on platforms two to seven had to use the subway which became congested during peak hours as it is narrow. The footbridge was opened in 2016.

“The escalator will mainly benefit senior citizens, children and patients who find it difficult to climb all the steps of the footbridge,” said K Raju, 59, a commuter from Lalgudi.

An escalator is already installed in the subway to connect platforms 2 and 3. It was established under Rajya Sabha MP Trichy N Siva’s Members of Parliament Local Area Development Scheme (MPLADS) funds. Officials said that there are plans to provide more escalators to connect all the platforms with the footbridge.

Title: Maharashtra: College teacher set on fire by married man stalking her
Content:
Accused Vikesh Nagrale

NAGPUR: A 24-year-old college teacher in Hinganghat town, about 75km from here in Wardha district, was set ablaze in public view by a man stalking her for past few days. Ankita Pisudde, 24, a contributory lecturer with local Matoshree Ashatai Kumawar Mahila Mahavidyalaya, sustained 35%-40% burns and is being treated in Nagpur.Police have taken into custody a fellow villager Vikesh Nagrale, a married man with a child, for carrying out the attack early on Monday morning near the college where Ankita taught.Sources in the Orange City Hospital and Research Institute, where Ankita was brought, stated she was in critical condition with Grade-III deep dermal burns covering scalp, face, right upper limb, left hand, upper back and full neck with injuries affecting her respiratory system. Doctors stated a surgery was performed on Ankita but another 72 hours would be needed to make a proper prognosis.Ankita, a postgraduate in Botany and pursuing BEd, was walking towards her college along with two students after getting off from the bus she took every day from her village Daroda. They were half-a-kilometre from the college when the attack happened.Nagrale came on his bike and hurled petrol from a container on Ankita’s head. He then threw a lighted torch, made by wrapping a cloth around a stick, towards her following which upper part of her body got engulfed in flames. Nagrale, who had kept his bike idling, sped away from the place.Later in the day, he was intercepted at MIDC Buti Bori by Nagpur rural police as cops traced his mobile phone location. Nagrale was communicating with a friend and Hinganghat police took help of the friend to nab him.Nagrale had earlier tried to end his own life over some issue with Ankita. Police said Ankita and Nagrale were friends earlier but she had snapped ties after he got married to another woman around a year ago. The accused also had child. He worked as an electrician with a railway contractor. Police received information from Daroda village, where Nagrale and Ankita stayed, that he was stalking her for the last few days.Home minister Anil Deshmukh told TOI strict action would be initiated against the accused who has been slapped with stringent provisions of law. “We will conduct trial of the case in a fast track court. The government would provide all possible help to victim and her family,” he said.“Any one engaging in such a heinous crime would be strictly dealt with,” he said. Deshmukh added he would shortly visit Andhra Pradesh along with senior officers to study the stringent anti-woman atrocity laws the state had enacted.Minister Sunil Kedar, guardian minister of Wardha, visited the hospital and had a discussion with the medical team urging them to focus on reviving her. “I am trying to either shift the victim to Mumbai or ensure a Mumbai-based expert attends to her. My first priority is to save her life,” he said. Kedar also stated he would delve deeper into the incident and find out what had led to the attack.Around three months ago, Nagrale had approached Ankita in the bus while she was heading to Hinganghat to speak to her. She had objected to it and also relayed to his father Arun about his advances. Arun had berated Nagrale and threatened to approach police if he repeated his act. At that time, no police complaint was lodged.Pandurang Tumaskar, chairman of the management body of the college where Ankita taught, said a passer-by tried to shield her but he failed to foil the attack. “A family in the vicinity rushed out with buckets of water with which they doused the flame and a man with car rushed her to a hospital in the vicinity from where she was referred to Nagpur and taken there escorted by police,” he said. He said Ankita was a regular and sincere lecturer in the college which she had joined in June last year.Ankita’s father Arun said he had never heard anything from his daughter after the incident in the bus. “We are completely taken aback by the attack. I want strict action against Nagrale,” he said. “The family was informed by a student of my daughter’s college whose father is my friend,” he said.State women commission has taken suo motu cognisance of the matter and directed the Wardha SP Basavraj Teli to take strict action against the perpetrator and prepare a watertight case against him.Hinganghat police station’s in-charge Satyaveer Bandiwar stated Nagrale was slapped with attempt to murder under section 307 and also 326A for injuring by burning under Indian Penal Code (IPC).WHAT IS SECTION 326AWhoever causes permanent or partial damage or deformity to, or burns or maims or disfigures or disables, any part or parts of the body of a person or causes grievous hurt by throwing acid on or by administering acid to that person, or by using any other means with the intention of causing or with the knowledge that he is likely to cause such injury or hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and with fine: Provided that such fine shall be just and reasonable to meet the medical expenses of the treatment of the victim: Provided further that any fine imposed under this section shall be paid to the victim.In Video: Woman teacher set ablaze by man in Maharashtra’s Wardha

Title: MLAs peeved over Yogeshwara’s possible cabinet entry
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bengaluru: The possibility of defeated MLA CP Yogeshwar being inducted into chief minister BS Yediyurappa ’s cabinet is causing ripples within the ruling BJP, with many legislators, especially from Kalyana-Karnataka region, raising a banner of revolt.

Several MLAs led by Surapur legislator Narasimha Nayak, also known as Raju Gouda , held a meeting at the Legislators Home on Monday and voiced their opposition.

"When there are more than two dozen MLAs aspiring for a cabinet berth, making a former MLA a minister is beyond logic," Gouda said. "We will convey our feelings to Yediyurappa and state BJP president Nalin Kumar Kateel." Murugesh Nirani, Paranna Munavalli, Rajkumar Patil, Dattatreya Patil Revoor, Basavaraj Mattimud are among others who attended the meeting. MP Renukacharya, political secretary to the CM and Honnali MLA, was also present at the meeting. "Some more MLAs will join us when we meet again tomorrow," Gouda said.

The MLAs highlighted the issue of caste and regional imbalance in the council of ministers to further their cause. With four from Bengaluru and three from Belagavi district set to take oath on February 6, the share of MLAs from these districts in the cabinet will rise to seven and five respectively. Currently, 16 districts have no representation.

Sources say Yediyurappa and BJP’s national leadership decided to reward Yogeshwar with a cabinet berth for his "active" role in getting 17 Congress-JD(S) MLAs to resign and join the BJP, enabling the party to grab power. The party also believes he has the potential to become the Vokkaliga face of the BJP in the Old Mysuru region, where the party’s organisation is weak.

If Yogeshwar is inducted, he will be the second former MLA to make it to Yediyurappa cabinet after deputy CM Laxman Savadi, who lost the 2018 assembly polls. Several party MLAs were unhappy with Savadi’s elevation and are now upping the ante against the party leadership.

"Let Yogeshwar be made Rajya Sabha or council member. We have no problem. But making him minister is not acceptable. If they want to make defeated MLAs ministers, then why not AH Vishwanath and MTB Nagaraj, whose sacrifices brought BJP to power?" said Gouda.

Reports say Yediyurappa has promised Vishwanath and Nagaraj, the disqualified MLAs who lost the bypolls, that they would be made ministers in June. Both met Yediyurappa and secured this assurance. The two were demanding that they be inducted into the cabinet on Thursday.

Meanwhile, Vijayapura MLA Basavanagouda Patil Yatnal urged the CM to evaluate the performance of existing ministers and drop those found non-performing. "Many ministers don’t even come to the Vidhana Soudha. What is the use of having such ministers?" he asked.

Yediyurappa also continued to face pressure to induct Athani MLA Mahesh Kumatalli into the cabinet. The Jarkiholi brothers, Ramesh and Balachandra met Yediyurappa separately on Monday with a request to make Kumatalli, their confidant, a minister.

Title: ‘Land allotment policy for Tuem IT park in works’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Porvorim: The department of information and technology is in the process of drafting the land allotment policy for the Electronic System Design and Manufacturing (ESDM) park at Tuem, said IT minister Jennifer Monserrate on Monday. Monserrate said the land allotment policy will make provisions for planned development of the Tuem IT park.

“The IT department is in the process of finalising the constitution of the special purpose vehicle for implementation of electronics manufacturing clusters,” Monserrate said, replying to a question in the state legislative assembly.

The Info Tech Corporation of Goa Ltd (ITG) has been identified as the implementing agency for setting up of the Tuem facility. ITG has already completed the survey for the plots and has also fenced off the land at a cost of Rs 22.8 lakh and Rs 12.8 lakh respectively.

Monserrate said that an escrow account has been opened with State Bank of India where the state government has deposited Rs 14.7 crore, which is 20% of the amount sanctioned by the Centre. The union ministry of electronics, and information technology has also deposited Rs 12.4 crore in the escrow account. “The Central government has already given its final approval for setting up the greenfield ESDM at Tuem and would be providing a grant in aid of Rs 73.8 crore against an approved cost of Rs 161.3 crore.

The department paid Jones Lang LaSalle Property Consultants Rs 36.7 lakh for carrying out transaction advisory services.

Goa State Pollution Control Board has granted the Tuem ESDM park consent to operate while Town and Country Planning department has granted the project technical clearance.

Title: Congress will take solid steps to tackle joblessness: Manmohan
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

New Delhi: In an where most campaigns have seen sharp personal attacks and blame game , former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Tuesday said that he would rather talk about the issues plaguing the youths .

“Today, I won’t condemn any party. I want to point out the issues plaguing the youths of Delhi... It is a matter of shame that despite being educated, our youths have to run around for jobs. We will take solid steps to deal with unemployment if we come to power in Delhi,” Singh said, while addressing an election meeting at Tilak Nagar.

The senior Congress functionary pointed out that the unemployment rate in Delhi in the last four months was 15%, while it was 7% in the rest of the country. “Congress is committed to the people and our thrust will be on employment,” he said.

He pointed out that there had been a fall in the number of factory workers in the capital in 2017-18 compared with that in 2013-14 when the Sheila Dikshit government was in office. “It was 75,273 in 2013-14 and fell to 68,630 in 2017-18,” Singh added.

He urged people to vote for the Congress candidates from Rajouri Garden and Tilak Nagar, Amandeep Singh Sudan and Raminder Singh Bamrah, respectively, who were also present at the meeting.

Praising Dikshit for transforming the capital with her vision, Singh said, “Sheila Dikshit is not with us today… For 15 years, she offered great service to Delhi and its people. She changed the design of the city with roads, flyovers and the metro. Delhi Metro started during her tenure. In the first ride from Connaught Place to Delhi University, she accompanied me and had said that she wanted to set up an extensive network connecting most areas of the city.”

Referring to various people-friendly promises in the Congress manifesto, the former Prime Minister said, “Problems related to environment are increasing in Delhi. We will ensure that development is done with special care to environment.”

Pointing out that Congress had a separate manifesto for environment and planned a Delhi Electric Vehicles initiative, he said, “Like Sheilaji who had transformed the bus fleet of the city from diesel to CNG, we will do everything possible to clean up Delhi’ air and water.”

Title: National Board for Wildlife approves road connecting Corbett & Rajaji reserves
Content: Haridwar: After years of back and forth, work on the controversial Laldhang-Chillarkhal road may soon get started as the National Board for Wildlife (NBWL) has given a go-ahead to the project.The road, proposed to cut down travel time between Garhwal and Kumaon, will cut through the reserve forest area of Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) which has a healthy wildlife population. The 11.5-km-long road also includes a 4.5 km stretch from Chamaria Bend to Siggadi Sot — which is the sole wildlife corridor between Corbett Tiger Reserve ( CTR ) and RTR, which are the two premier sanctuaries of Uttarakhand.In June last year, the project had been put on hold by the Supreme Court which had directed the state government to first get clearance from National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) and NBWL before commencing with the motor road project.Subsequently, the NTCA asked Dehradun-based Wildlife Institute of India (WII) to submit its observations on the project. Scientists at the Tiger Cell of WII recommended a “status quo” on the stretch between Chamaria Bend and Siggadi Sot. WII recommendations, a copy of which is with TOI, read, “Status quo should be maintained on the stretch between Chamaria Bend and Sigaddi Sot. Black topping should be avoided in this route considering wildlife movement in the area. However, the forest department may maintain this portion regularly by using ‘murram’ so as to allow passage of vehicles.”Notwithstanding WII suggestions, NTCA approved the project stating that a 100-metre-long underpass can be constructed after every one kilometre road on the stretch. After NTCA’s approval, NBWL also gave a green light to the project and extended the limit for the length of underpass from 100 metres to 150 metres after every kilometre. So, the total length of the underpasses on the Laldhang-Chillarkhal road would now be a mere 705 metres which wildlife experts say will be too less for smooth movement of animals. Notably, a forest department committee headed by current WII director Dhananjai Mohan in 2014, had suggested that the construction of a 7.5 km-long flyover should take place in a phase-wise manner so that movement of animals is not obstructed.Reacting to the approvals given by NTCA and NBWL, Bhanu Bansal of the Centre for Wildlife and Environmental Litigation, which had raised the matter in NGT as well as the Supreme Court, told TOI, “It is shocking that NBWL cleared the project without taking into consideration various government reports which clearly bar black topping of the proposed road. It is one of the rare wildlife corridors that joins two tiger reserves. Elephants and big cats frequently use the area and this move would be detrimental for them.”Anup Kumar Nayak, member secretary of NTCA, when queried, said,“We totally believe in co-existence of wildlife and human beings. The approval has been given in the buffer zone of Rajaji Tiger Reserve and not in the reserve areas. Also, the permission is accompanied by several relevant clauses which are meant to safeguard wildlife.”

Title: Women lead at city’s ‘Shaheen Baghs’
Content: Ahmedabad: Responding to ripples set off by Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh protest, non-violent dharnas against CAA have sprung up in Ahmedabad. Spearheaded by women, daylong dharnas are being organized at Ajit Mill compound in Bapunagar since January 14 this year. Similarly, another such protest demonstration has begun at Morarji Chowk in the same area last week. Protesters at both places say they will continue to stay put as long as the demonstration at Shaheen Bagh continues.The protests against CAA, NPR and NRC at Ajit Mill compound, which is on for almost three weeks now, has received support from academics, activists and others. Author and historian Ramchandra Guha along with several known academics, lawyers, activists and students from higher educational institutions have extended their support to the agitation by attending the demonstration.“We want this demonstration to be completely free of political presence and hence women of all religions have been spearheading the protest at Ajit Mill compound. It will last in a peaceful manner until the Shaheen Bagh protest continues,” said Dalit Muslim Ekta Manch activist Kalim Siddiqui.While there have been several instances of people organizing protests against the CAA, NRC and NPR, the ones at Ajit Mill Compound and Morarji Chowk have been modelled along the Shaheen Baug protests where, primarily women, have decided to demonstrate indefinitely against the government.

Title: Two newborns found dead on Hooghly bank
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Two newborns — one was a boy and the other a girl — were found on the bank of the Hooghly at Nadial in the port area under mysterious circumstances on Monday morning.

The babies were declared brought dead at the hospital. According to the police , the babies were found around 9am near a brick kiln on Riverside Road. Cops suspect that they had been killed. However, the post-mortem report can only ascertain whether the babies were murdered.

The police have started a case and are contacting local hospitals to identify the babies. “The brick kiln workers spotted them lying on the bank of the river. We rushed the two to SSKM Hospital where they were declared brought dead,” said a police officer. he added that no CCTV footage was available in the area.

“The investigation will find out if there was any negligence on the part of the nursing home authorities too,” added the officer.

Title: Tallah closure: Cops pass office-day acid test; choke points still a worry
Content:
Worker under way to demolish Tallah Bridge

KOLKATA: Vehicles crawled in north Kolkata but the chaos that paralyzed traffic on Saturday, immediately after the Tallah Bridge closure, did not return to haunt motorists on Monday. Police passed the acid test on Monday but on a long-term basis, they need to resolve a number of issues for smooth traffic movement.On Monday, the north-bound traffic along Lockgate flyover was relatively smooth as many vehicles were diverted along Central Avenue. Cars had very little or no issues in accessing Lockgate flyover and zipped past the chaos below during peak office hours. They took around 10-15 minutes to cross the area which normally takes five to seven minutes.Cars got lined up on a regular basis during morning peaks hours along the Belgachhia Road-R G Kar Road corridor, which ran both way. Kolkata traffic police officers, who were present all along the stretch, had a harrowing time in dispersing snarls. But since the queue of cars stuck in the jam was long, it was not possible to disperse all of them in a single signal cycle.Heavy congestion was also reported from Raja Manindra Road and Indra Biswas Road, which fed traffic to the Belgachia Road–R G Kar Road corridor from Paikpara and Tallah Park crossing, respectively. Even though Northern Avenue was made one-way, erratic traffic movement from the opposite direction made it difficult for cops to declog the area.Because of the tremendous traffic pressure, Kolkata Police on Monday switched to the automatic mode of signal to the manual mode. This was why a single signal cycle often ran into more than 15 minutes, causing further stress on fraying nerve of waiting commuters. The Kolkata station-bound traffic was diverted along Canal Circular Road from APC Roy Road. Police said this moved helped in decongesting the area to some extent.There were many choke points along this corridor that slowed down traffic and turned dispersal painstakingly long. The first choke point was in front of the RG Kar Hospital first gate, where a complex mix of the vehicular and pedestrian traffic left the area grid-locked. Similar was the situation at the entrance to Kolkata station complex from R G Kar Road. Traffic came to a standstill on either side when vehicles were allowed to ply one side by blocking the other side. Bad tram track conditions on the Shyambazar-bound flank slowed down car movement. Smooth, concretized tram tracks along the north-bound flank allowed vehicle dispersal faster along the stretch.The presence of a large number of police personnel, particularly traffic sergeants on motorcycles, who did not allow any vehicle to halt unnecessarily at any point, saved the day. Police put up barricades to streamline pedestrian traffic was another effective move.

Title: Gujarat to follow Nagaland model
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Gujarat forest department plans to replicate Nagaland’s success in conserving Amur falcons at Gujarat’s only R... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat forest department plans to replicate Nagaland’s success in conserving Amur falcons at Gujarat’s only Ramsar Site, Nalsarovar. Unesco’s Ramsar convention, named after the Iranian city where the convention was signed in 1971, seeks to protect wetlands of international importance. The falcons were once hunted in Nagaland but are now being diligently conserved with local participation.

In Nalsarovar, poaching of birds is rampant. Wildlife Institute of India ’s R Suresh Kumar — who is part of the Amur Falcon project in Nagaland — said: “After we realized that the falcons were being hunted in large numbers, we began satellite-tagging them.” The birds were also given a local name, that of a village in the vicinity, to instil a sense of ownership among the people.

Kumar said that when the birds returned, villagers were able to track their movements. The locals began conserving the falcons and poaching has almost ended. A senior officer from the Gujarat forest department said that the same model will be used in Nalsarovar. Flamingos and other migratory birds will be tagged, and the birds will be named after villages or the most respected persons in the villages. The department is hopeful that this will help in conservation efforts.

A senior officer said that tagging will also help the department to learn about bird migrations. He said that in the case of Amur falcons, they travelled from Nagaland to Africa and back every year.

The migratory path passes over Gujarat; the birds even make a brief halt in the state. These birds pass over Gujarat in the April-May period. Their distribution in Gujarat is widespread, with sightings reported in coastal, forest, and desert areas. Most sightings occur in the Little Rann of Kutch .

“These birds pass through Saurashtra and Kutch as the semi-arid conditions in Kutch are similar to those in Somalia,” Kumar said. “Those conditions are ideal for Amur falcons.”

Title: Police to devise special plans for exam season
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The first real test of traffic plans after the Tallah Bridge shutdown — factoring in the movement of office crowd — has convinced the police brass that there is no need to change the Lockgate flyover traffic flow for the time being. However, cops will return to the drawing board to chalk out plans for examinees since the area has 20 Madhyamik and 11 Higher Secondary examination centres.

Taking into consideration the situation on ground, a few changes were implemented at Chiria More, Bagbazar and Paikpara by Monday evening. The most important decision that has been taken is to switch off the automated signals and operate them manually. Of immediate importance for two-wheeler users, the cops have clarified on Monday that no bikers will be allowed to use Lockgate flyover at night.

On Monday, the police brass — led by special CP Jawed Shamim — was out on the streets since the morning. Spot checks were done at the entire area, particularly at Lockgate flyover, the Belgachhia flyover and Cossipore Road, through the day. More than 150 officers on the ground sent regular reports to the temporary command centre at Chiria More and the main control room at Lalbazar.

From Tuesday, claimed sources, if Raja Manindra Road gets more volume of traffic than it can handle, cops will try to divert a few vehicles to Indra Biswas Road. Similarly, an attempt will be made to temporarily divert some cars to Cossipore Road to ease pressure.

“We do not think that tidal movement is necessary at this moment. Most motorists are aware of the shutdown and willingly took the diversion at Chiria More. We have begun tweaking the traffic signal timings based on real-time data.
