We want to ascertain yet again — after extensive meetings with different civic agencies — that we cannot permit two-way traffic movements on Lockgate flyover at any point of time. Even with a speed limit, there are sharp turns that two vehicles — if one is bus — will find difficult to negotiate,” said Santosh Pandey , joint CP (traffic).

Police said the stoppage of truck movement in the area has helped decongest north-bound traffic. “Except for the RG Kar Road stretch, we have come up with alternative strategies. The pedestrian crossover near RG Kar gates still has not thrown up an effective solution,” said an officer.

Sergeants TOI spoke to said they wanted auto routes to be introduced from Paikpara to Lake Town and Belgachhia Metro station. The cops said they will forward the suggestion to Kolkata Police headquarters.

Title: Band vocalist hurt in accident
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kolkata: Folk band Bhoomi singer Soumitra Roy , who is also a senior member of the West Bengal Commission for Protection of Child Rights, was injured after his car hit a median and collided head-on with another car at Wipro crossing near J K Saha bridge in Sector V, Salt Lake around 4pm on Monday.

Roy, who was behind the wheels of the car and coming from Eco Park, reportedly lost control. Cops moved him out of the car and rushed him to Bidhannagar sub-divisional hospital, from where he was shifted to a private nursing home. “He sustained injuries on chest and legs. His condition is stable now,” said a relative of the singer. TNN

Title: Kolkata: Schools to relax entry time for students from Tallah and beyond
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Students commuting to different schools in north Kolkata had a tough time on Monday. While many of them reached schools late, other had a nightmarish journey back home. Many schools are now thinking of relaxing the entry restriction.

According to sources, schools may replicate their policy of relaxing the entry time that they had implemented in the wake of Majerhat bridge collapse in 2018. Rina Sharma, principal of Khalsa Modern School in Dunlop, said: “We are ready to allow grace time for entry of students travelling from Tallah and further north. Students will be given special assistance if anyone misses out on lessons. The annual examinations are approaching.”

Calcutta Public School, Baguiati, is yet to decide on relaxing the entry time for students travelling to and from the affected area. “In the changed scenario, travelling to and from school has become a major issue. We will take a call after checking out with students,” said a spokesperson of the school. Techno India Group Public School, Saltlake, principal Rupa Banerjee said the school had already decided to relax entry time for examinees. “We really cannot do anything about tweaking start and dispersal timing of the school,” she added.

Parents of some students have planned to meet the education minister to make an appeal so that students of the troubled area are exempt from certain regulations that bar entry of students after a point of time. “We are also thinking of appealing to schools not to penalize students if their attendance falls short of the mandatory limit,” said Aurobindo Ghosh, secretary of the Parents Association of North Kolkata.

Arijit Sarkar, a Syambazar AV School student, was late by 40 minutes after taking a detour of one hour from Chiria Mor. “I am now dreading to go to school by bus,” he said.

On Monday, a school bus was found stuck on R G Kar Road for over 40 minutes. “We are worried that they will be late. Parents will rebuke us if their wards are marked absent,” said Anukul Das, a schoolbus cleaner ferrying students to East Kolkata school.

Title: Revenue dept notifies 56 villages as urban areas
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Panaji/Saligao: Goa’s revenue department has reclassified 56 villages as urban areas under section 2(38) of Goa Land Revenue Code 1968 (LRC), the government said in a notification.

However, the department said the notification would not affect building or infrastructure guidelines and was only meant for assessment of land revenue.

“Under the LRC, notification of any village as urban area only affects the process of assessment of land revenue and this classification does not change any building or infrastructure guidelines as far as the revenue department is concerned,” said the government in a note.

The department said that the 56 villages are already classified as census towns as per Census 2011. “The notification simply adopted revenue villages, which are the census towns, as urban areas without any additional criteria,” the government said.

As per Census guidelines, a census town is defined as an area having a population of more than 5,000, with at least 70% males engaged in non-agriculture activities.

The Congress block, Aldona, has meanwhile demanded immediate scrapping of the notification. Congress block’s Aldona president Amarnath Panjikar said the move would destroy Goa’s identity.

Title: SCB fines residents for wasting water
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: For the first time, residents in Secunderabad Cantonment will earn a penalty for wasting potable water. The Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) is acting a tough against consumers who waste water.

It has been imposing penalty under Section 197 of Cantonments Act, 2006. If the consumer fails to pay the penalty, and the water connection will be disconnected.

SCB water wing officials noticed that most consumers waste water — which supplying by Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWSSB) — to bathe pet animals, wash vehicles and gardening. Besides wastage of water, the SCB is also losing revenue.

“We have inspected certain areas during the water supply timings and observed water wastage and served notices to nearly 10 consumers while imposing penalty,” SCB assistant engineer, water works, N Surya Shashank told TOI.

The notices with penalty are being served on the spot, and consumers are given two days to pay the fine. According to the Act, violators can be fined up to Rs 2,500 apart from cost of wasted water.

The official said consumers who were served notices have already paid the penalties to avoid disconnection.

Title: VMC official gheraoed over ‘illegal’ fish sale
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Valpoi: The Valpoi block Congress committee on Monday gheraoed Valpoi Municipal Council (VMC) chief officer Rajesh Ajgaonkar demanding strict action against ‘illegal fish vendors’ operating in different parts of the village.

Their trade, they claim, is adversely impacting the business of local fish vendors operating in the municipal market building. Valpoi Congress committee president Dasharath Mandrekar said they submitted a memorandum and also issued a four-day ultimatum for the council to evacuate those operating ‘illegally’. TNN

Title: HC directive to state on Karunanidhi statue in city
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has directed the state government to take a decision with regard to installation of statue of late DMK leader M Karunanidhi in Madurai within eight weeks.

G Thalapathi, DMK district secretary, in his petition stated that Karunanidhi had served as a chief minister for five terms between 1969 and 2001 and he has the credit of holding the longest tenure of chief minister of Tamil Nadu for 6,863 days.

Since Karunanidhi died at the age of 94 on August 7, 2018, his party functionaries decided to erect a statue for him at Madurai. He said that he had sent a representation to the authorities concerned seeking permission to erect a statue in Madurai on September 3, 2018 and has also sent a reminder letter dated December 6, however, no steps were taken by the officials in this regard.

He noted that while his representation to erect a statue for the late DMK leader is pending for nearly 15 months, the authorities concerned have permitted to erect a statue of late chief minister J Jayalalithaa at K K Nagar in the city.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking permission to erect Karunanidhi’s statue in Madurai by considering his representation. When the petition was heard on Monday, justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana impleaded the revenue department secretary in the petition and directed the state government to take a decision in this regard within eight weeks.

Title: 2 months on, leopard cub found abandoned is healthy at 3.2kg
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Mumbai: Two months after a weak leopard cub was found abandoned in Thane, it has not only survived the odds but even blossomed into a healthy and “playful kid”.

TOI got an update of the spotted male wild cat days after another abandoned leopard cub, a female, was also found in the sugarcane fields at a village in Nashik.

When morning walkers at Yeoor forest in Thane had first spotted the male cub in December, yowling furiously for its mother, the chances of its survival were slim. At the time, the cub weighed barely 380gm, said Dr Shailesh Pethe, wildlife veterinarian at Sanjay Gandhi National Park where both the abandoned cubs are now being tended to. “He’s put on; he now weighs 3.25kg,” he said.

The cub was christened Bittu by Thane corporator Purvesh Sarnaik, and his father Pratap Sarnaik, a legislator, adopted him in December. Initially, Bittu was being fed imported formula milk but is now on a staple diet of raw chicken. “He is fed about 500-600gm of chicken a day, split over four or five intermittent meals besides vitamin supplements,” said Dr Pethe who was helped by superintendent Vijay Barabde, the rescue team and Dr Manish Pingle.

Bittu’s abode is a guest house at the national park. He has a room all to himself where he romps about on all fours under the vigilant eye of his caretakers. Also, he’s taken for walks in the fenced frontyard—an hour in the morning, another in the evening, “This is done to keep his joints in good movement,” said Pethe.

Bittu is now a playful kid, say forest officials. He loves to play with a clutch of toys —a ball, a rattle and chewies —brought specially for him. “These toys are meant for kids and are often found at pet shops,” said Dr Pethe.

When fatigue bogs him down, Bittu curls up into his shawl-lined bed.

Anwar Ahmed, chief conservator of forests of Sanjay Gandhi National Park, said that the cub is hale and hearty. “He couldn’t have been better,” said Ahmed, giving credit to park veterinarian Dr Pethe and the entire team that has been baby-sitting Bittu.

Dubbing the cub’s survival as a “good thing,” Ahmed said, “Generally, cubs abandoned by the mother are prone to infections. While no one can take care of him like the mother would, for this cub we ensured that all possible sources of infection were kept at bay.”

The human touch has left an imprint on the wild cat, said Dr Pethe. “He knows our touch, he recognizes our voices... There’s no way he can now be released into the wild. Soon, he should be sent to a rescue centre at the national park itself.”

For now, though, he is having a rollicking time with his human companions.

“He digs his milk teeth into us... All of us in the team have got love bites from Bittu,” said Dr Pethe. “Since the other abandoned cub arrived last week, Bittu seems to be a bit wary of her.” Perhaps sibling rivalry applies to wildlife too.

Title: Notice on plea seeking speedy disposal of RTI second appeals
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The Madras high court has issued notice to the central and state governments on a plea seeking speedy disposal of second appeals by the Tamil Nadu State Information Commission and Central Information Commission.

In his petition, M Selvakumar, a litigant from Tuticorin district, appearing as party-in-person, stated that the enactment of RTI Act, paved way for the public to access the information available with the government agencies. He stated that this Act was instrumental in avoiding gratification demanded by the officials and it also helps bring out several kinds of scams.

When the people are denied information, the Act enables them to file the first appeal before the appellate officer and when the same is denied, then second appeal could be filed before the state and central information commissions. tnn

Title: 11MW waste-to-energy plant ready by year-end
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ahmedabad: The 11-megawatt waste-to-energy plant being built by the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) at Pirana will be operational by the end of this year and will turn 1,000 tonnes of waste to energy every day.

AMC commissioner Vijay Nehra tweeted that AMC has begun removing the Pirana dump site in the city. He said the plant will use 1,000 tonnes per day and will produce 11MW of electricity. Nehra called on citizens to ensure no more such dumps are created.

The AMC has entered power purchase agreements with two companies that will convert domestic garbage into energy. The AMC stated that Gujarat Electricity Regulatory Commission (GERC) has approved a rate of Rs 7.03 per unit for one company and Rs 7.07 per unit for the other. At least three companies had sent petitions to GERC for approval of the Rs 7 per unit tariff.

The AMC had also set up the first sewage sludge hygienization plant in the country, which became operational last year. The plant, set up at Pirana, can convert 100 tonnes of dry sludge into fertilizer every day.

Title: HC seeks reply over imposition of Section 144
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court on Monday almost echoed the concerns raised by the petitioners, at the continued imposition of Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) in the city, and observed that was is like sending a message to people that it is not safe to live here.

Last month, five petitioners, including a member of faculty from the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIMA), challenged this continual imposition of the section, which restricts the gathering of more than four persons in public, claiming that it had made Ahmedabad “an indefinite war camp which is under permanent danger”.

Taking cognizance of the details supplied by the petitioners, Justice S H Vora said that there was not a single day since 2016 that the police commissioner’s notification invoking Section 144 was not in force in the city. The court commented that it appeared unreasonable so far as the use of Section 144 was concerned, sources said.

The high court also highlighted other contentions raised by the petitioners and put before the state government a question that to maintain law and order, it is understood that the provision is invoked in specific areas for certain periods, but it cannot be imposed permanently across the city since 2016.

The high court ordered the state government to reply to its queries by Wednesday and posted a further hearing on the issue for February 13.

The petitioners complained that the continued imposition of Section 144 of CrPC takes away the people’s right to get together to express themselves. The HC was moved last month after police detained students from outside the IIM-A campus on December 16, when they were protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The HC had earlier suggested that the authorities publish in newspapers the reasons along with the notification imposing Section 144 of the CrPC and Section 37 of the Bombay Police Act, restricting the gathering of more than four persons in public.

The petitioners contended that the repeated imposition of these provisions is against Article 19(1) of the Constitution.

Title: Gujarat high court stays poll code case against Pradeepsinh Jadeja
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Pradeepsinh Jadeja

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Monday stayed the metropolitan court from proceeding further on a complaint against the junior state home minister Pradeepsinh Jadeja alleging him of poll code violation in 2007.

The election officer then had filed a private complaint against Jadeja, who was a BJP candidate in Asarwa in the 2007 assembly elections, for a pamphlet circulated with a photograph of then chief minister with slogan ‘Aapnu Gujarat, Aagvu Gujarat’. The pamphlet also contained a prayer – Vishwambhari Stuti - with a picture of goddess Ambe. It did not contain name of the printer, which is a must under Section 127 (A) of the Representation of People Act.

As Jadeja moved the HC for quashing of the complaint, Justice S H Vora observed that the election officer, Prakash Makwana, has not filed any reply till date. The HC observed that the statement of two witnesses, on whom the metropolitan court relied to order a trial against Jadeja, do not disclose name of printer or publisher of the pamphlet or information about printer of such pamphlet.

The HC further said that Jadeja was nominated as a candidate later. “On perusal of the contents of the pamphlet itself, on the face of it, it does not fall within four corners of provisions of Section 127(A) of the Representation of the People Act or any ingredients of said section surfacing from the statement of two witnesses. Therefore, present application deserves consideration,” the court observed while admitting Jadeja’s quashing petition and ordering a stay on trial court’s process.

Title: Mayem ryots want water from mining pit
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bicholim: The farmers from Mayem village have requested a mining company in Bicholim to divert water from its mining pit to their agricultural farms to help boost their crop.

The farmers said a mining company has its mining pit at Dhabdhaba, Bicholim, and the the water from it is released into the Bicholim river without being used. The villagers said the water could be utilised properly if it was diverted to Mayem village for plantation purposes.

“People from mining belt are starved for water as all the natural reservoirs have been destroyed due to mining, ” said Yeshwant Karbhatkar, president, Mulak Khazan.

Karbhatkar said the state government has undertaken a special scheme to divert water from mining pits to farms in areas like Mayem, Shirgao, Velguem, Pale, Kudne and Surla. However, neither the company nor the government has taken any initiative to divert water from the Dhabdhaba mining pit, he said, requesting the authorities to make a provision for providing the water to farmers.

Title: Drivers seek Rs 25L for kin of man who killed self
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: More than 400 auto rickshaw drivers gathered at Madurai district collector office on Monday demanding Rs 25 lakh compensation and a government job for the family member of an auto rickshaw driver, who died by suicide after touching a high tension wire recently.

The auto rickshaw driver, identified as Arichandran, 45, from Solai Alagupuram, took the extreme step after a police team took action against him for carrying more number of passengers than the permitted number of three people, said the drivers. The drivers from various associations started gathering at the collectorate since morning on Monday. A large number of police personnel and officers were deployed to prevent them from entering the collector office premises. They sat in front of the office and raised slogans against police personnel for harassing them.

The police carried out a drive against diesel auto rickshaw, which is being used as share auto rickshaw, on January 28 as a large scale violation was noticed. More than 20 auto rickshaws were impounded, while fine amount was collected from more than 200 auto rickshaw drivers.

In her complaint with the Avaniyapuram police station, Arichandran’s wife Chandrajothi, 43, stated that her husband, who came home dejected under the influence of alcohol picked up a quarrel with her. He was also under distress due to the pressure of repaying a loan amount. He left the house at around 7 pm and went to the backside of a school at Villapuram, where he climbed on to an electric pole and touched a live wire. With 90% injuries, he was admitted to a government Rajaji hospital, where he died on Sunday, without responding to the treatment.

Auto rickshaw drivers claimed that harassment by the police personnel has taken the life of Arichandran. R P Chandra Bose, coordinator auto rickshaw drivers associations, in a petition to the district collector T G Vinay, stated that a compensation of Rs 25 lakh should be given to the kin of Arichandran. He also demanded a government job for his wife. He also demanded that the city police should come forward to streamline share auto rickshaws by allowing them to carry six passengers, since they cannot earn their livelihood carrying three people just like a regular auto rickshaw.

Title: Secunderabad Cantonment Board readies plan to tackle water crisis during summer
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: With summer weeks away from setting in, officials of Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) have come up with summer action plan to ensure uninterrupted water supply .Major proposals in the plan include increasing water supply, additional tanker trips, and repair of defunct borewells and supply network. Cantonment Board officials are also preparing budget estimations to take up works under contingency plan.As part of this exercise, Board’s water wing officials on Monday held a meeting with Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWSSB) to chalk out proposals for increasing water supply to Cantonment areas.Currently, the water board is supplying 50 lakh gallons of water per day (LGPD) against an assured quantity of 60 LGPD, under ‘Bulk’ category. The SCB, in turn, is supplying water to its residents through its own service reservoirs and water supply network. Certain areas in Cantonment are getting alternate day water supply while some areas get supply three and four days a week.“Though we are managing water supply with present quantity, but with summer in view, we have asked the water board to increase at least nine LGPD to avoid inconvenience to the consumers,” a source in the SCB water wing told TOI.Apart from the regular potable water, the Cantonment Board is also supplying water through nine tankers and will increase them by five tankers based on demand, the source said.Regarding booking of tankers, we are sending tankers within 24 hours from the date of booking. In fact, tanker demand may double when summer reaches peak. We will take all measures to ensure to proper number of tankers are sent to needy consumers, said sources.A senior water wing official said, “There are 850 power bores, and all wells have been recharged with ground water in Cantonment area following bountiful rains. We are anticipating that water crisis may be overcome this summer.

Title: Flower merchants in a fix as marigold prices drop sharply
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

SALEM: The Salem flower market merchants have dumped marigold flowers in bins after its prices dropped significantly due to more than abundant yield. One kilogram of marigold usually costs Rs 150 and Rs 200 depending on the variety. “Now, it is being sold for mere Rs 20,” S Nagaraj, one of the flower cultivators told TOI.

Marigold, one of the important flowers for pujas, is largely cultivated in Ayothiyapattinam , Valasaiyur, Vazhapadi , Attur, Edappadi , Mettur, Omalur, Tharamangalam areas in Salem district.

Marigolds are brought to VOC market, the main flower market in the city. The merchants dispatch them to other retail shops across the district from here.

The marigold cultivators suddenly faced huge loss due to abundance in production.

“Many of the flower farmers across the district switched to marigold business after it had fetched good demand since Pongal,” Nagaraj said, adding that, due to huge demand for marigold flowers to make garlands, the rates skyrocketed once ‘Thai’ month started from Pongal festival.

Marigold is the most favored flower for garland makers as they start buying them in the huge quantities for marriages and other events.The prices have dropped significantly. “Big sized marigolds are being sold for Rs 20 while small sized ones are for Rs 10,” C Kathiresan, a merchant from VOC market said.

The farmers, who did not get proper price for their produce, disposed them in the bins of nearby areas.

Title: Probe into violence at Jamia still on, at crucial stage: Centre to HC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

New Delhi: The Centre on Tuesday told Delhi high court that the probe into the incident of violence at Jamia Millia Islamia during the protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act is at a crucial stage .

Seeking more time before a bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar, solicitor general Tushar Mehta said the investigation was still underway.

Taking note of the submission, the bench granted the Centre time till April 29 to file a reply even as senior advocates appearing for a section of students of Jamia sought immediate interim orders, underlining that 93 students and teachers filed complaints about the alleged attacks on them by police but no FIR has been filed against the cops till date.

Lawyers for the petitioners alleged that the government has not complied with the court order to file a response within four weeks of the last date of hearing on December 19 and should be asked to file on affidavit reasons for delay.

The bench, however, declined to pass any interim order and granted time till April 29 to the government to file a reply.

It had on December 19 asked the Centre, Delhi government and Delhi Police to respond to several PILs seeking setting up of a judicial commission to look into the violence at Jamia Millia Islamia protests against the CAA.

The court is hearing six petitions, moved by lawyers, students of JMI, residents of Okhla — where the university is located — and a Imam of a local mosque where among other prayers they have also sought medical treatment and compensation for the students.

Besides, the petitions demand registration of FIRs against the erring police officers.

The petitions had said the force used by police was “disproportionate”, even if it was required, and “brutal” and expressed concern over the “unregulated and unwarranted arrest and detention of students”.

Title: Prolonged court hearing makes Medha Patkar miss train
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Narmada Bachao Andolan activist Medha Patkar

AHMEDABAD: Narmada Bachao Andolan activist Medha Patkar missed her train on Monday evening due to prolonged court proceedings after she specifically requested the court to allow her to go early.

Patkar had to catch a train to Delhi at 5.40pm, but she could come out of the metropolitan court campus only at 7pm. The procedure was so prolonged that her advocate complained to the court that the activist was being harassed as if she is an accused in the case. Patkar’s cross-examination is under way since April 2012 in connection with her complaint about an assault on her at Gandhi Ashram at a peace meeting during the 2002 riots.

Her advocate Govind Parmar tendered an application to the court on Monday that the court may complete hearing early so that the activist could catch her train. When advocate Parmar tendered an application, a defence lawyer, Ajay Choksi, wrote an objection to Patkar’s request . The objection ran into 20 pages and the lawyer took a couple of hours to pen down his objections to Patkar’s request for early hearing . The procedure ended at 6.15pm and Patkar left the court campus at 7pm, said her lawyer.

Title: Ajgaonkar leads globetrotting netas on state-funded trips
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Porvorim: Tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar spent 43 days on official trips abroad, highest among cabinet ministers and all state officials during the current government’s tenure. A reply tabled at the ongoing assembly session stated that Ajgaonkar went to Paris, Madrid, Chicago, New York, China and Dubai. These trips cost the exchequer nearly Rs 20 lakh, with the cost of the Dubai trip yet to be accounted for. GTDC managing director Nikhil Desai was second in the list, having clocked 39 days on official trips abroad, costing the state nearly Rs 16 lakh.

Desai travelled to travel marts and road shows “to promote destination Goa” in London, Finland, Denmark, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Kazakhstan and China. Other officials who spent a lot time on official trips abroad are chief secretary Dharmesh Sharma, who was abroad for 35 days, and housing secretary Sanjay Gihar, who spent 17 days at three destinations in US.

Sharma’s trips — two to Portugal, one to the US and one to London — cost the state Rs 16 lakh. The cost of Gihar’s trip has not been stated in the assembly reply as “the matter was under submission”. The exact official reason for these two trips has not been stated in the reply either. Similarly, former WRD minister Vinod Paliencar went on a 12-day visit to three destinations in USA. Here too, the official reason has not been mentioned.

Chief minister Pramod Sawant, meanwhile, traveled abroad only on one occasion — to Russia on a four-day visit. His secretary Ashok Kumar, on the other hand, saw over Rs 10 lakh spent on his trips to China, London, Croatia, Bulgaria and Kazashtan.

Tourism director Sanjiv Gadkar, former WRD chief engineer ST Nadkarni, former art and culture director Gurudas Pilarnekar and former director of mines and geology Prasanna Acharya are other officials who travelled to multiple destinations abroad on state funded trips.

Former PWD minister Ramkrishna Dhavalikar made a nine-day visit to Portugal along with PWD principal chief engineer Uttar Parsekar, which together cost the state exchequer over Rs 10 lakh. The trip was to sign an MoU with a body of the Portuguese government so Goa could benefit from its expertise in water and sewage treatment facilities.

Other officials who went on lone trips abroad paid for by the state exchequer are power minister Nilesh Cabral, art and culture minister Govind Gaude, minister for science & technology Michael Lobo, GTDC chairman Dayanand Sopte, secretary for power Puneet Goel, IT director Ravi Jha and Goa waste management corporation, managing director, Levinson Martins.

Title: Cabinet approves Rs2,820 crore for sewage treatment plants
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: The state cabinet on Wednesday approved Rs2,820 crore for construction of sewage treatment plants (STPs) with capacity of 2,011.20 million litres per day (MLD). If all the approved STPs are commissioned, the state will probably become the first in the country to treat the entire sewage generated from urban areas.

The cabinet circular stated that “Sewage of 9,758.53 MLD is generated from 391 urban local bodies in the state. Sewage treatment capacity of these urban local bodies is 7,747.24 MLD which comes to 79%. It is a satisfactory situation. Still, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) issued instructions to ensure treatment of entire sewage. Therefore, approval has been given to STPs with capacity of 2,011.20 MLD at the cost of Rs2,820 crore.”

Funds will be provided from Swachh Bharat Mission and AMRUT phase-II.

The state’s urban development department will soon issue a notification in which funds to be allocated will have city-wise details.

Title: Sports infra used more for expos: Lobo
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Calangute: The sports set-up in the state needs to be overhauled for sporting talent to flourish, said minister for science and technology Michael Lobo. Speaking to reporters at Parra recently, he said a lot of new sports infrastructure like stadiums and other facilities have been built in the state of late, and more are being built for the forthcoming National Games. “But they are hardly being used for sports. Take the Shyama Prasad Mukherjee indoor stadium at Bambolim. It is used less for sports, and more for exhibitions and other events,” Lobo said. tnn

Title: Madurai: Meenakshipuram village gets bus service, courtesy 10-year-old’s plea
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Sahana (in pic) talked about hardships faced by the children in the village to reach their schools in the abse... Read More

MADURAI: Meenakshipuram village in Madurai East Panchayat union has been allotted a bus service connecting it to Mayandipatti village, thanks to the demand raised by a 10-year-old at a gram sabha meeting.

Around 60 students from Meenakshipuram attend the government higher secondary school at Mayandipatti and many of them are forced to walk for 7 kms to reach the school, navigating unsafe paths. Sahana, a class V student, raised the issue at a gram sabha meeting held on Republic Day. Following this, Madurai MP Su Venkatesan met the girl and assured her of working towards allotting a bus service for the village connecting Mayandipatti. He also gifted the girl a book appreciating her effort. Madurai district collector T G Vinay also had taken notice of the issue and assured of action.

On Monday Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), Madurai division, started the bus service that starts from Periyar Bus Terminal to Mayandipatti village through Meenakshipuram operating in the morning and in the evening.

The children in the village expressed their happiness saying that they could now reach their schools without any hassle, thanks to the the bus service.

Title: UN project to help Hyderabad, Andhra pradesh get rid of piling plastic waste
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) will be initiating a massive plastic waste management project in t... Read More

HYDERABAD: The United Nations Development Programme ( UNDP ) will be initiating a massive plastic waste management project in the two Telugu states. The project is part of an all-India initiative, covering 50 cities.

UNDP team has been constituted in Hyderabad to look into the project, which is being taken up in partnership with Hindustan Coca Cola Beverages (HCCB), for both the states. This team will coordinate with key officials to ensure project implementation.

“The goal is to break the ‘house to landfill’ model of plastic waste and focus on reduce, reuse and recycle,” said Prabhjot Sodhi, head – Circular Economy, UNDP. In the city, Rs Rs 5 crore will be spent only on plastic waste management, and in the state the figure will be Rs 10 crore.

Among the first steps to be taken is the establishment and scaling up of UNDP & HCCB-run swachhta kendras in the city. Set up at waste transfer stations, these will help in segregation and reduction of waste that otherwise heads to landfills.

In the first phase, one swachhta kendra was established in August last year under GHMC limits in Kaithalapur transfer station (Kukatpally). Two other swachhta kendras are going to be set up and operated in Lower Tank bund and Nagole in the next six months.

UNDP has several plans to fight plastic littering. It will be launching a ‘plastic to bag’ exchange campaign. This campaign will entail the setting up of ‘eco exchange stalls’ in and around active locations in the city where the public and shopkeepers will be encouraged to bring waste plastic and exchange them for cloth bags that are environmentally friendly. Plastic collected at stalls will be recycled.

Title: Only 45% denizens have paid corpn taxes so far this fiscal
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: With hardly two months left for the financial year to end, the cash-strapped Madurai Corporation has been able to collect only around 45% of tax dues from the residents. The civic body has now urged them to come forward pay the dues well ahead of the deadline.

Stating that lack of response from the denizens was the reason for the tepid collection of taxes, officials said that tax is the lifeline for the corporation to provide various basic amenities and to pay its employees.

Corporation collects various taxes like property tax, vacant land tax, water tax, garbage tax, underground drainage tax and professional tax. In addition, corporation also gets non-tax income though rentals from shops. Property tax fetches major share of revenue.

Sources said that revenue through various taxes and non-tax income such as rental through shops is around Rs 207 crore for 2019-20. However, only Rs 94 crore has been collected so far, which is just around 45%. Out of Rs 207 crore, property tax accounts for around Rs 110 crore. However, only Rs 97 crore is collectable amount with the remaining Rs 13 crore under various litigations.

An official said that people need to pay only the old tax as the revised tax rolled out by the corporation has been reversed after the intervention of the state government. The corporation’s revenue though property tax would have doubled if the rollback did not take place. It would have fetched at least around Rs 100 crore more, which would have been a boon to fund-starved corporation, he said.

About Rs 40 crore paid towards the revised property tax is with the corporation and it would be adjusted in the respective people’s account. Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that employees have been asked to speed up the tax collection process. The amount of tax collected so far has not been encouraging. People should come forward to pay taxes without waiting for deadline to ensure all basic amenities are provided smoothly, he said.

Visakan also said that tax collection centres will function on all weekends and on government holidays in February and March to facilitate smooth collection of taxes.

Title: Show of strength by pro-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

New Delhi: Waving placards and shouting slogans of “goli maaro...” , some 60 supporters of the Citizenship Amendment Act on Tuesday marched towards Jamia where the anti-CAA protesters were agitating, sparking fears of another standoff. However, police acted swiftly and stopped them much before they arrived at the university’s stadium. A similar protest also took place at Shaheen Bagh around noon. Amid frequent interruptions, the anti-CAA protesters took a pledge to exercise their franchise during the Delhi assembly elections on February 8.

Around 3.45 pm, the CAA supporters waved the national flag and marched towards the varsity. Most of them claimed to be the residents of the area. As they were about to reach the university stadium, Delhi Police barricaded the area. While the CAA supporters shouted “goli maaro…”, students gathered on the other side raised the slogan of “Halla Bol”.

“We also have the right to protest. They have blocked the roads for so many days, and now we have to show our strength,” said Ravi Kumar, a CAA supporter.

However, a student said that police should have stopped them at Sukhdev Vihar metro station itself.

Meanwhile, the varsity administration has put up a “wall of democracy,” where students and others can pledge to vote.

At Shaheen Bagh also, protesters on Tuesday took a pledge to use their voting rights on February 8. “Are we going to vote?” asked one of the speakers from the stage, and all the women protesters shouted in unison—“Haan jayenge”.

Saima, a resident of Shaheen Bagh, said, “Voting is our right and those who have stood by us will get our support.”

Ninety-year-old Asma Khatoon seconded her. “I will also go and cast my vote. It is my right,” said one of the oldest protesters at Shaheen Bagh.

Over Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s recent comments, Khatoon said: “He says that we want to break the country. But he is the one who is dividing it.”

Title: Sabarmati river still spews toxic waste
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ahmedabad: The high-profile river rejuvenation committee (RCC) had been formed after the National Green Tribunal (NGT) had pressed the panic button and warned Gujarat about the deteriorating condition of its rivers. The committee will meet on Tuesday and discuss the condition of the Sabarmati downstream of Narol bridge and the actions taken in the case of 20 other rivers.

The December 2019 RCC meeting did not yield an encouraging outcome for the Sabarmati. Many industry associations in Ahmedabad that were asked to urgently upgrade their central effluent treatment plants (CETPs) for treating chemical waste had missed their targets. Many had sought extensions for more than a year. However, the parameters for the Sabarmati within the city limits have been encouraging.

“We have been measuring the chemical and biological oxygen demand, faecal coliforms, and other parameters within the municipal limits and they are within acceptable limits,” said a senior AMC official. “We have managed to divert all illegal sewerage diversions off the river.” The official, however, added that downstream of Narol bridge, industrial waste let into the river was choking the Sabarmati.

CETPs such as the Green Environment Co-operative had sought an extension of a year as civil works had not been completed on time. CETPs such as Odhav Green Enviro projects have been reprimanded for not even attending the December RCC meeting and for not providing updates on upgrades. “Strict action will be taken against CETPs that fail to respond or provide updates on their facilities,” a senior GPCB (Gujarat Pollution Control Board) official and committee member said. Issues such as the status of spray dryer and aeration systems in various CETPs were discussed in the meeting. GPCB member-secretary T M Tambhani and environmental engineer G H Trivedi said in the meeting that performance bank guarantee of Rs 15 crore from various stakeholders had been deposited with the Central Pollution Control Board.

Title: Commuters in eastern parts of Hyderabad rue poor rail connectivity
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Commuters in Hyderabad railway division have long been complaining about poor rail connectivity in the eastern... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Commuters in Hyderabad railway division have long been complaining about poor rail connectivity in the eastern parts of the twin cities, as many have to travel to Secunderabad or Nampally to take trains.

“It is high time that Malkajgiri and Bolarum are turned into terminal stations as there are a huge number of people travelling from these areas daily to Kacheguda, Secunderabad, and Nampally to catch trains,” Vishwanath G, a resident of Sanjeev Nagar told TOI.

Passenger associations are asking authorities to develop the stations into a terminus saying that South Central Railway ( SCR )’s rail connectivity is focused in the city’s west zone.

They say connectivity to towns under division such as Nizamabad and Bodhan can also be improved.

“Until the MMTS phase two is functional, where we will have connectivity to Medchal, Bolarum, Manoharabad, and even Hi-Tech City, we need more express halts as there are no proper connecting trains to Secunderabad and Kacheguda,” said a member of Malkajgiri Suburban Train and Bus Travellers Association.

“Rail connectivity is cluttered at Secunderabad, Nampally, Hyderabad and Kacheguda stations from where many east and southbound trains move. Some important trains like Rayalaseema Express and Devagiri Express should have halts here,” he said.

Elaborating on this, SCR officials said that close to 20 express trains pass through the station, and only 10 halt here. “A number of trains travelling to Maharashtra and other parts of Telangana and AP halt here. Over the time, we have observed a rise in demand and need for more trains such as Rayalaseema Express, Sampark Kranti, and Devagiri to be halted at Malkajgiri,” said an SCR official. Passenger amenities at Malkajgiri railway station have been improved with new platforms, reservation counter, and signage, said SCR officials.

Title: Missing nine-year-old found dead
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: A nine-year-old girl, who went missing on Saturday, was found dead in a well near her house early on Monday morning. The incident took place in Vendurayapuram near Srivilliputhur in Virudhunagar district.

The girl was identified as K Vasanthagurulakshi, a Class IV student in the Saminatham government primary school. Since it was a holiday she and her elder sister had gone to graze few goats in a secluded place in the village. After some time, Vasanthagurulakshi wanted to go home and left.

Gopika, who returned later, did not find her sister. Her family members too searched for her. As they could not find her, they lodged a complaint with the Malli police station, where a girl missing case was registered. The incident created furore in Vendurayapuram and its nearby villages as a girl child, who had gone missing a few days back was murdered after being sexually abused.

While there was delay in find the girl, the family members threatened to carry out out a road block protest on Sunday. However, they were pacified by the police.

Meanwhile, she was found dead in the well early on Monday morning. Police suspect that she could have accidentally fell down while playing nearby. The girl missing case was altered to CrPC 174 – suspicious death.

Title: 224 aircraft hit birds, dogs at Goa airport since 2014
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Passenger jets taking off or landing at the Goa International Airport face a good probability of running into birds and other animals at Dabolim. According to data shared by the Indian Navy with the state government, 224 incidents have been reported at the naval-controlled airbase since April 2014.

Aircraft have hit kites, pigeons, lapwings, crows, peacocks, owls and even dogs.

While 99% of the incidents involved commercial airliners Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd’s light combat aircraft (LCA) Tejas also suffered a scare. The data, however, fails to mention the incident that occurred on November 16, 2019, where a MiG 29 KUB fighter jet crashed after reportedly encountering a flock of birds.

According to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), close to 90% of the bird collisions occur during take-off or landing. At the Goa airport , most incidents occurred during take-off, but rarely resulted in significant damage to the aircraft, data shared by chief minister Pramod Sawant shows. The data also revealed that out of the 224 instances when the aircraft hit an animal or bird, only seven resulted in damage to the aircraft engines.

Commenting that the Indian Navy and Airports Authority of India are responsible for tackling the risk, Sawant said, “Indian Navy has informed that the measures have been put in place for mitigation of bird or animal hazard.”

Among the factors that put the Goa airport at risk is its proximity to residential areas where dumping of garbage in the open is rampant. Sawant also acknowledged the threat posed by construction activities around the airport. The Indian Navy has identified five buildings which have been constructed without obtaining their permission, he said.

“Rules and notifications of the government of India are uniformly applicable to all airports in the country,” Sawant said in his reply to the state legislative assembly.

Title: Mahima Patel attempts another shot at reviving Janata Parivar
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Mahima Patel

BENGALURU: Prevalent upheaval in the three major political parties in the state appears to have boosted the confidence of lone-ranger Mahima Patel , state president of Janata Dal (United), who is looking to fish in troubled waters by attempting to revive the Janata Parivar as an alternative to Congress and BJP in the state.

Notwithstanding several failures on earlier occasions, Patel plans to take a cue from Aam Aadmi Party, that rode on the back of the Anna Hazare movement to become a force reckon with — at least in Delhi and Punjab. He has decided to make one more attempt with centenarian freedom fighter HS Doreswamy at the forefront.

"An alternative political platform is the need of the hour as BJP and Congress have failed to fulfil aspirations of people, especially the younger generation. What we need is a political party that propagates caste-less and cash-less politics," said Doreswamy, who plans to launch an indefinite sit-in (Satygaraha) against the Union government’s ill-conceived economic policies on February 6 in Bengaluru.

Patel, son of former CM JH Patel, said like-minded leaders across parties will leverage Doreswamy’s movement in order to forge a partnership before planning further course of action. "Anna Hazare’s movement was historic as it spawned a new wave of politics in India. Likewise, Doreswamy’s Satyagraha can take politics in Karnataka in a new direction. We can push for a new kind of polarisation in the state," said Patel.

The initiative coincides with disgruntlement in BJP ahead of the cabinet expansion exercise and chaos in the state Congress over appointing a president of the state unit. Incumbent Dinesh Gundurao had resigned in December, but there is a squabble over a suitable replacement.

Patel is hoping against hope senior BJP MLAs, especially wealthy ones like Murgesh Nirani and Umesh V Katti, will join him in building a formidable alternate political force.

"There are some functionaries, including those from the old Janata Parivar, who are unhappy with their parties. If they all to come together on a common platform, it will be possible to revive the Janata Parivar," said former minister and senior JD(S) MLC Basavaraj Horatti.

While several preliminary meetings were held at Patel’s residence, the team is planning to meet again on February 16 and 23 to discuss the way forward.

However, many leaders say it is another futile attempt as there is little or no scope for an alternative party in Karnataka, especially with the BJP becoming a force to reckon with.

However, the JD(S) is leaving no stone unturned in its bid to revive the party, which has been dubbed a sinking ship following a string of electoral setbacks. Former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy is said to have quietly embarked on a mission to rebuild his party before the next assembly polls in 2023.

“The idea of reviving Janata Parivar will not transpire in the present political situation,” Kumaraswamy said. “It is better these leaders join hands to strengthen the JD(S), which already has a strong base,” he said.

Reacting to this, senior Congress functionary BL Shankar, originally from the Janata Parivar, said the revival of JD(S) is possible only when the party is freed from the clutches of the HD Deve Gowda family. “What Kumaraswamy should first do is to ensure JD(S) is free of its family orientation. Then he must ensure a pan-caste and pan-region party by involving different leaders,” said Shankar.

Title: Niti proposal will not be implemented: Shailaja
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Health minister K K Shailaja said the Niti Aayog proposal to privatize district hospitals will not be implemented in the state. Many of the Central policies are against the interests of the state and the government will be forced to protest against such policies, she added.

“The government is not ready to privatize the district hospitals in the state. The Centre has not informed that it is a compulsory directive from the Niti Aayog. Anyway, we are not ready for it,” said the minister.

Shailaja said many of the central policies are not supportive of the state and hence, the state is not getting funds for the many of the new schemes announced by the Centre. “Most of the new schemes are tailor made for the north Indian states. A state like Kerala which has made rapid strides in the health sector are not getting enough funds from the Centre due to this,” she added.

“At present, the health department is sourcing funds from KIIFB for the development of hospitals. The state is not getting enough support from the Centre for the development of health centres,” she said.

The minister said the state government does not support the view that all the district hospitals should be upgraded into the medical college hospitals as mooted in the Union Budget.

“We are of the view of more specialty treatment should be made available in the district hospitals for which there was no need for converting it into medical college hospitals,” said the health minister.

Title: Indane LPG customers urged to opt for digital payment for refill
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL), the distributors of Indane LPG domestic cylinders have appealed to their consumers to opt for digital payment mode to avoid paying extra cash demanded by the delivery persons beyond the retail selling price (RSP) fixed by the company.

IOCL officials have made it clear that the RSP mentioned on the cash memo is inclusive of the delivery charges and that they have received complaints from end users that they are forced to pay anywhere between Rs 20 to Rs 100 extra beyond the RSP by the delivery boys, based on the distance from the agency to the point of delivery.

On booking their refill cylinders through interactive voice response (IVRS) the customer will be sent an SMS on their registered mobile number with the link for making the payment online. The link will be open for a day, through which they can pay the amount through multiple online payment options available such as netbanking or using their credit card, debit card, e-wallets, etc. On completion of digital payment they need not pay anything during the refill delivery.

Customers not using the above mentioned options can insist on making digital payment at the time of delivery too by using the mobile point of sale (mPOS) machine which is carried by the delivery staff. It can be made using credit or debit cards, e-wallets, BHIM, UPI, Google Pay, PayTM, etc.

Officials made it clear that IOCL does not advocate payment of tips for delivery of LPG refills. On receipt of the cylinder, an SMS is sent to the customers confirming the delivery along with the online link for the customers to provide feedback on five parameters to help them enhance the quality of service to customers.

For clarification and guidance contact Indane customer service cell in the following numbers from 9.30am to 5.15 pm on all working days: Chennai – 044-24339236 / 24339246, Madurai – 0452-2533956, Trichy – 0431-2740066 / 2740880, Coimbatore – 0422-2247396 / 2240696.

For any LPG related emergencies call 1906 or the toll free number 18002-333-555 round-the-clock.

Title: Opposition claims 21.9sq km of private forests reclassified
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Porvorim: Opposition members demanded constitution of a house committee alleging that 21.9sq km of private forests have been reclassified. Raising the issue during question hour on the opening day of five-day budget session of Goa legislative assembly on Monday, former forest minister Vijai Sardesai termed it the “biggest scam” of modern Goa.

Sardesai alleged that a committee appointed by the forest department had reduced the area of the private forest already identified from 25.92 sq km to 4.91 sq km.

He was supported by opposition leader Digambar Kamat who said that while the written reply to his starred question on the subject stated that no private forest areas, identified by any committees, was reclassified, the reality was different.

Kamat said that the forest department had informed the chief town planner in August 2019 that the area in question (private forest) can’t be considered under 16B of the Town and Country Planning (TCP) Act. The provision allows de-classification of orchard land. Suddenly, in September 2019, the forest department wrote to the CTP that the area is not a private forest, Kamat said. “There was no question of even granting provisional no-objection certificate since the report on private forests by V T Thomas and Francisco Araujo committee was finalised in October 2018,” he said, pressing for a house committee under the chairmanship of chief minister Pramod Sawant, who is also the forest minister.

Earlier, Sardesai questioned the purpose of appointing a review committee headed by joint secretary revenue to rework findings of the earlier review committee, which submitted its report in 2019. The report, he said, was submitted during his tenure as forest minister and it was rejected. Even the advocate general of Goa had given it adverse comments, he said.

Till date, he said the government has appointed seven committees to identify private forests. Some have given their reports, some are in the finalisation stage. “The government ought to tell people, which report it is following,” Sardesai said.

CM Pramod Sawant said there was no need for a house committee as the matter is pending before the National Green Tribunal. To this, the opposition members said the House is supreme

Title: Rogue biker in bid to flee leaves cop injured
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The bike that Akash Ghosh was riding

KOLKATA: A Jadavpur traffic guard sergeant, Raja Roy, suffered a fracture when a biker hit him while trying to flee during a routine check on Sunday. The incident was reported around 8.20pm from a cut on the median on Prince Gholam Mohammad Shah Road at the Lords crossing near South City. Roy had earlier been attacked twice while on duty.

Roy said he saw a young man on a sports bike coming down the north-bound flank (towards Prince Anwar Shah Road ). He was not wearing a helmet and not following lane rules. I was standing at the cut, which he tried to take to return to Golf Green. When I asked him to stop, he accelerated and hit me, and I fell on the road. The biker tried to speed away, but skidded and fell as well and locals caught him,” Roy said.

The Jadavpur police was informed and Roy was taken to MR Bangur Hospital where a fracture was detected in his left leg. He was later shifted to KPC Hospital where doctors advised him rest for several weeks.

An FIR was lodged by Roy in this regard. Cops said the errant bike rider, Akash Ghosh, did not have a driving licence. The bike he was riding was registered in the name of another person.

The lower constabulary that TOI contacted said mere arrests in individual cases of cop assault were not enough. An all-round tough police stand will automatically increase ‘respect’ for the uniform. As the cops are being targeted on roads, Kolkata police is increasingly becoming jittery.

While the initial cases, which were registered in 2013 were brushed off as “occupational hazards”, the rise in such incidents have forced Lalbazar to try and find ways to prevent them. The worst hit are the traffic cops.

Title: Best-case scenario: Phoolbagan Metro services by April
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The Phoolbagan station, which is almost ready for operations

KOLKATA: Now that East-West Metro’s operations on the elevated Salt Lake section are about to start, Metro Railway will be inviting the Commissioner of Railway Safety ( CRS ) to inspect the underground stretch till Phoolbagan later this month. Officials hope to extend services till Phoolbagan station by April. The 5km Sector V-Salt Lake corridor will be opened to the public on February 13. But not many people are expected to use the section and Metro Railway is likely to incur losses.

The CRS, under the ministry of civil aviation, gives the safety clearance to new Metro routes in the country. “We shall try and apply for the CRS’s inspection of the 1km stretch between Salt Lake Stadium and Phoolbagan this month. Hopefully, the Phoolbagan extension can be opened in April,” a senior Metro official told TOI on Monday.

The 16.5km East-West Metro — that will eventually link Salt Lake’s Sector V with Howrah Station — is being built by Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC) and will be operated by Metro Railway, that operates the north-south Metro.

Officials said the truncated operations can be somewhat viable if services are extended to Phoolbagan where the underground station has been built. The tunnel goes up to Sealdah. The stretch (till Salt Lake Stadium) that is ready to begin operations is elevated. From here, a ramp at Subhas Sarovar leads the tracks down to Phoolbagan station.

But the CRS inspection must be preceded by a clearance for the signalling system from French agency Certifier. On June 1 last year, East-West Metro’s first underground trial run took place as the train chugged 17m below the surface into Phoolbagan station. At that time, the deadline for the extension was October, 2019.

Officials said not many — especially from Sector V — would be able to avail the services because the Sector V station at College More is far from the IT hub. Even if some IT professionals try to walk for 10 minutes or more through the CSTC depot or the road next to Wipro to reach Sector V station, chances are most will prefer riding buses or autos instead.

But once the Phoolbagan extension is operational, commuters will be able to travel from Sealdah to Phoolbagan in autos and take the Metro till Sector V or elsewhere in Salt Lake. There are two auto routes catering to commuters in this section.

Officials said a passengers’ survey can be undertaken only after the Salt Lake services start. “But we are sure that it will merely be a joyride. To make the section viable, the Phoolbagan extension is must,” an official said, adding that, “The East-West Metro will receive a major boost when services are extended till Sealdah.” But the Sealdah extension will be possible only when the 2.45km tunnelling between Esplanade and Sealdah is complete.

This last leg of the tunnelling was stalled after a tunnel boring machine hit an aquifer on August 31 that caused large-scale subsidence, in which several Bowbazar fell like a pack of cards.

Title: SC to hear Maratha quota cases from March 17
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: While refusing any interim relief to city-based petitioners, the Supreme Court on Wednesday directed its registry to list the Maratha quota cases for final hearing from March 17.

A division bench comprising justices Nageshwar Rao and Deepak Gupta also told the petitioners and respondents that no adjournment application would be entertained at any cost, once the hearing begins. Further directing both parties to complete their pleadings before March 17, the judges indicated that they want to finish off the cases as early as possible.

The orders came while hearing Special Leave Petitions (SLPs) by parents led by Devendra Jain and one by the aggrieved students. Both pleas were filed under the banner of ‘Save Merit Save Nation’. Along with these two, many other cases from Mumbai and other parts of the state were clubbed together. A battery of lawyers led by senior counsels — Arvind Datar and Gopal Shankarnayaran — along with Hrishikesh Chitaley and Ashwin Deshpande represented the petitioners. Noted senior lawyer Mukul Rohatgi held the brief for the Maharashtra government.

The petitioners have challenged the Maharashtra government’s decision to implement 12% quota for the Socially Educationally Backward Class (SEBC) in medical and dental courses. The decision was later upheld by the Bombay High Court. It contended that injustice was being meted out to general category students by reducing their quota of seats with the introduction of the Maratha quota.

According to them, students are not only demanding quashing of new quotas that exceeded 50% limit set by the SC, but are also demanding 4% seats for the open category students after HC reduced the 16% SEBC quota to 12%. They accused the government of filling up PG medical seats with 16% SEBC quota instead of 12% despite HC orders which led to loss of 4% seats.

Title: Worrying trend: Defence forces saw 1,110 suicides in 2010-19
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Over 1,110 soldiers, airmen and sailors took the extreme step of ending their lives over the last decade, once again underlining the need for much better suicide prevention interventions in the over 14-lakh strong Indian armed forces.The defence ministry says several measures have been taken over the years to reduce stress among military personnel , ranging from counseling, yoga and grievance redressal mechanisms to improvements in food, clothing, married accommodation and a much more liberalized leave policy.But clearly, much more needs to be done. Latest figures show there were over 895 suicides in the over 12-lakh Army in the 2010-2019 timeframe, followed by 185 and 32 in the much-smaller IAF and Navy , respectively.Mental stress among military personnel, especially among active-duty ones, is of course a global problem. The US military forces, for instance, are currently grappling with a record high suicide rate, with as many as 541 cases in 2018. The suicide rate among active-duty troops was 24.8 per 100,000 personnel, up from 21.9in 2017.While it is true that the suicide rate in the Indian Army works out to just about half of India’s rate of 16.5 suicides per 100,000 people, it is nevertheless worrying in the highly-disciplined environs of the force because suicides can be largely prevented through effective intervention policies.Soldiers don’t have to deal with abject poverty, unemployment, farming distress or other factors that makes India’s suicide rate the highest in the entire south-east Asian region, as per the World Health Organization .But protracted deployment along the volatile border with Pakistan as well as counter-insurgency operations in Jammu and Kashmir and the North-East does take a toll on the mental health and physical endurance of soldiers.Soldiers posted in forward or “field areas” also undergo tremendous stress for not being able to take care of the problems facing their families back home, which could range from property disputes and harassment by anti-social elements to financial and marital problems. “Earlier, the news from the home-front came periodically. Now, they get updates 24x7 through mobile phones, which have certainly added to the rise in stress levels,” said a senior officer.“Moreover, police and civil district administrations around the country are largely unresponsive to grievances of soldiers and their families. A battalion commander could earlier talk to the civilian district authorities to resolve personal problems of his soldiers but that is no longer the case,” he added.Soldiers also have to contend with lack of basic amenities, relatively poor salaries, denial of leave and other such problems. A study by the Defence Institute of Psychological Research (DIPR) some years ago had also noted that the “perceived humiliation and harassment, over and above their occupational and familial causes'', at the hands of their superiors often served as the final “trigger'' for soldiers to commit suicide, as was then reported by TOI.The defence ministry says “domestic and personal problems, marital discord, stress, health issues and financial problems” have been identified as “the major causes” behind suicides in the armed forces in several studies conducted by DIPR since 2006.

Title: Ambedkar had thought of Dalitstan for dalits: Manohar Ajgaonkar
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Manohar Ajgaonkar

PORVORIM: Deputy chief minister Manohar Ajgaonkar on Monday said that although Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar, who is known as the Architect of the Indian Constitution , had thought of the concept of ‘Dalitstan’ for dalits, India has remained united.

While participating in the discussion on a motion moved to congratulate PM Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah for passing the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), Ajgaonkar said, “For the dalits, Babasaheb Ambedkar had said there would be Dalitstan, but we are all together in India.”

He said Ambedkar had travelled widely and was learned, and could hence frame the Constitution of India as a country encompassing people of all faiths. He also said that is because of the Constitution that Hindus, Christians, Muslims, dalits and others live peacefully in India. “Nobody can remove anyone from this country,” Ajgaonkar said.

He further said that when Pakistan was created, all Muslims went there and it was declared an Islamic state, but Hindustan did not become a Muslim or Hindu nation. “Some people say India will become a Hindu nation, but when you say Hindu, it includes everyone — Hindus, Muslims, Christians, dalits and others,” he said.

Title: BMC budget 2020: Property tax collections shrink Rs 630 crore in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Praveen Pardeshi who took charge as Mumbai's municipal commissioner from the now chief secretary Ajoy Mehta in May last year, will table his first civic budget for 2020-21 on Tuesday.

As the corporation’s revenue income has not shown a significant rise, sources say no large increase is expected in the budget size.

Last year, Mehta had presented a budget of Rs 30.692.6 crore—significantly higher than Rs 27,258 crore in 2018-19.

While no new taxes or rise is likely, the budget could look at newer ways to generate revenue, either by promoting tourist spots or charging for advertising. The BMC’s property tax collection till January 31 for the year stood at Rs 2,878 crore—Rs 630 crore less than last year, indicating slow collection due to dipping incomes.

Title: Hike paddy support price, says Churchill
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Porvorim: Benaulim MLA Churchill Alemao on Monday demanded that the state government increase the support price for paddy. He also said that instead of issuing traffic violations challans, police should be directed to crack down on the drug trade in the state.

Alemao told the house that the paddy support price of Rs 20 per kg had been decided by former chief minister Manohar Parrikar, but had not been revised since. He said that government should bear in mind increase in costs of labour and pesticides and appropriately hike the paddy support price.

Alemao also opposed the sewerage corporation’s decision to release treated water from the sewerage treatment plant at Colva into the Colva creek or the Sal.

Title: ‘BEST can exploit own assets to earn revenue’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Mumbai: BEST expects a grant of at least Rs 50 crore towards capital expenditure to purchase 165 new buses this financial year while it wants a financial assistance of Rs 100 crore every month from the BMC for “viability gap funding” to compensate for losses incurred in its bus operations .

Sources said BEST also expects aid of Rs 78 crore for the Intelligent Transport Management System (ITMS) in Mumbai and significant funding for installation of new LED street lamps across the island city. While it is yet to be seen what is in store for the cash-strapped undertaking in the civic budget , BEST committee members argued the transport body should not “completely depend” on the BMC.

Panel members told TOI that it was possible for BEST to commercially exploit its own land and bus depots and earn huge revenue to the tune of hundreds of crores of rupees.

“We need not depend on the BMC budget to bail us out. Now that we have gained a good ridership of 34 lakh daily commuters with the huge cut in bus fare (Rs 5 for 5 km and Rs 6 for AC rides), we can earn more revenue through advertisments on TV panels in buses and at bus stops, hoardings at depots and BEST owned land. We can construct commercial premises at depots and give them on lease to private operators,” said panel member Bhushan Patil from Congress. He recalled that BEST had already received Rs 2,000 crore aid from the civic body in recent months to clear past loans and run bus operations. “It is high time you can reduce losses on your own,” said BEST panel opposition leader Ravi Raja. “If we do proper asset management and commercially exploit BEST land, we can earn up to Rs 3,000 crore in four years.” BEST general manager Surendrakumar Bagde said there was no new plan to redevelop any of the 27 bus depots. — Somit Sen

Title: State govt expects Mopa airport cost to increase
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Panaji: After the Supreme Court gave the go-ahead, the state government and GMR Goa International Airport Limited (GGIAL) have begun working on a revised timeline for the greenfield international airport being built at Mopa , said chief minister Pramod Sawant .

Sawant, in a written reply to the legislative assembly, said that the cost of phase I of the airport was likely to increase beyond Rs 1,900 crore estimated earlier, due to the delay.

“The physical progress achieved in construction of Mopa airport was 14.28%. As per the earlier schedule, the first phase of the project was to be completed and commissioned on or before September 3, 2020. The revised schedule of construction is being worked out in view of the order of the courts,” said Sawant.

As per clause 30.2.1 of the Concession Agreement signed between the state government and GGIAL, the concessionaire shall pay 36.99% of gross revenue to the government from the sixth year onwards. GGIAL, a subsidiary of GMR Airports Limited, has “not yet” claimed any damages for the delay.

“In view of the Supreme Court order, correspondence and consultation with the concessionaire is being initiated to finalise the revised time frame to complete the construction work of the Mopa airport,” said Sawant.

The chief minister also said that land for the approach road to the airport has not been acquired.

Title: In a midnight rejig, Telangana govt shifts out 65 IAS officers
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a major bureaucratic overhaul, the Telangana government late on Sunday night transferred over 60 IAS officers, including two special chief secretaries and principal secretaries. Young IAS officer Sweta Mohanty, who is currently collector of Jogulamba-Gadwal district, has been roped in to handle Hyderabad. In all, 65 All India Service (AIS) officers were transferred late on Sunday. Of them, over 50 IAS officers were given fresh postings.The reshuffle was necessitated as some senior officers reportedly sought transfer, while some IAS officers had completed three-year stint as collectors. Also, some junior officers, belonging to the 2015 and 2016 batches got postings after completing their training as assistant collectors.After appointment of Somesh Kumar as chief secretary, many officers senior to him, now special chief secretary cadre, reportedly requested the government to shift them as they cannot report to Somesh. Considering their request, government shifted general administration department (GAD) special CS Adhar Sinha to animal husbandry department, while another special CS, Chitra Ramachandran, was posted as head of education department.Chief electoral officer Rajat Kumar is posted as principal secretary of irrigation and command area development department, while panchayat raj department principal secretary Vikas Raj was transferred to GAD and M Jagadishwar to the revenue department.B Janardhan Reddy, who is currently secretary of education department, is shifted to agriculture department, while incumbent principal secretary C Pardha Saradhi was posted as director-general of EPTRI. Sandeep Kumar Sultania, secretary in CMO and secretary of finance department, is shifted to panchayat raj department. Two more IAS officers B Venkatesham was made secretary of BC welfare and Rahul Bojja secretary of SC welfare department.T K Sreedevi, presently commissioner and director of municipal administration, and Mahbubnagar collector D Ronald Rose have been made secretaries in the finance department. Since finance department has become crucial in the wake of economic slowdown and government’s importance to financial discipline, government posted two secretaries.Kamareddy collector N Satyanarayana has been posted as commissioner and director of municipal administration, while Adilabad collector D Divya has been posted as secretary of women and child welfare department. Bhadradri-Kothagudem collector Rajat Kumar Saini would be director of CCLA and look after land administration. Hyderabad collector K Manicka Raj has been posted as commissioner of industries.The government also transferred several IAS officers working as additional commissioners and zonal commissioners in Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC). All of them were given postings as collectors of various districts. Dasari Harichandana (Narayanpet), Sikta Patnaik (Peddapalli), Shruti Ojha (Jogulamba) and Mushraff Ali (Nirmal). Another additional commissioner Adwait Kumar Singh has been named as executive assistant to the chief secretary.Ten collectors, who completed over two years in present positions, were shifted. Jagityal collector A Sharath was sent to Kamareddy, while Peddapalli collector Sridevasena was moved to Adilabad. Other postings include V Venkateshwarlu (Medchal-Malkajgiri), MV Reddy (Bhadradri-Kothagudem), K Nikhila (Jangaon), Pausami Basu (Vikarabad), Md Abdul Azeem (Jayashankar-Bhupalapally) and T Vinay Krishna Reddy (Suryapet).

Title: Vocational courses help halve dropout rate to 7%
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Panaji: The introduction of National Skills Qualifications Framework (NSQF) and the pre-vocational scheme has brought down the dropout rate at the secondary school level by more than half to almost 7.3% in 2017-18 as against over 16% during the previous years, according to a reply tabled during the ongoing state assembly session.

During the current academic year 2019-20 itself, over 7,200 students from Class IX to XII will be benefitting from the NSQF scheme, chief minister Pramod Sawant, who also holds the education portfolio, said.

NSQF allows students to opt for a seventh subject that involves skills training in 14 streams like tourism and hospitality among others. From the six regular subjects and the seventh NSQF one, students have to clear any six. The scheme helps students who prefer a vocation-based approach to studies clear their examinations by letting them study a vocational subject and it gives them vertical mobility.

Students who clear Class X under the scheme can continue training in the subject of their choice at the higher secondary level as well and study up to the degree level in the vocational stream.

Under NSQF at the school level, students have to attend lectures by industry professionals and complete at least four industrial visits in a year in their chosen specialisation. They are evaluated by industry experts in the practical portion of the course, which includes viva and creating a work portfolio.

From 2017 onwards, assessments are being done by industry persons through National Skill Development Corporation, based on an MoU signed between the national body and the state.

Similarly, the pre-vocational scheme was introduced around 2010 in aided institutions in rural areas. Under the scheme, students can drop any one subject from among mathematics, science or social science to opt for a vocational subject from Class VIII onwards.
