Title: Fishermen rescue 12ft-long whale shark
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Eight fishermen from Kanyakumari district who went deep sea fishing in the Arabian Sea rescued and released a more than 12ft long whale shark, protected under Schedule 1 of The Wildlife Protection Act, 1972, that was accidentally caught in their net. While there are incidents of whale sharks getting killed when boats accidentally hit them in Ramanathapuram and Tuticorin districts, fishermen termed the rescue a rarity.

P Dickson, owner and captain of mechanised boat ‘Deivasnegam’ said that 13 fishermen set off for fishing from Thengapattanam fishing harbour on January 11. Around 5pm on January 25 they were fishing 100 nautical miles (185km) northwest of Goa and had spread the net for a five nautical mile (9km) stretch.

The rescue and release was video recorded on mobile and shared among friends and with fisheries officials after the fishermen reached home on Sunday. tnn

Title: Sasikala: In last year of imprisonment, VK Sasikala yet to pay Rs 10 crore fine
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

VK Sasikala was imposed a fine of Rs 10 crore after she was convicted by the Karnataka high court in a disprop... Read More

BENGALURU: Stepping into the last year of the four-year simple imprisonment awarded to her in a disproportionate assets case, former AIADMK secretary VK Sasikala is yet to pay a fine of Rs 10 crore. Failure to do so may result in her spending one more year in jail.

Sasikala, her foster son VN Sudhakaran and J Ilavarasi have been lodged in Central Jail (Parappana Agrahara) since February 15, 2017, after the Supreme Court set aside their acquittal by Karnataka high court.

In September 2014, the special trial court of judge John Michael Cunha had sentenced former Tamil Nadu chief minister J Jayalalithaa, Sasikala, Ilavarasi and Sudhakaran under Section 109 IPC read with Section 13 (2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act — abetment of criminal misconduct of a public servant — to simple imprisonment for four years.

Jayalalithaa was fined Rs 100 crore, while Sasikala, Sudhakaran and Ilavarasi were fined Rs 10 crore each. In case they failed to pay the penalty, they would have to serve another year in jail, the trial court said.

All the convicts approached high court for bail, but the requests were turned down. Later, Jayalalithaa and others approached the Supreme Court, which granted them bail on October 17, 2014. All the four had walked out of prison after spending around 21 days in detention. The high court acquitted the quartet on May 11, 2015.

According to prison officials, most convicts who are slapped heavy fines pay only at the end of their jail term. In Sasikala’s case, the amount will have to be paid only through cheque or demand draft. “The source of income should be announced and a no-objection certificate should be obtained from the income-tax department,” said senior jail officials.

However, prison officials dismissed as baseless rumours of Sasikala’s early release due to good conduct. “We don’t know who is spreading these rumours. Premature release is for convicts who have completed at least 14 years of imprisonment and are guilty of heinous crimes like murder, rape and dacoity. If Sasikala and others pay fine, they will walk out on January 25, 2021. Else, they will be released on February 15, 2022,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad: Be active on Twitter, residents tell newly-appointed officers
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Activists and residents from central Hyderabad and IT corridor asked the newly-appointed officers to be active on Twitter like the former officers of that zone. The residents said that the previous officers used to reply to their complaints on Twitter and depute staff to resolve their grievances.

“The newly-appointed officers should be active on Twitter to understand the ground reality. In GHMC app, there are chances that the complaint might be closed even without being attended,” said Harish Daga, an activist.

Residents said that social media platforms are the easiest way to approach the officials. “Twitter is the easiest way to approach officials and we can also post pictures with the complaint. During one instance, I had posted about water-logging on a road near Nectar Gardens in Madhapur and immediately staffers were pressed into action to resolve the problem,” said Neeru Golconda, a techie.

“We visited the zonal offices in Serilingampally and Khairatabad. The officials there asked us to reach out to them online and told us to make use of technology for reporting all civic related issues. They also informed us about the recent developments by the civic body’s IT wing,” said PM Sai Prasad, a BJYM leader and RTI activist.

Title: Spread of nCoV rumours hurting us more: Prof from Chinese varsity
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Madurai: Pained at the damage caused by spread of false rumours as China battles the deadly novel coronavirus (nCoV), a 39-year-old assistant professor at a Chinese University from Madurai urged the public not to believe and spread such rumours.

C Neelakandan, a native of a village near Madurai, is an assistant professor at the department of Information Technology and Communication Engineering, Shaoguan University Guangdong Province. “It is painful to see people spread false rumours about nCoV. Some people are not aware of what is really going on and merge incidents to exaggerate the damage caused by spread of the virus,” he told TOI.

Neelakandan has been working in China for the past 10 years and was at his university during the initial outbreak of nCoV in China. “I first heard of news that a severe pneumonia virus is spreading in China. I had to go via Wuhan to catch my flight in Beijing but there was no panic then. I actually travelled with people from Wuhan in a train but everything was fine then. Only later, when I came to know of nCoV, it was scary and I was thankful,” he said. Neelakandan reached India on January 10 for his vacation.

“The screening at the airports in India, evacuations and lockdown in China began only after January 20. I actually wanted to go back to China by January 15 but I got to know that the reopening of the university got delayed,” he said and added that his university has been checking up on his health status.

“I’ve been checking with my friends at my work place and even some who are in Wuhan. They are all fine but are trying to stay at home and isolate themselves. I’m really glad to hear from friends that most of the students and professors from Tamil Nadu who were in China have been evacuated. During such trying times, everyone is doing their best,” said Neelakandan. He hoped that by the start of spring, things improve and urged Indians to keep their spirits up and welcome Chinese residents with open arms.

Recently, he attended an international Tamil conference at Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU). “It was heart-warming to see a few Chinese students come for an educational tour to India and spend time at MKU and meeting locals too. Winter vacations are special for students in China, but it is a sad time this year. I hope Chinese residents are not banned from the country,” he said.

Title: No delay in taking action against CoE on graft: MKU VC
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Vice-chancellor (VC) of Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU), M Krishnan on Monday said that there is no delay in taking action against the controller of examination (CoE) O Ravi over the graft charges against him. Meanwhile, Ravi has claimed that the charges against him are part of a conspiracy against him.

On January 23, an unauthorised person reportedly accessed the consolidated mark sheets of various centres in the office of the CoE. The VC is also said to have acted on a tip-off, nabbing the person in the act. When confronted Ravi, he denied having any link to the person.

Last week, general secretary, MKU Principals’ Association, I Ismail, sought the suspension of the CoE and a DVAC probe for allegedly collecting Rs 3 crore bribe from various distance education centre coordinators in Tamil Nadu and other states by distributing consolidated mark statements without collecting fees dues to the university. tnn

Title: CM misleading assembly: SDPI
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kozhikode: Social Democratic Party of India ( SDPI ) has asked chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan to withdraw the baseless comments on the party and tender an apology for misleading the assembly.

Addressing a news conference here, SDPI state general secretary P Abdul Hameed said that the remarks against the party should be removed from the assembly records.

The CM made the comments referring to an incident in Angamaly. Not a single person arrested in the case is an SDPI worker, he said. Hameed said CPM is worried that lakhs of people are participating in the anti-CAA agitations led by the SDPI while the protests staged by the CPM have low turnout. “That is why the CPM is raising the allegation that the SDPI is creating trouble on the pretext of anti-CAA agitations,” he said. “The CM is helplessly watching the growing RSS influence in the police,” Hameed said. Even while the government says that there will not be any case for participating in the anti-CAA protests, police have registered cases, he said. TNN

Title: Uttarakhand reports second case of suspected coronavirus
Content:
AIIMS Rishikesh

DEHRADUN: Another case of suspected coronavirus , the second in the state in less than a week’s time, was reported at All Indian Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) Rishikesh on Monday. The patient, a female medical student studying in China, had returned to her home in Rishikesh on January 1, and had visited AIIMS with complaints of symptoms similar to that of coronavirus, after which she was admitted in the isolation ward of the hospital.Harish Thapliyal, PRO, AIIMS Rishikesh told TOI that the patient, who is 24 years old, had visited the ENT (Ear Nose Throat) department of the hospital on Monday with complaints of mild discomfort in her throat, dry cough and headache for the past one week. “We found that she was interning at a university of traditional Chinese medicine located in the Nongchang state around 650km away from Wuhan City. During her stay in China before she left for India, she had developed the symptoms although there was no fever or breathing difficulty,” he said.“We have admitted the patient to our isolation ward and sent samples for coronavirus testing. Her condition is currently stable,” said Thapliyal adding that the other patient, a 21-year-old medical student, who was also studying in China and had been brought to AIIMS last week with symptoms of suspected coronavirus was discharged on Monday after she was eventually diagnosed with influenza.Meanwhile, officials of the health department said that they are conducting continuous review meetings on the deadly virus, which has cost over 200 lives and created a global scare.“The private hospitals have been informed about the protocol they are supposed to follow in coronavirus case. They have to inform the health department and government immediately in case of suspected cases and the patient should be kept in isolation,” said Pankaj Kumar Pandey, in-charge secretary health who added that anyone who is suffering from cough, cold, respiratory issues etc and has visited China after January 15 should be treated as a high-priority case.

Title: Patna: RJD to hold district presidents’ meet on February 8
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

RJD state president Jagdanand Singh. (File photo)

PATNA: RJD will hold a meeting of its district presidents at Patna on February 8 following the return of leader of opposition Tejashwi Prasad Yadav from Delhi. The meeting will, however, be chaired by RJD’s state president Jagdanand Singh .

Incidentally, it will be the first state-level meeting of RJD district presidents after its organizational elections held in November-December last year.

“The meeting has been called to chalk out strategy for assembly elections in Bihar slated to be held later this year. Feedback will be taken from the district presidents and they will also be issued instructions for expediting the poll preparedness in their respective districts,” RJD spokesperson Chitranjan Gagan said.

Sources said a proposal for holding such a meeting was made by party’s national vice-president Raghuvansh Prasad Singh as well. Raghuvansh had also written a letter to the party president Lalu Prasad on January 9 with a copy to Jagdanand, expressing concern over lethargic approach in the party towards formation of committees at the grassroots level and preparation for the assembly election.

Incidentally, the two Rajput veterans of the RJD were at loggerheads over the past few weeks after appointment of Jagdanand as state president of the party. Raghuvansh even went on to calling few new regulations introduced by Jagdanand as dictatorial. Later, Lalu had to intervene in the matter, following which Raghuvansh called on Jagdanand at RJD state headquarters last Friday. Incidentally, both addressed media persons separately and Raghuvansh met Lalu at Rims, Ranchi on Saturday.

Tej Pratap to meet Lalu

Incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s elder son Tej Pratap Yadav reached Ranchi on Monday evening. Sources said he is slated to meet Lalu on Tuesday at Rajendra Institute of Medical Sciences (Rims), where the latter is undergoing treatment, while serving jail term in fodder scam cases. “I am going to take blessings from my father,” Tej told reporters at Patna. Earlier, Tej’s mother and former Bihar CM Rabri met Lalu at Rims on last Monday after more than two years.

Title: Opa levels drop, PWD gears to pump water into Khandepar river
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ponda: With water no longer overflowing from the Opa barrage, the public works department (PWD) has asked officials of the water resources department (WRD) overlooking the Ganjem bandhara to get the pumps at the Ganjem and Selaulim Dam ready within a fortnight to rejuvenate the Khandepar river.

Following the commissioning of the new 27 MLD water treatment plant at Opa, over 160 MLD water is drawn from the Khandepar river and the authorities are preparing for an eventuality where the level of river could see a dip by February 15.

A total of five water treatment plants at Opa enable supply of potable water to Ponda and Tiswadi talukas.

Once the level of the Opa basin drops, it receives water from the Selaulim dam, Ganjem water scheme, a total 18 bandharas over the Khandepar and Kalem rivers and the mining pits in Codli village on the banks of the Opa river.

The Opa barrage has a capacity to hold up to 5m of water, but level it maintained at a maximum 4.4m to avoid flooding in surrounding areas. Surplus water is allowed to overflow from the barrage gates.

However, as of Monday, water stopped overflowing with the water level in the barrage touching 4.3m.

Ganjem Bundhara has two pumps of 330HP each that fetch 30 MLD water, while at Selaulim dam there are two pumps of 650 HP each that together draw 48 MLD water.

While the WRD fetches 35 MLD water from the Mhadei at Bolcornem Bundhara and pours it in the Ganjem river which flows into the Opa, the Selaulim treatment plant pours 48 MLD water in the Kalem river that flows down to the Opa water treatment plant, WRD canal officer Ankush Gaonkar said.

In addition to this, 70 MLD water is being poured into the river from the mining pits of Vedanta and an abandoned pit near Someshwar Temple at Codli in Dharbandora and Zarapkar mines at Satone in Dabal, said Gaonkar, who looks after rejuvenating the river during summer.

Title: Bihar: CRPF jawan fakes kidnapping to extort money from his father
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Kaimur police on Monday arrested a CRPF jawan for faking his kidnapping to get ransom from his father.

The constable, Rajdev Kumar Gupta, was recovered from a train between Patna and Bhabhua in Kaimur on Monday, six days after his alleged kidnapping by unknown criminals from Buxar-Thakura road under the Noan police station area of the district on January 27.

The victim’s wife, Nandini Kumari, had apprehended the involvement of Gupta’s stepbrother, who was detained by police. The suspect, however, denied his involvement in the kidnapping of Gupta, who was posted in Andhra Pradesh.

Nandini had told the investigating officers that her husband was kidnapped for ransom as her father-in-law had received Rs 30 lakh after selling some ancestral land in the village recently. The kidnappers had allegedly demanded Rs 18 lakh as ransom for his release.

Kaimur SP Dilnawaz Ahmad said, “Our investigation revealed that the CRPF jawan had been in constant touch with his wife ever since the kidnapping was reported to police. He, however, kept moving from one place to another and talked to his wife from different phone numbers.”

On Monday, when the location of Gupta’s cellphone was traced near Mohania in Kaimur, police rushed to the place and recovered him.

“During investigation, it came to light that a sum of Rs 6 lakh was transferred to Gupta’s bank account from his father’s to pay the ransom money to the alleged kidnappers. In fact, Gupta had taken a Rs10 lakh loan and had enacted the drama of his false kidnapping to return the money,” the SP said.

The role of Gupta also came under the scanner after the Andhra police disclosed that the CRPF jawan had been missing from duty since December 3 last year. The officials of the central force apprehended that he might have been kidnapped by the Left extremists operating in the region and subsequently a missing complaint was lodged.

Gupta, who is a native of Buxar district , was produced before a court at Bhabhua, which later remanded him to judicial custody for 14 days.

Title: Water Resources Department ready to lay pipeline above nullah bed
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Villagers fear digging into the nullah will destroy the water source

PONDA: Following opposition from locals, the water resources department (WRD) on Monday said that they were ready to lay the pipeline from the river bed instead of laying it 2m deep below the nullah bed.

Fearing that digging along the existing natural water nullah to lay a pipeline would destroy the underground natural water resources, a group of over 50 people from Dhatwada-Usgao and surrounding areas in Ponda taluka stopped the laying of the pipeline on Saturday.

Locals demanded that the WRD either change the route of the pipeline or lay pipes over the nullah bed.

The WRD has been laying a 1,000mm pipeline for the augmentation of water from Ganjem water scheme on the Mhadei river to Khandepar river, for rejuvenating the Khandepar river during summer. The Opa water works complex, which comprises the five water treatment plants that collectively supply potable water to over 90% of Ponda and Tiswadi talukas, is fully dependent on water from the Khandepar river.

Water levels of the river dip every summer and the WRD is then forced to source water from elsewhere, including 35MLD water from the Ganjem water scheme.

Until last summer, the WRD used to pour the Ganjem water into the Dhaushirem nullah, from where it would flow into the Khandepar river. As the entire quantity of water does not reach the Khandepar river due to losses by evaporation, ground seepage and drawing by farmers mid-way, the WRD has been laying a pipeline that would pour the Ganjem water directly into the river.

A WRD official said that the contractor would fill the trench and restore the nullah basin after laying the pipeline, but the locals were not convinced.

Title: Telangana: Govt to take over portion of Mint compound for Secretariat
Content: HYDERABAD: After demolition of Irrum Manzil was proposed for construction of new Telangana Assembly building, the state government has decided to take over Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited ( TSSPDCL ) building at the Mint Compound for construction of new Secretariat building . While there is a high court order pending on demolition of existing Secretariat buildings, the government is getting ready with its plans.Sources in TSSPDCL said the government has asked the power discom to vacate its offices in the building, adjacent to the present Secretariat complex. As of now operations division, electrical inspector and other offices have been functioning from the building which is about 100 years old.A few years ago, the government had proposed to use the building for security personnel guarding the Secretariat. But TSSPDCL authorities said that they do not have space to shift their offices. Now, the government reportedly instructed the power discom to vacate the building because as per Vaastu compliance the land is required for new Secretariat. The office in Mint Compound is spread in about 2.5 acres of land.It was once called as Nizam’s Mint Compound and later, in 1980, ministry of finance set up government’s Mint and Security printing press in the building. Earlier, there was a plan to seek government of India’s land in the same compound, but keeping in mind the Bison Polo experience the idea was dropped as Union government may not part with the land. “Officially we have not received any communication on handing over the Mint Compound buildings to the state government,” a director of TSSPDCL said. However, officials said that the government is dealing only with the top brass as heritage conservationists will make it a big issue.Official sources said the government wants to speed up the construction works of new Secretariat as it is expecting high court’s verdict in the case. The HC had said that it has no objection with government getting ready with the plans and the stay is only on demolition of exiting blocks.The seven-Secretariat block would be razed using implosion technology. The cabinet sub-committee has submitted its techno-feasibility report to CM K Chandrasekhar Rao and suggested demolition of existing Secretariat.

Title: Coronavirus: Need not rush to buy masks, may trigger shortage, say doctors
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The demand for face masks in view of the coronavirus outbreak in China has increased, but they are mostly bought by tourists rather than locals. The specialised N- 95 masks are not available.Dr Utkarsh Betodkar , state epidemiologist, said people don’t need to use specialised masks. They can do with a three-layered mask if necessary. It costs relatively less and is a one-time use mask that should be replaced after six hours of use, he said.Kedar Jirage, proprietor and chief pharmacist at Jeevan Rekha medical stores in Panaji, said they sell about 30 to 35 masks a day. “They are bought by mostly travelers,” he said. He said his pharmacy had received an order for supply of 100-150 masks, but they could not fulfill it. The person who placed the order, he said, wanted to send them to China.Raj Vaidya, chief pharmacist at Panaji’s Hindu Pharmacy, said they too have sold more masks since the new disease surfaced.Betodkar, however, warned people not to buy masks unnecessarily, particularly the specialised kind, to avoid the shortage of masks.“Correct disposal of masks is very important,” he said, further adding that specialised masks are for use by doctors and health workers who are exposed to the infection. Goa has two cases of suspected Coronavirus isolated at Goa Medical College ,and hospital, while 14 persons are under observation. The blood and nasal swab samples of one patient was sent for testing at Pune's National Institute of Virology (NIV). The report of the other patient, a foreigner is awaited.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Govt should issue travel advisory, says Pratapsingh Rane
Content:
Representative image

PORVORIM: Poriem MLA Pratapsingh Rane on Monday said that the Goa government should issue a public advisory against travel to certain countries, to avoid bringing the coronavirus infection into the state.“What action has been taken by the government to prevent a coronavirus epidemic in Goa?” he asked. “We don’t want to die like flies as it happened in China. God knows how many people died,” Rane said.He said that the health department should take proactive measures against the spread of the infection. “Many people from Goa work overseas; they travel and come back, and so it is important to take steps to prevent the virus from coming into Goa,” Rane said. He asked the CM and the health minister about the steps the government has taken in the matter.

Title: Self-help groups will continue to supply midday meals: CM
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Porvorim: Chief minister Pramod Sawant told the state legislative assembly on Monday that his government does not intend to appoint any agency to provide midday meals to schools and that women’s self-help groups (SHG) will continue to do the job.

“If at all any memorandum of understanding (MoU) was signed, it will be cancelled,” Sawant said while replying to the question tabled by opposition leader Digambar Kamat during the ‘question hour’.

Raising a supplementary query, former town and country planning minister Vijai Sardesai said that the state government had signed an MoU with Akshaya Patra Foundation, a not for profit organisation that runs school lunch programme across the country.

Earlier, Kamat pointed out that payments to some SHGs was delayed. “The government should ensure that the payments to SHGs be released on time,” he said.

To this, Sawant said that payments to some SHGs was not made on time as there was a delay in signing an agreement. The delay, he said, was on the part of SHG.

He further said that payment was held back as one of the three signatories to the contract had not signed. “There could be double claims. The department can be questioned if payment is released without other signatories,” Sawant said.

Nonetheless, he said, it should be ensured that payments are to be made to all SHG within one month of submission of bills. The chief minister expressed the need to put a mechanism in place to allow timely payments to SHGs.

Title: Minister intervenes, crumbling govt school may get new bldg
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: As many as 31 students of a government-run primary school in Kadekal village in Mulugu district are facing a grave risk. With their school building in a dilapidated condition and set to collapse, the students are at their wits’ end.

A software engineer Suman, who recently got a job in the school, highlighted its condition on Twitter and pleaded with education minister Sabitha Indra Reddy to do something. He posted photographs of the school. In one photograph, he stood with the children pleading that they be saved from an impending tragedy.

The minister said she had asked the commissioner of school education to look into the matter. “I have instructed the officials to construct a new school building in place of the dilapidated classrooms,” Sabitha said.

Following the minister’s intervention, an official visited the school on Saturday. “We hope something will be done for the children so that they can study in a better environment,” Suman told TOI.

The decades-old school building has been neglected. It has three rooms. One room is always locked, while the condition of the other rooms is very bad, forcing the children to study under an asbestos sheet. Suman, who comes from a tribal background, worked in an IT firm in Hyderabad before becoming a teacher in the school in December last year.

Title: The voice of Ahmedabad’s Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ahmedabad: At the anti-CAA protest venue at Ajit Mills the microphone goes to Safia Pathan, 10, who keeps raising slogans for nearly half an hour without any fumble. The younger of two siblings, Safia, a Class-4 student and daughter of an autorickshaw driver, is seen resting her back on a big replica of the Constitution placed at the protest venue when she shouts slogans and also raises her left hand like a seasoned activist while shouting Azadi slogans. When asked how she learnt shouting slogans, Safia said she observed some activists and for last 10 days she has been raising slogans against CAA, NRC and NPR.

Title: Maharashtra: Tansa pipeline cycling track a non-starter
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Condition of cycling track laid out alongside Tansa pipeline has worsened

MUMBAI: Two years have passed and work worth crores has been sanctioned, and yet completion of the 39km cycling and jogging track along Tansa pipeline continues to be a pipe dream. Though the BMC had sanctioned more than Rs 488 crore in its previous budget for the project, work has been moving at a snail’s pace.

Photographs from Bhandup-Mulund areas, where the BMC started the project in 2018, show the condition of the tracks that have been laid so far has already worsened. The project was to be completed by financial year 2020-21, but it is set to miss the deadline. Civic officials involved in implementation of the project refused to speak on it.

Politicians alleged that delay in the work has escalated costs. In 2018, the BMC had decided to lay out a cycling track along the Tansa pipeline between Mulund and Sion , connecting the stations in between, at a cost of Rs 300 crore. Within two years, though, the project cost increased to nearly Rs 500 crore.

Ravi Raja, opposition leader in the BMC and Congress corporator, said, “A cycling track is a good concept. But the BMC had planned it in a hurry, without conducting a proper study. A cycling track should be close to roads but it is being constructed along a water pipeline. We don’t know how the project will be executed. The BMC has already allocated work worth Rs 275 crore but it is unable to expedite it due to encroachments. It keeps delaying the project and the cost keeps rising. It is a waste of public money.”

In 2017, the BMC began massive demolition drives to remove over 16,000 encroachments for the security of Tansa pipeline following a Bombay high court order.

To ensure encroachers do not return, the BMC drew up a project titled ‘Green Wheels Along Blue Lines’ to develop a 10-metre-wide cycling and jogging track on the cleared land between Mulund and Sion. The proposed cycling track will have 40 exits and it will be connected to 10 Central Railway stations, five Western Railway stations, four Harbour line stations, seven Metro stations, two monorail stations and a few arterial roads. The BMC plans to put up a foldable track near Mahim creek area.

Title: Sattari villagers fret as lone KFD test unit shut
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Valpoi: Goa has no facility to diagnose Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) despite the cashew fruiting and harvesting season being just a few months away. This has stoked fear among the people — specially those in the Sattari taluka — who frequent forested areas during the cashew season and run the risk of contracting KFD.

A virology unit set up in 2015 by Manipal University at the Valpoi community health centre (CHC) to diagnose the dreaded disease shut in September last year upon completing its three-year research, state epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said.

The facility, which was headed by virologist Dr G Arunkumar, was instrumental in the early detection of KFD, leading to speedy treatment and fewer deaths. The tests it conducted for KFD and other virus-related diseases were free of cost. Reports were made available within 24 hours, enabling doctors at the CHC to provide prompt treatment.

The absence of such a facility now has people worried. “Cashew season is nearing, and in absence of this virology unit, people will suffer. Who will be responsible if there are any dire consequences? The government should take note of this,” Copardem-Sattari resident Uday Sawant, said.

However, Betodkar said people need not worry. “In case of suspected cases, samples will be sent to Manipal hospital’s laboratory at Dona Paula. An arrangement has been made,” he said.

Thane-Dongurli panch member Nilesh Parwar said a virology centre at Valpoi CHC was a necessity as several people from the Sattari taluka go to the forest during cashew season.

Until last week, no cases of KFD were detected in Goa while in the past, cases were seen as early as in October and November, coinciding with start of the cashew season. Commonly known as monkey fever or ‘makad taap’ in Goa, KFD was first diagnosed in 1957 in the Kyasanur forest of Karnataka’s Shivamogga district.

It spreads through infected ticks and affects both monkeys and humans. The mortality rate among monkeys, however, is higher. The ticks drop off as soon as a monkey dies, making others vulnerable to the disease. A 50-metre area around a monkey carcass is considered to be infected area.

Title: Corpn bldgs to have rainwater harvesting structures soon
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: The city corporation has appointed a technical expert to prepare detailed project report (DPR) to construct rainwater harvesting (RWH) structures at its buildings under the smart cities mission.

The civic body has obtained the in-principal approval to construct the structures at corporation offices, schools and hospitals as part of area-based development (ABD) component of the mission from the smart city board, corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar said.

But during the board meeting in January, where the corporation presented a few models, the board raised objections related to the smart components of the project, said a corporation official. “The board directed the corporation to justify the reasons for proposing it under the mission,” he said.

“Recently, we appointed a technical expert as consultant to prepare DPR by collecting underground water level data in the city to understand how constructing the structures would increase water level,” said the commissioner. “The consultant will also recommend a suitable model with smart components, which could be adopted while constructing the structures.”

Last year, the corporation had directed public to construct RWH structures to collect rainwater that falls on rooftops on or before August 15 and had warned of severe actions on those, who fail to do it before the deadline.

Sravan said that 40% of the buildings in the corporation limit have working RWH structures. “Notices were issued to the owners of 30% buildings, directing them to repair the structures. We have already taken the assessment and are taking measures to ensure that all buildings are equipped,” he added.

Title: Tributes paid to Annadurai
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: DMK and AIADMK men vied with each other to pay tributes to late chief minister C N Annadurai on his memorial day on Monday.

The two parties took out separate processions in the city and paid floral tributes to the late Dravidian stalwart. The AIADMK men led by urban district secretary P R G Arunkumar started the silent march from the party office in Huzur Road towards the Anna Statue on Avinashi Road.

DMK cadres started a procession led by Singanallur MLA N Karthik from V K K Menon Road in Sidhaputhur. Carrying placards bearing the popular quotes of Annadurai, they marched to the Anna Statue in Gandhipuram to mark the 51th memorial day of the leader. TNN

Title: Two held for MRPS activist’s murder
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: Two persons were arrested on Monday for their alleged role in the murder of Ch Pandu (45), a Madiga Reservation Porata Samithi (MRPS) activist near Valigonda on January 30.

Police arrested B Ravinder (32), a truck driver, and N Naresh (33), a tractor driver from Lingarajupalli.

On January 30, Ravinder and Naresh had obtained permission to supply six tractor loads of sand mined from the Musi bed to a villager. “As they had mined 2 tractor loads illegally, Pandu informed the tahsildar and VRO,” Bhongir DCP Narayana Reddy said.

On the same night, Ravinder asked Naresh to come towards Valigonda so that they could confront Pandu. “The duo intercepted Pandu and hit him on the head with a stick. Family members rushed him to hospital where he was declared dead on arrival,” Reddy said. tnn

Title: Goa: 367 govt primary schools shut since 1989
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: As many as 367 government primary schools have shut in Goa since 1989 due to zero or very low enrolment, chief minister Pramod Sawant said in a reply tabled in the House on Monday. Sawant, who holds the education portfolio, further said that another 24 government primary schools are staring at possible closure as they have an enrolment of between zero and five students.

In a bid to prevent this, measures such as renovation of school buildings, provision of trained English teachers and the recent appointment of more Marathi primary school teachers have been taken, the chief minister said.

Low enrolment schools are also single-teacher schools. As per norms of the directorate of education, an additional teacher can be allotted to a government primary school only if it has more than 24 students. The recent Niti Aayog report stated that Goa, along with Arunachal Pradesh and Jharkhand, has the highest percentage of single-teacher schools at 26.6, 19.7 and 16.9 percentage points, respectively.

During the 2019-20 academic year, 108 government primary schools saw enrolment of 10 or fewer students, while in 2018, 15 government primary schools closed down due to low enrolment. Such closures for want of students have seen the number of government primary schools reduce from 921 a decade ago to 753 currently.

Interestingly, while numerous state-run institutions have shut down, privately-managed aided and unaided schools have increased from 325 in 2010-11 to 397 in 2018-19. The state has now stopped issuing permits to new private primary schools to help the government retain control of the primary education sector.

Title: New wetlands definition sees Maharashtra lose 29,000 sites
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

HC has asked district collectors to file affidavits explaining why incorrect information was given

MUMBAI: In 2010, 44,714 wetland sites were identified in Maharashtra. A decade later, their numbers have shrunk to approximately 15,865. The state environment department gave this information in an affidavit filed before the Bombay high court this past week.

The drastic fall in the numbers is on account of change in definition of wetlands under the 2017 Wetland Rules , said D Stalin, conservationist with NGO Vanashakti . In other words, a majority of areas classified as wetlands earlier are no longer identified as thus under the new definition.

The severity of the problem can be gauged from the depletion of wetland sites in one district alone. In Satara district of western Maharashtra, of a total of 7,909 wetland sites, there are only 719 in existence, states the affidavit. The 7,909 sites were identified by the Space Application Centre, Ahmedabad. The ground reality is that there are merely 719 sites in existence, sid Joy Thakur, under secretary, environment department, in his affidavit.

“For four years, the government did nothing despite the high court ordering them to draw up a list in 2013. The loss of wetlands is worrisome, especially in a state that regularly suffers from drought,” alleged Stalin.

The affidavit before the Bombay high court has stated that in 2010 the Wetlands Atlas published by the Space Application Centre had identified 44,714 sites in the state. According to the 2017 rules, 23,055 sites are indicated as per the Wetland Rules of 2017. But an onsite inspection shows there may be approximately 15,865 sites.

The affidavit states 15,189 sites have been visited and verified and that there are no wetlands in Nagpur, Nandurbar and Parbhani.

Subsequently, though, the court was informed there are wetlands in these three districts. The court has now directed the respective district collectors to file an affidavit explaining why incorrect information was provided.

D Stalin, said the state deliberately dragged its feet on identification of wetlands in accordance with the 2010 rules.

Title: Short film on road safety a big hit
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: Moira, a short film on road safety , was screened to an invited audience at SPI Cinemas in Brookefields shopping mall in the city on Monday.

The 40-minute film shows the plight of a youngster, who drove rashly through crowded lanes to catch a movie. He soon meets with an accident and meets Yama, the lord of death, who tells him about drunk driving, overspeeding and even about noise pollution.

Moira is a Greek word meaning fate, said TR Vijayaanand, who wrote and directed it. “I wanted to create a space to discuss about death on a one-to-one basis. I wanted to speak not about the death of an individual, but also about the grieving loved ones. I hope the film will create awareness about road safety rules and a flicker of fear for life,” he said.

The film was shot in Coimbatore and London. The shooting began in 2018. It was a joint initiative of Young Indians and Round Table India 20.

Coimbatore is only second to Chennai when it comes to road accidents, said B Praveen Kumar, chair of Young Indians. “Many of the accidents are a result of ignorance and carelessness,” he said.

The organisers have tied up with Moviebuff to stream Moira on YouTube from Friday.

In a similar event, actor Sivakumar honoured the winners of the short film contest conducted by Uyir – A people's movement against road accidents, at Sri Ramakrishna College of Arts and Science in the city.

The theme of the contest was road safety. Managing trustee of Uyir S Rajasekaran said that 162 entries were received from across the country for the three categories – 30 seconds, one minute and two minutes. The jury selected 10 short films. The winner received Rs 20,000 along with a shield.

Title: Extremist groups like SDPI trying to create unrest: CM
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan , on Monday, said that there are attempts to create religious hatred in the society in the name of agitation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). While replying to the allegations of the opposition in the assembly that innocent people are being arrested for attending CAA agitations, the chief minister said that the SDPI activists were involved in violence in the name of agitations.

“The government has not taken any case against those who were peacefully agitating against CAA. But cases have been registered against those who purposefully created violence in the name of the agitations,” said the chief minister.

He reiterated that SDPI tried to create violence in a few parts of the state in the guise of anti-CAA agitations. The government will not allow anyone to destabilise the communal harmony in the state. Any attempt to create religious hatred will be seriously dealt with, he added.

Roji M John of the Congress raised the allegation that police booked people involved in agitations against CAA in his constituency. He said that over 200 people from the mahallu committee of Angamaly have been booked though they were protesting peacefully. “Cases have been registered against them for obstructing traffic,” said Roji.

To this, the chief minister said that mahallu committees have been organizing protests in several parts of the state and in almost all places the agitations have been peaceful. “However, in a few areas, certain fundamental elements had intruded into the agitation and purposefully created violence. It has been found that SDPI activists were behind this. The police will not allow such radical elements to create trouble,” the chief minister reiterated.

“No one will be allowed to create trouble in the state and attempts to create religious hatred are being seriously looked into,” said Vijayan. He also criticized the opposition for taking up SDPI’s cause. “Why are they upset when I speak about SDPI?” he repeatedly asked, gesturing towards at the opposition benches.

However, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala charged that the state government is adopting the same policy of the BJP government by taking action against those agitating against CAA. “The police in Uttar Pradesh are taking action against the agitators. Why should we have the same policy? Is the state government adopting the policy of Amit Shah?” asked Chennithala.

Title: Eco clubs to be set up in govt schools
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: Soon, all government schools in the state will have youth and eco clubs.

In a recent communication, the state project directorate of Samagra Shiksha directed all the 37,358 government schools in the state to form the club. “The motive of the club is to educate students on environment and ecosystems and make them aware of ways to protect the environment, so that they would create a clean and green environment,” the communication said.

It said the clubs should be started in all the 24,250 elementary schools, 7,043 middle schools and 6,065 high and higher secondary schools. While each elementary school would receive Rs 5,000 for the club, middle school would get Rs 15,000 and high and higher secondary, Rs 25,000. A total fund of Rs 37.84 crore has been allocated for the purpose, said the communication

In elementary and middle schools, the clubs should be run by five-student teams, and in high and higher secondary schools, they should be run by 15-student teams. Interested teachers should take turns to coordinate the club functions.

The clubs will have three sections: The literary section, which would conduct essay, elocution and poetry writing competitions; the arts and culture section, which would conduct music, dance and drama events and also plant and preserve gardens in the school campus; and the awareness section, which would conduct awareness campaigns in and around the school.

A Samagra Shiksha official said while several schools already have the clubs installed, following the direction, all schools should ensure the clubs are functional. “The fund is meant to buy gardening equipment and set up gardens on the school campus. The clubs would also conduct talks on environment and observe Environmental Day,” the official said.

Title: Bengaluru: Techie in debt kills her mom, stabs brother
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representtaive image

BENGALURU: Saddled with Rs 15-lakh debt, a 33-year-old software engineer allegedly bludgeoned her mother to death with a digging bar and tried to kill her younger brother before fleeing from her house in Ramamurthynagar, KR Puram, on Sunday.

C Nirmala, 54, died instantly after her daughter C Amruta hacked her in the bedroom around 5am, police said. Amruta then allegedly entered her younger brother, C Harish’s room and stabbed him in the neck using a kitchen knife.

“I was sleeping when she barged in. When I asked her why she was doing this, Amruta said she owed Rs 15 lakh and debtors would defame the family. She said it was better to die than live like this,” Harish, 31, told police.

He tried to grab Amruta but in vain. She ran away and Harish called his aunt Sudha who lived nearby. “Sudha shifted Harish to hospital and saved his life,” a police officer said. Harish works as an engineer in a private company, while Amruta was employed with a firm in Mahadevapura. The siblings were not married and lost their father long ago.

Title: Modi’s rally a shot in the arm for BJP cadres seeking to end 21-year exile
Content:
BJP supporters during Prime Minister Narendra Modi's election campaign rally for the Delhi Assembly polls, at ... Read More

NEW DELHI: The maiden election rally of Prime Minister Narendra Modi at CBD Grounds at Karkardooma in east Delhi on Monday worked as a confidence boosting measure for BJP cadres in their aggressive attempt to defeat AAP and end the party’s 21-year exile from power in Delhi.The ground was overflowing with people as BJP candidates from all 20 assembly constituencies from East and North East Lok Sabha seats gathered to make an appearance alongside PM Modi.A group of women wearing saffron turbans sitting in the front rows worked as cheerleaders. “Delhi is voting to strengthen the hands of Narendra Modi. The election is an opportunity to reinforce nationalist forces,” said Kusum Rawat, a BJP functionary.“Bharat Mata Ki Jai” and “Jai Shri Ram” were a few slogans that rippled through the crowd holding BJP flags. BJP functionary Vijay Goel made the crowd chant “Rashtravaad jeetega, Shaheen Bagh harega”.Speaking before the PM arrived, Union minister Dr Harsh Vardhan underlined the infrastructure projects carried out by the Centre for the development of the trans-Yamuna region. BJP star campaigner and East Delhi MP Gautam Gambhir called Kejriwal a liar. “AAP asks us the battle is Arvind Kejriwal vs who? I want to say it is Kejriwal vs the truth,” Gambhir said, claiming that the CM had wasted five years.There were huge hoardings with Modi’s photograph in the background displaying the message “Desh Badla, Ab Dilli Badlo”. Many in the crowd wore Modi masks. A man turned up with his body painted red and a huge lotus made of thermocol fixed on his head. The absence of home minister Amit Shah ’s photo from the hoardings left many BJP workers impressed with the democracy in the party. “It happens only in BJP. Now that JP Nadda is the party chief, his photos have replaced Shah’s,” said Anand Singh, a resident of Vishwas Nagar.References to Shaheen Bagh by the speakers drew a passionate response from the crowd, which off and on chanted Jai Shri Ram. Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari termed the polls a battle between those who want to make the capital Shaheen Bagh and those who want to make it Shanti Bagh

Title: Modi’s rally a shot in the arm for BJP cadres seeking to end 21-year exile
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

BJP supporters during Prime Minister Narendra Modi's election campaign rally for the Delhi Assembly polls, at ... Read More

NEW DELHI: The maiden election rally of Prime Minister Narendra Modi at CBD Grounds at Karkardooma in east Delhi on Monday worked as a confidence boosting measure for BJP cadres in their aggressive attempt to defeat AAP and end the party’s 21-year exile from power in Delhi.

The ground was overflowing with people as BJP candidates from all 20 assembly constituencies from East and North East Lok Sabha seats gathered to make an appearance alongside PM Modi.

A group of women wearing saffron turbans sitting in the front rows worked as cheerleaders. “Delhi is voting to strengthen the hands of Narendra Modi. The election is an opportunity to reinforce nationalist forces,” said Kusum Rawat, a BJP functionary.

“Bharat Mata Ki Jai” and “Jai Shri Ram” were a few slogans that rippled through the crowd holding BJP flags. BJP functionary Vijay Goel made the crowd chant “Rashtravaad jeetega, Shaheen Bagh harega”.

Speaking before the PM arrived, Union minister Dr Harsh Vardhan underlined the infrastructure projects carried out by the Centre for the development of the trans-Yamuna region. BJP star campaigner and East Delhi MP Gautam Gambhir called Kejriwal a liar. “AAP asks us the battle is Arvind Kejriwal vs who? I want to say it is Kejriwal vs the truth,” Gambhir said, claiming that the CM had wasted five years.

There were huge hoardings with Modi’s photograph in the background displaying the message “Desh Badla, Ab Dilli Badlo”. Many in the crowd wore Modi masks. A man turned up with his body painted red and a huge lotus made of thermocol fixed on his head. The absence of home minister Amit Shah ’s photo from the hoardings left many BJP workers impressed with the democracy in the party. “It happens only in BJP. Now that JP Nadda is the party chief, his photos have replaced Shah’s,” said Anand Singh, a resident of Vishwas Nagar.

References to Shaheen Bagh by the speakers drew a passionate response from the crowd, which off and on chanted Jai Shri Ram. Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari termed the polls a battle between those who want to make the capital Shaheen Bagh and those who want to make it Shanti Bagh .

Title: Man arrested for suspicious movement in Old City
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: Tension prevailed in Bilal Nagar under Kalapather police station limits in Old City on Sunday night after a few locals caught a person moving suspiciously in the area. The person was identified as 23-year-old B Gopalakrishna.

The locals caught Gopalakrishna and upon questioning he said that he was conducting a GPS survey in the area on behalf of Google. However, he could not produce a valid identity card and the people handed him over to the police patrolling team.

“With tensions mouting due to CAA, his movements and appearance were found to be suspicious and he was handed over to the police for further investigation” said Sikanderullah Khan, a local social worker.

Meanwhile, Gopalakrishna could not give a satisfactory reply nor could he produce documents to the police. “We have received a complaint that Gopalakrishna was creating nuisance by roaming in the area. A case has been registered against him,” said SHO of Kalapather, S Sudarshan. tnn

Title: Man tries to set himself on fire
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: The collectorate on Monday witnessed tense moments after a 35-year-old man tried to set himself on fire.

The man was identified as R Vinodh of Neelikonampalayam in Singanallur in the city. Grievance day meet was in progress at the collectorate on Monday morning, when Vinodh came in an autorickshaw along with his seven-year-old son and three-year-old daughter. He got out of the vehicle, ran into the collectorate premises, doused himself with kerosene and tried to immolate himself.

Police personnel stationed at the spot thwarted his attempt, poured water over him and took him and his children to the Race Course police station.

In a letter, Vinodh said that his family had been cheating him. “I also suffered loss in business and am burdened with debt,” he said.

Title: ‘Produce Bhagat in handcuffs for trial’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Colva: Additional sessions judge Dvijpla Patkar on Monday ordered that Vikat Bhagat, an accused who is facing trial for allegedly raping and murdering a 28-year-old foreign national, be produced in the court for trial in handcuffs.

The court had earlier ordered that Bhagat should be produced during the trial through video conferencing. However, a couple of times the accused refused to attend the hearing via video conferencing.

After hearing the prosecution and the accused on the application for hand-cuffing, the judge ordered that Bhagat henceforth be brought for trial in handcuffs.

Bhagat is accused of befriending the foreign national, on October 13, 2017, taking her to an open isolated field in Canacona taluka and allegedly raping and assaulting her with glass bottle on her head and face, and then murdering her by compressing her neck. He has also been accused of robbing her cellphone and also destroying evidence.

In December, 2018, a police sub-inspector from the escort cell, PSI Uday Umarye, had filed an application seeking the court’s order to handcuff the accused.

The PSI had brought it to the notice of the court that the accused does not cooperate with the escort team while being taken to courts and hospitals and keeps arguing.

Title: Karnataka man dies in accident
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: Dhillan Gaonkar, 29, a native of Karwar , Karnataka , died after the car he was driving collided head on with a bus at Barcem in Quepem, early Monday morning.

Police sources said that Gaonkar was proceeding from Verna towards Karwar while the bus was headed towards Margao.

“Gaonkar, who works at the Verna industrial estate, was travelling to his native place to visit his mother,” police sources said, adding that there was no other occupant in the car

Gaonkar’s body was handed over to his relatives after conducting post mortem examination.

Cuncolim police are conducting further investigation.

Title: CISF seizes 1.5 kg gold at airport
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Hyderabad: Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) sleuths seized 1.5 kg of gold at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) on Sunday that was concealed in an abandoned bag.

CISF sleuths observed the unattended bag through CCTV surveillance at the international arrival belt no. 5 at 7.30 am following which bomb detection and disposal squad rushed to the spot and checked it. No explosives were detected during checking and when subjected to physical check, a customised motor was found in the bag. As the motor weighed more than it should, CISF sleuths informed customs department and scanned it.

They opened the motor and found 1.5 kg of gold bars painted black. The seized material was handed over to customs sleuths for probe. tnn

Title: Dog bites kid, owner arrested
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bhopal: A one-and-half year old boy was attacked by his neighbour’s dog in TT Nagar locality on Saturday afternoon. The boy sustained injuries on his right cheek and is undergoing treatment at a hospital.

Family member of the injured child approached TT Nagar police station and lodged a complaint against the dog owner. Acting on the complaint, TT Nagar police registered a case under section of 289 (negligent conduct with respect to animal) of the IPC and have arrested the dog owner.

Investigating officer ASI R K Gautam said that the injured child — Virat Singh resides with his family at Arjun Nagar-Phase 2 in TT Nagar. His father, Brijendra Singh, is a driver and mother a house wife.

On Saturday around 4.30pm, Virat was playing near their house when the accused Jaswant Kamle, 35, who resides in her neighborhood and works as a driver, came out of his house with his pet dog. The unchained pet dog suddenly attacked the kid. The kid’s mother managed to save her child from the dog and rushed him to a nearby hospital where he is in undergoing treatment. Later, she informed her husband who approached police to lodge a complaint.

The ASI said that local residents alleged that the same dog has attacked three to five people in the past too, but the victims did not approach police station to file complaint.

Title: Cancer is preventable, curable: Early detection is key
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: India has nearly 25 lakh cancer patients as per data available for 2018-19. During the year, 11,57,294 new patients were registered while there were 7,84,821 cancer related deaths. Of them, cancers of oral cavity and lungs in males and cervix and breast in females accounted for over 50% of deaths.

Breast cancer accounted for 27% cancers in women and led to 70,218 deaths.

In Maharashtra there are 1,32,726 cancer cases while 60,735 death were registered as per recent data.

World Cancer Day aims to save millions by creating awareness and education about cancer, and seeks action against the disease from governments and individuals across the world.

The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) estimates that India will have over 17.3 lakh new cases of cancer and there will be over 8.8 lakh deaths due to the disease in 2020, with cancers of breast, lung and cervix topping the list.

How to prevent cancer

Quit tobacco | Using any type of tobacco puts you on a collision course with cancer

Healthy food | Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables and foods from plant sources such as whole grains. Minimize intake of high-calorie foods, refined sugars etc

Eat right | Antioxidants, garlic and vitamin-D rich foods are supposed to safeguard against cancer

Limit processed meats | Eating large amounts of processed meat can increase the risk of cancer

Be physically active | Maintaining a healthy weight might lower the risk of various types of cancer

Protect from sunlight | Skin cancer is one of the most common cancers but preventable

Get vaccinated | Cancer prevention includes protection from certain viral infections like Hepatitis B, human papillomavirus (HPV)

Practice safe sex | Limit your number of sexual partners and use a condom

Screening is secondary prevention

Breast cancer | Mammography

Cervical cancer | Pap smears

Prostate cancer | Blood PSA levels

Oral cancer | Regular dental care

Colon cancer | Stool for blood and serum CEA

QUOTES

Over the years, prognosis of many cancers has improved significantly. Cancers of breast, prostate, thyroid, leukaemia, and lymphoma can be completely cured in more than 80% of cases. But in India, only 20% of patients can be cured as remaining 80% report to hospitals in advanced stage

Dr GK Rath | Head, National Cancer Institute

I request all of you to stand beside those who have lost their loved ones due to cancer. Let us pledge to raise awareness about this disease so we can together prevent, diagnose, treat and beat cancer

Dr Sushil Mandhaniya | Medical Oncologist

If detected at early stage, we can treat and cure breast cancer completely. Unfortunately, women neglect early symptoms. When detected with cancer, they feel as if it’s all over. In fact, we can conquer this disease with confidence, proper treatment and self-belief

Madhuri Tijare | Director of Samarth breast cancer support group

Cancer if treated early is curable. We can definitely channelize our efforts at all levels towards fighting this grotesque disease and in turn drastically reduce the mortality and morbidity. Let us join hands and work towards creating awareness

Dr Abhinav Deshpande | Surgical Oncologist, NCI

Title: Man held for filmingneighbour having bath
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bengaluru: A 33-year-old manager of a garment factory was arrested for allegedly secretly filming a 29-year-old woman with his mobile phone when she was having bath in her flat in Mahadevapura .

The accused, Safin Ali, a resident of Mahadevapura, was woman’s neighbour.

Police said the woman noticed someone secretly filming her through the window of her bathroom in her flat on Saturday morning. As she raised an alarm, the suspect fled. She complained to the manager of the apartment complex , and they verified CCTV footages and zeroed in on Ali.

The woman then complained to the Mahadevapura police, who rushed to the spot and arrested Ali.

“We produced Ali before the court, which remanded him in judicial custody. We have seized his mobile phone for further investigation,” a police officer said.

Title: 1 woman dies of cancer every 10 minutes: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Every 10 minutes, a woman succumbs to breast cancer in India and over 60% of the cases are detected in advanced stages, say experts.

Data by the state health authorities reveal that incidences of cervical and breast cancer are the highest in Telangana, followed by head and neck cancers. In 2018, 45,713 cases of cancer were reported in the state and the numbers have been going up every year by 4,000-5,000.

Experts point out that pollution and absence of screening protocol are pushing up the number of cases.

“Over 60% of breast cancers are detected in the advanced stage due to lack of awareness and organised nationwide breast cancer screening programme. In India, 1,50,000 new cases of breast cancer are reported every year of which 70,000 succumb to the disease,” said Dr P Raghu Ram, director of Kims-Ushalakshmi Centre for Breast Diseases and president of Association of Breast Surgeons of India.

“Consumption of tobacco is a major factor contributing to the rise in oral cancers and lack of vaccination leads to cervical cancers and sedentary lifestyle and obesity has caused more breast cancers,” said Dr Chinnababu Sunkavalli, robotic surgical oncologist at Apollo Cancer Institute .

Title: Rs 75cr for facilities at Medaram Jatara
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Medaram: With just a day to go for Sammakka Saralamma Jatara in Medaram , the state government has released Rs 75 crore to create permanent and temporary amenities in the village. About 20 lakh pilgrims have been already been offering prayers since the past month.

The Jatara will begin on February 5 and end on February 8. On the first day of the festival, the idol of goddess Saralamma, daughter of Sammakka, is taken to the ‘Medaram Gaddhe’ or platform from Kannepalli. Day 2 of the festival sees the arrival of Sammakka on to the ‘Medaram Gaddhe’. Police and district collector honour Sammakka by opening a few rounds of fire in the air. On February 7 and 8, mother and daughter are available for darshan to devotees. Lakhs of pilgrims offer jaggery to the deities.

In the evening on February 8, priests take back the goddesses to the forest (known as vana pravesham), which signals the end of the Jatara.

State government is expecting around 1.5 crore pilgrims this time. A 100-bed temporary hospital has been set up at the venue.

Title: ‘Monkeys, peacocks devour agri produce’
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Margao: Monkeys and peacocks have turned out to be a nuisance for farmers as they devour horticulture produce from orchards and gardens, chief minister Pramod Sawant told the state legislative assembly on Monday. He also said that various steps were being taken by the agriculture department to control the menace.

In a reply to a question posed by Congress Curtorim MLA Aleixo Lourenco Reginaldo, Sawant admitted that locals have complained about monkeys and peacocks having destroyed their horticulture crops, and said that the agriculture department deals with the compensation for crop damage.

Speaking about the measures taken by the forest department, Sawant, in a written reply tabled in the House, said, “Fruit-bearing forest species are being planted in forest areas and other lands available for plantations. Water holes are also maintained inside forest areas for the use of wild animals.”

Damages caused by wildlife to agricultural crops are compensated under Shetkari Aadhar Nidhi Scheme of the directorate of agriculture, Sawant added in his reply.

Title: Disabled people complain about dilapidated roads
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Coimbatore: The disabled people living in and around Samathurpuram are finding it difficult to use the local roads, which have been so deteriorated that two town buses have stopped plying through the area.

As a result, they find it difficult to travel to the ration shop and offices to collect pension, the people, who sought the help of the collector on Monday, said.

The complainants said that roads from Samathurpuram to Kalaignar Nagar and Annanagar were taken up for relaying by the Chettipalayam town panchayat last December. “They dug up the road and started the work but abandoned it for reasons not known. Now, the road is full of dust and gravel,” said R K Rangasamy, a petitioner. “The road is in a worse condition.”

As many as 30 disabled people stay in the area, including people with visual impairment. “We have to travel 5km to Kalaignar Nagar to access a ration shop and travel all the way to the Chettipalayam panchayat office to collect our pension. Without buses, we are paying Rs 100 to hire autorickshaws, which we can’t afford and as a result, are struggling,” stated the petition.

“Being disabled, we can’t even walk on these roads, which are full of large gravel stones, for the fear of it knocking us down or making us trip and fall,” said Rangasamy.

The petitioners urged the collector to instruct the town panchayat complete the road work.

Title: Jharkhand education minister visits Deoghar school, finds teachers’ performance lacking
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Bokaro: School education and literacy mission department minister Jagarnath Mahto on Monday made a surprise inspection of a government middle school in Devipur area of Deoghar district and found performance of the schoolteachers unsatisfactory.

Mahto, who took charge as minister on Friday, made a stopover to the school while returning from the Baba Baidyanathdham temple. Soon after taking charge of the ministry, he is on a school-touring spree to take stock of the ground realities.

While visiting the school in Deoghar, Mahto sat along with the students on the floor and asked them to take turns in writing what they have learnt so far. Teachers and education department officials present at the school were left red-faced when many of the students failed to write simple Hindi alphabets.

“Obviously, the teachers are not performing up to the mark,” the minister remarked.

Mahto had also made surprise inspections in two schools of Giridih district earlier. At a school in Bengabad area of Giridih, he asked the students to don the role of teachers while he sat on the floor with the others to test their knowledge. On Saraswati Puja, he visited an upgraded high school in Chitardih under Jamua block of the same district after a video clip of a teacher in an inebriated state surfaced. He summoned the education department officials and presented a rose to the teacher before everyone and asked him to mend his ways. He later transferred the teacher and said, “Such acts will not be tolerated. What will students learn from him?”

Talking to reporters, Mahto said he will continue his tours to assess the quality of teaching as well as other aspects of the education system to take corrective steps. He said, “Improving teaching standards at government schools is in my priority list.”

Title: What is the right vaccination for swine flu?
Content: Swine flu (also known as the H1N1) is a respiratory condition which is highly infectious and can spread very quickly from one person to another. While it was earlier only detected in people with regular exposure to pigs (hence the name), it now primarily spreads from person to person.Like many other strains of flu, swine flu is extremely contagious and can spread through air droplets produced by sneezing, coughing and even by touching infected areas where droplets have recently landed, including desks, utensils and tabletops. This is why the best means to prevent this deadly flu is to get vaccinated.Infact, people with a compromised immune system, pregnant women, elderlies and those suffering from chronic health conditions are more susceptible to falling prey to swine flu. Even though the symptoms of H1N1 closely mimic the usual influenza infections (including cold, cough, high fever, body ache, running nose, sore throat etc.), some people may require hospitalization.Although the symptoms of swine flu are usually mild, pregnant women, very young children, elderlies and those with a weak immune system are more likely to be seriously ill with swine flu. Hence, even though everyone should make it a point to get swine flu vaccinations, the priority groups which are more at risk of catching this infection should get vaccinated without fail.Vaccines have been developed to protect against the virus that causes swine flu. According to Dr Sushant Chhabra, HOD Emergency Medicine, Manipal Hospital, one should get the seasonal flu vaccine as it keeps getting updated every year to protect against new strains of viruses. The flu vaccination available in the market has four inactive strains and is known as the quadrivalent flu vaccine.0.25 millilitres0.5 millilitresThe swine flu vaccination is ideally taken once in a year and its immunity period is usually between 6 months to one year.Some of the most common side-effects of a swine flu vaccine include allergic reaction, fever and redness and pain at the site of injection. Some people may also experience tiredness, headaches and muscle ache after getting the flu shot.Keep in mind that if you had a severe allergic reaction to the previous dose of vaccine, it is important that you inform your medical care provider about the same.

Title: Only 20k got 100-day work under NREGA in Jharkhand
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Ranchi: Only 20,000 families — out of the 26.23 lakh active MNREGA (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act) card holders in the state — have got 100 days of work at a stretch in the current fiscal year, according to a study by civil society outfit NREGA Watch.

Stressing that the centrally-sponsored scheme for rural income generation is failing in Jharkhand, the study claimed that in the 2015-16 fiscal year, 1.74 lakh got 100 days of work. Since then, the study said there has been a steep decline every year at a time when Jharkhand is reeling under rural and farm distress, the study said.

Convenor of NREGA Watch (Jharkhand) Jamesh Herenj said there’s a lack of interest among the rural people in taking up MNREGA jobs owing to the non-timely payment of dues and the poor wages. “Since December 24 last year, payments worth Rs 83 crore are pending under MNREGA due to the non-allocation of funds and the liability only increases with time. In Jharkhand, a worker gets Rs 171 per day, which is lower than the amount a worker gets in non-MNREGA schemes, which is about Rs 257.29 per day,” Herenj added.

“One of the reasons behind the steep fall in job seekers is because of job diversification. Rural jobs comprise a whole range of works, right from digging wells to ponds, constructing roads, among others, as laid down by the gram sabhas. However, in Jharkhand, the former state government ignored the gram sabhas’ advice. For instance, in the last six months, the only work which took place in the state was TCB (trench cum bunds) creations. Before that, works like building toilets or rural houses were alloted at places where there was no demand,” he said.

Title: Drone aid helps cops destroy poppy crops in Jharkhand
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

RANCHI: Acting on tip-offs from multiple sources, including the Narcotics Control Bureau, police used drones to verify the inputs and destroyed illegal cultivation of poppy crop in 320 acres of land spread across remote areas of the state within two months of the season.

In view of the current growing season of the crop, police are carrying out regular drives almost on a daily basis in the districts, including Ranchi and Khunti, known for growing the illegal crop. According to Criminal Investigation Department (CID) figures, poppy plants on about 320 acres of land have been destroyed in various parts of the state during the last two months with the maximum destruction of crops in Chatra district , where 272 acres of the crop were destroyed. Over 50 acres were also destroyed in Khunti while the crop in three acres was destroyed in Ranchi district . In the previous cultivation season, the state police had destroyed standing popply crop on over 1800 acres of land.

Ranchi SP (rural) Rishab Jha said, “We are using drones for tracking the crops, which are usually grown in remote and inaccessible areas. Use of drones is saving us a lot of time and manpower as it can fly for about an hour and up to a distance of 15km.”

Khunti SP Ashutosh Shekhar said, “Opium cultivation is concentrated in several police station areas, including Arki, Murhu, Saiko, Maranghada. A concerted drive is going on to destroy the crops. Locals are giving us maximum inputs.”

Notably, the CID has stressed on nabbing the kingpins involved in promoting cultivation and trade of opium. “We need to work on the big players with inter-state connections. As of now, they are not caught in large numbers,” CID ADG Anurag Gupta said.
