Title: Bright minds pitch ideas, show future vision
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: On Sunday evening, Nagpur witnessed the grand finale of a countrywide highly competitive startup contest organized by Vidarbha Industries Association and Lemon Ideas. The 5th edition of Innopreneurs Startup Contest saw the country’s brightest enterprising minds pitch their ideas and talk about a vision for the future.

Chief guest of the event, Union minister Nitin Gadkari, said, “Our country needs more eco-friendly ideas and it is a good thing that it is happening in India. Conversion of knowledge into wealth and conversion of wealth into good green projects has been coming true in recent years.”

Since the last five years, Lemon Ideas, headed by Deepak Menaria, has been organizing the contest for new entrepreneurs and startup firms in which they explain and present their ideas in front of the juries and investors, giving them a chance to bring their concepts in public view. At the event on Sunday, Dinah Grace Akello, ambassador of Uganda, was also present.

In this year’s contest, over 60 teams presented their ideas and projects in which some teams were from foreign countries. Seven teams were finalized for the finale, out of which three teams won in two runner-ups and one winner pattern.

Most of the teams had eco-friendly concepts, which would help in betterment of the environment. Gadkari appreciated all the teams and encouraged them for their efforts. He promised to help their projects in all ways possible. He said, “We will have to face many challenges but for the betterment of the society and environment, we should keep thinking and making such green projects”.

He also talked about many of his eco-friendly ideas which have been implemented across the country.

Of the seven finalist teams, The Last Ripple, Courier Wala, Vision Empower and Imature got the consolation prizes. The Green Road and Re-Bell were the first and second runner-ups who got Rs60,000 and Rs 40,000 cash prize respectively. The winner of the contest was Cortex Technologies which got Rs1l lakh cash prize.

Talking with TOI, Cortex Technologies founder Siddhant Dangi, still a student of BITS Pilani, said that they are planning to merge with hospitals across the country for their project. Their project prototypes are mind-controlled bionic arms and other body parts for the disabled or paralyzed people.

Gadkari too showed his enthusiasm and interest in new innovations, as surprisingly he ate a prototype made by OECO Initiatives. The product was a replacement for plastic water bottle, in which water can be contained and after finishing the water, the bottle can be eaten also. Rituraj Giri, founder of OECO, got the prize for youngest entrepreneur.

Rikesh Gurung from Timphu ,Bhutan, the 1st runner-up, presented his innovative idea of green road made up of plastic waste inspired from Indian science. This technology of using plastic waste as one of the components as a mix to black top roads helps in waste management and giving durable roads, which will be in best condition till almost 8 years.

Title: Isro starts process for YUVIKA-2 student training in space activities
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Isro chief K Sivan

NEW DELHI: Indian Space Research Organisation (Isro) on Monday started the online process for applications for the second session of ‘YUva VIgyani KAryakram’ scheduled to be held in May.

The programme, scheduled from May 11 to 22, is aimed at imparting basic knowledge on space technology, space science and space applications to the younger generation with the intent of arousing their interest in emerging areas of space activities. Three students each from each state/UT will be selected to participate in the programme, which will include students’ visit to Isro facilities and labs, exclusive sessions for discussion with space experts, practical and feedback sessions.

The online registration will be open from February 3 to 24. Those who have finished VIII standard and currently studying in Class IX (2019-20) will be eligible for the programme. Even Overseas Citizen of India students can apply for it. The selection is based on the Class VIII academic performance and extracurricular activities.

Students will get an opportunity to go to Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre in Thiruvananthapuram, which specialises in rocket technology and U R Rao Satellite Centre, Bangalore, where satellites are developed. They will also be taken to the Sriharikota launch centre.

Besides YUVIKA, Isro is also working on setting up six incubation centres and the same number of R&D centres across the country. Isro chief K Sivan had told TOI, “These incubation and R&D centres will give a platform to young minds to use their talent in the field of space research and technology.”

Title: Ahmedabad may be Trump’s first port of call during February visit
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

NEW DELHI: As preparations pick up for US President Donald Trump ’s visit later this month, it is learnt that he is likely to land in Ahmedabad on February 23 where, apart from visiting Gandhi’s Sabarmati Ashram , he may address a town hall-like event.

The event is likely to include Prime Minister Narendra Modi as well, and might be even bigger than the ‘Howdy Modi’ function in Houston last year. The US advance team to finalise preparations are expected to arrive this week.

Trump is likely to come to Delhi that evening, beginning his official visit on February 24. It is unclear whether he will come with wife Melania or daughter Ivanka, who has already visited India, representing her father at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit in Hyderabad in 2017.

After his official engagements, which include talks with Modi and a banquet at Rashtrapati Bhavan among others, Trump may make a short trip to Agra to see the Taj Mahal.

The visit will be Trump’s first to India as president, and has acquired significance since he will be coming just after a bruising impeachment trial and in an election year. The US and India are expected to conclude a limited trade deal during Trump’s visit that has been in negotiations for the past few months.

Title: Allow permit rooms in Tadoba resorts: Min
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Chandrapur: In a bid to maintain Tadoba’s competitive edge in attracting more tourists, state’s relief and rehabilitation minister Vijay Wadettiwar on Monday demanded issuing liquor permits to resorts in the tiger reserve.

“Tourists from across the world come to Vidarbha for tiger tourism. While Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) is a popular tourist destination, tigers are also being sighted in nearby Pench reserve, Bor and Umred-Karhandla tiger sanctuaries. However, when it comes to facilities available for tourists, Tadoba lags behind in terms of availability of liquor,” said Wadettiwar, who is also guardian minister of Chandrapur.

“Due to liquor ban in the district, the possibility of tourists opting for tiger sanctuaries other than those in Chandrapur cannot be ruled out,” he said expressing his resolve to take up this matter with the state government.

The minister also pointed out that though liquor is banned in entire Gujarat state, it is made available under special provisions to tourists there. Similar relaxation can be given to resorts in Tadoba to run permit rooms, he said.

Wadettiwar also formally announced a nine-member committee instituted to analyse the outcome of liquor ban in Chandrapur. The committee comprises SP, ZP CEO, superintendent of excise department, prohibition experts and members of social organization. District collector would head the panel.

The panel will analyse facts on nine parameters related to prohibition and would submit its report within a month, he said. “After receiving the report, I will take up the issue in the state cabinet,” said Wadettiwar.

Wadettiwar also demanded survey of the tree plantation carried out in the state last year in which then forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar has claimed to have planted over 33 crore saplings.

The minister said he has written to forest minister Sanjay Rathod seeking survey of the plantation carried out by forest department and other agencies last year. “If lapses are found, inquiry should be set up and action should be taken against guilty,” said Wadettiwar.

The 33 crore tree plantation drive was the dream project of former forest minister Sudhir Mungantiwar.

“Recently, Kamal Nath-led Congress government in Madhya Pradesh had carried out similar survey and found that only 17 lakh saplings out of the 7 crore plantations claimed by the BJP government have survived. All I want to check is how many of the trees were actually planted in Maharashtra, how many of them survived and what is the survival rate in the drive led by Mungantiwar,” said Wadettiwar. He also maintained that if the plantation drive turns out to be eyewash and major lapses comes to fore, then inquiry must be set up.

Title: Environment lovers come together for cleaning drive
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Nagpur: Environment enthusiasts teamed up on World Wetlands Day at Ambazari Biodiversity Park, Hingna, for a cleaning drive organized by the social forestry division and forest division on Sunday.

Nearly 200 volunteers participated in the campaign and started with the cleaning process at 8am. A truckload of litter was collected by them from Nag River and the Ambazari backwater areas. They were awarded with certificates of participation for their conscious efforts.

Speaking about the drive, divisional forest officer (DFO), social forestry, Geeta Nannaware said, “We celebrate this day every year. This time around, we decided to step out for a hands-on experience in sanitation. We were elated to see a great response from kids who tagged along with their families to display awareness.”

“Voluntary participation on a weekend is a sign that people are aware of the importance of this day. Ambazari is the heart of the city and the wetlands should be spic and span,” she said.

Nannaware said that around 20-25 garbage bags were piled up from the area.

Present at the drive were chief conservator of forest, Nagpur circle, Kalyan Kumar, deputy conservator of forests Prabhunath Shukla, divisional forest officer Deepali Talmale and assistant conservator of forest Rajan Talmale among others.

With fishing activities on the rise, several thermocol blocks were found at the site since it is used by fishermen to keep the nets afloat. Along with polluting the water bodies, thermocol is an extremely harmful substance for the aquatic life.

Kumar said it is a cause of concern that thermocol was collected in heaps.

Asked about finding an alternative to the hazardous effects of thermocol, he said, “It is not the domain of the forest department. We need to take technical advice from the fisheries department to come up with a sustainable measure so that aquatic life is not under any threat.”

Title: German House team meets Bengal speaker
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

KOLKATA: A 10-member delegation from German Federal Parliament (Bundestag) met West Bengal Speaker Biman Banerjee on Monday.

In an hour-long discussion with a number of state cabinet ministers, the visitors expressed interest in further cooperation and investment in a number of sectors.

“We have been apprised of the functioning of various government departments and we will take the deliberations forward and hope to invest in several sectors like health, education and renewable energy,” said Jurgen Hardt , member of German parliament and head of the visiting team.

“Both India and Germany are democratic countries and this sort of interaction will strengthen the bonding between the two countries,” Speaker Banerjee said.

The event was organised by Indo-German Parliamentary Association under ‘Agenda for the Indo-German Partnership in the 21st Century’.

Title: On track: First phase of East-West Metro to roll out on February 13
Content:
Kolkata’s biggest infrastructure project in several decades will operate on a truncated route of 5km, between ... Read More

Tailwind for project after new Metro GM’s visit in January

KOLKATA: India’s oldest ‘ Metro city ’ is set to get its second line, 35 years after the first opened, as the East-West Metro opens its doors on February 13, almost 12 years after it was sanctioned.For now, Kolkata’s biggest infrastructure project in several decades will operate on a truncated route of 5km, between Sector V and the Salt Lake stadium. The completed 16.5km corridor, when it opens, will connect Kolkata with its twin, Howrah, under the Hooghly, making it the country’s first underwater rapid transit system.The section that will be operational is an elevated stretch, consisting of six stations: Sector V, Karunamoyee, Central Park, City Centre, Bengal Chemical and Salt Lake Stadium.Commuters who avail themselves of the East-West Metro will get to travel in futuristic rakes that are capable to attaining speeds of 80kmph, completing the end-to-end trip in nine to 13 minutes. Three trains will be used at 20-minute intervals; they will halt for 20 seconds at each station. According to sources, in about three months, the service shall be extended to Phoolbagan, where the underground station has been built and the tunnel dug up to Sealdah.Railway minister Piyush Goyal is scheduled to flag off the route in a ceremony at the Sector V station on February 13, where CM Mamata Banerjee has been invited, said Union minister for state, Babul Supriyo. “I am happy to announce that the East-West Metro will be launched on February 13. The railway ministry will follow protocol; we don’t want politics. I had personally invited the CM for the inauguration. I have had PM Modiji’s permission to execute the project with the state government’s cooperation. Glad that has happened,” Supriyo said. Passenger services should commence soon after the inauguration.The Rs 8,575-crore project has suffered from several hiccups, the largest setback being the tunnelling disaster on August 31 last year, where one of the two tunnel-boring machines hit an aquifer, causing subsidence in Bowbazar and the collapse of several buildings. Around 700 residents were evacuated and put up in hotels. The last seven residents moved out of hotels to rented flats only last Saturday. Only 354 have so far managed to return to their own homes after repairs.Had that not happened, the entire stretch — Sector V to Howrah Maidan — would have been operational by end-2021, sources told TOI. The last bit of tunnelling, between Esplanade and Sealdah, has completely ground to a halt because of the subsidence disaster.Construction of the underground section between Phoolbagan and Sealdah has been over for three years now, but the stretch can’t be commissioned until the Esplanade-Sealdah tunnelling is complete. Underground tunnelling between Howrah Maidan and Esplanade, too, has been completed.Before the tunnelling disaster, the project had been mired in a land acquisition logjam, and 365m of the viaduct couldn’t be built at Duttabad, on the EM Bypass, because 80 families refused to shift. The matter was sorted by the chief minister at Supriyo’s request in 2015.While Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC), the special purpose vehicle created to implement the project, is currently engaged in strengthening the ground loosened by the tunnelling fiasco, permission to restart the tunnel-boring machine is pending at Calcutta High Court. The twin tunnels, covering 2.45km, would have been built by December 2020, paving the way for the commissioning of the entire 16.5km stretch in June 2021.For now, Kolkatans can only look forward to boarding hi-tech trains and using the six elevated stations.“That, in itself, is great news, considering the hiccups Phase 1 itself went through,” said an engineer involved in the project.Even as construction got over and everything in place, the Salt Lake section missed multiple deadlines. The Commissioner of Railway Safety, in giving its safety nod last August, had mandated opening the stretch by November 30. On Metro Railway’s request, the commissioner had to extend the validation till February 29. In December, Suneet Sharma, the Eastern Railway GM, officiating as the Metro GM, had formally informed the Railway Board that Phase 1 was ready for immediate launch. Then, the anti-CAA agitations started and no unveiling date was announced for more than a month. Service trials were done all over again. On January 18, Manoj Joshi, soon after taking over as the new Metro Railway GM, did his inspection and wrote to the railway board about the section’s preparedness.“Since July, 2018, we have been watching the standard-gauge six-coach cars puffing in and out of the Central Park depot and waiting impatiently to ride the trains. Thank God the wait is about to end,” said Promita Chatterjee, a 66-year-old resident of Salt Lake’s BE Block.

Title: Rose Valley scam: ED attaches a/cs linked to KKR, St Xavier’s
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Kolkata: The Enforcement Directorate has attached several bank accounts, belonging to Knight Riders Sports Private Limited (owner of the IPL franchisee Kolkata Knight Riders), Multiple Resorts Private Limited and St Xavier’s College, as part of its probe in the Rose Valley scam.

The bank accounts attached on Monday have Rs 16.2 crore in them. The ED, probing the Rs 17,520-crore scam, also attached property worth Rs 53.9 crore, officials said.

The central agency started a probe into the alleged scam after a Securities and Exchange Board of India complaint accused Rose Valley of duping thousands of investors. The ED made its first arrest — that of Rose Valley head Gautam Kundu — in 2015.

There was no response from KKR CEO Venky Mysore to a query from TOI.

St Xavier’s College principal Fr Dominic Savio was unavailable on phone; messages sent to him went unanswered. But a college office-bearer said “all cooperation was being given to the probe”.

“The account was frozen three years ago and what happened on Monday was a procedural formality. We have also told the authorities that we want to return the amount under scanner, kept in this account, following the due legal process,” he added.

The agency initiated the probe against Knight Riders Sports as it had entered into a sponsorship agreement with the Rose Valley Group. The group, officials said, was KKR’s principal sponsor in IPL seasons 5 and 6 (for a total payment of Rs 11.8 crore during 2012 and 2013). The Multiple Resorts account attachment, officials said, was because of a Rose Valley acquisition of a resort (made against a payment of Rs 5 crore). The attachment of the three St Xavier’s College bank accounts was related to “a donation of Rs 96 lakh from Kundu for his son’s admission”, officials added.

Besides the bank accounts, a one-acre plot in New Town, a hotel on VIP Road, 24 acres in Ramnagar and Mahishadal (both in East Midnapore) and a flat in Mumbai were also attached, officials said.

Title: West Bengal assembly’s budget session to begin on February 7
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar with Amit Mitra and Partha Chatterjee at Raj Bhavan on Monday

KOLKATA: Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar has summoned the budget session of the Bengal assembly on February 7 at 2 pm in exercise of his powers under Article 174(1) of the Constitution. The session will begin with the governor’s speech and state finance minister Amit Mitra will place the Budget sometime later during the session.

Accordingly, chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Monday placed the draft of the governor’s speech in the state cabinet meeting and got it approved before sending the speech to Raj Bhavan. Not only that, Mitra, prodded by the CM, called on Dhankhar to clarify the finer points of the state’s economy and its growth path when the governor has been at loggerheads with the government on several issues, particularly higher education. Two days ago, state parliamentary affairs minister Partha Chatterjee met the governor with a request to call the budget session on February 7.

The Raj Bhavan visits by senior Trinamool Congress ministers gain significance in the backdrop of a development in Kerala, a week ago, when governor Arif Mohammad Khan wrote to the Kerala CM stating that he wouldn’t read the paragraph in his speech that states that the Citizenship (Amendment) Act is “unconstitutional”.

Political observers do not rule out the Bengal governor raising questions over certain paragraphs of the governor’s speech. Leader of the opposition Abdul Mannan, who has been in parliamentary politics for long, said there was no scope for the governor but to read out the speech prepared by the state government. “The governor may seek clarifications, but has to make the speech as constitutional head of the state,” Mannan said. However, there are at least two instances where the governor held back two bills because the state government couldn’t clarify his queries.

Dhankhar made his constitutional primacy known and seized the opportunity to point out that the budget session couldn’t have been summoned unless he prorogued the assembly session on January 31, invoking Article 174(2) of the Constitution.

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Kolkata-China flights go off the radar
Content:
Representative image

HK flights keep options open

KOLKATA: With the number of passengers travelling to China down to a trickle following the coronavirus outbreak in the country, airlines operating between Kolkata and different Chinese cities are either suspending flights or rationalizing them. Two Union health ministry advisories, the latest on Monday, asking people to refrain from travelling to China and adding that travellers on return from the country could be quarantined, has further aggravated the situation.While IndiGo has already announced suspension of its daily flight from Kolkata to Guangzhou from February 6, China Eastern Airlines that operated daily between Kolkata and Kunming will now fly only on four days from this week.IndiGo and China Eastern operate Airbus A320 and Boeing 737-800 — with capacity of 180 and 162 respectively — on the sector, and airport sources said, passenger count was as low as 35-40 on some days last week. In fact, China Eastern had to cancel its February 1 flight due to low passenger count.“From this week we will operate on Monday, Thursday, Friday and Sunday. The decision was taken after passenger load to China from Kolkata dipped significantly over the last few days. But we have no immediate plans to suspend the route as Kunming-Kolkata flights are still running near capacity,” a China Eastern official said.The Chinese carrier’s move comes two days after IndiGo announced suspension of all its flights to and from China. IndiGo said in a statement on Saturday that it was suspending its Kolkata-Guangzhou flight from February 6 to February 25 “in line with the WHO guideline to contain the spread of coronavirus”. An airline official said the suspension was temporary and a purely precautionary measure. “We will refund the full amount to the impacted passengers,” he said.Officials of Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon, which run flights to Hong Kong from Kolkata, said they are yet to take any decision on suspending flights but are keeping an eye on the situation and are prepared to rationalize flights as and when necessary.“None of Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon flights out of India has been cancelled. We will rationalise our flights in keeping with the demand. In most cases, these decisions are taken well in advance to avoid any inconvenience to our passengers,” said an official of Cathay Pacific.TOI had reported on January 25 that around 40% flyers scheduled to travel to China from the city in the last week of January and in February had already cancelled their journey following the coronavirus scare Industry sources said around 4,500 people travel to China from the city every month. “During this time of the year, the passenger count drops by around 25%-30% because most shops and stores in China are shut for two weeks for the lunar new year and spring festival celebrations. But because of the coronavirus scare, even Chinese nationals are skipping home visit this year. Also, the large number of Indian students sent back have been asked not to return till further notice. As a result, outbound passenger count from Kolkata has dropped drastically,” said a senior airline official.

Title: Navy completes first patrol of Sunderbans
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

The crew charted a route along river Matla in the Sunderbans

KOLKATA: The Indian Navy completed its first-ever exercise in inland waters on Sunday by charting a route for its boats along river Matla in the Sunderbans. This is the Indo-Bangladesh trade protocol route and the Navy has always been apprehensive of barges moving along it unchecked.

Till now, the Navy had operated at sea. This was the first time its boats entered the Sunderbans for the exercise named ‘Matla Abhiyan’.

“The coastal security exercise led by Captain Joydeep Chakraborty was flagged off from Kolkata on Wednesday. On Sunday, the two boats were flagged in by Commodore Suprobho K De, naval officer-in-charge, West Bengal , at the Man of War Jetty. The boats not only patrolled the protocol route (till Hemnagar on the Indian side) but also interrogated fishing boats, tankers and launches operating on the Matla, river Hooghly and the narrow creeks of the Sunderbans. During the patrol the boats stopped first at Namkhana, where sailors interacted with local fishermen. Thereafter, the crew interacted with marine police stations at Maipith, Gobardhanpur and Gosaba enroute to Hemnagar,” a senior naval official in Kolkata said.

At Hemnagar, the naval detachment interacted with Inland Waterways Authority of India and Customs officials. Chakraborty and his team also visited a school and interacted with students and teachers, distributing pamphlets about the Navy and details of how to join. The vessels left Hemnagar on Saturday and met BSF boat at the zero point along the Indo-Bangladesh border.

The naval boats were escorted by IWAI vessel Meghna, highlighting the strong inter-agency coordination among various stakeholders. IWAI vessels are used to the protocol route. Meghna also provided logistical support to the boats.

“Given the impetus being given to inland water transport, this exercise was very crucial. Now, barges primarily carry fly ash from India to Bangladesh along this route. Very soon, vessels will pass through the Sunderbans with all sort of cargo and enter the Brahmaputra through Bangladesh for easier transportation to the northeastern states,” the official added.

Title: UT plans to extend bar timings till 2am
Content:
This story is from February 4, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The UT administration is considering extending bar timings from 1 am to 2 am in the city, a suggestion the Chandigarh Hospitality Association members had made recently apart from lowering the drinking age limit from 25 to 21 years.

Sources said the UT officials will prepare a proposal, which will be taken up before the UT adviser and deputy commissioner who further discuss it with the UT administrator. “The proposal will be implemented only after the approval of the UT administrator,” said a senior official dealing with the excise policy.

The excise and taxation department on August 2 last year had suspended the liquor licence of a club in Industrial Area, Phase I, for keeping the premises and bar open after 1am. The department had sought suggestions from hoteliers and wine merchants’ body before finalising the policy. In the meeting with deputy commissioner Mandip Brar, the hoteliers had submitted the suggestions.

The administration is also considering increasing prices of premium brands of whisky and beer by 10% to 15% in the next excise policy, which will come into force from April 1. Sources in the administration said the officials were contemplating a hike in the prices of whisky and beer and those of wine and beer at microbreweries were likely to go down.

In the current excise policy, the prices of premium brands of whisky had gone up by around 20%. However, the rates of beer and wine had remained unchanged and those of beer at microbrewery had gone down.

According to the administration, the 2019-20 excise policy would help it earn a revenue Rs 600 crore as compared to Rs 510 crore in 2018-19.
